151088268.review:
Graphics – 5/10
Sound –5/10
Gameplay – 5/10
Story – 6/10
Replayability – 4/10

Overall – Castlevania: Lords of Shadow was supposed to revitalize the Castlevania franchise, but it wore its Devil May Cry and God of War influences way too heavily for my liking. The gameplay feels like it drags heavily, the boss fights are copy/pastes of God of War games, and the beat-by-beat exploration just doesn’t feel rewarding. The main saving grace for this game is Robert Carlyle’s great voice acting as Gabriel Belmont and Patrick Stewart as Zobek, other than that, you can probably skip this one, unless you plan to play the trilogy. Not Recommended.

148777643.review:
Right. The good stuff first. For its age this game looks excellent. Modelling and animation per-se are rather good and it evaded the pitfall of its time by actually using a lot of colors in its environment. The presentation is great and impressive as are most of the character designs and monsters.

This is about where the praise ends for me. Because unfortunately this game has a collection of design plagues that sure are a mark of its time but have already been mastered back then and by now.

These the following issues:

Terrible Hitboxes. Enemies, especially the larger ones, are EXTREMELY inconsistent in when and how they hit you. Hits that nowadays clearly would count as misses WILL count as hits. Getting damage from attacks that clearly did not connect with your character model is consistent and constant. I am talking here models being at least a meter apart and still "connecting". 

Ridiculous damage. Enemies here hit hard. I am talking about medium enemies a few levels in eating a god fifth of your starting health bar with said hit being often part of a flailing combo and said enemy being part of a group of enemies. 

Flailing attacks are in general a pest in this due to inconsistent telegraphing. Telegraphing means enemies show via a variety of animations when and if they attack, for example a troll charging a heavy attack by lifting the arm up before crashing down on the player. This can help an attentive player to decide which attacks to evade or block or maybe decide to eat it for some tactical reason. Telegraphing in this game is inconsistent at best and makes no sense at worst. For many especially mid enemies don't really have different telegraphs, they just flail at you and if that attack is a small swipe or a massive lunge able to take half your health doesn't really matter.

Awful camera. For starters you do not have any control over the camera. Doesn't matter if you are traversing between areas or are in an arena like combat scenario. That game decides where it looks and how it moves. Especially in combat that leads to attacks from outside the frame. often the camera is zoomed out so much that you can't really see the telegraphs or moves of enemies, especially when they, like the goblins often do, blend into the color of the ground. Those guys throw grenades by the way.  

Despite this I pushed trough since i was aware of the games age and its qualities were actually quite good. 

I best describe the combination of all these things that finally made me quit. Traversing from an arena to the next area absolving the typical directed climbing section along glowing ledges a Mid strength Werewolf spawned on me on a small path. These guys attack really fast and with sweeping and lunging attacks. There is no space here to really evade and worse the camera frames the whole encounter from a side view meaning i can even worse see how to best evade the enemy. Still hurt from the last encounter this enemy one hit killed me at least five times in one hit and that the MOMENT I landed on the platform. There is barely space to evade, it is hard to read what moves the guy is going to do since telegraphs are basically non existent and camera does what it wants. And every time I died I have to repeat the last Uncharted style climbing and jumping area over and over again.   
 
Trying this for the fifth time I realized that I still have barely touched Metal Gear Solid Revengence and that Devil May Cry 5 is still waiting for me. The point being that there is no reason to torture myself with this clearly flawed game when there are better alternatives in my very own library. 

Again, for its time this game is not bad, However many of the games issues had already been solved a console generation before that for example with the first generation of God of War games.
This game attempts to do the same genre but does not excel at any of its aspects besides the visuals and that is just surface level and not enough to push me trough.

There are frankly quite better examples of this game for cheaper.

147924091.review:
I played the hell out of this on PS3, not PC, hence the low playtime here.

At first glance it has a lot of red flags.  It's a franchise reboot from a 2D platformer into a 3D character action game.  Funnily enough this isn't Castlevania's first foray into trying to leap into a 3D combo-driven adventure title, and I suspect your opinion of this title will be similar to how you received the games Lament of Innocence and Curse of Darkness (lets not talk about the 64 game).  I would say that overall this package is a lot tighter than either of those games in terms of gameplay and presentation.  If you've recently watched the Netflix adaptations and want a game to jump around and whip night creatures in this is for you.  As you'll see mentioned in lots of other reviews it's very God-of-War -esque in its execution, but with a couple timing based tricks for people who like things a bit more technical and less button-mashy.  It's no Devil May Cry technical masterpiece but I found it a bit more challenging at times than GoW.

Comparatively where the game tends to suffer a bit is its link to the Castlevania lore.  CV has a very rich and long history of games and characters its introduced.  Tossing all that out to start over with a reboot is a questionable decision and it's hard to experience this without feeling like something is missing for it.  To its credit the voice acting is well done (they got mf'ing Patrick Stewart for this one holy shit) and the story it has to tell is interesting but it still isn't the gigantic legacy of the previous Castlevania history and future games fail to really drive it home.

So if you're looking for an action-adventure game that's got fun combat, spooky atmosphere, and the best whip-based fighting system you're going to see anywhere this is a pretty decent buy.  There are some real high points between the combat and some of the impressively delivered bits of flash.  I almost wonder if this game would have done better without the Castlevania name on it, as it looks weakest when you try to stack it up directly against other games in that franchise.

147887085.review:
Si recomiendo este juego, es muy bueno y entretenido.
Pero tiene muchas cosas que frustraron mi experiencia como jugador. Honestamente espero que la segunda entrega no tenga estos fallos.
A continuación listo lo bueno y lo malo.

Lo bueno:
Un gran juego con una buena historia y desarrollo. 
El arte visual es impresionante, y la banda sonora una maravilla.
El gameplay es bueno, tiene mecánicas interesantes.
Buenos niveles, y jefes desafiantes.
Se ve claramente en que juego de un dios de la guerra esta inspirado.

Lo malo:
El [u]sistema de habilidades y combos[/u] esta mal hecho. Existen muchas habilidades y combos que prácticamente son inútiles y jamas se usan, ya que los enemigos ignoran totalmente el daño que les haces y te atacan directamente aunque los estés azotando contra el suelo. Ya sea en el aire, agarres o explosiones siempre te veras perdiendo hasta el mas simple de los combos por ello, obligándote a aplicar el golpe simple y bloqueo el 90% del juego.
Y claro, combates 20 vs 1 no es muy equitativo.

Los [u]DLC[/u] ...
Son 2 dlc de 2 misiones cada uno que no aportan nada interesante.
En una sola ubicación repetida.
Dibujos animados en lugar de cinemáticas (Muy buenos dibujos hay que decir)
Y hay que recalcar que el segundo dlc y sus 2 misiones no son más que esconderte y después 1 pelea final de "5 etapas EXACTAMENTE IGUALES", sin regenerar salud ni magias, y con un jefe fácilmente olvidable (como lo indica su nombre) y que es ridículamente resistente a golpes y que repite los mismos 3 ataques todo el tiempo, ataques que son capaces se hacerte instakill.

La [u]dificultad[/u] no es realmente desafiante ni cambiante dentro del juego
Ya sea que se juegue en muy fácil o muy difícil el juego es exactamente ¡igual!
Me refiero a: Solución de puzzles, desafíos, cantidad de enemigos, vida de enemigos, objetos encontrados, consumibles, etc. Nada cambia, lo único que refleja la dificultad es el daño que recibe el jugador, haciendo que el tener niveles de dificultad sea innecesario.

Los [u]puzzles[/u] ... los puzzles no son complicados, ni siquiera exigen un nivel de razonamiento. El 90% de los "puzzles" se resume a encontrar una o dos llaves, dentro de tu misma área en cadáveres o enemigos.
Los puzzles no están para retar al jugador a pensar, si no para ser un estorbo en el nivel y alargarlo más de lo que debería.

La [u]cámara y las vistas[/u]. 
La cámara siempre es un obstáculo en los juegos de este estilo, pero en Castlevania se vuelve molesta y aburrida. Desde combates finales donde la cámara no solo no enfoca al jefe o enemigo, si no que ademas se obstruye con cualquier muro del escenario.
Ademas de los muy molestos acercamientos a objetos o plataformas ya de por si brillantes y que duran una eternidad, porque el juego te trata como imbec1l y te obliga a verlos a modo de guía para que no te pierdas. Pero eso te hace perder tiempo o la concentración en combates dejándote vulnerable.

Los [u]checkpoint[/u].
Siempre que hay un combate final o complicado, es importante meter un checkpoint para que en caso de fracasar en los primeros intentos, el jugador no se tenga que repetir 85 mil veces las cinemáticas ni secciones del mapa que solo es caminar hacia la área de combate. Y este juego no tiene esos chekpoints.

147528434.review:
Mixed feelings about this game.
1. I don't like these God Of War likes, the only one I liked was Marlow Briggs because it was non stop action. I am glad they don't make these kind games any more.
2. The voice actor for the main character is awful, the other characters have solid to great voice actors so a strange decision.
I will not go into the story in this review because this is my first Castlevania game, I didn't play the other 30 games :)
The game goes like this- you walk a little, fight small enemies, climb some walls and swing on a rope, do some lite puzzles and fight a boss. That is a pattern through out the whole game and it is really boring at times.
Despite the boring patterns the game has some good boss fights and some great visuals. The other positive thing is that almost all things you learned will come in handy in combat and puzzles, really liked that the game forces you to use almost every gadget.
When you beat 4 or 5 bosses you will quickly realize they have almost identical attacks and you will figure them out.
The game is heavy on QTE's but that is expected in this type of game. Lot of cut scenes etc.
Not a bad game and since I have really mixed opinions on it i will recommend it but at a high discount of course.

147106256.review:
Obviously Symphony of the Night & Rondo of Blood(Dracula X) set the Castlevaina series in stone for all eternity.  It broke boundaries & raised the bar on how 2-D games were created in the 90's and years to come.  I have played every Castlevania game that has been made available to the public, loved every one of them. (except for those 2 abominations released on N64, we won't talk about those)   

The Lords of Shadow trilogy is a must have/must play for any and all Castlevania fans.  Hell, even if you're not a Castlevania freak like me, it's still a great game to play.  Lords of Shadow does have some camera angles that could be considered controller breaking annoying, but they are few and far between.  Lords of Shadow 2 make up for it & Mirror of Fate gives us the original 2D Metroid-Vania style we all fell in love with and still love to this day.  The game play and graphics is a redeeming quality for them for the few amateur angles.  

The game is hard.  It takes patience & skill to play through.  Especially if you are a gamer like me that needs those achievements.  It does allow for difficulty settings to be adjusted during game-play for those that want to cruise through.  But I rather like the paths least traveled.  I give it a rating 9 out of 10.  Buy it, you will not be dissatisfied.

145721425.review:
I'll preface the review by saying that I liked the game enough to go for all achievements and look into buying the other games in this series, but I could still see the game's flaws. 

I went in with no expectations and really liked it, but I don't know if that would be the case for people who played more Castlevania games.  This series reboots the story with religious themes and its own set of characters. The story is decent enough, but far from being one of the best things about the game. Still, the game has quite the presentation, with animated cutscenes, voice acting and a narrated opening for each level. 

It plays like the PlayStation 2 God of War games, a 3D action game with hack-and-slash combat with combos and special abilities. The combat is ok but can get somewhat shallow: it's not really clear what will make enemies stagger, so if you're playing on the higher difficulties and can't afford to get hit, you'll usually do the first moves of a combo and roll away to avoid being hit. Rinse and repeat. There are lots of air combos but I found that I was barely using them, since you can't really dodge midair and most enemies just swat you away if you're messing around too long. Besides the combat, there's puzzles and lots of parkour sections in which you use your chained weapon to jump and climb around. Those were generally a nice change of pace, but were also a part of the worst thing in the game: Shadow of the Colossus-like bosses. There aren't many of those, but each one of them is a drag. "Hold RT to grip" is just not an entertaining game mechanic. 

The game works with levels spread around chapters, and has a level selector accessible at all times. This makes the "metroidvania" aspects of the game somewhat awkward, since after you acquire new abilities, you got to replay previous levels to get whatever you couldn't get before, making you replay some levels two or three times. From the level selector you can see each level's completion rate and missed artifacts, so at least you won't replay levels looking for stuff that doesn't exist.

The part I liked the least were chapters XIII and XIV, chapters that were part of DLCs that got integrated in the base game in this version. These chapters include sections in which you play as a weaker and more rigid character, some of the worst puzzles of the game and an infuriating final boss. The boss has a lot of phases but uses the same attacks across all of them. The safe time window for damaging the boss after his attacks is quite short, so the entire fight is just a test of patience in which you dodge until he does the move you can punish, get a couple of hits in and retreat. The DLC barely has healing spots, so it's quite common to reach the boss while 1 or 2 hits away from death.

Still, this is a positive review. I had a blast playing and really think it's worth to give it a go.

144360127.review:
Titlu: O Poveste Mistică și o Acțiune Încântătoare în Lumea Întunecată a Castlevania

★★★★☆ Recomand

Castlevania: Lords of Shadow - Ultimate Edition aduce o perspectivă proaspătă asupra seriei clasice Castlevania, oferind o poveste epica și o acțiune captivantă într-o lume plină de mister și întuneric. Cu o grafică impresionantă și mecanici de joc revizuite, acest joc combină elemente de aventură, acțiune și RPG într-un mod încântător.

Un aspect notabil al acestui joc este povestea sa profundă și mistică. Veți urmări povestea lui Gabriel Belmont, care pornește într-o călătorie epica pentru a salva lumea de forțele întunericului. Atmosfera gotică și narativa intrigantă adaugă o adâncime captivantă experienței.

Gameplay-ul este o combinație de lupte, explorare și puzzle-uri. În timp ce luptați împotriva creaturilor malefice și a șefilor puternici, veți dezvolta abilități și veți debloca noi tehnici. Mecanicile de luptă sunt satisfăcătoare și vă permit să efectuați combo-uri și mișcări speciale.

Ultimate Edition adaugă conținut suplimentar și suport pentru rezoluții înalte, îmbunătățind aspectele vizuale și oferind o experiență mai plăcută pentru jucătorii moderni.

Lumea jocului este plină de detaliu și se extinde prin diverse medii și locații, de la păduri întunecate la castele înfricoșătoare. Designul nivelurilor și detaliile vizuale contribuie la crearea unei atmosfere înfricoșătoare și misterioase.

Un dezavantaj poate fi că, în ciuda îmbunătățirilor aduse de Ultimate Edition, jocul încă prezintă unele mecanici datate și design de niveluri care pot părea repetitive în anumite momente.

În concluzie, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow - Ultimate Edition aduce o abordare proaspătă și captivantă la seria Castlevania. Cu povestea sa intrigantă, gameplay-ul echilibrat și atmosfera întunecată, acest joc este o alegere excelentă pentru fanii aventurii și acțiunii supranaturale. Indiferent dacă sunteți un cunoscător al seriei sau un nou venit, Lords of Shadow - Ultimate Edition vă va aduce cu siguranță în lumea fascinantă și misterioasă a Castlevania.

143694157.review:
I've always known my first impressions were blinded by my disappointment as a castlevania game. Five years later, my second impressions weren't much better. Now, after a decade I gave it one final chance for it to prove itself... and... eh... I'm glad I did? This time through... a full completion and I'll likely even run the DLC.

I think the best description for this game I've read "This is my favorite 6/10 game" and even then I think its a stretch. There is loads of potential here and there is fun to be had but every time I found myself smiling it smiles its janky smile and reminds me that it's got severe issues.

Lets start by saying... the pacing is off.  It feels like the developers set out to make the next great epic fantasy and had sky-high dreams...but ran out of money at the end of chapter 2.  At this point, it stops being bloated trash that's pretending to be amazing. I'd still cut out 5-10 hours of cheap filler, but even that felt better than the early chapters.

The early chapters just aren't a good indicator of the game experience and they last for far, faaaar too long. (Of the 40 or so stages, almost 15 are Chapters 1 and 2. The remaining 25 are split across an entire 10 chapters!)

The first chapter seems to want to show off how varied the gameplay is and has one mission per gameplay type. (It's worth noting you can't heal in this first chapter, and you can't use combat magic until even further.) 
 - Hack and Slash / Platforming (with QTE kills galore)
 - Horse Riding (Which is NEVER again used and should have been cut)
 - Puzzle Stage 
 - Navigational Puzzle (Slowly shimmying along ledges to look at pretty views but not doing much else)
 - Titan Battle (Climbing up giant monsters all Shadow of the Colossus Style)

The problem with recommending this game is that for every one of the above gameplay types... this game was inferior to the one it copied. Sure... 7/10 hack and slash isn't bad... but why not play the 9/10 God of War or Devil May Cry... and there's zero reason to recommend this game's 3/10 Titan Battles over SotC. 

If you ask me what to play... I'll recommend each of the inspirations over this. 

The other major problem that this game does have is its inclusions and implementation of puzzles. The full-on puzzles stall the progress but at least make good mental challenges (With a Give me the answer option if you hate puzzles). 

But there are a number of specific navigational puzzles that require obscure traits of attacks that I forgot existed. I shouldn't have to google "How do I hit this switch" or "Why can't I make this jump?" or "Why can't I finish off this boss"... but I did have to several times.

One area I do want to highlight... the non-titan boss battles. While fairly samey in terms of movesets and strategy, they were legit fun. It's in the moments of focused 1v1 combat that the 7/10 starts to shine and I really appreciated this game. (The last boss really ended on a high note for me)

After you unlock all your basic skills... you unlock a surprisingly in-depth combat system.  I-Frame dodges, Perfect Parries, raising combo to recharge mana burned to boost attack or heal, magical combination with each of your moves or weapons. 

Enemies hit extremely hard, non-combat healing is basically non-existent, and you do need to master it... but it feels pretty darn good when you do.

In fact, The combat system was good enough that I almost forgot to mention that the camera is trash. Like... literal trash. 

Overall, this deserves a sideways thumb because there's actually a good game here. Take my "Recommended" thumb as a literal coin flip. I just don't know.

143391136.review:
”A storm is coming. Mankind faces ruin and despair. The world is changing, yet hope remains in the hearts of the people.”
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow is a third-person action-adventure game that is very similar to the early God of War games, just with a slightly different main weapon, the Combat Cross; a retractable chain whip that has many uses when handling enemies and level obstacles. I never played the old Castlevania games, so I won’t be doing any comparisons between them.

Pros
✔️ Good Story with interesting side characters.
✔️ The combat is fun, with lots of abilities and combos to learn.
✔️ Puzzles can be challenging.
✔️ Great variety of enemies.
✔️ Excellent boss fights.
✔️ Replayablility (trials).
✔️ Fun DLCs that have challenging puzzles and boss fights.
✔️ The game is visually Impressive, with lots of areas to explore.
✔️ Character models look excellent.
✔️ The game is well-optimized
✔️ Mostly great and memorable soundtrack.

Story
You control Gabriel Belmont, a member of the Brotherhood of Light, who found that his wife was murdered recently. Your goal is basically to destroy an ancient order, known as the Lords of Shadow, to bring her back to life and save the world from darkness.


Despite the well-made cutscenes, there was little focus on exploring Gabriel's character. 


Most of the characters in this game are interesting, mysterious and intriguing. On the other hand, Gabriel has very little personality; he is a generic protagonist with his cliche one-liners that you see in other games. It is until you play the DLCs where his character is more fleshed out.

The game has a total of 12 chapters (including the DLC), which include over 40 levels. Each level in this game usually takes about 10-20 minutes to complete, so you will be seeing a lot of loading screens. However, the story and writing overall were good enough to keep me intrigued till the end.

Gameplay
Combat:
Your main weapon is the Combat Cross, a retractable chain whip that can hit enemies from a great distance . You will be earn new abilities and throwables while you progress that make the combat much more varied and engaging.

You can also perform awesome finishing moves on enemies which vary from one enemy to another. QTEs and button mashing are also a common occurence; during kill animations, while solving puzzles, when operating a mechanism and sometimes during cutscenes. The QTEs were easy to execute and didn't bother me much.


The game has fixed camera, so you can’t control it in-game. Luckily, it worked well for me and it didn’t affect the gameplay. 


You earn points from slaying enemies and solving puzzles, which you can spend on learning new combos and skills. You will also obtain two types of medallions later in the story; one of which inflicts more damage to enemies while the other replenishes your health by attacking them.

You can check all combos and skills in the menu, as each one has its own simple animated video that shows what happens when you do it ingame. The only issue I have with the combat is that the block/parry button is also used for dodging, so you can accidentally dodge an enemy instead of parrying an attack.

Enemies:
You will face all kinds of enemies in the game, such as Vampires, Zombies, Lycans, Skeleton Warriors, Cave Trolls and so many more. You can learn more about them in your Bestiary (located in the menu). You can ride some of the large beasts, after inflicting a good amount of damage, and use them to kill the other enemies.

Puzzles:
There are a lot of puzzles in this game. Aside from killing enemies, the Combat Cross can also be used to solve different puzzles and act as a grappling hook to swing to unreachable areas, or during platforming sessions. The puzzles get harder and harder as you progress through the story, and some require you to find particular scrolls from dead knights (can also be accessed in the main menu) or mount a certain monster to solve them.

Bosses:
There are a lot of bosses in the game that range from lieutenant vampires to huge titans, and some will grant you new abilities, once you defeat them. I like the boss fights, they are engaging, creative and balanced, even on higher difficulty settings.

Trials:
You can replay the chapters again, after you complete them, but with special challenges. Each and every level in the game has its own Trial, which are difficult but add more replay value.

Difficulty:
I chose the Knight difficulty (hard) and it was perfect; the enemies and bosses are tougher and deal more damage but remain fair and balanced, as you will be using the abilities and combos that you learn to slay them and progress through the game.

Graphics and Level Design
For a 2010 game, the graphics look pretty good. From vast and detailed environments to good looking character models. There are ingame cutscenes and prerecorded ones, the Ingame cutscenes still hold up and characters have decent facial animation.

You will be visiting different areas in this game, such as enchanted forests and the cold and chilly oblivion lake, and these areas provide a good sense of immersion. Areas range from the more generic, like the Dark Dungeon, to the absolutely beautiful, such as the Clockwork Tower.


One advantage of the fixed camera is that you get to see some amazing and visually impressive locations in the game at a larger scale. 


Every so often you will come across a branching path, but the game fails to show you which way leads to the beaten path (long walks and similar looking paths), and if you missed it then there’s a chance you can’t go back and have to restart the level all over again. There are a lot of secrets and hidden areas that you can find and explore in the levels, so watch out for them.

Technical
The game is well-optimized and ran beautifully. No issues to report.

Soundtrack
A few of the songs are okay and not very memorable, while others are just excellent; some give you this gothic atmosphere, while others have a pleasant and calm melody when solving puzzles and during exploration. The songs range from the epic orchestra of Hunting Path to the pleasant, heart-wrenching melody of Waterfalls of Agharta and Belmont’s Theme.

DLC
There are two main DLCs in the game, Reverie and Resurrection, and they continue the story of the base game. I can’t say more than that to avoid spoilers, but they are 2 chapters and 1 hours long each and they were pretty fun. The first DLC is mainly puzzles and less fighting, and the second one is just two very challenging boss fights and that’s about it.


Final Thoughts
When I first installed Castlevania: Lords of Shadow, I had low expectations and thought I would just delete it after an hour or two, but I actually had a lot of fun and enjoyed my time playing it. Despite some issues in the story and level design, the combat was solid, the story was good, the graphics still hold up and it has a great soundtrack.

142385383.review:
The game is good enough that I believe it deserves a proper review and not a singular paragraph, so I'll correct myself. 

Lords of Shadow is an amazing game and the only reason its name was dragged through the mud was because it carries the Castlevania moniker. Castlevania, it is not. The levels are fairly straightforward and lineal, nothing like you'd see in a roguelike and thus what most Castlevania fans were expecting is not to be found here. 

But if you're not familiar with the original games, like me, there's a game with a lot of potential here. I haven't finished it, as a disclaimer, but I am on Chapter 8 (out of 12) so I do believe I'm in a position to give my overall thoughts on the game. 

The graphics hold up surprisingly well, there are a lot of awe-inducing vistas and the character models aren't... terrible, even though they are a bit anatomically weird for some reason. The whip is fantastic and really fun, I loved the platforming and this is coming from a person who typically doesn't enjoy his action games to be padded out by jumping around ledges. You can use your whip as a rappel and jump from it, climb it, swing to the sides, it's all around pretty fun even if it's streamlined.

Seems there's a heavy emphasis on backtracking, what with each chapter and its subsequent levels having a % level. I assume this was done to pad out time or for people who really really enjoyed the combat (I did not, more on that later) and I probably won't be coming anywhere near close 100%ing this game. 

Story starts out really slow but if you stick it out I promise it gets really good. Like I said, I haven't finished the game, but I'm hooked. The only thing preventing me from actually getting to the ending is the god-awful combat. 

Whose idea was it to bind dodge and block to the same button in a game with a PERFECT PARRY?? 

That's not even the worst of it; Gabriel has a really hard time stun-locking enemies, so you'll get hit out of combos quite frequently. Don't even DARE going for an air combo because you will be swatted out of the air like you're a fucking Boeing 737 in March 23rd 2022. Most of it boils down to press X a bunch of times, pre-emptively dodge because the enemies don't have good windup animations, press X a bunch of times again, ad infinitum. Of course, pressing light attack a bunch of times does nearly negative damage, so it drags the combat out a lot. 
I've found a strategy that has been working for me, somewhat, and it's that of standing completely still, waiting for an attack then PARRYING it. It guarantees a lot of damage on that particular enemy (even more if you're using shadow magic) and it almost entirely fills your focus gauge (which is an important mechanic that is also non-sensical because it requires you to no-hit enemy encounters lol)  

There's QTEs like any game worth its salt in 2013, but they're easy enough and don't require a specific button press; it's more like a rhythm game than anything. 

I read somewhere that the developers were somewhat bothered by the GoW comparisons, and while I can see where those are coming from, this isn't a GoW clone simply because there are too many major differences. 

Kratos has an enormous arsenal of weapons, you are ENCOURAGED to button mash and combo the shit out of enemies and juggle them in the air and all sorts of stuff, platforming in GoW is a pain in the fucking ass and the story is... a story. 
Gabriel only ever has his whip, which he upgrades throughout the story, the combat is more tactical because like I was saying, you can't stunlock for shit and the windup animations are stupid to the point where the attack might as well just pop into existence for 1/4th of your health bar, platforming is incredibly fun and the story is shaping up to be ABSOLUTE KINO.

Side note, the extras menu has some HUD options that you might wanna activate, such as XP gains, damage dealt by Gabriel and enemy health bars (this one is crucial imo) 

So yes, buy it, it's a game worth purchasing and it's a game worth experiencing with the caveat that combat is going to be really hard for no reason other than bad design. 

If push comes to shove, the game has incorporated cheats which give you god-mode, unlimited damage, etc if you so wish and I do not believe it affects achievements in any way.

140564879.review:
[b]TL; DR[/b] Castlevania: God of War edition. I think that this is a great sub-30-hour action game with some minor puzzles and exploration in-between combat encounters but do not expect this to be a metroidvania. 

[b]Note[/b] if you are playing with KBM change your keybinds [i]immediately[/i]

[h1] Story [/h1]
This is a reboot of Castlevania and is set in a new timeline, and these are dark times, times without hope, this is a world that God has abandoned, and which is dominated by the three Lords of Shadow. Your quest is to destroy them, fulfil the prophecy by becoming God’s Vassal on Earth and bring back your wife. 

This is generally told from the perspective of the main character Gabriel Belmont, a warrior of the Brotherhood as he travels leagues across the lands all for the sake of his wife. However, a lot of things cannot be shown from his perspective because he rarely talks to himself, and we are not privy to his thoughts. 
Instead, we receive something similar through the perspective of another character, one introduced within the first Chapter who sets the mood for any area with his narration, who tells us of Gabriel’s state, and who arrives to aid Gabriel at points during his journey.  
These are really, really cool, it is a good quiet reprieve for a few moments, and can tell us things that would feel forced in-game, it also has a certain atmosphere about it that you will pick up on.

Some more worldbuilding can be found in the Knight Scrolls, they are hardly a necessary addition, but they give you some tips for how to complete areas or info on where to find upgrades. They are basically glorified hints, and I like their inclusion since it shows what other warriors of the Brotherhood are hopelessly trying to do.   

[h1] Presentation [/h1] 
This game looks great even today because it is carried by its beautiful environments and a number of outstanding designs. This is further highlighted by the cinematography as the developers knew exactly how to show off an area and its world. Something is always centred, and it looks great, this is how fixed camera angles should be used. 
Naturally the cutscenes are about on par with this but they are heightened even further by the voice acting, because the cast does a really great job to bring emotion and some nuance to the characters. Perhaps that is not so surprising considering that a few of them had received awards even before this game was released.  

Another important note is the music, on the whole it is beautiful, however, a handful of tracks can sound rather generic which is not much of an issue since tracks are often specific for chapters or bosses. This has the added benefit of giving areas their own distinct moods though there is always an underlying feeling of hopelessness and ruin, which synergises well with the art style and, naturally, the story. This score received an award, and I think it deserves it.

If I have any complaints, it will come down to the enemy designs, they look great, it is easy to tell them apart, however, some of them are a bit generic, but that is ok because the game also has designs like the Creeping Coffins that look nightmarish.
On the other hand, the architectural designs are superb and even the ruins make me stop to appreciate them, while others are simply imposing on account of their massive, supernatural scale.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
First things first, the first Chapter is in many ways not representative of the rest of the game, but it does give you a taste of things to come. There is combat, there are puzzles, and there are puzzle bosses, but after the first Chapter they are paced out much better and feel less compartmentalised. 
  
So, besides the combat there is platforming and puzzles to shake things up. However, none of these things are particularly difficult, and the game gives you the option to solve the puzzles automatically which would negate any experience you would have gained if you had solved it. 
Of course, there is also exploration, but it is not open exploration, you are either looking for the path to progress, a key or you are straying from the path looking for collectibles. This is disappointing, collectibles are not hidden, and you are often given explicit hints for their locations through documents.  
You do not backtrack in this game either, in fact individual areas are so short you can easily do them in a few minutes once you know what to do, however, the game does incentivise you to replay chapters by placing collectibles behind double-jumps or breakable walls that you can only access later. In other words, do not expect this to be a metroidvania since it is not. 

There are also the Trials, one for each area, most of them are trivial and a few are tedious, then there are the timed ones. I do not like timers in video games, and even when playing perfectly these can get very close, but even then, they should only take a few tries once you get the method down. Thankfully they are completely optional, but it might be fun to try out a few that sound interesting, if only to play certain maps in a different manner, or to discover things you did not know were possible.
 
[h2]Combat[/h2]
Fighting in this game is rather simple and does not need much explaining, at its core is the combos and magic. The latter comes in two varieties, Light which heals you, and Shadow which deals extra damage, both of these have their own unique combos, and both require mana. 
So how do you get mana? You attack enemies to build your Focus and once your Focus meter is full, they start dropping mana. However, whenever you get hit your meter resets, this would incentivise a more defensive playstyle, but parrying not only keeps you safe but it also gives you a massive boost to your Focus. This means the most effective playstyle is parrying paired with aggressiveness, dodging whatever attacks cannot be parried, and spacing. 

Killing an enemy unlocks their bestiary page which gives you some further info on them such as what sub-weapons they are resistant or weak to. The weaknesses are in general very obvious, take for example the werewolves, what could they possibly be weak against? 
However, you can easily underestimate the strength of these sub-weapons when you first start playing, because they are shockingly strong and remain useful until the end of the game, especially when paired with magic, since this can change their effects and their effectiveness.  

Objectively the worst part of the combat is a few quick time events. These QTEs are terrible primarily due to their implementation with a keyboard and require you to do the equivalent of spinning a joystick in a circle but with WASD within a short timeframe. That is very unintuitive, but it is not impossible, so it may take you a while to get the rhythm down. One boss fight makes a lot of use of this mechanic, so you might be better off using a controller if you are struggling. 
For the most part the other QTEs are fine, and some are pretty cool, if you count the grabs then I like those too. It is just very satisfying to finish enemies off, and its quite funny to activate a goblin's grenade and throw it towards a group of them. 

It should also be said that the game has pretty great enemy variety and that they are spread out in such a way that each Lord of Shadow has their own roster of servants. This means that new enemies are constantly introduced and that you will need to adapt to new tactics and resistances at a regular basis which keeps the gameplay fresh throughout the story.  
This also hold true for the bosses as while they follow the general flow of the combat, they also have some sort of mechanic to make them stand out from each other. If not requiring you to complete a QTE, they might have adds, and sometimes they will make use of equipment that will help you in the future. On the whole they are fun, especially when they force you to think differently and not rely on tactics like parrying or spamming.

139815706.review:
Would I recommend this? "Yes, but".

The largest obstacle the game has is the expectations that come with a Castlevania game. You expect side scrolling metroidvania gameplay, a setting pretty well rooted in eastern European history with a healthy dose of mythology (I've no idea where this game is supposed to take place, but its not Earth), and fantastic music tracks like Blood Tears, Vampire Killer, etc. None of that exists here, and so if you feel like you're not playing a Castlevania and that diminishes your enjoyment, you would absolutely be correct.

That said, the game is fun enough. On the plus side, you have absolutely gorgeous levels, decent gameplay, and Patrick Stewart's voice chewing scenery like nobody's business. On the less than brilliant side, you have a protagonist with a distractingly small head, quick time events (seriously? Didn't you all realize those were a bad idea back in the 90s?), annoying camera angles, and music, that while decent, is just not at all memorable.

All in all, its a good reimaginating of Legacy of Cain... I mean of Castlevania.

139531083.review:
So first of all, as you can see i don't have a lot of play time on this game and i think it will stay this way.

The reason being, that i got bored after the first 2 hours of playing. I kept on playing for about 1,5 hours and after looking at how much i have left of the game, i abandoned it.

Pros:
The music is great in this game.

The voice acting is okay but can sound janky sometimes.

The character design is cool.

The game adds challenges to every mission once you complete it. Gives them a little bit of replayability.

There are chests in some levels, that you can only reach once you have a different item that you get in a later level. Once you have that item, you can go back and get that chest. I don't know if i like that or not, you decide.

Cons:
Combat is very repetetive and some moves break you out of the flow of the fight (grabbing enemies and waiting for a bar to fill up)

This game has a fixed camera, you can't move it which is frustrating sometimes. You move from one fixed camera to the other and that suddenly changes the direction on which your character is moving.

I didn't even know you could sprint in this game, i only figured it out through a review.

Daggers. You find sacks all throughout the game which replenish your daggers. But almost every crate or jar can be destroyed and they have daggers in them most of the time. This makes the sacks almost useless cause you will never be out of daggers.

This game is looooong. I only reached chapter 3 and every chapter has different missions in them. This game has 14!! chapters and i got bored at the 3rd one.

Levels are very linear. You can explore to some degree but you'll almost always end up in a dead end if you don't go the correct way.

If you explore the levels and you progress through the correct way, the game sometimes doesn't let you go back and explore other paths, locking you out from some collectibles and making you replay the mission or load a checkpoint, hoping it let's you grab the collectible

There is some kind of combat meter that fills up while fighting and depletes once you are out of combat. If you get hit, it depletes completely. I almost NEVER managed to fill that bar completely because the game often throws a lot of enemies at you.

The story is very bland and predictable.

Of course, all of this is my own opinion and you may like this game more than i do. If this game is on a good sale then maybe get it and see for yourself, but i won't recommend buying it at full price

The good:
- Interesting take on the Castlevania concept, good story
- Cool character designs, nice vistas

The (really) bad:
- Fixed camera. You might walk to some place and the camera will snap to a different position, that means your stick will be suddenly pointing to a different direction. This will stop your dash, make you fall of ledges, run into enemies and more. Enemies go out of sight often too, and even bosses sometimes. This thing died in the PS1 era for a good reason.
- Boring Titan bosses. They tried to do Shadow of the Colossus and failed
- Lots of monkeying around. These acrobatic sections are usually one-track, ledges and places to go are highlighted so all you do is push the appropriate button. There's no skill or decision involved on the player's part. Boooooring.
- Annoying puzzles at every turn. A puzzle here and there is a great way to mix things up but there's so many, making even entire levels.

Good slasher. Basically a mix and match of the Castlevania lore with God of War gameplay. You play as Gabriel Belmont, a knight of a holy order who must defeat evil using your whip/chain.

Pros
-Good combat controls based on God of War
-Good visuals for an old game with great atmospheric environments
-The 3d platforming is decent enough

Cons
-Combat gets tedious after a while as you use always the same weapon
-Really annoying quick time events, where if you miss, you die
-Story is too simplistic and predictable

7.5/10

138955247.review:
I don't know why the swamp is the first "regular" level because it is not very good and is not representative of the quality of the game as a whole. Tough it out because the game will get much better.

A safe way to fight any monster is to hit once or twice with quick attacks and then dodge its retaliation. It will take a long time to kill anything but you will not take much damage. Useful when you just need to survive a battle.

Don't be afraid to use your dark crystal. It will clear the screen of anything that's not a boss and it doesn't take very long to get back.

The challenges, should you want to do them, can be accomplished on any difficulty.

Make sure to stick around after the credits for one final, bizarre scene.

There's a few unreachable areas that will unlock later in the story with upgrades. Keep note of crumbly walls, or chests slightly out of reach.

If you're into floating damage numbers, you can enable them in your options screen.

Your whip never gets stronger as far as raw damage.

You lose out of xp rewards if you auto-solve puzzles.

Bosses will have QTEs. Don't put your controller down when you finish them off.

Burn through all your sub weapons. The game gives you plenty.

Unlock whatever skills look good or cool to you. The earlier stuff tends to be the more important and new skills that are unlocked with story progression. Regardless you'll have them all by the end of the game.

138583365.review: Loved the Lords of shadow games since they came out. I've played all the Castlevania games since the first one came out and may be in the minority on this, but I think these are great successors to the past games. I appreciate the sincere melancholy tone, the fantastic music, the beautiful art style, the story, even with some wonky stuff here and there. I even feel, especially Lords of Shadow 2, that the art may be the best of it's generation. If you're an old school Castlevania fan and appreciate the same things that I've written about, do yourself a favor and get the trilogy of games here, although Mirror of Fate was more of  a tech demo for 3ds IMO. Castlevania has always been about pulpy Gothic horror mixed with vampire and monster slaying action and these games do that style justice. If you don't like it, sucks for you. I personally find them beautiful games and, for now, a great swan song for the Castlevania series.

138555469.review:
До четвертой главы готов был бросить и посавить "не рекомендую". После стало куда интереснее, сюжет постепенно развивался, однако игра, в своём основном сюжете, не даёт ответ на главный вопрос, в итоге делая практически бессмысленным всё, что делал главный герой на протяжении всей игры (точнее это обесцениться в длс). Если не знать кем должен стать Габриель, но воспринимается нормально, но игроки, приемущественно, знают, и игра, делаю кучу намёков, в конце их просто наглухо обрезает. После чего сваливает на нас "сцену после титров" в которой ты просто сидишь и спрашиваешь "а какого хера?" ничто из игры (основной части) не должно было привести к тому, что мы видим там. Верх идиотизма.
Хотя нет, врехом убогости является длс, последние три главы, в которых нам объясняют как Габриель стал тем, кем стал. Здесь убого всё - геймдизайн (построенный на том, чтобы максимально задержать игрока на одной точке), левл дизайн в купе с камерой это просто пздц, финальный и продвижение к нему... что я могу сказать, один из самых убогих файтов, что мне доводителось видеть. И дело не в том, что он слабый, как раз наоборот, герой всегда будет получать дешёвый урон, поному что игра знает, как ты будешь вынужден атаковать и не даёт тебе возможности избежать атаки, только если ты не хочешь (опять же) возиться с босом пару часов, лупя его своим хлыстом.
Боевая система то ещё удовольствие. Герой не станит врага вообще, поэтому под любыми атаками гг любой враг движется к нему и атакует. Из-за чего бои с самыми толстыми врагами превращаются в цирк с постоянными перекатами и двумя ударами. Медленные атаки здесь просто бесполезны и нужны только для пазлов.
И тем немене я её прошёл. До полуфинального, так сказать, поворота, всё шло хорошо, игра набирала темп, я приловчился к боёвке (которая после ДМС выглядит очень слабо). Но концовка, убогие длс просто убили наповал. Как можно было делать одновременно так хорошо и так убого? Не представляю. 
В целом в игре очень классный визуал (опять же, после 4 главы). Бесящая камера, постоянно берущая всратые ракурсы, чтобы ты ничерта не понимал. Судя по всему фанатом серии зашла, и мне не совсем понятно почему. Хотя иигру есть за что похвалить, в целом, по итогу я жалею потраченное время. 
Наверное, ни одна игра за последнее время не давала мне такого разочарование в конце. Так нагнетать, создавать интригу, чтобы потом превратить всё в убогую постанову непонятно во имя чего.

138490969.review:
CLoS has a very odd characteristic of being a decent game but being a very poor Castelvania game. The game play is decent, Music is ok, level design has  a few peaks but most of it is middle of the pack and plot...plot is actually pretty decent.  

The game works by doing it in a episode/mission fashion You complete a episode/mission you go on to the next the one. And while this does allow easy methods of back tracking to get collectibles and power ups I feel it takes away form the castlevania  formula as the the paths are fairly start forward with no real exploration being needed beyond a few basics.Part of this is the fact they tried to go away from the platforming angle and more into the hack/slash why would they do this on a series that has built it self on platforming is beyond my knowledge.  That being said level design has some questionable choices but overall not a bad job.

Combat wise they tried to take a page from God of war and Devil may cry and while  that formula works  it just seems unrefined here. Enemies attacks seem to hit you when they should not. Often before they even complete the animation for it.  Your attacks don't seem to hit them when they should. Your combos are clunky and not actually  very easy to combo  and even trying to do air attacks is just not worth it.  because of that enemies attack hit you when they shouldn't I mentioned earlier.   

Music wise it was a major let down.  Every Castlevania I have ever played has had a music/sound track that just hits that spot of epic.  Lords of Shadow did not. It was more back ground noise then something that would suck you in like prior games have. And honestly this is probably my biggest thing. 

Plot wise its not bad. Granted its not Final fantasy or some other JRPG but over all not bad. And as this was meant to be a Retcon of the series it could probably of had some more work on it. But the story was fairly consistent and went to A to B to C in a manner that was easily understood though the plot twist they tried to bring in you could see a mile away. 

Otherall like I said earlier its a decent game, but a very poor  Castlevania one. I feel that it tried to hard to incorporate things taken from God of war, devil may cry, even Prince of Persia making it a Jack of all trades master of none. 
Is it worth playing? Absolutely  my issues with the  game aside I still had fun playing it. But I can't really recommend paying  full price I would advise to wait till its one sale.

[h1]Castlevania is Amazing Adventure![/h1]
[b]I love its boss fights[/b]
There are many types of enemies, with different phases and attack patterns. 
Levels include, but not limited to: giant Titans, sneaky vampires, overwhelming tiny creatures and slashing werewolves.

It doesn't end there - bosses tend to heal themselves, they literally pick up meat chunks, drink own kind, sometimes suck on our hero. Don't relax and keep your fingers ready for QTE!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2973396178

[b]Choose your battling style[/b]
There's a lot of combos to try. There's block and dodge mechanics. There's damage enhancements and life restore techniques. 
Moroever - on a rare occasion you can mount a dark beast and smash them annoying attacking mobs. Plus, such rides often a must for further progression i.e. you need cobwebs to access another building, a werewolf to jump over a bridge or a troll to break through rocks. 

[b]Puzzles, thousands of them![/b]
I'm finally happy - the game has enough brain teasers! Tiles movements, ornaments connections, lasers, energy towers, trap walls, correct sequence and many more. It gets even better, when riddles become part of fights e.g. clearing out scarecrows, pushing columns during chases, etc.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2973396510

[b]Fantastic Levels[/b]
The whole game is quite long - multiple chapters with 4-8 sublevels in each. Travel in forests, mountains, fields, castles, towers, dungeons and even get teleported inside a musical box.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2973395791

138121466.review:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow is a fantastic entry into the legendary series. To keep it short and sweet, the western fantasy approach ends up fitting like a glove for this series, whose roots are already inspired by Western horror fantasy. 

It's a bond made all the stronger by strong voice over performances from the entire cast, but most notably Patrick Stewart. Not only playing a role in the game, but also being the narrator and setting the tone for each and every level. This is narration done right, and Stewart delivers a Shakespearean quality performance that makes the experience more immersive and exciting. 

The gameplay is quite fun, essentially designed in the vain of Devil May Cry and God of War. There are plenty of combos and unique powers to use through out the game. Keeping everything fresh. The QTEs are a mixed bag. They keep things simple enough for the most part, but there are moments I'd prefer to watch as reward for winning. There's also plenty of platforming and puzzle solving, which might be a mixed bag for some, but I found to be welcomed and fun. Admittedly, some of the parts I got stuck on most were puzzle segements, and the approach to platforming, while not difficult, can be confusing at first or if you come back from a game hiatus. Still, the platforming and puzzle solving make use of the powers you use in combat, making sure you as the gamer experience the protagonists many abilities. 

Story is quite good. A horror fantasy epic about a crusader hunting down monsters in the name of God. In this particular setting, you're tasked with defeating the worst monsters of them all, the Lords of Shadow. Who rule over their lands like warlords. Part of your journey is to use the power they possess and bring your dead wife back to life. It's a lengthy journey with plenty ups and downs. The cutscenes are animated like a major studio production and are a treat to watch.

This world is infested with a wide range of enemies. Werewolves, vampires, zombies, ghosts, titans, goblins, and more. Even Chupacabras! The combat is well designed and balanced for the most part, and the bosses are extremely memorable. The game borrows influence from Shadow of the Colossus to break up the other intense boss fights, and make for incredible set pieces. In addition, there's plenty of backstory, lore, conceptual art, and other goodies to find and enjoy. Including multiple difficulty levels and trials for each level. 

The DLC for this game is included in the Ultimate Edition, and as post game content, is good overall. Mainly first episode which offers new gameplay experiences. The final boss in the DLC was a let down for me, simply bad design. Instead of CGI cutscenes, we get storyboarded scenes, which while still good, lack the visual flair we come to expect, and robs us of what could have been a great ending. We do get to play as one of the surviving characters in the game though, which helps to mix things up.

The Lords of Shadow ended up being a quality experience, if flawed, but it ultimately deserved the initial success it had.

Good lord this game is dull. 

Truthfully the combat I think has alot of potential, but suffers from poor balance as spamming the basic combos is your best option 95% of the time, which gets dull very quickly.

There's platforming which is, meh okay I guess, but far less engaging than the combat. However the game seems to have you climb around for a few minutes and then stumble into a combat encounter that takes like 15 seconds.

Combine that with characters and environments that have less charisma than a plank of wood's ballsack and you get an entirely soul-sucking game to play.

And that's not too mention the god awful soundtrack that blares overly dramatic "Sad" music in every level that feels incredibly out of place with the rather mundane opening stages of the game.

I'm willing to bet further into the game it gets better as more mechanics are introduced but I cannot stomach slogging through anymore of this painfully mediocre crap.

I went into this expecting an uninspired God of War ripoff and honestly I would've been happy if the game was just that, but no we get a game trying just barely hard enough to not be a blatant ripoff that it's bogged down with enough crap to take the joy out of smacking things around with a big chain.

I know this game has it's fans and all the power to ya, but I just don't see anything here that hasn't been done 10  times better elsewhere. Play the old GOW games, play Devil May Cry or Ninja Gaiden, hell go play any one of the numerous classic Castlevania games. Those are all doing things this game is aiming to replicate but exponentially better.

137660341.review:
This should have been a movie, not a game. There are lots of great set pieces, scenes, acting, and art in general, but the gameplay drags it all down into hell, literally. The gameplay is best described as quicktime events, the game, and most of the cutscenes, during boss battles, require them to finish a fight. The final DLC boss made me quit the game, it's not worth it for a cutscene. I have played through many other bosses without crap mechanics in other games.

The player combat is passable, and sometimes fun, but most of the bosses and enemies suck to fight. You're given lots of combos, most of which are useless and impossible to use in bossfights. There are no upgrades to damage, and the only way to get magic half the time is to be a perfect player without getting hit, which is impossible in bossfights, especially the DLC. 

Many enemies are simply defeated by grabbing and quicktiming, which defeats the point of combos. There is no air dodge, even though there is a ground dodge and you have wings. Jumping carries momentum most of the time with no air control, making it very hard to control direction of movement or attacks in the air, which is required for later boss battles.

Most of the bossfights revolve around cheap gimmicks rather than anything fun. The titan battles in particular are a bore, only hard because of cheap quicktime events. Platforming sucks, ledgegrabbing is extremely overused and poorly controlled. Depending on camera angles and because the entire game uses fixed cameras, interactable objects can be hard to spot even when pointed out. The DLC especially has some very poorly planned platforming/ledgegrabbing sequences.

The game is extremely hand holding with annoying hints constantly taking camera control away both in and out of boss battles, and annoying reminders that the player is stupid for not immediately solving some stupid puzzle or mechanic. While at the same time, areas that clearly need more direction are ignored, especially some of the puzzles that need some basic directions to solve. There seems to have been very little QA testing. 

There are many navigation bugs present forcing checkpoint restarts when getting stuck on geometry.

137338640.review:
[h1] 💀Hell of a terrible game design💀 [/h1]
Don't know where to start. This game suffers from a poor design in almost every aspect, especially world navigation. There're lots of situations when you intuitively want to rotate your camera to observe all those quite beautiful surroundings or simply check where are you supposed to jump. But there's just [b]NO camera rotation[/b] in Lords of Shadow. Simple as that. Developers think like you're playing on Playstation 1 or PSP or something otherwise I can't explain why the hell you're not using second analog in 2010 game   O_O
[hr][/hr]
Another frustrating thing. Sometimes core mechanics of the game, such as pillars and jumping just [b]DON'T WORK[/b] as they've been working for entire game before.
 Throughout the game you can hold the RT when turning the pillars and the game doesn't care. You don't actually need to hold it, but the game carries on regardless. But in the clock tower, if you hold RT, the pillar stops revolving after a second for no obvious reason. Only place in the game that does it.
And here, in the very Epilogue, this is the only place you have to tap the direction and jump simultaniously, rather than holding left and tapping jump like everywhere else.
 You might ask "is that such a serious problem?" And I'd answer [b] Hell yeah[/b], because Castlevania: Lords of Shadow is really really difficult game at it's core with lots of bizarre puzzles and trials, so it's [b]EXTREMELY[/b] important to make sure the game works stable throughout player's walkthrough, because as long as it doesn't, many annoying situations will happen when player can't understand, is it [b]HE[/b] who sucks, or is it the [b]GAME[/b] which doesn't work properly.
[hr][/hr]
Although combat system is pretty solid, you're probably gonna use 2-3 combos through the whole game for the sake of it's efficiency and simplicity.
Story contains a lot of fantasy cliché. [spoiler] The main character is literally Anakin Skywalker, lol. [/spoiler]
Soundtrack can be really good sometimes, I'll give them that.
Voice actors did an amazing job too. Scottish accent of Robert Carlyle is a music to my ears! :D And of course, the Legend Patrick Stewart doing his thing. Lovely.
[hr][/hr]
In conclusion, it's a shame that LoS could be much better than it is. This title has quite a lot of strengths, such as an amazing atmosphere (it includes soundtrack, visuals, characters) and decent combat system. But the whole experience eventually become ruined because of issues i've listed. 
If you're really into some dark fantasy and you love God of War - you might give it a try, but you should be aware of design issues and be ready to use YouTube at least couple of times.

137030286.review:
En pocas palabras: OBRA MAESTRA


Extendiéndome un poco, si buscas un Hack and Slash con buena historia y unos diseños brutales. Es tu juego. 

- Gráficamente sigue aguantando bien a pesar de los años que han pasado.
- Artísticamente es delicioso. TODO está cuidado, todo tiene unos diseños espectaculares. Hasta una maldita reja está bien detallada y da gusto verla. Si puedes, compra el artbook que sacaron antes de que lo descataloguen. 
- Sin mundo abierto. En una época donde todo es mundo abierto, da gusto ver un juego con un mundo pasillero pero muy bien construido y detallado. Da igual donde mires, todo esta lleno de detalles, incluso barrocamente recargado. 
- Jugáblemente una gozada, los que son de probar muchas combinaciones lo disfrutarán.
- Historia interesante y con unos personajes bien construidos. 
- Variedad. Han cogido todo lo bueno de los mejores del genero y lo han juntado con muy buen hacer. ¿Plataformas? Hecho. ¿Puzzles? Bastantes. ¿Luchas contra monstruos inmensos. Claro. 

- Lo único malo, es que ha veces la cámara no se posiciona en el mejor lugar. Lo bueno es que son contadas ocasiones. 


No me van mucho los metroidvanias así que no he jugado a la saga Castlevania, Lords of Shadows sin embargo lo jugué en su momento (sin los DLCs) y me pareció increíble. Por suerte había comprado la preciosa edición especial. Luego jugué al Mirror of Fate lo jugué en 3DS y a pesar de ser estilo metroidvania lo disfruté bastante gracias a sus diseños y al 3D. 

Ahora lo he rejugado con los DLCs para pasarme el dos, que no lo jugué en su momento. y me reafirmo en lo que me pareció en su momento. OBRA MAESTRA. 

Lástima que Konami de asco y no continúe con el legado de la saga Lords of Shadows. Al menos jugablemente si no quiere seguir con Mercury Steam, pero demostraron que era posible un Castlevania fuera de lo típico que no solo mantuviera el nivel, sino que lo superase.

Cómpralo, no lo arrepentirás.

135670231.review:
It's been over a decade since I played Castlevania: Lords of Shadow. I remember that I didn't pay the game a whole lot of attention because, despite being a big Castlevania fan, my college midterms were going on at the moment and I was more focused on that obviously. Well, thirteen years later I can finally give this game the attention it deserves. The game is broken down into three main pillars: Combat, platforming, and puzzle solving. The combat is excellent and does a good job not shoe horning itself into God of War-clone territory that was so prevalent at the time. The platforming is fun and does offer some areas of challenge, however the game is sometimes very cryptic on where you need to go next to find the next set of platforms. The puzzles are fun and don't require too much thought to overcome (for better or worse). The story does it's job and the voice acting is acceptable, although Sir Patrick Stewart does an amazing job in his role and is by far the stand out performance. 

My one big complaint (SPOILERS) are the Chupacabra segments. The Chupacabra will take your powers and it's up to you to get the back by overcoming trials, platforming, and combat challenges. These segments do nothing but completely halt the game's momentum and offer nothing but filler to the overall composition of the game. 

I would highly recommend this game to Castlevania and God of War fans, or if you just like good hack n' slash action adventure games. 7/10

135101847.review:
This is a hard game to recommend. At its core, LoS is a good God of War clone with high production value, unmistakable Castlevania style, wonderful acting, writing, and rewarding gameplay, with a completely nonsensical and unearned ending. The "Ultimate Edition" ruins this further with the inclusion of the previously DLC levels, which are some of the worst levels I have ever played in a video game: instakill platforming that requires perfection, no source of healing or energy besides fights against hordes with unblockable attacks, and a trial-by-error, multi-stage boss fight with--you guessed it--entirely unblockable/parryable attacks, bubble AoE, and insanely lazy, cheap, drawn cutscenes.

Maybe this sounds fun to the hardcore enthusiasts, but LoS is not designed with reflexes in mind. Pressing a button three times means you will play three, if not four full animations. There is no block cancelling, no aerial block or dodge, learn-by-dying unblockable attacks, and nothing but "whip-sponge" enemies. I bounced off this game hard twice, taking me nearly 10 years to finally get around to completing. At least the core game feels somewhat balanced with its energy/items/health and telegraphed attacks, but the DLC ending (which tries to justify the twist final cutscene of the core game and fails miserably) throws all of that out of the window with punishing padding and misery. I must have died to the "Forgotten One" 50 times, and only won thanks to checkpoints after every phase and having my health refilled to 50% after very death, or it would have been literally impossible--on Normal difficulty, by the way, and achievements dictate I play the entire game on Very Hard. I already have most of the health and energy upgrades, items are useless on bosses, and you never get "strength" upgrades, only combos/inputs. And don't even get me started on damageboxes, as many attacks will hit before the animation connects, making parries mostly guesswork.

All in all, I'm coming away from this game miserable an unfulfilled, mainly because of the DLC. The core game is stylish and while it isn't a metroidvania in most senses, it still has a lot to offer for fans of 3D action games, and Gabriel's voice is a pleasure to listen to. Try it, but don't expect to love it.

WARNING! To anyone looking to purchase this game with the intention of using mouse and keyboard. You can rebind the keys just fine but the mouse cursor is not confined to the screen bounds. If you have more than one monitor like me you will continuously click outside of the screen resulting in the game minimising which gets annoying fast. I did try to look for a fix online but to no avail.

For wanting to play the game I decided to switch over to game-pad. From this point on my experience changed for the better! 

Considering this launched 13 years ago it holds up pretty well in 2023. Visuals are still great with some amazing backdrops and scenery. The combat and game mechanics are fantastic and the boss battles are nothing short of epic. I'm really enjoying this... like a lot!!

For the price this is an epic adventure you cannot skip! Would love to see a reboot of this series in the future.

EDIT: Finished the game in about 22 hours including the 2 DLC missions. All for the price of a sandwich(on sale). Id say thats pretty good bang for buck. Although I wasn't a huge fan of the puzzles(there are fucking loads of them) for the most part this is a good game. Will I be playing it again any time soon probably not but it was a memorable experience with some cool ass boss fights. Defiantly recommended but can get a bit tedious towards the end. 7/10

Looking forward to playing LOS2!

134068968.review:
Castlevania holds a special place in the heart of gamers.
By giving the opportunity to a european study to "give a shot" on this serie, Konami did the right thing.

So long the Iga formula, I really enjoyed like many of us. Here, no claustrophbia in one single gothic castle, but an epic journey in wonderful environments. I praise MercurySteam from the day I discovered their artistic direction.

Gameplay wise, I am not fond of god of war battle mechanics, largely preferring extreme combat from classic DMC, but Gabriel is really fun to play as. I found his struggle interesting, and the story really well written. Adding sound and grounded western christianity to the over the top japanese stories, it was definitely bold.

Of course, it is a product of its time, many mechanics were taken from here and there, but Gabriel Belmont is definitely a unique character.

Could use either one last skill to help locate hidden areas or hard to find treasures.  

Camera is set to make some of the hidden areas and treasures harder to find.

Full completion with all unlocks and achievements will likely take you 40+ hours easily.

132749536.review:
De esta saga he jugado varios, termine Symphony of the Night de PS1 (para mi uno de los mejores y mi favorito), termine Mirror of Fate y jugué varios juegos más. 

En mi opinión la saga jamás debió salir de su temática de scroll lateral en 2D aunque se hubiera aumentado gráficos y demás creo que este estilo le sentaba muy bien (aunque hubo varios intentos en el pasado de convertirla en algo parecido a un "devil may cry" o juegos más abiertos como paso en la Nintendo 64, PS2 y alguno más), ¿Esto quiere decir que los hace malos juegos?, NO al menos los que he probado como el Castlevania: Curse of Darkness de PS2, simplemente creo que podrían haber se centrado en historias y cosas igual o más interesantes sin salir de ese Scroll lateral que era parte atractiva del gameplay.

Pero pasemos a hablar del Lords of Shadow en si...

Es un buen juego con buenos gráficos música decente y mecánicas interesantes, una historia bastante interesante y unos escenarios bien hecho pero... ¿Es un buen Castlevania? PUES NO... te recordará muchísimo a un Devil May Cry con toques de Prince of Persia y alguna referencia a Castlevania, pero sin duda se aleja mucho de lo que fue la saga. 

En definitiva y para no enrollarme, si buscas un juego para pasar el rato y distraerte sin importarte mucho su título o su saga, es un buen juego, si lo que buscas es un Castlevania.... pues te jo-diste.

No enserio, si lo encuentras de oferta cómpralo, no es un mal juego, AHORA no es un buen Castlevania jugablemente al menos.

(Haber si Steam habilita un botón más por que hay juegos que es imposible darles un SI de recomendado pero es injusto darles un NO)

132496908.review:
I fully recommend Castlevania: Lords of Shadow – Ultimate Edition. Even if you’re a fanatical follower of this historic franchise there is still enough core story material in play to keep you interested, and there is no denying the hypnotic visuals, great story, excellent voice acting, and the adrenaline-fueled gameplay that is only matched by the first titles of God of War series. This is a visionary new look for Castlevania, both in stunning graphics and a new style of gameplay that hardcore action junkies and adventure seekers won’t want to miss.

PROS:
✓ Great boss fights
✓ Epic orchestrated soundtrack
✓ Story theme is engaging
✓ The visuals and artistic design are so good
✓ Nice voice acting,

CONS:
- Superfluous quick-time events
- A troublesome fixed camera
- Few game puzzles are bit frustrating

132335311.review:
The Castlevania series together with the Metroid saga created a whole videogame genre (Metroidvania) loved by many. This game breaks with that style and explores the [b]Hack & Slash[/b], creating an amazing game. 

Both the [b]soundtrack[/b] and the [b]landscapes [/b] are beautiful, carefully made. The menus are just as beautiful and eye-catching as the game itself. The [b]gameplay [/b] is usually pretty fun, with a good variety of flashy combos and powers. The Gauntlet is one of- if not the worst weapon in the game, just useful for puzzles as most moves leave you really exposed in fights.

The story starts [i]in media res[/i], when Gabriel has already started his journey. The main character is arguably one of the biggest flaws in the game. He lacks personality and you can't really empathize with him much at all. There are no noticeable changes in his personality throughout the game, despite being described. "I can see the hate in his eyes"- bruh, I can't. The ending is also pretty nice.

[b]DLCs[/b] - They offer some more pieces of the story, the fights with [spoiler]The Forgotten One[/spoiler] can be a tough challenge at high difficulties. The path of Gabriel [spoiler]into vampirism[/spoiler] is explained in them.

I'd recommend anyone to experience what this game has to offer. Great game =)

132148880.review:
I really tried, but this game is trash, and not really a Castlevania game at all. I never played the early God of War games, I watched others play those games and this feels like the Castlevania license was just slapped on bad God of War clone. 

Cons:

-Tedious Button mashing combat

-Tedious puzzles

-Fixed Camera angle

-Poor level design, invisible barriers everywhere, unclear where you can and cannot travel unless your being lead by the nose through the environment by highlighted objects

-Waaaay too many cut scenes, QTE's, and general filler

-Weak Story, after the novelty of Patrick Stewart's narration wore off, I was skipping all of the story bits, and I love Patrick Stewart

I don't even know what else to say  about this. Maybe this style of game just isn't for me, but literally no part of this game was fun. I got it on sale and wish I could have the 4 hours I wasted with it back. I was actually going to give it a little more time, but thankfully I stopped and read some other reviews and realized there was nothing but more tedium ahead. 

I don't understand the good reviews of this game, or how it got a sequel which is also in my library from the same sale. I could slog through the mediocre gameplay if there was a compelling story, or endure a bad story if the gameplay was awesome, but this game literally fails on every level.

132034901.review:
[b] Summary [/b]  10/10
A masterpiece in every sense of the word from game play, to graphics and my word, the music! Gabriel is one of the few fictional heroes I admire and I enjoyed his story in Castlevania: Lords of Shadow. Be sure to pick up a copy (even better on a sale)!

[b] Gameplay [/b]  10/10
You play as Gabriel Belmont on a mission to save mankind from evil forces known as the lords of shadow. As you progress, you will realize things are not what they seem, but hang in there, it gets even better! Combat is satisfying through the dazzling use of an upgradeable combat cross, daggers, holy water, fairies (yes! they can stun enemies) and a purple crystal with a very funky demon inside! In addition, you unlock light (healing) and dark (damage multiplier) magic.

[b] Multiplayer [/b]  0/10
Ha, I wish. Game is awesome with or without it!

[b] Graphics [/b]  10/10 
Dated. Seriously the graphics are older but no less satisfying. No graphical issues, stutters or freezing either.

[b] Audio [/b]  10/10 
Yes. Yesssss! The sound track for this game is so satisfying and enjoyable. The music can be uplifting, sad, awe-inspiring depending on what's going on, but never once did I feel like it did not suit the current atmosphere in the game. One of my favorite sounds tracks, check out the OST on Utube.

[b] Controls [/b]  10/10
Controls worked flawlessly, no remapping needed.
