Its a solid hack-and-slash adventure game, with plenty of platforming and some puzzles that make it feel quite Castlevania instead of a tedious 'mash X to attack and win' sort of game.     The story line is nothing spectacular and doesn't make sense at a lot of parts, but you also get to hear Patrick Stewart more than anyone else!

However, it has some issues.   Keeping in mind this is a game from 2013, there are still certain things that really grind my gears.
First, the fact that enemy attacks connect and do damage at the START of their animation is pretty janky.   Plenty of bosses have landed killing blows on me before their attack actually makes contact with my model.   Each attack seems to have a wind-up animation, which you need to identify in order to react properly, but as soon as the actual attack animation plays, you're gonna get hit, or not.
Second, camera.  The camera is fixed into certain angles and placements through the environments, you dont get to control it, and so you may find yourself fighting enemies that are not actually visible on screen.  Or, in the middle of a fight, the camera transitions to a different angle and suddenly the fight is taking place in some corner, behind a wall, and you need to break off to reposition into an area with a better camera angle.      To make matters worse, the transition of moving from one camera view to the next is sometimes jarring, where the controls are quite wonky.
Third, the checkpoint system sometimes screw you up.  Autosaves happen at various points, and they save all of your current health and ability bars.  So if you get to a checkpoint with low health, be prepared to fight your way out of the next battle with low HP, again and again and again, until you get through it.  Its a good way to master those fights, though!  Just a little frustrating when you finally reach a boss, or the second phase of a boss, and with one hit worth of HP left youre stuck loading back into that point over and over.
Fourth, Quick-time events.   A lot of them.   A sign of when this game was released, be prepared to mash input buttons at points through combat, and hit a button at the correct times during cutscenes even.  Im glad this sort of thing has been done away with, and this game reminds me WHY it was so annoying.   You just whittled a boss down, defeated him, and instead of relaxing and enjoying your victory you better be paying attention at all times, waiting for that required input during the cutscene!  Otherwise...  well, you lose and gotta restart from the most recent checkpoint!


However, overall its a really solid game, well put together and a lot of fun to play, so long as you get past those gripes.  The experience of playing it is absolutely worth it!

128019573.review:
An enjoyable but flawed game that I cannot help but feel would be a smash-hit if it was remade with modern quality-of-life updates and graphics in a similar way to how Capcom is doing with the Resident Evil games. It is worth getting on sale if you are into this genre and can look past the cons listed below.

Pros:

1) A fantastic premise and story. The lore is rich, the characters are varied. Granted, the presentation may have lost it's lustre when you compare it to modern games because it falls short technically, but if you consider the time it was made - spectacular. Heck, they even had Patrick Stewart on board as narrator/side character!

2) Beautiful worlds and meticulous character design. I play a lot of whatever the current-gen AAA games of the year may be, but even I couldn't help but stop and say "wow" to myself when going through some of the Gothic castle ruins. I can only imagine what something like this would look like if done again now with say Unreal Engine 5.

3) The boss fights in this game are a real highlight. They are varied and interesting, sometimes even taking inspiration from cult-classics like Shadow of the Colossus, God of War or Dark Souls. The final boss of the DLC especially had me fighting for my life, and gave me a glorious sense of satisfaction over a hard-fought victory.

Cons:

1) The weakest aspect of this game is the choice they made to go with a fixed camera angle. I suppose this was done to keep the costs of production down, but it was like shooting the game in its own foot. Certain puzzle sections and hidden areas can be a proper headache to deal with due to this.

2) If you are playing on normal difficulty or higher, enemies in the later half of the game tend to be mountains of health that take forever to deal with. They wont finish you off, so it is not hard - just a grind to kill them. I often found myself avoiding fights with these types of enemies entirely (if the fights were avoidable) and running to the next area if I could, just to save time.

3) The economy for earning the two energies you use in the game for your more powerful special moves, light and shadow is a little stingy. I wish the hit-combo bar you needed to fill in order to earn these energies filled a little faster or once it was filled, you earned this energy in larger amounts.

This game was made with gameplay similar to the 2000s God of War and Dante's Inferno but this isn't a bad thing at all. If you like that style of gameplay or have wanted to try it then this game can give it to you.

the story is a simple tale of a stoic man traveling from place to place to kill monsters of the occult, like Vampires, Werewolves, trolls and the like. The protagonist isn't very deep but this was ok for me, I went in just wanting to kill monsters. The Quick Time Events (QTEs) can be a pain if you're not ready for them. if you miss it, bosses will get health back and fights can take longer. That said, these QTEs were entertaining for me to watch.

When it comes to traversal, it can be a mixed bag. Sometimes sections of walls you can scale may not be obvious and the camera can be you worst enemy. This becomes real problem in the last few levels of the game when you deal with the final boss and by then I just wanted it to be over. 

Overall I enjoyed the monster killing action and the simple story, so much so that I got the sequel and will be playing that at some point. If you do decide to try it, I hope you like it too.

124783137.review:
The highest point of 3D Castlevania---Lords of Shadows is the last big-budget effort, even starring Patrick Stuart to narrate before each level. The sheer amount of content here is: wow. The lore and atmosphere envelope players, creating old nostalgia and a new adventure that fleshes out the Castlevaniaverse (I'm coining that term here and now -JS). Limited by only its time, the combat mechanic meshes seamlessly, making Gabriel a perfect tool in the hands of imperfect players---those of whom loudly cry out their tears of failure into negative Steam reviews for their digital inadequacy.

If your hands can still handle Devil May Cry and the like---and you love Castlevania---how could you not enjoy it? Definitely a game to be played for the fall, into the winter. Again, I don't think there has ever been a hack n clash with this many individual levels, each with its own routes and backtrack items to collect. No, it's not Metroidvania; It's Castlevania.

As for the sequel, well, if you love this you'll like that, but not nearly not as much. It's that weird, desperate, sci-fi twist---the kind that comes along when there's no more left of a good thing yet it must be made anyways. We forge ahead, searching for a glint of originality though there is none.

124693011.review:
This is not a metroidvania style castlevania game. It's more of a 3D hack and slash game with linear progression. Noticeably absent from this game is the castlevania theme music that somehow did not make into the game, although there was a level inside a music box with music that sounded vaguely familiar, but different. Perhaps there was some weird licensing issue with the music?

Anyway, it's kind of a game that is castlevania in name and story only. Here's a summary of my thoughts:

PROS:
- Sir Patrick Stewart provides narration
- Kind of a fun 3d hack and slash gameplay with a nifty whip
- There is at least one level with a clocktower and lots gears with annoying medusa heads
- Good story with a surprise ending

CONS:
- No castlevania theme music, there's like this orchestral string music to create suspense and stuff, but it's not the same. Thinking about the music from symphony of the night and even the nintendo DS games, there just really isn't any comparison. 
- For me, the most difficult portions of the game occurred in the first 3 chapters, especially with werewolves/lycans that would block nearly every attack. Later chapters were easier...that's kinda weird.
- Gabriel Belmont has a tiny head and grunts all the time.

True castlevania fans might want to put this on their list to play through at some point, but it's much lower on the list than symphony of the night, dracula X, dawn of sorrow, etc.

124508958.review:
If you want to play a good version of God of War, this is it. 

The voice acting and music are some of the best of all time. It's a shame this game is regularly overlooked and underappreciated. It might not be "CASTLEVANIA" the way you know it, but it is a fascinating take on the lore and material that earns its place in the series as something completely unique. 

You can also feel the clear inspiration of the Peter Jackson LotR trilogy all throughout this game. It's done tastefully and feels like the developers clearly love and respect his work and crafted something super interesting that stands on its own. 

You really can't go wrong with this game if you enjoy linear action games with fantastic stories, engaging combat, brilliant art design, and--quite frankly--a masterpiece of a soundtrack. 

It may not be old school Castlevania, but there is 100% room for more of this in the series and I appreciate everything about this game.

Again, oh well- I'm happy to have purchased and played through.

123806891.review:
To my surprise I actually had a lot of fun with Lords of Shadow! I will say though, it has a LOT of unnecesary blood, violence, crude elements and nudity in it which personally made me uncomfortable. But other than that, this game is enjoyable! It's a character action game (kinda like Bayo or DMC!) where the key to success involves timing your attacks and dodges, perfecting counters, using different subweapons, buying new moves all that fun stuff! What's really cool about LoS was how the magic system worked: you have two kinds of magic at your disposal - Light for Healing and Shadow for Attack - and managing those two ressources according to your situation was a blast!
Besides the fun gameplay loop, I thought the music was pleasant but ultimately not catchy enough, the story somewhat stilted at times but with some quite good moments here and there - and honestly? I thought the environment design was great!! I loved exploring the areas due to the colors used, the way they looked, they just, really drew me in and fitted a modern day Castlevania game pretty well!

So yeah, I didn't hear great things about the core CV fanbase before playing this, but Lords of Shadow is actually really good in my opinion! Definitely worth a shot, even if the post credits scene... is a bit weird!

123778887.review:
[h1] Lords of Shadow - A Miserable Slog [/h1]

[b] Ever wonder what God of War would be like if it were terrible? [/b]

You might get a bit of enjoyment out of this one if you like to mash buttons over some admittedly nice looking environments. It doesn't take long, however, for the frustrations to show - and they get steadily more grating as the game goes on. If you value your time, stay away. 

This game has a giant problem with information. Too much at times, too little at others. Environments are not legible and there are invisible walls everywhere, sometimes even one-sided ones. At every turn, an ugly Arial font will appear at the top of the screen telling you exactly what to do, sometimes even coupled with slow-mo camera zooms. There is no way to turn tutorials off. When it isn't the text, side characters will yell in your ear giving you explicit instructions, including even the final bosses. When the boss is quite literally telling you how to beat him, it highlights a greater issue: this game has no concept of how to organically convey the arbitrary tasks it expects of you, so it just points a big glowing neon arrow at them and acts like that's a job well done. 

Combat starts out relatively strong but devolves after the unlockable combos get silly, with most of them just using two buttons in alternating press/hold/press a bunch of times sequences. Encounter design is also a mess, on top of that, with most levels just having one (or maybe two!) enemy types repeated ad nauseam. Many of the bosses don't even use the core combat systems, instead opting for giant enemies that have to be scaled and whittled down a la Shadow of the Colossus. It misses the mark by failing to understand why that game worked though, and these encounters play out more like an elongated quick-time event with Uncharted style climbing. The only tension you will feel is when you consider having to do any of it over again. These are legitimately some of the least engaging bosses I've ever faced. 

The most fun I got out of the experience was listening to Patrick Stewart's narration of the awful script and picturing Captain Picard telling stories to children on the holodeck. When judged as an actual narrative, though, it falls flat once again because of the game's information problem. The story prefers to tell us what happens to the characters and what they're going through rather than showing any of it. The protagonist is supposed to be undergoing a dark downward spiral but that only really happens in the narration, he mostly just doesn't say much or do much unexpected. I also can't be expected to take it seriously when they do things like following up a supposed tragic revelation with an off-key Star Wars reference. 

I can count on one hand (or two, generously) how many links to the Castlevania series are present here. Not every game in a series has to be a love letter to itself, and tenuous links can sometimes be needed to break out of a stale formula. This has been proven to work, and the shake-up is often welcomed, but it doesn't work here for one reason - this game has nothing going for it. I guarantee if this weren't called Castlevania, no one would care about it. I played through this entire game in roughly 20 hours and it felt like twice its length for how miserable it was. 

Hopefully the sequel is better.

123491704.review:
Como pienso habitualmente, no se puede hacer una valoración de un juego si no lo has jugado al completo o casi. Por ese motivo he hecho todo lo posible por acabar este Castlevania.  

El principal motivo de mi no recomendación a jugarlo es que, a menos que seas muy habilidoso en los hack n slash la curva de aprendizaje está un poco descompensada por la poca barra de vida inicial o potencia de ataques para un nivel medio de dificultad. Esto, unido al diseño en mini episodios y a la necesidad de repetirlos (para potenciar al personaje con combos o mejoras), no solo una, sino varias veces a lo largo del juego, hace que se te pueda atragantar.

Yo empecé este juego hace mucho tiempo, y hasta el 40% lo estaba jugando casi como un casual, pero me propuse terminarlo porque estaba un poco harto.

Cuando comienzas el personaje principal es muy flojo, y necesitas ir avanzando y repetir fases para conseguir más monedas y desbloquear combos. En los mini episodios hay mejoras que solo las puedes coger con objetos de poder posteriores, con lo que esto también obliga a repetir las fases. Una manera más holgada de jugarlo hubiera sido poner el juego en fácil e ir avanzando en la historia, y ya, hacia el final del juego, subir el nivel a medio y repetir las fases para conseguir las mejoras. Yo iba repitiendo a medida que veía que podía desbloquear o conseguir algo nuevo, o hacer un reto. Por eso un juego que si fuera lineal costaría unas 10 horas, acaba convirtiéndose en un juego de 40 o más por repetir y repetir.

Este juego lo iba a jugar en PS3 pero lo dejé para PC por la mejor resolución. Recuerdo otros juegos del estilo como el Bayonetta, que aunque había momentos de dificultad grande, sobre todo los QTE, por lo menos ibas avanzando en la historia. Y luego hay otros juegos como el Darksiders que son una maravilla en la curva de la dificultad y en el gran diseño que tienen para no darte la sensación de que no haces más que repetir y repetir cachos de historia.

Por lo demás las mejores fases son las que te recuerdan a los clásicos, las de localizaciones góticas y tenebrosas (abadías, pueblos en la montaña, castillos, catacumbas), no tanto las de lugares fantásticos o ruinas en medio de la "selva" o páramos desolados. En el apartado artístico no se le puede poner un pero y está todo bastante bien diseñado. La cámara falla a veces eso si y te puede desorientar o dificultar el combate.

En resumen, es un juego que si quieres sacarle algo de jugo has de repetir y repetir y se hace muy largo para lo que realmente ofrece de historia. Ya lo he dicho, 10 horas bien, 45 es un horror. Viendo la progresión de los logros de la gente se nota, porque he llegado a ver que más o menos un 20% de la gente no pasa de la fase 5 o 6. Y muchos logros no los consiguen ni el 5% (incluso completar los retos de fases iniciales). Habrá gente muy hábil con el mando que no esté de acuerdo con mi percepción de la dificultad del juego pero como digo, solo hay que ver la gente que se lo ha terminado y el % de logros conseguidos.

Veremos si en un futuro tengo ganas de jugar a alguna de sus continuaciones o no. Por ahora lo aparco para dentro de mucho tiempo.

PD: Edito ya que me faltaba la fase XIV por acabar. El enemigo final del segundo DLC un suplicio en el último punto de guardado final de la batalla. Jugado con un mando con no muy buena respuesta, en nivel medio y llegando con bastante magia y vida. Me he sacado un montón de logros salvo los de dificultad y un buen puñado de retos pero ya no me dan ganas de volver a jugar por lo "pesado y cansino" que ha sido.

I'm going to give a complete honest review of this game.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]
Visually this game looks like any other 2010 game. And yes it still not that bad as of 2022. I could still enjoy the game. In some levels it might look a bit old. But some chapters really do look good. Like the castle and most interiors. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
The gameplay is classic God of war mixed with Devil May Cry and Darksiders. Most aspects like platforming, puzzle solution, find that item etc are similar to those games. 
I do have some negative comments about the gameplay. First of all, in some situations you'd straight up go crazy because it'll put you in such situations where you'll almost rage quit. Reason? Unnecessary gameplay situations (one good example is [spoiler] where you have to grapple and climb onto the dragon like titan and kill it. [/spoiler] THAT WAS SUPER ANNOYING. Where you'd get pissed very easily. It's connected with platforming and climbing as well. 

[h1] Story [/h1]
The story is really good. If you haven't played lords of shadows 2 before this and didn't get any spoilers, you'll get to see a bunch of twists and surprising moments.
Here's a basic summary. It'll feel a bit boring at the start. For few chapters...but when it passes, the more you play the game, the more interesting it becomes. It's because of the story. 

My personal rating of this game will be 7/10 .It wouldn't even have gotten 7 if not for the story. Because there are some gameplay moments where you will get pissed very much like it doesn't make any sense to be there.If the gameplay was like Castlevania lords of shaodws 2, then it'd have gotten a solid 8.

122790831.review:
Antes de jugar este juego nunca había tocado la saga de Castlevania. Apenas vi el trailer supe que era un Hack and Slash y no dude en jugarlo. Mi experiencia fue gratificante y he aquí mi humilde reseña.
La historia no tiene nada que ver con los otros juegos de la saga, por ese motivo no necesitaras jugar ningún juego anterior para entender la historia. 
A grandes rasgos la historia se centra en una profecía de que un guerrero destruirá a los 3 señores oscuros que amenazan a la humanidad con llevarla a su fin. Dicha historia será narrada capitulo a capitulo antes de empezar cada uno por un personaje secundario del cual sabremos no mucho después de iniciar la aventura.
La trama también incluye algún que otro giro inesperado, reflexiones del protagonista y sus respectivas revelaciones. La historia es sencilla de llevar y no requiere romperse la cabeza para entenderla.
Los gráficos del juego han envejecido bien. Sin embargo, luce mejor gracias a su apartado artístico que es lo atrapa más al recorrer la aventura. Los ángulos elegidos para poder apreciar paisajes y estructuras son los indicados. De cierta forma el juego desprende esa sensación épica al visitar cada lugar nuevo.
La música de este juego acompaña muy bien las batallas, la incertidumbre de avanzar por nuevas áreas y los encuentros brutales con los jefes.
En el aspecto jugable es un hack and slash que premia mucho la concentración al combatir enemigos, ya que al mantener el ritmo de las batallas saliendo ileso ya sea esquivando o bloqueando correctamente recibirás energía que podrás distribuir en 2 diferentes tipos de magia: Azul para recuperar vida y roja para amplificar el daño, así de simple. Dependiendo de la situación habrá que decidir que tipo de magia utilizar o de ser necesario ambas en conjunto para sacar ventaja en cada pelea. Como en todo juego de este tipo se cuenta con una lista de combos los cuales podrás adquirir comprándolos con puntos de experiencia que conseguirás a lo largo de la aventura. Por otro lado, se dispone de armas secundarias que también se pueden utilizar en combinación con las magias, y por ultimo, se dispone de 4 tipos de objetos gastables que podremos utilizar. Algunos de estos objetos hacen mas daño a enemigos específicos por lo que habrá que utilizarlos siempre que podamos. Todos estos elementos combinados o por separado harán batallas distintas haciendo que el juego sea variable.
Una de las cosas que mas me ha gustado de este juego es la gran diversidad de enemigos, cada uno con diferentes tipos de ataque y movimientos. Los diseños de algunos de ellos son muy buenos y es divertido enfrentarlos. Solo por mencionar a algunos: Licantropo mayor, vampiros, trolls, espadachines, duendes, arañas gigantes, guerreros esqueleto, entre muchos otros mas.
Los jefes finales son intimidantes en primera instancia, 3 de ellos requerirán ser escalados para ser destruidos. Una mecánica ya antes vista en otro juego: Shadow of the Colossus.
Aparte de ello, se cuenta con acertijos. Los tenemos desde muy básicos hasta algunos complejos. Hay la opción de poder pasarlos por alto desbloqueando la solución. Si eres de los que gusta de este tipo de mecánicas te recomiendo que intentes descifrarlos por ti mismo.
La aventura también implica mejorar las armas del protagonista, para ello será necesario explorar bien los escenarios y encontrar fragmentos de mejora tanto para los medidores de magia como de salud y capacidad para objetos. Sugiero hacerlo de primeras para llegar mas cómodo a las instancias finales del juego.
Este juego cuenta con varias cinemáticas, algunas como introducción para un enemigo, otras para hablar un poco mas de los personajes secundarios, etc.
Para complementar el juego tenemos los retos que hacen rejugable cada capitulo. Una serie de desafíos que deberás cumplir con ciertas condiciones que harán el juego mas interesante.
Por ultimo, tenemos los 2 capítulos extra que vienen con el DLC. Los cuales son muy importantes para entender el nexo que tiene este juego con su secuela. 
Aquí encontrarás al enemigo mas difícil de enfrentar de todo el juego. Podría decir incluso que la dificultad es equiparable a enfrentar un jefe tipo soulslike. Personalmente fue un desafío vencerlo y sobre todo en la dificultad mas alta. Derrotarlo despues de varios intentos fue muy gratificante.
En conclusión, Castlevania: Lord of Shadows es un hack and Slash con muchos elementos de varios tipos de juego que hacen una mezcla divertida. 
Es casi inevitable pensar en los antiguos God of War al combatir con los enemigos, sobretodo por el gran parecido de las armas de los protagonistas en ambos juegos. 
Sin embargo, ambos juegos tienen ritmos diferentes.
Lord of Shadows es mas pausado. 
Se toma un break invitando al jugador a contemplar los paisajes o grandes estructuras, resolver algún que otro acertijo o invitando a la exploración para ser recompensado. 
Precisamente por ese detalle me parece un buen Hack and Slash para empezar en el genero, ya que a parte de tomarse sus pausas, tiene una dificultad que se incrementa lentamente conforme avanzamos en la aventura. Eso lo podrás confirmar tu mismo si llegas hasta el final, y con eso me refiero al final del dlc. Verás la gran diferencia de dificultad. Si sigues bien las indicaciones con cada tutorial que aparecerá no deberías tener problemas para progresar en el juego.
EL juego tiene mucho contenido y explotarlo al maximo me tomo 60 horas. Sin embargo, creo que se puede completarlo en menos de 50 horas.
Si todavía no has jugado ningún Hack and Slash, mi recomendación es que empieces por este, ya que me parece el mejor para entrar al genero. No olvides comprarlo en oferta!

I wanted to like this. I really did. I devoted over 6hrs of my life to really, genuinely trying. But man this game blows. Like, a lot.

Wikipedia says this got positive reviews on release. How? It's a blatant GoW ripoff but so subpar I actually quit to replay the first GoW.

Let's talk story. Wtf is going on here? Brotherhood? Lords of Shadow? Where TH are we? Where's the friggin castle? The story reads like a 12yo's fanfic and I'm legit surprised Sir Patrick Stewart did voiceover. Like, he had to have read it beforehand and though like, "Man, is this paycheck worth THIS dribble?"

Gameplay. Dudes. Just don't. It's on such strict rails you'll wonder why they even made the environment look moderately good if they don't want you to explore it. Oh, let's not forget when you DO find a secret you have no way of marking it to remember to revisit when you finally get the upgrade that lets you pass. Which, btw, upgrades suck. They do half of Jack shit.

So do yourself a favor and go to your local pawn store to pick up a PS3, then pay however much to get the GoW collection, or Dante's Inferno, or any DMC game, or literally any other hack-and-slash because this is a waste of your money.

Gran juego, algo antiguo pero muy bueno.

-Gráficos y ambientación: Los gráficos son muy detallados, tanto de las cinemáticas como de los entornos y las criaturas, se nota que le han puesto mucho cariño y se han esforzado en los detalles.

-Música: Sinceramente, se que hay música porque la he escuchado en algunos momentos y cinemáticas, pero estaba tan centrado en matar monstruos que no puedo calificarla. Diría que acompaña al juego sin que te enteres de ella.

-Enemigos: Diversos y variados, hay los suficientes de cada especie de monstruo para que no te resulte monótono pelear con ellos. Además de la variedad y los diferentes jefes y mini jefes que aportan mucha sustancia al juego.

-Jugabilidad: Seamos sinceros, el juego engancha, el manejo en el combate no es complicado a pesar de los muchos combos que hay, y al final acabaras usando tu propios combos o los que mas cómodos te resulten.

-Historia: La historia en buena, me ha recordado mucho al Dante's Inferno. Pero te atrapa y siempre quieres saber mas. Y una cinemática del final te dejara con el culo torcido diciendo: Queeee?

-Dificultad: No es difícil, he jugado en el nivel mas difícil que te permite al empezar el juego y a excepción de algunos puzles no ha supuesto un dark souls.

-Contras: La única cosa mala del juego, cerca de la mitad hay que hacer movimiento en diagonal con una habilidad para resolver un puzle y con el teclado era imposible hacerlo. Tuve que jugar el resto del juego con el mando de la Xbox y ya no supuso ningún problema, pero si empiezo con teclado me gusta terminar con teclado, manías de cada uno.

Lo recomiendo, es un buen juego de duración alrededor de 16 / 20 horas, ya depende de lo que quieras desbloquear. Tiene buena historia y entretiene mucho.

This game is incredible. Don't let the haters tell you otherwise. I legit enjoy the combat style of this game much more than the classic God of War games. It makes sense, is intuitive and looks fantastic. It looks very much how I would imagine a fantasy whip user would fight. 

If you are a fan of metroidvanias, you won't find one here. This is a departure from that kind of Castlevania. And this move disappointed many fans of the series. But while it is more akin to God of War, this game truly does still maintain the spirit of classic Castlevania to a T. This game is more heavily inspired by Super Castlevania 4 and the early games. Therefore it is linear, but the atmosphere and gameplay is incredible. If you are a fan of classic Castlevania, you gotta try this!

Lastly if you are either Catholic or Christian this game has heavy themes in your favor. It is refreshing to see a Catholic protagonist and have him be unapologetic in his pious nature. You don't often see characters in fantasy settings or medieval settings be Catholic or Christian and not be evil in one shape or another and it was nice to see it for a change.

118325403.review: Do not bother with this game. Having finished this I can tell you that this is hot garbage. The story, as a long time fan of Castlevania, is highly questionable, EVEN for a reboot. Controls are made for console and not for PC  and the you will have constant problems with such. I started the game on normal difficulty cause I wanted to experience the game as it is. But half way I had to change due to the aforementioned fact of the controls that were making the game more difficult than it already is. Furthermore the controls themselves are bad as well. Jumps are mid to badly controlled in mid air, dodges and blocks can't be more badly implemented with the timing for the blocks being actually terrible as when you think he is making an attack the game registers it as not attacking for even though the animations tells you otherwise. Parkour (yes there is parkour in this game for some damned reason) is mid to good actually. With some good little ideas implemented but not that much. Puzzles are mid tier. Not hard not easy. But they got that one problem where you don't understand what is going on. A specific puzzle is that you need to ground slam some tiles for a gate to open and the hint that the game gives is so cryptic that the first thing that comes to mind is completely different from what you need to do. Battles and combat are also mid tier. Some are amazing some are outright terrible. And the one thing I can say here is that you will rarely use the AoE attacks. It is so damned awful that you would be better off with the normal attack than that due to the damage output. Finally the control inputs were specifically terrible. Like mentioned the blocks and so on are bad, but due to 2 facts the game gets even worse. First there are QTEs (Quick Time Events) which doesn't help the game at all, and second the QTEs are also random buttons. You would have expect the Character is struggling for an attack you would press the attack button, but nope, it can be from the actual attack button to the jump button for some reason. Do not bother with this game. Play Lords of Shadow 2, you aren't missing anything.

Genuinely i went into this game with high expectations as someone who mildly enjoy's the Castlevania series, seeing as this is one of the few Castlevania games on PC i thought i'd give it a try. It just gives you a small prompt at the beginning vaguely describing the controls, then thrusts you in and i had no idea what i was doing, i was playing this on the "medium" difficulty (knight) and already enemies just felt like fucking sponges, the bear like enemy that was the boss of the first encounter just sponged so many hits and once you get it down low enough it begins a """cinematic""" interactive sequence that HAS to be ended with a "quicktime event" that is thrown out of nowhere and has like a time window of 5 or so seconds. And since this game's default controls are so ass you have to stop and scan your keyboard for the button, but by then you missed the time frame and the bear is back up to like 60% health. And it will NOT DIE until you do the sequence. I know this game was made around the late 2000s / early 2010s but this games visuals are really on the low end and the design of the game is horrible. The game looks almost cartoony in a way, and the enemies were so boring it just felt like generic fantasy enemies and shit you'd find in WoW. I'm not amused by this game and im frankly disappointed. 117788148.review:
I can say I have some experience with the Castlevania franchise. I played Symphony of the Night for the PS1 and all the titles released for the PS2, the GBA and the Nintendo DS. Excluding those made for the PS2, all of these games shared a number of characteristics. They were all 2D RPG-lite platformers with maps composed of interconnected areas which the player could explore to advance the game and find secrets, itens and equipment. Lords of Shadow is an evident deviation from this model, designed to be a 3D hack n' slash action-adventure title not dissimilar to the original God of War. At first, while this change could disappoint die-hard fans of the metroidvania iterations of the series, it didn't mean this game would necessarily fail to become a worthwhile addition to the other genre. Its developers had the right to try out a new approach and make something different -- that's fine by me. However, in my opinion, LoS presents many design decisions that made my experience playing it quite unpleasant, and so I cannot recommend it. Let's see.

First, a summary. As a hack n' slash title, Lords of Shadow revolves around combat. The player has access to a chain whip weapon that serves as the primary means of dealing damage. Four secondary armaments can also be used to dispatch or distract enemies, and two magic pools allow Gabriel, the protagonist, to heal his wounds or increase his damage potential with the whip. Certain pieces of equipment with special purposes will be looted over the course of the game from specific bosses or chests. Experience points are acquired by killing foes and solving puzzles that show up in certain levels, and these points may be allocated for the acquisition of whip combos and special abilities. A number of collectibles can be found in most levels to increase the size of the health bar and the mana pools. Since action is the focus here, exploration falls on the sidelines. Pretty standard fare for the genre, I suppose.

Now, the issues. The camera in this game is, simply put, obnoxious. You can't move it anyhow. Yes, it works to present some breathtaking vistas and cinematic takes, but it frequently hampers combat and platforming with cumbersome angles and distant zooms. Sometimes it's hard to see what's happening because everything is far away, and keeping track of all enemies on the screen is problematic. It is not convenient, I'm afraid.

A major aspect of this game is climbing and platforming. The player will be forced to climb a lot of cliffs and structures, and the task becomes quite repetitive. All levels are entirely linear, so these paths are unavoidable in order to proceed. Certain areas will also require precise jumping. This is a problem since the jumping and aerial mechanics in LoS are not precise, at all. I lost count of the number of times I died in a precipice because the controls were cumbersome, or when Gabriel refused to scale a wall in a certain way. Navigating through these vertical segments was a bothersome slog.

I despise quick time events, and this game is full of them. Most bosses will prompt the execution of these commands, and performing finishing moves on ordinary foes will also require pressing a button at specific times during a locked sequence. This was annoying because I felt that most bigger enemies were bullet sponges in LoS. The secondary weapons are only useful against particular creatures and the whip seems quite weak against large foes. You'll have to swing it at them multiple times before getting the prompt to start the fatality sequence. Most combos and special abilities are either ineffective or impractical given the enemies' general resistance to stun effects, so expect to resort to a select group of combat moves and get ready to perform lots of individual executions. Sure, shadow magic can speed things up, but good luck maintaining its mana pool full on the hardest difficulty settings.

The majority of bosses were alright, I must say. There is a respectable variety of big guys and they all present a reasonable challenge, especially on the hardest difficulties. Exceptions to this standard are the titanic creatures, which are basically extended climbing and puzzle segments. I did not like the trudge of scaling them, frankly. I also need to complain about the final boss of the DLC content, a guy named The Forgotten One. I'm convinced the developers missed the mark with this one. As I said before, the aerial mechanics in LoS are cumbersome and imprecise at best. Given that this fella is rather tall, you have to use air attacks to hit his head during the final stage of the battle. Since the game doesn't have a target-locking feature... well, you can imagine the situation. This part became a nightmare on Paladin difficulty for the wrong reason.

Lords of Shadow looks beautiful, even for a game released in 2010. The amount of different locations and the richness of detail and colors in each one of them ensured that I wasn't bored by any drab areas. Many distinct creatures are found in the game and they all have interesting designs, in my opinion. I enjoyed looking at the elaborate architecture of castles and monumental structures, which, together with imponent natural landscapes, helped create a unique dark fantasy world. It's talented artistry, really. This is all accompanied by a nice soundtrack that has a bunch of inspiring songs which I had to add to my personal list of OSTs.

As for the story, well, we can't really expect to see Shakespearean dramas in videogames. The voice acting by Robert Carlyle, Patrick Stewart and others is well done, I guess. The protagonist goes on a quest to kill some evil dudes and revive his dead wife by assembling a magical mask. A bunch of twists happen along the way and Gabriel ends up becoming this iconic character. Standard fantasy stuff, nothing remarkable nor insulting here.

To end my text, completionists beware. This game has a bunch of achievements that will make you suffer. It took me 50 hours of replays and repeating deaths to unlock everything. Get ready for a challenge indeed. And if you simply want to play a game of this particular genre, keep in mind the problems I listed here.

117404723.review:
TLDR: Would recommend on sale when it's like $8. Absolutely not for $30.

I knew nothing of Castlevania. I bought because I thought it would be some kind of hack and slash similar to God of War/Dante's Inferno style combat with vampires. I didn't get that at all.

The combat itself is unfortunately the biggest downfall. In GoW/DI, you can hitstun and juggle enemies waaay more smoothly and better, allowing for those big meaty combo ending finishers that just feel good. In this game, you can be knocked out of the air by ground attacks and there's no juggling/hit stunning enemies for any big ending combos. You're always getting interrupted, and enemy telegraphs are NOT very good. Some are, most are not especially with lighting/distance. It's not a matter of just "get good" I beat the game on the second hardest which most don't even finish it, its just not very fun. Boss telegraphs are very good. Area attacks are basically completely useless. You'd think you'd have some invulnerability during magic use but nope. Just everything about the combat is designed so weirdly and not in a good way either.

The quick time events could have been so much more entertaining and engaging.. but they decided to simplify it to any button press and it's super boring. Glowing finishers could've been a million times better.

The story is sooo boring for about the first 3 hours. The pacing is REALLY bad, but it was enough to keep me going for the rest of it because I enjoy hack and slash combat even though this one was a bit bad.

Things this game absolutely nails: platforming, soundtrack, visuals, enemy variety and bosses. The puzzles are actually fun and engaging, some even challenging. Visually appealing and voice acting and the bosses are THE most fun parts of the game. Enemy variety is actually huge and that is awesome. Platforming is very creative, sometimes boring but I didn't mind those sections at all. I minded the boring combat more than the platforming and climbing. The soundtrack, some songs, are excellent. Some are really annoying, sadly.

It's an absolute shame they didn't expand upon the things that made GoW/DI good, this could have been an incredible experience. Hopefully they learned their lessons and put them into the Lords of Shadow 2 which I'm about to go through.

The best moments in the game by far were the bosses. Getting through the first 3 to 4 chapters was so unbelievably boring I'm surprised I even made it through. 

Would recommend on sale when it's like $8. Absolutely not for $30.

I remember liking this game when I first played it many years ago. Oh man, it did not age well at all..
I mean, it was probably pretty good (or at least decent) when it was released. As of current day almost any other game with similar gameplay does its job better.
-  Fixed camera sucks, making already pretty awkward platforming levels a nightmare.
- Most (~80%) of the skills you can buy are useless.
- Overall battle system is not thought through: dodging works really bad, hit areas of enemy attacks are stupid, blockable and unblockable attacks are almost indistinguishable.
- Replayability is frustrating because of tons of small cut-scenes you cannot skip. Even scenes you can skip are still annoying because of weird windows-style skipping mechanics (are you ABSOLUTELY sure you want to skip it?).
- Bunch of raw and dumb mechanics you see only once or twice per walkthrough.

If you are like me, have warm memories about this game and want to play it out of nostalgia - DON'T. Let it be a good memory rather than disappointment.

It's fun. 114020714.review:
An entertaining side story in the Castlevania setting (similar to Rogue One in the Star Wars universe). The controls are good and responsive on an Xbox controller, and the game runs well even on older hardware. The visuals are excellent for it's age. The story and voice acting are very good.

AMD GPUs can experience environment mesh anomalies which can result in odd texture shards obscuring the action or missing backgrounds but Nvidia GPUs seem unaffected.

The game play is very reminiscent of God of War or Darksiders but not as complex. If you don't expect it to be a classic Castlevania such as Symphony of the Night you will have fun. 3D Castlevanias usually have suffered from awkward game play but this one is quite playable if somewhat simplified and derivative.

113987267.review:
Don't listen to the "NOT CASTLEVANIA" idiots. If you're familiar with series lore you'll enjoy how they play with it in this reboot. It goes for a western fantasy aesthetic but the original Vanias until Rondo of Blood had that same aesthetic, if anything they brought the series back to it's routes. 
If you're not familiar with Castlevania you'll get a fantastic action game with satisfying risk-reward combat, tough enemies, beautiful graphics, heavy audio, and really expansive lore. It's one of the best games of the 7th gen and this PC version is the definitive way to play. Extremely stable, fixes issues caused by the framerate on consoles. Only ran into issues when streaming to Discord (as an application, sharing the screen it's on doesn't seem to effect anything).

112195379.review:
I played this during my childhood and loved it. Playing it now, it is still highly enjoyable but has many flaws to it. I will provide a sentence on everything I think you will notice in the game.

- Controls: When on the ground they are smooth and responsive, up in the air though the game will decide what happens. Also why is sprint clicking the joy stick up twice, annoying!
 Combat: It's a good hack and slash, nothing special. Horrendous air combat system though. 
- Graphics: They still hold up pretty well for a 2013 game especially the scenery (for example the long shot of castles)
- Story: It's pretty basic, bad guys want to destroy Earth/Heaven, go kill them, be saved, be betrayed, etc etc.
- Music: Wow, I forgot how good the music is, especially near the beginning of the game. 
- Puzzles/Platforming: There is a LOT, they are tedious. Puzzles don't add much to the game but the platforming does, but it can be hard to know where to go and the camera angles are horrible. 
- Replayability: There's a good amount, you only unlock paladin difficulty after completing the game once, there are tons of collectables and trials after each level is completed. 

Overall, it is a fun game, it does have a few problems, but if you're able to overcome them, you will enjoy this game.

112044447.review:
Es más un reboot que reinterpreta radicalmente la saga que un juego de la linea temporal de Castlevania, y adopta un estilo a lo God of War o Dante's Inferno que se aleja totalmente del metroidvania clásico pero aun así es bastante digno de su nombre.

El juego tiene sus años y se quedó algo desfasado en lo técnico, pero es lógico tras dos generaciones. Olvidándome de eso, la historia está bien escrita y consigue enganchar, el protagonista presenta una evolución palpable, y tras algunos giros finales de los acontecimientos la trama se cierra de forma coherente. En ese sentido es muy disfrutable.

No obstante, como digo se le notan los años en ciertas cosas, lo que no quiere decir que haya envejecido mal, posee la jugabilidad clásica de cualquier Hack 'N' Slash, además de algunos puzzles y secciones de plataformas que le dan variedad, vamos el conjunto ha llegado bien a dia de hoy y se deja jugar bien, pero por ejemplo la cámara fija es un dolor de huevos constante y hoy en dia se hace dificil ver algo así.

De todos modos el diseño artístico y la música compensan bien la balanza, algunos temas, escenarios y jefes tienen un trabajazo. Algunas batallas contra ciertos jefes también recuerdan inevitablemente a Shadow of the Colossus.

En definitiva, que todo funcione y sea disfrutable más de una década después ya dice mucho a favor del juego.

110812726.review:
I completed this this game. But not because it is fun, but because it was an important birthday present. And the path to do so was a very annoying one, which I can not recommend anyone else to struggle through:

Cons:
-Lack of monster variety:
Castlevania was always known for the plathora of different monsters and creatures. But here you get werewolves, small werevolves, big werevolves, werevolve-mounts and werevolves riding other werevolves. And this is the entire first chapter. Later there are a few more monsters, but do not expect anything even close to a typical Castlevania-feeling.
-Extremely linear gameplay:
Almost the entire game you have one single path that you can walk. one single way to climb a wall, one single direction to take. And if something actually changes at the same location and the path is blocked then once again you get only one single solution thrown at you. There are a few exceptions in terms of revisiting places, but the overal gameplay is a single string that you follow without valuing explorations. The only revisiting means that the game gives you are single sideweapon upgrade chests that require very specific later abilities. Do not expect any new pathes though: it is just a later ability unlocking a single room in an earlier level.
-Level 2 uses a riding mechanic that is NEVER used again:
Sweep Y to attack enemy riders, slash X to attack enemies mounts hold a combination of buttons in the correct moment to dodge rams. And then throw everything out of the window after doing so, since this mechanic does absolutelly never appear again in the entire game. Don't bother even learning...
-Your first Sub weapon, the knife, is the only one that can be upgraded with an additional ability:
You get a total of 4 subweapons, where the knife is the one you get at the very first level. It can instantly be upgraded with a holding technique, allowing you to throw 5 at once. Is this a preview of all the other subweapons that you can upgrade and master? No, this is the very only one. They didn't bother about anything else. They just want to give the impression.
-The last 2 chapters use layout scetches for animated scenes:
The last 2 chapters didn't even bother using cinematics and went with the scatches instead of having actually proper cutscenes.
-Corpses of the same order are scattered everywhere, even if it doesn't make sense:
So you are on a mission from the order. Of course you are not the only one. But there are even members' corpses at places where they could not have physically reached! Like one for example is bayond a monster-infested lake, that requires water-walking, behind a few obstrure mechanism and the note is clearly telling that he was around far after the great evil took over the place. Other are bayond places that took the main character a great sacrifice to get past. And bayond this are a huge amount of order corpses that appear to could have easily passed this without needing any strength at al.
-Very disconnecting character lore:
In the first chapter you have internal dialogue scenes, dreams and get to learn about the character's reasoning at that moment. This continues at some occasions in chapter 2, but afterwards is just dropped. Almost the entire story is told by a 3rd person assuming the main character's reasoning and thoughts. Do we see that reasoning actually anywhere reflected at all after chapter 2? Nope. If you have a main character struggle with evil feelings, then add it in a cutscene. If he is sleep-deprived, then let him make a comment about it or something. But the main char doesnt look any different in chapter 12 than in chapter 3! And you wont get anything aside some third-party comments or some cringe order notes about that corpse itself that can assume anything about the main char that you play.
-Horrible camera:
This is a 3D game. A 3D game with objects and scenery all around you. Does the game actually allow you to have a look around? No. Aside from cinematics ofc. In fact, the right stick on the controller is completelly useless aside from that press-in-button (R3) in order to collect shadow energy. And often enough you can dies or miss things because you can't look around. It would greatly help emersion, if you can actually look at the scenery that visibly had a lot of efford put into... And during fights you really better hope that the camera is where you need it to be or you get sniped by some offscreen attacks, which becomes exspecially annoying if that offscreen attack comes from the last boss of the game.
-Literally each single riddle gives you the solution in corpse-form:
It even states ,,show solution". But most of the ,riddles" are these things that you are doing right now anyways. But just in case, you get that solution, if you did not think about continue going a straight path further.
-Too many arrows point at the ,,surprise" at the 3rd last chapter:
By the time you get there, it is not really a surprise anymore. But hey, your character is at least very surprised. Luckily it isn't something that you as player knew since chapter 2 or anything :P (sarcasm)
-Deleting your existing save stat is not supported by the game:
If you want to start over from scratch, the game does not allow you. Everything runs on a single save stat and while you may replay a level, you can not fully restart from zero. Even deleting your save files on pc will just leave them undone by steam's cloud function. In order to really start over, you have to not only delete your files on your pc, you also have to go into offline mode and finish the first level to bypass steam's restoration whenever it goes online again. This is not a function that should require such a tedious workaround! Even Castlevania-games for Gameboy from before 2000 have the function to start over, copy and paste save stats!
-You can never deactivate a learned combo or ability:
This game only relies on combos and a series of button inputs. While I am not a fan of that, others may like it. However, the issue here is that you can not disable or deactivate a certain ability. So for example, there is one move where you have to press X in the air, then hold down X while still in the air. Another move needs you to hold down X as first option while in the air. So both moves need an X-input and at the moment you learned a move, it will always perform the wrong move if you accidentally held down X for the wrong amount of time. In this case you are better off, just not have learned that skill in first place, if you do not want to use this move. But since the game does not support multiple save stats, you would need to either work around by messing with steam's cloud service or need to memorize a full list of things of what not to press in the heat of a fight.
-Many moves take too much time to execute:
This is a game with an active combat and stuff does not wait for you to finish a combo; they just attack and interrupt you. While it is nice to have some strong moves at your disposal, these are almost never used, if they take over 4 seconds to be executed. 4 whole seconds where an enemy that is beeing attacked is not allowed to actually decide to punch you for doing so.

This game has some pros, too though:
-Beautiful graphics:
Scenery looks nice, water reflections in the first scene are dope and each single level has a lot of details and graphical planning flown into it. It is just a shame that you can't zoom in or move the camera around on your own.
-Hidden stuff:
It may only be another order's corpse in most cases, but these appear everywhere. And a lot of them carry stones for increasing your health or MP. So exploring a bit to the left or right to find more corpses is worth a look. There are no alternate routes though.
-Chess-like minniegame:
At a certain point, you get to unlock a chess-like board game in the main menue.
-2nd playable character
Even only in 2nd last chapter...

Ultimatelly, this game is only using the ,,Castlevania" franchise...

110677573.review:
A trilogy starting out strong. This is the first game in what would become a trilogy in the well established Castlevania series. This game had quite the hatebase when it came out due to it being such a huge departure from the previous entries in the series. As a fan of the old castlevanias, I still love this attempt at a different take on the series. 

Lords of Shadow stars Gabriel Belmont, a monster hunter and member of the brotherhood. The brotherhood's sole purpose is to hunt the monsters of the land and keep the people of the world safe. It's a time of death and darkness, and the world is looking grim. We follow Gabriel on his mission from the brotherhood to find out what is causing all this stuff and sort it out. This mostly boils down to finding the three titular Lords of Shadow and slaying them for the good of the human race. The story telling here is pretty good. It's a mix of in game cut-scenes, a bit of CGI, and most of it being done in talks between characters during game-play. This story heavy approach to Castlevania is pretty new to the series and honestly I think it paid off well. The story isn't the absolute best thing in the world here, but It's definitely no slouch either.

Mercury Steam's take on God of War, with a little Uncharted and Shadow of the Colossus thrown in for good measure. Basically, the game consists of you fighting monsters, running around the levels figuring out how to progress through the games' many puzzles, and somewhere in-between all this you will have some uncharted-esque climbing sections in it. The combat, while a tad simplistic, had enough variety and flare to it to keep me interested and engaged the whole way through the game. As you progress in the game you acquire new moves, such as a parry system, and also as you battle you earn combat experience, which allows you to buy new combos and upgrade existing ones. This helps greatly in keeping the game fresh and having you eager to check out the new moves you just unlocked. The puzzles in this game are a mixed bag though. Some of them are pretty good. Good meaning you need to use at least a portion of your brain to figure out the solution. Some of them are incredibly simple and barely could be called Puzzles though. One example of this is lighting up plaques with your magic. You basically just touch the plaques and it's a simple case of trial and error to figure out what color goes where. Thankfully though i'd say this type of puzzle is easily in the minority here.

Now, let's talk about the music in this game. The tracks in this game are absolutely beautiful and possibly carry some parts of the game on it's back. while playing this title there were quite a few times where I just stopped and admired the music. Every single area of this game has the perfect music choice to fit it. The emotional impact these more somber songs are trying to convey gets through clearly. and bumps the game quality up quite a bit. Hats off to Óscar Araujo for his work on this game. He definitely deserves more praise, and more gigs.

The graphics and art style of this game are stunning as well. As we follow Gabriel on his quest we see vibrant forests, murky bogs, and gothic architecture that would make any fan of the aesthetic happy. The art style they went for works so well for the tone of the game, and anything more cartoony would have really hampered the feeling they were going for with this game. Just like the music, there were quite a few moments where I would stop and just take in the scenery in front of me. It's a testament to their developers that they were able to pull of such graphics with the hardware of the time.

In summary, this is a great game that has been maligned for over a decade now by people who wrote it off at first glance and never gave it a fair shake. If anything in this review sounds good to you, or you have seen stuff covering this game and think it looks cool, try it out. You might just walk away thinking it's a hidden gem like me.

This game is quite old when I write this review. Neithertheless the graphics are still awesome. Must have been state of the art back those days. I rated the graphics fair based on this fact.

The strong points:
* a timeless and detailed mystic setting
* very creative small plots and a wide variety of sceneries
* a good mix between logic puzzles and battles
* good fighting system
* cool bossfights
* atmospheric soundtrack
* for a 9 year old game still good graphics

The weak points:
* game gives you sometimes no clues for puzzles
* no proper fight tutorial
* aerial control (especially with the wings) could be better
* no auto-refill of health and mana after a level ends (you need to farm it before boss fights)
* Paladin difficulty is very challenging, for completionists a hard nut to crack

Konami did a very good job on this one. Usually I prefer the old retro style Castlevanias from the SNES times more, but this one is really awesome, I must admit. See forward to the sequel, which leads on the story.

108900490.review: If you are a fan of the Castlevania series, then this is simply a must-play game. The storytelling and realizations of the classic Castlevania enemies are amazing in terms of their visual detail and animations. The combat can become tedious, however. The whip design and magic abilities are obviously God of War inspired, which isn't a bad thing in itself, but the mechanics here are overly complex and not introduced the player in an intuitive way, so you'll end up purchasing moves that you may use once and forget, or may just not realize you have available, given Gabriel can perform so many variations of his basic combos. Discovering strategies to beat certain enemies is at times fun, but most of the time you're just learning by failure since enemy weak points aren't at all obvious. The camera is another problem - the fixed perspective means you'll often miss paths of exploration, or required jumps from forced camera angles make them needlessly difficult. If you can overlook these annoyances, you'll have a great time with the game. The story, music, and atmosphere really shine. It's too bad the design isn't up to par with the rest of  high quality bar.

ASPECTOS TÉCNICOS: Comenzamos con unos gráficos que para ser de 2014 están más que geniales y la optimización es excelente y no he tenido ningún tipo de problemas.
JUGABILIDAD: Los controles son extremadamente cómodos tanto como para hacer combos como para esquivar, domar, etc, etc.

103976998.review:
[h1]This Game is Not Fun[/h1]

That is really the only way to summarize it. Lords of Shadow introduces absolutely nothing new, interesting, or innovative to the genre, but rather borrows sloppily from its predecessors while trying to shoehorn in elements from other genres.

[h1]Combat is Not Fun[/h1]

A tell sign of bland combat is a game introducing new mechanics at every turn. The developers acknowledge the stale combat by introducing new powers and abilities that would be better left streamlined. By the end of chapter 3, which takes somewhere around 5 hours, you have:
-Main weapon
-Light Magic
-Shadow Magic
-Daggers
-Fairies
-Dark Crystal
-Gauntlet
-Boots

This sounds great, but none of these flow together in a way you would expect or want from a character action game. Aside from the [i]very[/i] odd button mapping choices (like not having a dedicated dodge button, or LT being extremely over mapped), using anything other than your main weapon in combat is being ineffective and impractical. Need to switch secondary weapons? You need to take your thumb off of the left stick, immobilizing yourself, to use the D-pad to switch. You will be fighting bad controls and bad design just as much as you will be monsters. It sucks.

Speaking of monsters, expect nothing really new or interesting here either. Enemies come in the form of small, medium and large, with the only difference being how many hits it will take to kill then. Doesn't matter if they're werewolves, goblins, trolls, vampires - they are all the same. It is boring from the very start. Boss battles range from bigger enemies to rip-offs of Shadow of the Colossus, the ladder of which will test only your patience.

[h1]The Platforming is Bad[/h1]

The other side of this game is platforming. In general, it's extremely unresponsive. Gabriel will fail to grab ledges for no reason. The rules of using the whip to navigate change on a case-by-base basis. Sometimes you need to release from swinging, sometimes it's automatic. Sometimes you need to Press A/X to jump down, sometimes you don't. When you can't reliably predict how your character will behave in ostensibly the same situation, then platforming becomes a chore. It's just not fun. 

Paths will also branch and be sealed off, making exploration more of an anxiety inducing trip than any amount of fun. You can return to any level at any time, but I never found myself wanting to revisit any level. It felt like more of an opportunity for punishment rather than to get something I might have missed.

[h1]Story is Bad[/h1]

Rather than letting the story unfold throughout the game, Patrick Stewart gives you a narrative between each level. You can find scrolls from fallen knights that tell you things you already know. They don't add anything to the story or atmosphere. Characters just come in and out, or die having never been developed, and we are somehow supposed to give a shit. Having a famous actor reading lines doesn't fix a bad narrative.

[h1]Overall[/h1]

Game is bad. Play anything else. Music is okay. Environments look nice. But those are the only nice things I can say about this game.

102440964.review:
Never played a Castlevania before and thought about picking both this one and Lord of shadow 2 in a deep sale and actually had some mindless fun in the first few hours. After those flew by, the reality slowly started to sink in and regrettably, I couldn't just ignore the extensive amount of problems that the game's had anymore, so here we are.

Cons
- Uninspired characters
- Cringeworthy/mediocre or overly dramatic voiceacting
- Okay to sometimes fun combat, depending on the enemy you are fighting against
- Music is also okay, nothing to brag about
- Boss battles are boring and very similar all around
- Ridiculous difficulty spikes that seemed to come outta nowhere
- Story is poorly written with lots of plot conviniences and cheese C-tier movie developments
- Terrible camera angles that you cannot control whatsoever
- A huge amount of mostly uninteresting (with some exceptions) puzzles that end up disrupting the already slow pace of the story
- Chupacabras (Need I say more?) - You will get it once you play the game.
- Some boss battles dragged on and were not fun after a while
- Maybe it's just me, but Im bothered by the fact that the protagonist can defeat all manner or gods and whatnot like carving butter with seemingly no explanation besides "destiny" or "chosen".

Pros
- Nice level design
- Lovely artstyle and vibe
- some interesting story elements sprinkled here and there that barely keep you going (even though it mostly is just porly written)
- Some replayability in order to collect everything from previous levels
- Cool boss designs

Overall, this game borrows a lot of things from other ones and just makes them boring and way too vanilla. 
If you really are in the mood for these types of games, just play the god of war games and you will feel much better about yourself. This games never actually gets going in the story department either... Sure there is a twist at the end but ends up being overshadowed by some dumb plot decisions. 
Lastly, It just feels that nothing has weight, even when they tried, which left me feeling quite uninterested with most of everything by the end.

Final ratings:

Story: 5/10
characters: 4/10
Sound: 6.5/10
Graphics/visual style: 7/10
gameplay: 6.5/10
World: 7

102427927.review:
There are some definite things to like about this game, but at a little under 6 hours in...I just couldn't take it anymore.
The idea sounds great: A 'God of War'-esque game in the Castlevania universe, but:
The camera is very rough, as many point out -- but not horrible. 
The combat...very repetitive, including the enemies themselves. Since so much of the game is 'this', that's a tough pill to swallow.
The controls are, well -- "meh". Not good, but not bad. The camera makes them feel worse than they are. You WILL die often for your character doing things you aren't intending him to do, though. 
The boss fights? Pretty horrible...this was one of the last straws for me before checking out. 
For all of this, I just couldn't continue. 

I *DID*, however, skim through a play-through on YouTube -- and it did bum me out that the core mechanics weren't "there" a bit more for me, as there were some great sights and set pieces to experience. 
That being said...having viewed it: I'm glad I didn't continue. Gameplay-wise, my opinion wasn't going to change.  

I WILL happily say though: the art direction is wonderful, and the settings in-line with my preferences. The music is great as well (though for me not nearly as good as "classic Castlevania" games). 

I got this on sale at around $7.50, and considering I got almost 6 hours of entertainment based on where I called it quits: I'm happy enough with my purchase. I don't think I'd recommend it to others though, as I didn't feel enough incentive to even continue playing...so hence the thumbs-down (since it's only one or the other).

102409919.review:
Cuando pensamos en un juego que se queda marcado en tu retina, nadie votaría por Castlevania: LOTS.
Sin embargo, Mercury Steam dio un auténtico puñetazo sobre la mesa en 2013 dándonos el mejor Castlevania de la saga, sí es una osadía, sobre todo teniendo omnipresente el Super Castlevania IV de Super Nes, pero este juego es el culmen de un trabajo que con el paso de los años va a hacer que se convierta en un juego de culto, si es que no lo es ya.
Finales de 2021 y lo he vuelto a jugar por segunda vez, y ha sido en esta segunda ocasión cuando me he dado cuenta de la magnificencia de su historia, sin palabras, de la epicidad de cada canción de la banda sonora, para mí, la mejor banda sonora que se ha escuchado jamás en un videojuego.
Castlevania: LOTS, es pasión por la música, pasión por la historia, pasión por el narrador, Zobek, el cual tiene que decir muchas cosas durante el juego, pasión por el hecho de reunir pergaminos situados en cadáveres de antiguos caballeros caídos que han intentado acabar la aventura que empieza nuestro Gabriel Belmont y que gracias a estos pergaminos junto a la ayuda del narrador te vas dando cuenta de que Gabriel, poco a poco y sin darse cuenta, va cambiando la luz por oscuridad. Pasión, también, por un último nivel digno de pasar a la historia como uno de los niveles más espectaculares, más bonitos y más épicos que se hayan creado para un videojuego. Es en este nivel, cuando al derrotar al jefe final, el penúltimo del juego, cuando la tecla F11 para capturar pantalla te otorgará una postal digna de quedarse para siempre en tu retina como si fuera una obra maestra a la que muy pocos desarrolladores con sus respectivos videojuegos te pueden dar.
Yo siempre he dicho que para mí, el mejor juego de la historia, es Dragon Age Origins, pero después de volver a jugar a este Castlevania, parándome a buscar y rebuscar todas las gemas, tanto luminosas como oscuras, a buscar y rebuscar todos los pergaminos en los cadáveres de antiguos caballeros de nuestra misma Orden, a buscar retos para recibir gemas luminosas y oscuras para cogerme las magias más brutales que te ofrece este título, a buscar dentro de mi esa 'serenidad interior' que la música te impide encontrarla debido a la epicidad de todas sus notas, de todas sus canciones, de todos sus matices....
Hoy, 7 de noviembre del año 2021, escribo y doy por concluido este análisis exponiendo que Castlevania: LOTS, ha sido, es y será, una obra maestra del videojuego. 
Y si este tipo de aventuras no es tu género favorito, cómpralo y date el capricho de escuchar una banda sonora que no tiene nada que envidiar a las partituras que Hans Zimmer, entre otros, se sacan de su cabeza para las películas de la gran pantalla.
Vale la pena jugar esta joya sin corona, esta joya apartada por la prensa y desconocida por los jugadores, única y exclusivamente, por la banda sonora, aunque como he expuesto antes, esta obra magna de Mercury Steam, tiene más, mucho más. 
Déjate seducir por Marie, por Zobek y por el incomprendido y confundido Gabriel. 
Déjate seducir por las tinieblas que emergen de la luz de un amor perdido.

Nos leemos cuando haya jugado Castlevania: Mirror of Fate.
Adios!

101532884.review:
Now I have beaten the DLC, I can confidently say that this game really is a tragedy. The music is amazing... as ambient tracks in Skyrim. It constantly gives off the feeling that they are not created with the scene in mind. The tracks are beautifully composed, but they lack any motif that reinforce the atmosphere of the levels players are in. Forest, bog, vampire castle, hell all play thematically indistinguishiable music which made those levels more generic. 
The combat is solid at its core but mauled by many, many of this game's design shortcomings. The lack of lock on is not an issue thanks to the wide range of Gaberial's whip and easiness of telling where the enemies are due to the fixed camera perspective which always stays high above the battlefield during combat, but some enemies are absolutely painful to deal with. For example, the skeleton warriors give me immesurable dread on any difficulties above Warrior when they come in hordes. They are in white (obviously) and love to spam unblockable attacks whether they are nearby or across the battlefield. Unfortunately, when they stay close to each other, it's very likely that the enemy in the foreground to the camera will obscure their buddies behind them. So, when the latter is about to use unblockable attacks, it's really hard to see their white flashes(also because they are white) and react. Sure, there is also an audio cue, but a lot of times they charge unblockable at the same time, so who knows which one is making the audio cue!
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Once again I wish there is an indifference option in Steam review. This game has amazing artistry and production put into it but just feels off when playing it, as if it is a beta build that has content ready but haven't sort out the balancing and fine tuning. Sometimes it's a perfectly enjoyable beat em up, and the next moment you are faced with multiple enemies with long health bar and barely telegraphed unblockable attacks. Sometimes it's a handholding to a fault platformer, and the next moment you go from scratching to banging your head trying to figure out where to go next without looking up a guide.

This game's Steam achievement is very telling: more than 50% of players who own the game beat the first chapter. But only 30% of people beat the next chapter, and with each subsequent chapter we see a roughly 2% completion rate drop off. Clearly the game frustrates even those that wish to see it to the end like I do.
