101507960.review:
This is kind of a weird one, I want to leave more of a mixed review than anything but Steam doesn't allow it. I'm going to give it a thumbs up with a warning. I did enjoy most of it more than I hated it so it's more neutral, leaning slightly to positive. Let me start with the base game which is the first 12 chapters. The gameplay is pretty solid. It's fun and satisfying taking on either single large enemies or groups of smaller enemies. The controls feel a bit iffy when jumping but when you're on the ground, it's smooth and responsive. The combat is absolutely where the game shines. If the game was more of a hack and slash game, I would give it more praise but there are too many weird problems this game had that I feel like was just poor decision making.

First and foremost, this game has one of the worst camera systems I've seen in a game. As a result, platforming can become a complete mess. In fact, in addition to awkward cameras, the jumping mechanics are just plain bad. You'll get frustrated in areas with no enemies far more often than areas with enemies because you'll constantly find yourself having to reset some areas due to bad controls. Furthermore, sometimes the checkpoints in those areas are frustratingly bad. You can take your time and carefully work your way through a weird platforming area just to miss a jump late in the sequence due to an awkwardly timed camera change only to be reset back to the beginning of the platforming section. There are also a good amount of puzzles in the game. I didn't think they were bad but they weren't particularly great either. They mostly just felt out of place to be honest.

There are also three bosses for some reason that have you constantly climbing them and it's more of a platforming boss than an action boss. They just felt really tedious as you figure out the route to take and weren't very fun. The standard bosses, which there are a lot more of, are a lot more fun and the kind of action you expect from the game. Other than the three awkward platforming bosses, I thought all the bosses were a lot of fun.

The biggest problem with the Ultimate Edition though is the DLC. The DLC in this game is quite possibly the worst DLC I've ever seen in a game. There are two chapters. The first chapter is almost all awkward platforming and puzzle solving. It just felt more like a chore. The second chapter in the DLC is basically one big boss fight and it's probably the most frustrating, unfair boss I've ever encountered in any game. You'll fight it twice. The first fight is fine and pretty fun. The issue is the second fight. The boss' hit box is high up so you have to jump to hit him. The problem with that is there's no sense of height at all. Sometimes you'll jump and attack too high or too low and you won't know why because the camera gets really awkward in tight. It's only an issue in the last boss of the DLC, not any of the other bosses. You have to get in tight to attack it, you have to be in the air, and the controls in the air are really awkward, it's just a recipe for disaster. You'll often find yourself where you stop attacking but the game wants to continue your mid air combo and even though you stopped attacking a whole second ago, it keeps going and you can't get away. It has a lot of AoE attacks too so you have to be able to get away quickly.

The story overall is really enjoyable. I thought it was a lot of fun all the way through. The story for the DLC was pretty interesting too but for some reason they went away from in game cutscenes to the cutscenes being drawings and it felt really half-assed.

Overall, if you're interested in a hack and slash game or like the Castlevania game, I would say give it a go for the base game and skip the DLC entirely. Considering the age of the game, I would also recommend waiting for a sale. Give it a shot and see how you like the camera. The camera isn't too bad for most of the combat but it gets really frustrating for the platforming which is a fairly large portion of the game. If you don't like the camera, refund it and don't look back because it's not going to get any better. If you're fine with it and enjoy the combat, play through the base game and enjoy the combat/story. Again, just make sure to skip what is probably the worst DLC I've played.

101368590.review: This is a strange game. I'd recommend it, but with several pretty big caveats. If you're coming to this as a Castlevania fan, I think you need to temper your expectations of what you'll find here. This is very much a character action game in the vein (ha!) of the PS2/PS3 God of War games, with a setting that is sometimes reminiscent of the classic Castlevanias, but more often recalls the Lord of the Rings movies or Guillermo del Toro's Pan's Labyrinth. This isn't bad at all, it's just different! In terms of story, the setup is really good and the production values are great (it still looks beautiful in 2021, and the voice actors are really solid), but it's in service of a pretty weak narrative that struggles mightily to justify it's connection to the Castlevania series and never quite gets there. That said? It's fun to play from start to finish, with a very fleshed-out combat system, interesting levels with lots of secrets to find, and a load of one-off gimmicks and puzzles throughout its varied environments that keep things from ever feeling stale and repetitive. It tries a ton of different things, and even though not all of them work, it's always exciting to start a new level not entirely sure what you're going to get. Once again, it struggles in it's final stages to bring everything together into a really satisfying whole and ends up feeling like less than the sum of it's parts as a result, but those parts are frequently very well-made. Buy it on sale maybe? I think you'll enjoy it as long as you don't get swept up in the promise of what it could be, and instead just appreciate what's there.

101301545.review:
Really fun hack and slash, amazing score (one of the best I've heard), interesting story, nice graphics (for its time), and pretty damn challenging and fun to complete. What I like the most about this game is its art. You can find wonderful illustrations, interesting and beautiful scenarios (of all kind--forests, swamps, magic realms, dark castles, villages, etc.), and Sobek's monologues at the beginning of every level are well written and acted. 
Only downside I can find is that its gameplay, at its esential, is basically a blatant copy of god of war's. It has a combo system though which adds a layer of depth to the gameplay but still, only difference aside from that is that you don't have chaos blades but some sort of strange holy whip-cross instead. 
DLC is actually the best part of the game. Really recommended overall, just try to be open-minded with it specially if you expected some continuity with the original castlevania saga, which this game has none.

100803932.review:
Unfortunately this game suffers from trying to be so many things but fails at reaching it.
- It tries to be like Castlevania, but comes off too "generic gothic" without the charm or charisma of all the other Castlevania games
- It tries to be like God of War and Darksiders but pales in comparison to the gameplay. The QTEs are numerous in quantity and boring in execution.

Excelente juego, lamentablemente se torna aburrido ya para la parte final en cuanto a los Puzzles. La lógica no es tan lógica en el juego, ejemplo: Existen cuerpos que están a lado pero no puedes tomar su item si no te posicionas correctamente frente al cadáver, esto pasa en uno que está a un costado de una alcantarilla por dar un ejemplo. Otro ejemplo de la mala lógica que usaron en la jugabilidad fue la parte del Dragon "Dracolich" (adverencia: spoiler) básicamente se torna aburrido e ilógico el ir subiendo, escalando y trepando de un lado a otro de las costillas del dragón de una forma demasiado específica cuando fácilmente podría irse ido balanceando con el látigo por todo el cuerpo (eso pasa por ser un juego muy Lineal y por eso me gustan más los que son más mundos abiertos o que tienen un poco más de libertad para escoger). Peor aun es que NO  derrotas al dragón como todo mundo esperaría: en una batalla épica. Mas bien se torna algo parecido a escalar una montaña de un lado a otro y repito de una forma No muy lógica : te cuelgas de una de los huesos del dragon que pareciera la pelvis ó sacro, luego tienes que rotar y subir por dicho hueso hasta llegar al tope de la espina del dragón, luego en lugar de ir directo saltando por las vertebras, tienes que hacer un completo rodeo hacia atrás y luego hacia la punta de dichas vértebras luego volver a bajar... ufff ni hablar. Otra ILOGICA de este juego es por ejemplo cuando estás en el Laberinto de Arbustos, resulta que con tanta fuerza y habilidades que tiene Belmont, él no es capaz de destruir un simple seto ó saltarlos, no... tiene que Golpear literalmente una enorme columna de piedras que notoriamente son más fuertes que esos setos, escalar sobre dicha columna y brincar hacia el otro lado. Por cierto, existen BUGS en el juego los cuales no voy a mencionar, son mínimos pero existen y te puedes llevar un pequeño rato rabioso. 
La mayor parte del tiempo estarás Escalando como en Prince of Persia y usando muy pocas veces el látigo a comparación de lo que hubiera sido un juego tradicional de Castlevania donde el Látigo lo usas casi todo el tiempo para escalar y balancearte. En este juego faltó más balanceo con el látigo a la hora de escalar. También recuerda un poco a God of War pero No tanto, de hecho me hubiera gustado que fuera más como God of War porque en GOW tienes más poder, más lucha y más acción. 
En todo lo demás, el juego es una chulada, una belleza, una grandeza, una excelencia ... jajaja!! En serio, me ha encantado, pero hubiera tambíen preferido un poco más de estilo "anime" al que ya estabamos acostumbrados en las series de Castlevania: las chicas como las lolis usualmente se ven mejor en Anime :) soy Otaku Furro awebo! 
Faltaron las Cruces, no hay las clásicas cruces voladoras pero igualmente está bien, se pasa. 
El diseño de personajes es muy bueno pero  algunos personajes no llegan a ser muy "apegables", muy desaprovechados y casi no te encariñas con ellos como es el caso de Marie en mi caso al menos no me gustó mucho, pudo tener la nariz y boca más finas y los ojos más grandes para mi gusto al estilo anime pero bueno... además de ser la esposa de Gabriel y la razón por la cual se desata toda esta batalla (él busca revivirla) realmente creo que hasta podría y debió quedarse mejor con Claudia y que hasta se aventuraron los de Konami al poner una Loli y dos (si contamos con la chica vampira) enamorada de Gabriel, y que pudiera haber fácilmente hecho olvidar su aventura a Gabriel y otra historia nos contaría (Por eso me gustan los juegos con multiples finales alternativos especialmente si se trata por nuestras acciones que tomemos pero este no es el caso, este juego es super lineal). 
El diseño de los entornos son muy buenos y hermosos, pero flaquea en el desarrollo de niveles sobre todo en los mapas finales y por ser extremadamente lineal,  y la perspectiva de la cámara puede que no sepas a donde ir en el mapa del Desierto. 
Los Puzzles son muy buenos, te hacen pensar pero en algunos puzzles, especialmente otra vez en los finales son tremendamente difíciles y hasta frustrantes y dejan de ser divertidos por ejemplo: si no eres ASTROLOGO tendrás que aprender porque te pide una fecha mediante astrología y si no lo haces será imposible pasar. 
Básicamente CLOS no es un hack and  slash sino más bien un PUZZLEVANIA, con una excelente historia.
La Historia repito, es Excelente, aunque creo que es alterna a la verdadera saga de Castlevania aunque tiene personajes de la misma saga.
Los primeros 10 niveles puedo decir que son muy buenos pero para el final empieza a fallar un poco la diversión por lo antes mencionado.
Como fuera, es un muy buen juego y lo recomiendo.

100586413.review:
Let's face it - if you're at a point in your life where you're reading a review (this review) for an 11 year old action adventure game, Lords of Shadow (LoS) is probably for you.  Is it the best game ever? No.  Is it just 'alright' enough to satisfy the distraction you need from the monotonous rut of your (currently) pointless existence? Yeah, sure. Maybe.

Look, I'm not a therapist or anything like that, but chances are, you're a lot like me.  36 years old.  A couple of kids.  A job.  Responsibilities and shit.  You don't have time (or energy) to be the first to download some latest AAA bullshit.  We wait for the sale.  We wait for the other trail-blazers to show us the way.  And sometimes, we go looking for an older experience that may have been cool at the time but didn't quite rise to level of our awareness because...you know, we had better shit to do back then.  That, and it's just the sort of distraction that we can pursue in finite increments.  A few minutes after bedtime routine.  Maybe a half hour while the kids are at gymnastics.  You get it.

Enter LoS.  A weird hybrid of a game that screams late 2000s QT cheese, with puzzles you can (sometimes) skip.  It's like God-of-War knocked up Uncharted, and the kid turned goth.  Like the youngest kid in class, you're catching LoS right around the time of puberty.  Like, totally late to the party and approaching it like an amateur.  That's good ole' lovable LoS.

If you do buy this, don't fret or give up (or get mad).  LoS really doesn't get going until chapter 3-ish, right around the time you get the nekid-titty monster weapon.  Personally, I flexed the difficulty frequently.  Stuck on a weird, nonsensical puzzle?  Give it a google - there was always an answer.

If you're the sort of person that likes to complete everything, on hardest difficulty, with no help...yeah, again, that's probably not you if you're reading this... so, yeah. I forgot my train of thought.  If you are still with me, then you're trending psychopath.  

Pros:
- Sweet character art
- Sir Patrick Stewart narrates
- Genuinely interesting combat
- Fun take on Castlevania story, lore
- Not overly complicated
- Runs wicked fast on modern rigs

Cons:
- Sir Patrick Stewart narrates (yeah its cool they got him and all, which was high production value circa 2010, but it's these weird chapter interludes.  It's just...weird.  Is the character 'Zobek' watching Gabriel in the woods, like some peeping Tom? Play to find out!)
- Oddly misplaced sound effects - I think I read somewhere they hired a homeless guy off the street to rattle aluminum cans, an old egg-beater and bar chimes.  Lots of bar chime action going on here guys.
- Some puzzles totally interrupt the flow.  Most of these you can skip though and you really don't need the experience.  Except for the music box...*shudders*
- Inconsistent jumping & climbing rules - just remember, jumping and climbing is some combination of all the buttons...

TLDR Conclusion - thumbs up, worth a few bucks.  Will it change your life?  No.

100536518.review:
The one positive thing about this game is that the trailer is super well done. Upon watching the trailer, there were so many raving reviews from critics saying that this was a potential GoTY candidate and best game on the PS3, extc. The trailer sold me on the game, so I ended up purchasing it. 

What a letdown.  The controls are clunky and the fixed camera angle is annoying which makes it very hard to navigate. There's a character in the game called a chupacabra that steals your items almost every level, and then you have to run around playing hide and seek with them until you find them in order to get your items back. It totally breaks the flow of the gameplay and is extremely irritating. 

However, worst of all is the lazy storytelling. Ever heard of the term "show, don't tell"? This game does the exact opposite. During the gameplay, there is no indicator of what's going on through Gabriel's mind. Then after each stage is a brief cutscene where Gabriel speaks in the most monotone voice, speaking very little if at all. There's definitely no significant dialogue which leads to any meaningful exposition. And then as you start the next level, there is a story book sequence where the narrator describes everything that is going on inside Gabriel's mind and somehow these storybook sequences are supposed to resemble character development. It's so utterly lazy and is such a lame excuse for story telling. There's such a disconnect between the actual gameplay versus the narration sequences. This is possibly the worst storytelling I've experienced with a game in a long time.

100529420.review:
So I waited to write this review until after completing both this game and Lords of Shadow 2, as I wanted to be entirely fair to both games in how I felt. Lords of Shadow 1 has some clunkiness that isn't there in its sequel (the overlong puzzle sequences, the lack of real enemy variety, a lot of sections that feel like padding or which were meant to be setpieces, etc.) but the reason I was drawn to the game was the combat. 

I'm not a Castlevania fan so this isn't coming at it from that angle. I'm talking as a fan of games like Devil May Cry 1, 3, 4, and 5, God Hand, Metal Gear Rising (which I played on PS3 when it came out), and other similar titles. Lords of Shadow is an in between of God of War and Devil May Cry, though taking more from the former. The flow of combat revolves around some rather lenient parries, absorbing orbs into one of your two super meters, and is based around the use of area attacks (AOE's with your whip) and direct attacks. The move list variety for what it set out to do is actually pretty large, larger than I expected when going in. 

While I think this game is hurt by sections like the Chupacabra tracking in a lot of missions, or some of the platforming sequences which are reminiscent of the Uncharted games, or the mountable enemies, I think at its core it's a fun game. Play it first especially if you plan on playing Lords of Shadow 2, which I consider to have the more memorable writing and the better combat, or if you like games like Uncharted, God of War, etc. The game is very competently made.

100493512.review:
This is by far the worst experience I've had with the entire Castlevania IP.I like even the bad games on Gameboy but this is just a trash fire. The combat tries way too hard to emulate God Of War but doesn't nail any of the nuance that most hack and slash games need to be even the least bit fun. there are fun ideas here like the new origin for some key figures in the series but the gameplay is just dogshit. Gabriel feels like he's made of rocks glued together wish rotten garbage which ruins the whole flow of combat. Most of the games in this vein are built around speed and reaction times but this one feels more like just a test of how much BS you can put up with before you bite your fingers off to save yourself. The combat is boring and sluggish, the exploration if you truly wish to describe it as such consists of nothing more than very slightly veering off the main path for a seemingly worthless 'upgrade' that will almost never feel needed in combat, and the arenas drag more ass than your average wal-mart shopper.

The display for how long I spent in the game is also inaccurate. I spent nearly 40 hours trying desperately to drag myself to 100% hoping that that might somehow make the combat feel less awful but it truly was an exercise in futility.  I would be hard pressed to recommend this even to the most hardcore of Castlevania fans. You should pretty much only play it if you've given up on life and you're looking for something to push you over the edge.

I just don't think it's aged well.  I was a little surprised to read the praise in old reviews about it.  There's a lot of bad platforming, frustrating fixed camera angles, and way, way too many logic minigames.  The story is just nonsense and I don't think they understand good and evil doesn't mean much without will.  For battles, you can perfect block an enemy, have another hit you and perfect block it, and during the same animation take a ton of damage because an enemy heavied you from off-screen.  Also, a lot of the animations of heavies (which require rolls) and other moves just look too similar to normal ones so you can't make a good decision.  There's just not a lot of strong group AI either so combat can feel frustrating and repetitive.  It's not the worst game (the ending narrative is pretty fun, unlike the rest of the game), I should know as I 100%ed it, but I'd say you'd have to scrape the Character Action Game barrel pretty deep to bother.

Edit: Oh, I'm also not sure but I think the HD remastering might've messed with some of the lighting.  A lot of times I'd be squinting at a screen and going, "What am I supposed to be looking at here?" trying to find the next platform to jump to or whatever.  Or be knocked by a ghoul I couldn't see in the shadows.

I will start by saying that I have never played any of the original Castlevania games, so I went into C:LOS with no expectations. I found it to be a solid 7/10 experience, but without a controller my rating would be lower.

Pros: Great visuals (graphics, art, settings, worlds, etc - all stunning especially for an older game), excellent music and voice acting, and fun combat. Puzzles were both a pro and con for me, some were fun, others were not. Many think the story is just OK, but I personally enjoyed it.

Cons: Game drags for first two chapters (not sure why, but they did for me and seemingly for others too), weird fixed camera angles that take a lot of getting used to if you are not already, and weird default key bindings- definitely use a controller. Even with a controller some maneuvers are weird, but it is much better. Puzzles, see above.

Overall I was very pleased with the game and am immediately moving on to C:LOS2

98950886.review:
Let me buck the controversial meta and lead with, this is the smoothest playing game I've ever played. For that alone you must at least have a look/play at it. 

As for the "god of waring" of this legacy franchise, how could it ever had gone any other way? Having to avoid Devil May Cry's lane, after ironically inventing it. And even after Metroid's numerous successful 3D iterations, how could Castlevania's soul ever be wrestled from being the absolute king of 2D side scrolling? To say any attempt isn't loaded for a huge swath of dissatisfied fans. Same with so many other stories, drowning in cannon, that has to go against the grain to be its own thing. As much as stunning art direction is defacto these days, I'd say this still shines. The corruputing surrealism of Dracula's unnatural power, bordering on baroque wacky-ness, is litest here across the titles iterations, happily maintaining an overall darker tone. 

Its a beautiful game, with a beautiful story. It's Castlevania.

Even this long since release, with Konami's dick stepping business practices (moral and otherwise), will never be on a substantial sale: 20% off MAX past years. Some might say you have a moral obligation to steal it.

This game is.... Well crap I don't even know how to explain how I feel towards this game, but I'll do my best.

Let's start with the graphics. For the time this game looked great. The character models, environments, and monsters all look amazing. (Keep in mind this game is almost ten years old.) This has a "Castlevania" feeling to it as well, meaning spooky locations with werewolves, vampires, and of course bats..(ugh) 

The voice acting. Especially of Patrick Stewart and Robert Carlyle, man I could listen to them both all day. Such a treat. Some of the other dialog seems kind of forced and overall just not very well done. 

The gameplay overall is good. I wouldn't give it a great rating because a lot of it because tedious pretty quickly. Some of the battles last way too long, and it's kind of boring. The boss fights again are hit and miss. I thoroughly enjoyed some of the boss fights, but others I hated with a passion.  

I was very skeptical of a 3d Castlevania game, especially after the games that shall not be named on the Nintendo 64, but this game works very well for the most part.  

Overall this game is entertaining and is worth a playthrough. Being as old as it is though, I wouldn't pay over $20 for it.

Al crecer formamos nuestros propios objetivos que darian forma al propósito de vida pero otros creen que existe algo mayor algo mas allá de la comprensión humana y los invisibles moviéndonos a un camino inevitable que conocemos como nuestro destino nuestro propósito.

La historia se centra en un habilidoso guerrero que fue destinado para un propósito mayor que sin darse cuenta quienes lo acompañaron en vida fueron sus guías para convertirse en una de las figuras mas importantes para su mundo.
El Guerrero
Gabriel Belmont

Muchos fans de la saga llaman a este juego como el inombrable la verdad yo no puedo opinar sobre eso ya que es el primer castlevania que juego y lo analizare como si fuese independiente

[h1]HISTORIA[/h1]
Castlevania Lords of Shadow nos cuenta la historia de Gabriel Belmont un miembro de la Hermandad de la Luz quien se embarca en una cruzada para encontrar al dios Pan el cual dicen que tiene la clave para que los muertos vuelvan de sus tumbas, Gabriel desea desesperadamente encontrarse con él ya que desea traer de vuelta a su esposa de entre los muertos, la esposa de Gabriel; María murió de una manera misteriosa a manos de seres obscuros que desean sumir a la humanidad en una época de obscuridad y alejarla de la gracia y protección de dios, los tiempos en los que le toco vivir a Gabriel son muy obscuros y desoladores y María al parecer tiene la clave para que la humanidad se reconcilie con dios y poder tener una esperanza para el futuro, el viaje para Gabriel es largo desolador y cansado, pero su deseo de volver a ver a su esposa es mayor a los desafíos que le esperan enfrente.
A pesar de no haber jugado ninguna entrega de la saga me pareció excelente y muy interesante  aunque al final el antagonista no me llego a convencer del todo

En tema de combate esta muy bien logrado en un principio, las opciones se limitan  a lo que dan de sí unos pocos movimientos. Una cruz bendecida, una cadena para la que más adelante conseguimos unos dientes de sierra, un guantelete, cristales de poder, hadas del bosque, orbes sanadores y destructores… conforme crece el nivel de los enemigos, también lo hace nuestro repertorio y ¡de qué manera! El control de Gabriel es muy directo, con ataques que duran un suspiro y otros más elaborados. 96719003.review:
[h1]Summary:[/h1]
I wish there was rating that was halfway between positive or negative. Lords of Shadow has some pretty cool stuff going for it. Awesome art, story, voice acting and sound track. However, inconsistencies with game design make some moments of the game very fun while other moments extremely frustrating and tedious. Overall, if you are a fan of games like Dante's Inferno, God of War or Darksiders you might like this game but a few design decisions left a bad taste in my mouth preventing me from giving it a thumbs up.

[h1]Rant:[/h1]
Some levels have platforming sections where the game is clearly not built to be a platformer. When you stop moving your character, your character will still takes a few steps forward to stop their momentum. While this looks cool from an animation standpoint, from a gameplay standpoint where semi precise platforming is involved, this is a pain

The game seems to try to encourage the idea of building a combo meter when in combat. Once you completely build up the meter, enemies begin to drop "neutral energy" that the player can absorb in order to use light/dark powers. This can be very important with certain fights because if you fight while using light magic you will heal from each attack, becoming the difference between winning and losing a fight. The problem here is that while combos are encouraged none of the enemies allow you to combo them easily compared to other games that Lords of Shadow draws inspiration from. In a game like Devil May Cry or Darksiders there is ample opportunity to combo an enemy and you just need to be on the lookout for a few attacks that are uninterruptible from the enemy. In this game you are constantly bombarded by these kinds of uninterruptible attacks making it so that you are constantly trading blows with the enemy. Instead of letting loose and barraging your enemies with hundreds of different attacks you are instead always on the defensive, dodging and blocking and waiting for a moment where you can sneak 1 or 2 hits in. It feels more like playing a worse version of Dark Souls rather than a game like God of War.

To make matters worse, hitting enemies with multiple individual attacks to build up your combo meter takes longer and is more unsafe versus just countering an enemy attack. When you wait and counter an enemy instead, your meter fills up instantly rather than taking 2 minutes to fill, or longer if you get hit. Further encouraging a defensive play style rather than a offensive combo oriented one.

Many mechanics are re-used multiple times throughout the experience. The entire gameplay loop is: climb somewhere, fight some guys, do a puzzle and repeat until you reach the boss. The game introduces many different kinds of enemies but you deal with all of  them the same way, so effectively, gameplay does not feel different as you go on. You can unlock new moves to use in combat but since enemies will always bulldoze through your attacks, having a cool move that will just get interrupted is not worth it.

The game also provides items to use in combat which allow you to bypass some encounters quickly. Such as using holy water against vampires or summoning a demon to kill all enemies on screen. While these items are nice distractions they are never pivotal in combat and for the most part, I avoided using them.

As you play you also learn new major moves such as being able to sprint, double jump or do a charge dash. The game will try to spice up platforming by incorporating these moves into their usual challenges. As well as making puzzles that sometimes center around these new moves you have earned. Sometimes this leads to some cool results where you can now reach areas previously impossible to access or solve puzzles in creative ways.

The game usually offers hints after you have died in the game over screen. Most of the time this is helpful and helps guide the player to the right direction. However, the game sometimes tries to be funny by saying "Try not to swim in Lava" or "Don't fight like a Diary Farmer" when you die. The latter being constantly shown during the boss fight in the DLC for the game that's included in this edition. While stuff like this can be funny the first time through, it becomes annoying after fighting with the game's systems. The DLC boss fight in particular, is pretty cheap. It almost feels like they were worried that there was not enough content in the DLC so they wanted players to waste time by fighting a cheap boss. This boss fight really soured my experience of the game at the end and you are probably better off not even playing the DLC for this reason unless you are really into the story.

96612276.review:
Overall, it's a sorta meh game, that often feels frustrating and like I'm wasting my time.
The core combat is not the most satisfying, though not terrible or anything, just ok feeling. Sometimes good, othertimes bad. Sometimes you fight one or two enemies in a clear battle of positioning, timing, blocking, skill, etc... and othertimes it's just getting swamped by fifteen flying demons while stuck on a tiny playing area so there's no real way to reliably avoid getting hit and taking damage except for maybe punishing the grab attack, something that works on smaller enemies and leaves you immune while performing... for all of them....

And the problem is that this combat is honestly, while nothing great, still the best part of this game I'd say.

First, this game doesn't know what it wants to be, its copying other games of its time. Primarily God of War, and Shadow of the Colossus. And then some prince of Persia thrown in to cover the 3d platforming side. The games all over the place honestly. Very often while playing during a new boss or area you get surprised with something new for the first time... only to deal with some weird often contrived feeling mechanic that doesn't seem like it was greatly pollished or even fits in the game. You find yourself stuck climbing big bosses that try to shake you off, but with move sets limited to normal climbings, and then with god of war cinematic style quick time events thrown in at random with quick time events, and somewhat contrived sudden rules on what kills your or not. Most parts of the game, falling even ten feet kills you, other areas, fall fifty and your fine, one boss battle, fall over a hundred or two and you're A ok. No real reason or excuse, it's just that it fits that moment so they make things work that way. A giant throws a massive boulder at you, grab it with your chain and spin it back, where's that insane ability to root yourself to one location and handle such weights during other times? No where to be found... your character randomly changes to do whatever they think he should or shoudn't for a given idea of the game or part to work. Makes me not feel attached to him or his skill, or his struggles. Just frusterated when he can't do what he could or should.
Also don't even feel powerful with the powers you do more reliably keep. I mean, there's one enemy type that just can take your powers and gear, just like that, and ever time you see one you just stare at it and can't do anything till it makes noise, and then takes your stuff. I didn't realize the abilities of the gods or ancient artifacts are all so easy to take by random creatures, and they aren't the only ones to randomly be able to do this. As the game goes on seriously wonder whats going on with so many characters or creatures that can just disapear the players abilities at a moments notice, and how I can take any real big bad enemy fights seriously knowing of this detail in the world. 
Oh well, so the climbing from SotC is botched and doesn't feel good, and you can't get scenic feeligns when you can't control the camera quite often. The mood isn't well matched either. You have quick time events and some combat ideas from God of War, literally the worst parts in my opinion, made even worse when they can be of random inputs quite often, and also often placed in areas where one faillure means death and going back to redo a fight for another five or ten minutes to get back to that point. You know, the thing that really pisses you off when handling quick time events like that...
And the platforming alla prince of persia, is poorly done. Visuals for what you can/can't climb or handle are often unclear, you can't control the camera and the fixed positions/angles aren't always good to see stuff. And the climbing movement constantly changes its rules to fit how they want you to climb any given point.
Climbing up with your chain as a rope of sorts, sometimes you can climb up and down, other times you randomly fall because... idk, the chain wasn't long enough? Sure seems crazy long some times. Sometimes you can swing side to side, but that's only allowed when they want you to, many times I wanted to as it'd get me where I wanted to go but they lock that out then. Or the ability to jump, swing back from the surface and to jump away, also randomly locked, only allowed just when they want it. 
When jumping backwards to another ledge, the distance and height he can jump also varies insanely, sometimes like ten feet, even up five feet, other times they just block that and you can only jump back to a ledge ten feet down and five feet back instead. You just learn to try and feel out what they want you to do at any moment, there's rarely any choice, it's just follow their path with the immediate rules set for your movment at that one moment.

And for a Castlevania game... they miss the biggest parts they should have brought in. The equipment and abilities, and branching world. Instead it's completely linear, with fairly limited abilities and keys of sorts to unlock areas. Often said abilities are also rather... oddly forced into a situation so you might only use one ability like once in an early tutorial, then need to remember it five hours later into the game because it never sees any other use before then. Or how you can't punch a wall out of the way, but can smash it with a body slam. But body slam can't push large objects, only punching works on those, even if that pushes it into and through a wall... both moves clearly have the power, the distinction feels completely arbitrary. Overall, it's this lack of consistency that made me never able to really get immersed into the game,it always feels just like a game I'm trying to figure out the controls or design of, even up to the very end. And the story, what kept me around till the end... was honestly kinda shit, way worse of an ending than I expected.
Only real plus is the animations, some of the animations are honesty pretty good, especially for their time, others not so much... but the good ones did really stand out to me some times.

95741833.review:
Replayed this game as one of my favourites as a teenager, originally played on Xbox in 2010. The in-game graphics have held up well, although cutscenes are a little blocky. This game is well paced, combination of combat, puzzle, bosses and exploration. Beautiful level designs, amazing soundtrack and voice acting, unique and interesting characters as well as creative use of your abilities in relation to your enemies.

Each enemy has its own particular strengths to which, you as the player should strategically respond to if you want to be effective. You can customise your combos with your skill points which is handy if you don't like being forced into a particular fight style. However, the use of relics is recommended to be effective in the game. 

Of course, as a teenager I remember this game being much longer and harder, however I very much enjoyed playing it and appreciating all over again. There are multiple difficulty levels if you find the default too easy, however I cannot comment on how changing difficulty effects some of the game play, such as puzzles. 

If you enjoy gothic themes and monster hunting, this game is a great addition to a collection.

95474125.review:
Definitely great game.
1) Plot: Great plot, very good linked with sequel and all DLC.
2) Characters: During game you meet different characters and everyone is unique and play important role in the game.
3) Music:  Just superb music, I don't know what to add else here.
4) Gameplay:  In this game skills and secondary weapons are crucial. You need to combine all of them to have better result or just survive or kill enemy faster.
5) Graphics: Decent visual for 2013 year game,  zero bugs and perfect optimization.
6) 45 unique monsters (not the same model with different textures), with weakneses, resists and attacks
7) Epic boss fights: each boss has its own attacks and move sets, so you need find out tacktis to defeat it ( not annoying).
8) Quick time event: adequate not annoying quick time events.
9) SUPERB puzzles :) You have really a lot of puzzles, they are logical and not stupid/annoying.
10) Cutscenes/actors (voices) as plus too.
11) Replayability (Metroidvania)

What I didn't like it: camera, sometimes it f#cks you hard. Camera is static and sometimes you cannot see  place for jump or monsters.

BasicallyI had real fun when was playing this game. If you like good plot and gameplay like DMC or Bayonetta this game are definitely for you :)

95015052.review:
This review is more of a neutral one, and although I didn't like this game too much, I don't feel it deserves a negative rating. Despite being competent enough at what it's set to achieve, this game ends up feeling bland and mostly forgettable. The game drags for too long despite a very respectable attempt to translate as many elements from the 2D originals as possible and use them to offer some degree of variety across all levels. This isn't helped at all by the irrelevant and awkwardly voiced story line. The fixed camera is not that much of a problem but might get in the way regularly. What stood to me the most was the environment design: they look amazing for a game of the era and it does the whole job of setting the tone of the game.
All in all, it's an OK game. Not a disaster nor a masterpiece. Holds up well enough to be completed, but this is one I'm not replaying ever.

the game feel like a long epic journey , ( the game start slow but after chapter 2 it start getting really good )

the characters , enemies and bosses [b] (accept the last base game boss) [/b] designs are very good too .
[b] Soundtrack [/b] epic soundtrack fit the word of the game . the voice cast is very good too .

                                                                        [h1] GAME PLAY [/h1]


[b] combat [/b] is very fun . you have your basic moves like attack and block .
as you progress the story you unlock new stuff . you have (red magic) and (blue magic) 
red magic buff your attacks , blue magic heal you when attacking enemies .
you unlock consumable items too and a dark crystal 
[spoiler] basically the dark crystal summons naked female exodia [/spoiler]

[b] healing [/b] you have one way to heal it's by attacking enemies while using blue magic 
you get blue magic by attacking without getting hit so the game reward you when you are playing good
or you can get it by an energy station.

[b] enemies [/b] you have a variety of enemies and boss a lot of them are weak from specific items and the boss fights are unique and challenging .

[b] puzzles [/b] the puzzles are unique and fun if you don't like puzzles you can pay point to skip them .

                                                                            [h1] conclusion [/h1]

i think this game is very good .

92885027.review:
I hate leaving negative reviews. I can usually find the good in things. buuuut - TLDR: F**K this game. The story is kinda good so just watch the cutscenes on YouTube or something

I just finished the Netflix Castlevania series and was like oh yeah I've been meaning to play Lord's of Shadow for years! Perfect way to celebrate the awesome "anime" so I really wanted to like this game. 
Unfortunately I would say a sharp stake in the eye would be more enjoyable

I'm the kind of guy who when I start a game I pretty much finish it whether I like the game or not so maybe it will get more fun but I'm already halfway through.

Maybe the game was good for it's time? Maybe it just didn't age well? I dunno

Take all the bad stuff from God of War, Assassin's Creed, and Dark Souls and multiply it cause they just kept doing the same thing over and over

Combat sucks. At first I was like damn I SUCK at this game. 

I pride myself at being a pretty good gamer. I like hard games. The combat's not hard. It's just boring and tedious. It's boring because they give you all these awesome combos and like 80% of them are useless. They give you an amazing array of moves that if you ever try to use them you will immediately get bashed in the nuts because EVERYTHING just takes the damage you throw at them and rolls right through you. So you end up sticking with just swing swing dodge... Swing swing dodge. This is especially true for boss fights. If they wanted to make a Souls game the shoulda made a Souls game. 

Also the BLOCK and DODGE button are basically the same button! I hate that crap.

The boss fights sans 1 or 2 are basically the same boss fights over and over again. Once you've fought one you've fought them all just in a different skin. They all have the SAME MOVES and they are basically just REGULAR ENEMIES WITH MORE HEALTH. Just Werewolves and trolls reskinned. 

The camera SUCKS. A LOT. You can't see the enemy you are trying to fight half the time cause they are off camera. You can't find where you are supposed to go because the ledge is basically off camera.
Oh and you can't find a lot of the power ups because they are off camera which wouldn't be so bad if the jump/hit detection wasn't crap. Maybe it's the nature of this generation of games but invisible walls make it really uninteresting to explore and find gems of bullshit power. Just hopping around hoping to find a hole in the invisible wall... Or the ledge you spent 3 minutes trying to climb for nothing to happen and then you spend 15 minutes looking for another way to go only to have to look it up and see you WERE going the right way but apparently you were a millimeter off and the damn invisible wall was in your way.

You know how in Assassin's Creed you are trying to jump to the ledge on your left and instead you jump to your death? Yeah this game does that in spades. I can't tell you how many times I've fallen into pits for this reason.

Oh and to make matters worse you gotta revisit most of the levels if you wanna get all the power ups. I hate that shit. If the game was fun maybe it would be better

I felt bad for my Twitch viewers cause I'm usually a very positive gamer. I like to give games the benefit of the doubt.

Yeah... I'm just gonna uninstall and watch some poor schlub play on youtube. Maybe I'll see what I was doing wrong. Or maybe I'll just be glad I uninstalled.

[h1] ES UN NO RECOMENDADO CON SABOR A RECOMENDADO

Bien Antes que nada, aunque no lo recomiende no quiere decir que no sea un BUEN JUEGO me plantee mucho en poner que lo recomiendo, su ambientación así como la reinvención de la saga me parecen un concepto magnifico, de las historias que más he disfrutado como fan de la saga Castlevania el solo hecho de romper la fórmula de la un respiro merecido a la franquicia. 

PERO..... Hay varias cosas, por las que me reusó  completamente y firmemente a recomendarlo, quieres jugarlo adelante el juego no decepciona, aun así tomate un momento antes de que hagas tu compra y lee los que yo considero los puntos malos del título.

[b] 1.- LOS CONTROLES.-[/b] probablemente uno de los controles peor distribuidos e intuitivos que he tenido la desdicha de usar, me pase el juego y aun no me acostumbraba, simplemente NO PUEDES ponerle 25 usos al joystick que doble tab para correr, que <-- y x  para un combo, ----> y x para otro, presiona R3 para absorber esencia, R3 +L3 para otro combo.... sin reproches el peor aspecto del juego.
 
[b] 2.-LA DIFICULTAD ARTIFICIAL.- [/b] no es posible que estando jugando en difícil, no pudiera matar a el jefe del dlc y tener que bajar la dificultad no porque la pelea sea difícil NO, si no por un QTE (las lanzas del olvidado ) mal implementado en todo lo que va del juego nunca te piden un QTE de ese estilo y el control es pésimo si el control está mal, pues el control del QTE lo empeora todo en un 100%, tuve que repetir ese QTE durante  40 min, al final simplemente una de las veces lo hice al azar sin intentarlo y salió, baje la dificultad del juego simplemente para agilizar el proceso de el QTE por que sorpresa si fallas el QTE o te mata y te manda al inicio de fase o se recupera un porcentaje de vida y tienes que volver a quitárselo si quieres repetir el QTE. Otra cosa es que ponen enemigos a montones para que sea difícil, en los niveles contra tiempo o lo haces perfecto o no lo pasas, -tienes que dar muchas vueltas para encontrar las pistas de los puzles (a veces los pase sin siquiera saber  que eran un puzzle , porque no lo explican)

[b] 3.- EL PLATAFORMEO.- [/b] aquí no hay mucho que decir solo que a veces por el difuminado algunas cosas se ven las lejos de lo que están en realidad.

[b] 4.- LA CAMARA .-[/b]bueno esto se lo atribuyo a los juegos de la época en general, así que solo lo menciono.
 
[b]  5.- LOS QTE.-[/b] no puedes ver una cinemática en paz porque siempre hay un maldito QTE que no te deja disfrutar la historia.

En General es un BUEN JUEGO. No Increíble, no excelente, no memorable simplemente un BUEN JUEGO con mucho potencial desaprovechado.

PD.- La secuela mejora algunas de las cosas anteriores aunque empeora en otras

92473011.review:
Well the combat has the mechanical complexity of God of War 1 and the polish of a 3D Sonic game.
There’s all sorts of strange, underdeveloped ideas the game likes to spam for a bit and then forget about (mounts!), as well as tons of one-mechanic minigames that feel like the devs were just putting in whatever.
The pacing is atrocious. Chapters end in bizarre ways, with one not ending on a vampire boss fight in a burning village, but immediately after on a level where you walk through two rooms worth of sewer.
Platforming is mostly automatic Uncharted-style climbing that you will only fail when the scripting doesn’t work.
It has no real identity of its own, with most of the game feeling like cargo-cult versions of things taken from other (non-Castlevania) games, the most notable of which are the three Shadow of the Colossus style boss fights which don’t seem to understand any of the reasons why people liked SotC.
They seemed to have deliberately picked the least helpful angles for the fixed camera to take in every screen without it being outright broken.
Minor upgrades are obnoxiously gated behind mundane obstacles that require later upgrades in this linear, stage-based game.
The environments are actually quite nice to look at, but the character models are hideous and the animations are poor.
Despite the number of cutscenes and dour, gamefuneral tone, the story is very boring, very dumb, and ends on a post-credits stinger that's so jarring it’s hard to describe it in any way other than “lol”.
Music is so bombastic constantly it becomes irritating despite being generally unmemorable epic movie score styled music. Disappointing for a franchise that usually delivers on music even in its worst entries (Hi, The Adventure).
The game will never stop telling you that you cannot carry any more daggers.
And it doesn’t feel anything like any Castlevania game.
I can’t really recommend this, as a Castlevania or as a video game in general, very 7th gen reboot, very bad.

EDIT: Ignore everything above, the real reason not to play this is so you don't have to play the DLC and deal with one of if not the most poorly designed boss in a character action game. Whose moveset consists 50% of shockwave attacks that hit you in the air anyway and requires you to constantly be in the air to hit him in a game where you have no air control or quick way of getting down (the stomp rarely works while swinging)

92429328.review: Unbelievably boring game. Broken mechanics, long unskippable cutscenes during combat, tutorials and "look at this gimmick" type prompts that freeze the game and allow you to do nothing and break the flow of the game.

92409877.review:
Castlevania Lords of Shadow Ultimate Edition es la edición definitiva del mismo título lanzado en 2010 en consolas y, esta versión, en PC en 2013. Desarrollado por Mercury Steam, estudio español, producido y distribuido por Konami, dueños de la IP.
El juego se planteó en un principio como un reboot, un nuevo inicio, para la saga Castlevania, finalmente quedó en una trilogía que reimaginaba o reinterpretaba el mismo.
Nos encontramos ante un juego de acción-aventura 3D, hack & slash, con toques plataformeros y puzles, divididos en distintos niveles de duración variable.
 
Estamos en el año 1047 y nuestro papel será el de Gabriel Belmont, miembro de la Hermandad de la Luz cuyo objetivo es acabar con la Oscuridad que está lentamente consumiendo el mundo. Para ello contaremos con la Cruz de Combate para derrotar a las incesantes hordas de enemigos a los que nos enfrentaremos. 

El combate es uno de los puntos destacables del título, se nota su fuerte inspiración en la saga God of War. Contaremos con dos tipos de ataques y todo un arsenal de herramientas: dagas, agua bendita, etc. Que nos ayudarán a acabar con los enemigos más duros, los controles durante el mismo responden bien y es espectacular, además contaremos con una buena variedad de combos que iremos desbloqueando.

En cuanto al apartado gráfico, hablamos de un juego antiguo, 2010, y que tampoco fue puntero en su momento, por otro lado sí destaca su apartado artístico, que nos deja auténticas estampas tanto naturales como de la arquitectura mas barroca y gótica.

También son destacables su banda sonora y su doblaje, ambos rayan a un muy alto nivel, contando en su doblaje con actores de primer nivel como son Patrick Stewart o Robert Carlyle, en los roles principales.

La historia, por otro lado, no sorprende, no pasa de ser la más que vista lucha entre el bien y el mal y en muy pocos momentos se apartará de estos clichés tan vistos. Se sigue con cierto interés pero no es uno de sus puntos fuertes.

Comentar además otro de sus puntos débiles, el control. No con ello quiero decir que sea algo grave, el juego es perfectamente jugable, pero notaremos más de una vez que el personaje no responde como debería y en más de una ocasión nos encontraremos que no se agarra a ese saliente, cuando de sobra, debería. Como digo, nada doloroso, pero sí, visible.

Además hablar de que el juego se llama Castlevania, pero poco toma del mismo, más allá de ciertos aspectos del lore de la saga, en muchas ocasiones sentiremos que estamos ante una especie de God of War, como ya comenté antes, del cual se nota que es su principal referente, entre otros como Shadow of the Colossus. No termina de tener una identidad propia que permita diferenciarlo claramente, aparte de su ambientación.

Y para ir acabando, la duración es más que correcta, nos puede durar entre unas 20-25 horas dependiendo de cuanto jugo le queramos sacar, contamos con desbloqueables tales como arte conceptual, añadir que en esta "Ultimate Edition" se incluyen dos DLC que vienen a cerrar el arco de este primer título.

En conclusión, es un juego correcto, efectivo y divertido, pero que tarda en arrancar. No es un clásico ni una obra maestra, sin embargo es una aventura ciertamente recomendable si te gusta el género, no pierdas la oportunidad de descubrir el destino de Gabriel en su lucha contra los Señores Oscuros.

92069736.review:
[h1]The most brutal white knight[/h1]

I think this game is underrated. I played it without knowing anything about it and I loved it.

You play as Gabriel who serves to protect people from evil forces. His wife dies and her soul end up being trapped in between worlds. She guides Gabriel so he could defeat the lords of shadow and bring peace to world and its people.

The game starts with a really nice cut-scene and throws you in combat right after that which serves as tutorial. After getting used to controls you go on a journey to deal with the darkness. On your way you'll be slaying monsters like undead beings and solve some puzzles. Of course your wife is always with you and you get some nice cut-scenes once in while. It also has a really good, gloomy atmosphere.

One of the things I loved the most is combat. It's brutal, fast but not too hard to learn although on harder difficulties you'll need to sweat  a lot i guess, i've on easiest like i do most of the time. You have various skills which unlock with time and some nice moves. The combat is similar to God of War.

Then there are boss fights. Boss variety is great in this game. From smaller ones like werewolves or trolls to gigantic monsters, again similar to God of War. Speaking of variety, most bosses are very different and require a different approach each time so it never becomes boring. Boss design is great too, same as all the minor enemies.

The puzzles on the other hand are not so fun. I'm not even sure an action game needs those. I loves those light, easy puzzles in Uncharted games but here they're a bit too much. Some may be quite challenging and you spend time figuring it out but instead you just want to brutally murder more monsters. I mean it's a matter of taste but I personally don't like when action games are disrupted by lengthy puzzles, I just want to kill things and bring light to the people. But overall you'll be fighting most of the time.

The only bigger downside I could think of is that some areas are annoying. Not because they're hard but it just feels like it lasts forever and you just want to move on to something fresh.

It's a wonderful game graphically. Obviously it doesn't look like current AAA games but when it came out it looked really good and in my opinion still looks good today, especially the cut-scenes.
There's also a huge variety of environments and they're beautiful. Forests, castles, greenery, snow, you name it, everything looks really nice.
I guess some people might not like the fixed camera. Well, maybe not fixed but you can't control it. I find it nice since it always puts you on the right perspective and zooms in or out when required. It works perfectly.
Controls are responsive and you can execute all the moves without any bugs or clunkiness.

Sound design is great too. Voice acting is up to AAA standards and characters sound believable. Sounds add to the atmosphere a lot, it might be calm chirping of birds one second and in a blink of an eye orchestral music starts playing and you stand up against a deadly foe.

Overall one of the best action games i've played. If you enjoy third person action games, fast, fluid combat, good story and want to kill a titan it's for you.

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Fun combat
[*]Great graphics
[*]Great sound design
[*]Great variety in environments
[*]Great boss variety
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Some areas drag too long
[/list]

91790838.review:
When I first played Lords of Shadow on PS3 I quite enjoyed it. Playing it again now I have no idea why. Perhaps it's because back then I hadn't yet been spoiled by masterpieces like Dark Souls and God of War (the 2018 one), perhaps younger me just had a much higher tolerance for broken mechanics and poor game design.
Whatever the reason, I now feel that Lords of Shadow is a game that should have been left in my memory and not revisited, because now I hate it. I hate the awful controls. I hate the fixed camera. I hate the terrible parry system that only works when it feels like it. I hate being hit by enemies before they even start their attack animation. I hate the pointless backtracking through linear levels to find a minor upgrade to useless items and abilities. And most of all I hate how this game goes out of its way to waste the players time. I don't mean waste time like playing games in the first place, to have fun while doing nothing productive; I mean literally waste time by having long, unskippable animation sequences in the middle of fights, by checkpointing right before cut-scenes and then making the player watch or skip those cut-scenes every single time they reload, by taking all of the player's gear away and then making them chase around for minutes before giving it all back.
I don't hate everything about the game, just every part of it that is the game. The visuals are nice, if a little dated now. The soundtrack is great and the voice-acting is superb. The world design is generally very well done. The problem is, everything that's good about the game doesn't even need to be part of a game. If Lords of Shadow were a movie then it would actually be better because then nobody would have to struggle with the aggravating game design.

In truth, I only bought and played this on pc now because I never got round to playing the sequel and I thought it would be a fun romp to recap on the story. I was wrong and I regret it; it's just not fun to play.

If you have the patience of a saint and nothing better to throw your money at then you might get on with Castlevania: Lords of Shadow, but I still wouldn't recommend it. You would be better served watching a heavily edited playthrough on YouTube for the story and then forgetting the game exists.

91662036.review:
I didn't go in expecting it to be a traditional Castlevania experience, and knew very little about it other than vaguely remembering that it was a hack-and-slack title.

With those tempered expectations, I can honestly say I got my money’s worth, as I put 21 hours into beating the game on Hard on my first playthrough, and then about 8 hours more finding collectibles and beating the DLC chapters. Jank and bad puzzles be damned!

What I particularly liked was the amazing atmosphere in each of the environments, with every nook and cranny intricately detailed, making every location feel real - even environments that you’d scarcely spend more than 30 seconds in. (For example, you start one level off in a beautiful, gleaming purple cavern with tufts of heat rising from the depths and distorting the air. You’d think with that amount of detail the [i]cavern[/i] would be the level, but nope - you can rappel yourself out of there in no less than 15 seconds, and you’re off to a completely area). And add on top of that there’s [i]45+[/i] different levels, so by the time you reach the end, you really do feel like you’ve gone through a hard-fought journey.

The story and voice-acting were also top-notch (especially the between-level narrations), and I was really invested into Gabriel’s journey and how things would unfold. I was pretty thoroughly satisfied with the story, even to the point where I ended-up enjoying some of the QTEs, internally yelling at a particularly heinous individual as I was tearing them a new one while giving myself repetitive stress injury in my wrists. And props to stapling that cliffhanger at the end of the main story, since it now legitimately has me excited to continue the story in the sequel.

The orchestral soundtrack throughout the game was also memorable, and all the sound effects -- both in-game and in the cutscenes -- were spot on. Nothing much to say other than it served its purpose in getting me totally immersed.

So, onto gameplay, which is where I can begin picking at some faults.

The amount of difficulty in the combat was spot-on, for the most part, as it was challenging but fair (at least on Hard; never played Normal). But as the game progressed, I began to realize that the vast majority of the enemies (and even some of the bosses) all kinda did the same thing: they claw-swipe you, dodge around randomly, and do a groundpound. And it mostly devolves into mashing X (with 1 or 2 magic-guzzling moves thrown in), dodging during an enemy’s windup animation, and being wary of either their unblockables or their groundpound attacks that need to be jumped over. Sometimes it really felt like a slog due to the relatively roteness of the combat. The mechanic of whittling down a midboss’s health, and then taking control of him to open-up environment obstacles was also over-used. But thankfully, there were a good few bosses that had interesting and novel patterns that had to be mastered, and which sometimes required re-accessing my strategy before they could be beat.

I guess next are the low-key, non-combat portions of the game that serve as breathers in-between the combat, namely namely the parkour and puzzle portions. The parkour parts served their function, and were enjoyable as it let me really take in the environment, but it wasn’t as fluid as I would have liked, and would sometimes punish you by having you fall to your death if you didn’t go [i]exactly[/i] where you were supposed to be. And the puzzles, or perhaps I should say, minigames, well... I can’t tell if the game would be better or worse without them in terms of pacing, but I’ll just say some of them were downright awful, and didn’t belong in a Castlevania game.

Onto SECRETS. Oh gosh, I loved the secrets in this game, as they very tangibly rewarded your efforts with buffs to your health, light/dark magic, and consumable item capacities. After I beat the main story, I spent a good 6 hours or so going back through previous areas to find any secrets that I had missed. And to top it off, the DLC final boss was a monstrous badass that took as much health & magic as I could possibly muster, making the secret-hunting feel truly purposeful. So after repeatedly getting my ass handed to me by him in his final phase, I was finally able to squeak out a victory against him due to having a slight increase to my health/magic pools (and better magic conservation throughout the battle).

To summarize: yeah it’s got the occasional jank, some bad puzzles, and repetitive combat. But it’s polished AAA product that’ll take you on a journey through many scenic locations, deliver a good story, and give you a few memorable badass boss fights.

90702670.review:
Before starting the review, I'd like to say that this game is not a Castlevania game. A Castlevania game (or at least the Castlevania games I've played) have an open world where you discover new areas and new bosses, while you get new upgrades/ tricks to get to other parts of the castle, and square off against Dracula, Death and other bosses.

This game is non of that. It is more of a God of War type game, with some puzzle elements in it. But it mostly involves combat. So let's start with the combat.
The combat starts pretty weak. But when you get some new gear, it starts to get fun. Light magic eg. regenerates your health, and Dark Magic gives some extra damage. You will get more combos as the time goes on, and some combos only work when you activate one of the two Magics. You get more goodies that work with specific Magics, like a double jump or the Shadow Claw. When you play on higher difficulties (which I recommend), you need to be on-point with counters and dodging. I found the combat fun, and challenging enough to entertain throughout the whole game.

There are also puzzles and platforming you need to do. The puzzles are okay. They are never very difficult, and you can buy the solutions if you really want to. The platforming is a hit-or-a-miss scenario. I didn't really enjoy them, for the game uses a fixed camera. I often found myself jumping into lava, deadly fog or committing suicide by jumping off a cliff when the camera spontaneously changed position. Some of the climbing seem to go to a dead end, due to the camera not showing the points of interest...

The graphics themselves are beautiful. You will be visiting ruins that are overgrown, frozen castles, dense libraries, damp catacombs, deserts and swamps. It is diverse, and it looks gorgeous. The main character, enemies and NPCs are also very good. It was a beautiful game when it came out, and up to this day it is beautiful. There is also handdrawn art, which is great as well. The music is also very good.

The story itself is okay. It starts very dull, gets a lot better in the middle, and is somewhat disappointing at the end. The final fight at Chapter 12 is somewhat of a letdown, mechanically and storywise. The Epilogue is very interesting, but it does not build towards that in the DLC at all.

The DLC... Is pretty bad. It focusses on the climbing, which is really the bad part of the game. I had the most issues with the fixed camera when playing the DLC as well, and the fun part (combat, unlocking new moves) are neglected. Some mechanics are introduced, only to be forgotten a few seconds later (like running over water). The story is full of plotholes and is completely forgetable (which is ironic, for the BBEG in the DLC is the Forgotten One).

If Steam was able to give a 'meh', I'd give this game that rating. The combat is good, the platforming is not. The graphics are very good, as is the audio, but the story has ups and downs. This game has the title Castlevania, but this is definitely not a Castlevania game. It has a Belmont with a whip, but is lacks the rest. No open world, no side-tracking/ shortcuts, and worst of all: no Dracula. I compliment them for doing something new, but I think naming it as the rest of the francise is not that smart. Just calling it Lords of Shadow would have been enough, and you wouldn't generate expectations then...

90532531.review:
So I will start by saying that this game is worth playing even though it has a bad rep. in the Castlevania universe. The company Mercurysteam did a good job with creating a 3-d Castlevania after the train wreck that was the N64 version. It is very solid with some minor gripes to it.

The combat is very solid with a close feel to Devil May Cry but with it's own mechanics and unique signature to things. You still get artifacts that grant you new moves as you play and it is very consistant. Minor gripes being some encounters and enemies can be a bit tedious and hit boxes can be inconsistant with certain enemy attacks (FINAL BOSS I AM LOOKING AT YOU!). 

The world/stages are wonderfully constructed and look amazing though it can be misleading at times. Some places you think you can go and you end up falling to your death just because pathways and camera views don't always help paint where you can and cannot go. Overall sound design is good and the music is wonderfully composed by a symphony even though it can be very repeditive at times when you are trying to figure out where to go. Voice acting is good especially when you have Captain John Luc Piccard doing the narration.

Overally this is a solid game though is it perfect and what we want out of a 3-d Castlevania...no but I appreciate what has been built here as a retelling of the Castlevania story. Given the age of when this game was made I find it is still a good game to play with some replayablity in it given it's minor gripes on it.

Rating: 7/10 - A good action/adventure game that can easily be within the B+ tier of other good action/adventure titles in the Devil May Cry section. If you like these types of games this I can recommend as a good purchase!

90346299.review:
1)Story
LoS focuses more on the story and cutscenes than previous Castlevanias and quite frankly developers did a garbage job at it

Here is a protagonist with tragic past
There are three Lords of Shadow, go kill them
Wanna know why ending is so stupid? Play DLCs and sequel
That's it!

Everything what happen in between was pointless waste of your time and have no story meaning

This is so much a western game that not only it pulls out all of lame cliche plot twists at the end of the game including the classic
"a good guy being a bad guy all along and now its time for me to start long monologuing for 5 minutes (!) where I explain my evil plan"
but also the game copypasted the main villian and majority of story plot points from other very similiar character action western game released 8 months earlier - Dante's inferno

In short: every single attempt at expanding the importance of the story is terrible
90% of cutscenes and dialogue is boring, pointless and skipping cutscenes (if its even possible to skip them ffs) does not change the main dull plot for a single bit

LoS would be actually so much better without any dialogue like Shadow of the Colossus did but we cannot have that in a game from PS3 era because cinematic experience is way more important over gameplay



2)Gameplay
Very average western character action game and its painfully visible
Tries to copy Devil May Cry mix with God of War but it fails miserably
but that doesn't mean that combat is bad - just its fundamentals are shaky as heck.

There is so many gameplay mechanics shoved into the game and so many novelty level gimmicks in the game that its distract from central identity as a whole.

For example: we have dodge, block, parry, ground attacks, air attacks, mounting monsters, normal attacks, heavy attacks, multiple different consumables, 2 devil triggers(offensive and defensive), grab, quick time events, mashing button, focus, combos, platforming, puzzles, minigames etc...

How of many of those are refined or polished? None. 



3)Platforming
"You can't have a western character action game without brainless platforming" developers from PS3 era said
So how is it in LoS?
The same as in other PS3 type action games such as Uncharted - clunky, imprecise, sluggish, boring, limited with horrible camera angles



4)Level design
30% good, 30% average, 40% horrible
Easy the worst aspect of the game

Lots of boring empty spaces
Way too many same looking filler levels to pander game length
Common backtracking and walking blindly towards camera

At least there is a big variety of environments but the amount of levels with actually interesting visuals - not so many
 
Many things you do quickly gets too repetitive:
like for example another "use magic to press buttons" puzzle in row or   
how often you need to mount once again a big monster just to do that one single action to progress area and then discard monster like a flat tire.

Combat enounters aren't any better - most of the time you fight a group of single enemy type or a group of single enemy type with addition of one big enemy type.

Fights where you have ANYTHING other than those combination are a rarity in LoS which is such a wasted opportunity

At least level design does get way better after chapter 4 with additon of pretty alright designed puzzles



5)Puzzles
Surprisingly puzzles in this game are in 90% good. There is not much bad I can say about those
Still better than anything from action games like Tomb Raider reboots, God of War or Uncharted ever did



6)Graphics
Overall graphics does look really meh. 
Character models look ok but textures on them and everything else are horrible muddy and pixelated

Visuals are dull in first 3 chapters. After this game gets WAY better with variation of colors and locations but still there is way too much boring brown, white and green colors IMHO

The game does run in 60 fps at least but cutscenes are in some weird galaxy brain low framerate and resolution for some reason



7)Sound and music
Painfully generic fantasy based songs.
Nothing special or original. Nothing that screams Castlevania to you
No remixes of classic songs or even anything remotely similar in the style
Many songs are just playing on 30-60 second loop and sometimes its just pure silence.
Also soundtrack itself doesn't have much variety so you will end up keep listening the same thing over and over for majority of the game

About sound effects? Nothing special
Majority of QTEs are even missing sounds effects
You try to cut massive statue in half with your chain that is conveniently blocking your path? Not a single chain noise during whole QTE and one flat explosion sound at the end as statue explode into multiple pieces (for some reason)



8)Basic enemies
Shocking it's also painful generic and as westernized as it can be
Nothing groundbreaking or interesting in design
Trolls, boars, zombies, goblins, wolfs, warewolfs, spiders, skeletons...
90% of enemies have 1-2 different attacks which is usually a melee or grab or ground smash or charge
No cool gimicks or anything that would make those enemies stand out amongs the crowd.
If you think about, those enemies are just reskins that rotates in between chapters with minor changes

Basically nothing that made bestiary of previous Castlevania games so good and unique

Where are minotaurs, crawling skulls, Frankenstein monsters, mummies, lizard mans, zombie dogs, ghosts, medusa heads, wherecats, hunchbacks, mermans, giant skeletons, doppelgängers, Legion or Grim Reaper?



9)Bosses
Mostly generic looking as much as you may imagine
For example: big Ogre, big boar, big troll, big werewolf, big bird, big vampire...
You get my point

Boss fights are most of the time alright but mostly average in term of moveset and visual design making them super forgettable
Parrying bosses does feel really good and final boss fight was REALLY fun tho

The worst boss fights in the game are bootleg Shadow of the Colossus style titans - a combination of terrible camera, long dull platforming with tons of QTE's and zero actual combat

There are three titans and those are so bad that 68% of players permanently quit the game on second titan in chapter 2 and I wouldn't even blame them for doing so



10)But “Where is Castlevania?"
Good question because LoS just screams "I was a generic western character action game but then Konami told us to make Castlevania" and then developers shoved in few Castlevania references
Where is Dracula or his castle? 
Where is iconic music or iconic monsters? 
Where is anything that made Castlevania games so fun and unique?



11)DLCs 
In term of story,cutscenes,locations, platforming, encounters, boss fights - pure hot garbage
Even game producer Dave Cox did call DLCs (and I quote) a mistake
Puzzles in them are ok'ish tho




12)Personal nitpicks
>Game length
25 hours streched out by tons of copy pasted ideas, encounters and filler stuff that does not push story or introduce interesting events
Developers could easy cut this game into 10-15 hour game and nothing would change.
It would make this game pacing actually good 

>Camera is really bad. Like OH MAN its so bad

>Everything is glowing or telling you what to do
LoS is like big brother holding your hand and spamming hints for a whole time

>The huge amount of unskippable annoying and slow cutscenes that stop you from playing the game is outlandish. Especially during puzzles and boss fights



13)Verdict
How a company trying to copy as simple concept as DMC with GoW can fail so miserable still baffles me

Just make a game with good, fleshed out combat, variety of unique enemies in each encounter, decent boss fights and variety of puzzles.
Is that way too much to ask for a game from seventh console generation?

Overall this game is an average PS3 western character action game to its core
My score is 5/10

Feel free to skip it but if you really want to give it a try, just know that the worst part of the game are first three chapters
