89889025.review:
I bought this game on my 360 way back in the day, and proceeded to almost 100% it. Picking it up on Steam and going through the chapters again is a mix of nostalgia and renewed frustration at the controls.
C,LoS is an action adventure game with some RPG elements that borrows heavily from the formula of the original God of War series. Much like the other underappreciated game in this genre, Dantes Inferno (I often hope it comes to PC as well), the developers tried to build on this formula with a mixed bag of results.
At first, it will feel very familiar to any GoW veteran, but progressing through the game not only gives you points to unlock more varied and complex attacks, but you will also acquire new items that in themselves add a whole array of moves to learn. By the end of the game, if you put the time in to learn much of these moves, your fingers will be moving like a concert pianist on your controller (I HIGHLY recommend controller play; the concept of doing this with keyboard controls scares me). Even though the new abilities are spoon fed to you through the first third of the game, this can scale the frustration with later game encounters. Even knowing what I am doing, I'll often find myself angrily messing up my attacks and falling to attempting a brute force win, more often than not losing entirely.
Where this game shines, though, is in its narrative and presentation. Where GoW used a sense of grand scale to make it feel like you were combating the Greek gods at the height of their power, LoS uses a softer musical score with these grand shots to convey the feeling of being a lone warrior in a world in decline. While the pseudo-fixed camera can make certain parts of the game (namely combat) annoying, the splendid vistas given when navigating this massive world make up for it.
And the world [i]is[/i] Massive. A simple play through the main campaign can clock in at close to 40 hours. And that's not including replaying every level to complete the unlockable challenges or the DLC content.
I strongly recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the GoW formula for what it was, and don't mind the added challenge of increased complexity in control. If you frustrate easily, this game is not for you.

88806517.review:
Game Hack'n Slash que suga a mecânica de combate e câmeras dos 'God of War' em sua essência mas não deixando de ser um bom jogo.

História:

Simples e boa, no começo do game dá a entender que é só mais uma história genérica, porém com o passar dos cenários o protagonista Gabriel ganha bastante profundidade e realmente no final do final do game que eu realmente gostei pra caralho da história desenvolvida no game.

Gameplay:

O combate do jogo é o típico sair batendo e fazendo combos com a Cruz Sagrada e com os itens que o Gabriel vai pegando ao longo do jogo. Há bastante quicktime event durante as lutas porém nada exagerado e pra ser sincero, um game como os god of war antigos pedem esse tipo de mecânica.
A camêra dinâmica do jogo deixa a desejar, visto que em vários pontos do game a câmera te confunde podendo fazer você errar a ação.
Há poucas coisas para pegar no mapa, shards de vida e de magias e scrolls encontrados nos cavalheiros pelos cenários que contam um pouco do que eles passaram em suas jornadas.
Há pouca variedade de inimigos e eles vem em pouca quantidade na maioria das áreas, algo que deixa as lutas não tão legais como poderiam ser.

Dificuldade:

Eu joguei no Hard tranquilamente, com excessão de dois bosses para o final do game que são verdadeiros filhos de uma rapariga e apelam bastante, se chegar sem vida neles dá um trabalhinho vencê-los.
Os puzzles são bem fáceis, algo que me desapontou.

Trilha Sonora:

É boa, porém muitas vezes as faixas que estão tocando se tornam repetitivas, o loop de áudio não foi muito bem feito e também poderia haver mais variedade de faixas musicais.

Nota: 7/10.

I don't usually bother leaving reviews for games, but I felt I should on this occasion. The story, world-building, and voice acting are superb. The highly variable aesthetics of the different chapters and levels are incredible. Each location has a distinct atmosphere, which keeps things fresh. A lot of thought and effort have gone into developing Castlevania: Lords of Shadow. The gameplay is generally fun and smooth once you get the hang of it. There are a few puzzles and boss battles that are frustrating, often because the mechanics are fiddly. For example, the stone idol titan boss fight at the end of chapter 2 is especially irritating. I suggest when you reach these points you might want to swallow your pride and look at one of the many great walkthroughs available! 

Tl;dr - I would give this game a 9/10 and I am about to begin the sequels!

87390105.review:
Solid action game. I've played this numerous times on the X360 and I still enjoy it today.

This game borrows a bunch of styles - God of War, Shadow of Colossus, and Onimusha (gauntlet/souls system). if you've played God of War then you're all set. Note: fixed camera angles - may not be liked by some but I never really had problems with its implementation. Use a controller.

There is a ton of impressive artwork here and I especially enjoy how the entire game plays out like a journey similar to Castlevania IV where each level builds off the previous one. There are plenty of colorful vistas and I think this is an example where good art design can still hold up after a decade (2010 on consoles).

The soundtrack also deserves praise. Some incredible pieces that range from calming/chill to more heroic. You are not going to find much in the way of remixed tunes from previous games other then 2 or 3 songs. The most notable one being Waterfalls of Agharta from Castlevania IV.

Good story overall. Good voice work considering they payed some money to get Captain Picard and Dr. Nicholas Rush to voice the main characters.

Overall - great game. Get it on sale for sure if you are on the fence.

I always loved the Castlevania series when I was a child, and after a long break from video games I've decided to revisit this one. I was immediately surprised by Patrick Stewart's welcome, but still reserved final judgement. It's a PS3 era game, there's a good chance it won't be very good.
I am happy to say I was wrong. Sure, the combat can be repetitive, the lack of camera control can put you in some awkward situations when fighting, and the level design, while detailed and inspired, suffers from the inability to communicate to the player what direction it is possible to go (I was stuck for a good ten minutes in one stage until i took one opportune turn, just to reveal a new camera angle!).

But all these did not stop me from enjoying a rich story, interesting characters, some really cool puzzles and epic boss fights. This is a gem even in 2021, and I would recommend this game to everyone, and not Castlevania fans alone.

85787393.review:
Great production with a fantastic story, and the game is fine-tuned up to a point.

Advantages:
- The game lasts for +/- 22h
- The plot is excellent - a continuous journey
- The theme of the book is present throughout the game (since its launch), which gives the production an unusual atmosphere
- Satisfying combat system because it wants to be as enjoyable and realistic as possible
- Music perfectly reflects the world perfectly
- Even a nice treatment with a camera over which you have no control
- The levels are not monotonous.

Defects:
- Some game elements have only 30 FPS (very rare view)
- The last two chapters of the story are slightly bagged
- The last boss in the game is very underdeveloped and should lose more health as he becomes more aggressive due to the armor being broken (the last stage of the fight, attacking the boss on the head is a nightmare) - Konami fix the endgame, you have the source code so go ahead and fix it.
- The game does not allow you to collect all the collectibles because the hero does not have the skill that you acquire much later
- The cutscenes could have been in higher resolution or replaced with a cutscene in the game engine (I don't care about the cutscenes of the last two chapters because they haven't aged)
- I advise against playing on PC controls - the game is designed in such a way that it works well only on the Pad
- Who the hell hides Game Settings and Save Status in Steam App Files? - This is not the only case I know, I can also mention the Lord of the Fallen.

Final rating 7/10. 



Świetna produkcja z fantastyczną opowieścią i gra jest świetnie dopracowana do pewnego momentu.

Zalety:
- Gra starcza na +/- 22h
- Fabuła znakomita - ciągła podróż
- Motyw książki jest obecny przez całą grę (od jej uruchomienie) co nadaje produkcji nietypowy klimat
- Satysfakcjonujący system walki ponieważ chce być jak najbardziej przyjemny i realistyczny
- Muzyka świetnie odzwierciedla znakomicie świat
- Nawet fajny zabieg z kamerą nad którą niema się kontroli
- Poziomy nie są monotonne.

Wady:
- Niektóre elementy gry mają płynność tylko 30 Klatek na sekundę (bardzo rzadki widok)
- Ostatnie dwa rozdziały opowieści delikatnie pobagowane
- Ostatni boss w grze jest bardzo mocno niedopracowany i powinien tracić więcej zdrowie gdy staje się coraz bardziej agresywniejszy z powodu rozbijanego pancerza (ostatni etap walki, atakowanie boss'a po głowie to jakiś koszmar) - Konami naprawcie końcówkę gry, macie kod źródłowy więc ruszcie się i to naprawcie.
- Gra nie pozwala odrazy wyzbierać wszystkich znajdziek ponieważ bohater nie posiada umiejętności którą się dużo później zdobywa
- Przerywniki filmowe mogły być w większej rozdzielczości lub zastąpienie nich przerywnikiem na silniku gry (nie czepiam się przerywników dwóch ostatnich rozdziałów ponieważ się nie zestarzały)
- Odradzam grania na sterowaniu PC gra jest tak skonstruowana, że dobrze się gra tylko na Padzie
- Kto normalny ukrywa Ustawienia Gry i Stan Zapisu w plikach Aplikacji Steam? - To nie jedyny przypadek jaki znam, mogę wymienić jeszcze Lorda of the Fallen.

Ocena końcowa 7/10.

85641519.review:
One of my all time favourite games! A great story with decent characters, awesome voice overs and beautiful environments to enjoy! The action is solid with good depth and dynamics to ensure combat never gets boring. Interesting set pieces...awesome boss fights...it's just great - Well, that was how I felt originally when the game came out over 10 years ago...

It's now 2021 and a lot of games have come out with better character movement, full camera control and mechanics that respect the players intelligence and available time. So...playing this now may result in some frustration. You must employ patience to get through as it will annoy you at times BUT this is purely down to it's age and what knowledge was available at the time. There is still a worthwhile gaming experience to be had here...and it's epic!!

You are going to curse at the camera - Although it can be a beautiful game with some amazing zooming and cinematic angles it can also be the deciding factor over you losing a battle sequence due to it hiding the enemies from your view!!

Puzzles are messy - The first puzzle is one of the trickiest in the whole game!! After that, you complete puzzles without even thinking about them. However, Chapter 7's Electric Laboratory must go down as the worlds most annoying puzzle in an action game. I would gladly stomp on the genitals of the feeble, ignorant tw@t bag that designed it. The same can be said also for Chapter 9's Music Box!!! He had no respect for the players patience and trust me...you will need quite a bit to get through this without your blood boiling!! And then we get to Chapter 11 which contains two cr@ppy puzzles back to back and an environment you randomly teleport around. It's absolute bullsh!t and a real vibe killer kinda similar to the Zen world at the end of Half Life!!!

Boss fights are a lot of fun but you will need to "manage" the camera as best as you can...it's not going to be an issue with every boss...just a few and it's not a huge impact...just noteworthy!

Navigating levels can also be frustrating. If you're like me and want to be sure to see everything a level has to offer then you will have to do some planning as to which path you commit to for progress. Like many games there will always be one path forward for progression and one or two other paths for pickups/items. It's never obvious which one is which...and in some cases if you go the path of story progression by accident without having picked up the items down other paths then you can sometimes be locked out of backtracking. This kills the mood for me when it happens BUT it is due to the games age. Signposting paths and managing the players movement wasn't a priority back when this was released so just be aware that the path you take might close behind you meaning replaying the checkpoint/level are your only options. Not a massive negative point but for 100% runs this will kick you in the balls a bit!!

Player controls are a bit bloated in my opinion to with many buttons doing multiple functions depending on what's happening around you. RT is the most frustrating. You press RT to grab an enemy BUT you also need to press RT to pick items off the floor or interact. SO...an enemy throws a grenade at you whilst another enemy pushes forwards towards you. You want to pickup and throw the grenade so you press RT but that other enemy is now in your face so you grab it instead of the grenade. Having this happen again and again during a fight is pure nightmare fuel and you will scream and shout at your monitor!! It's infuriating how busy the control system is...! And that is only one example...

Tip - Turn on Anisotropic filtering on your graphics card...the game looks a bit nicer with it enabled!!

And this is a long game...it doesn't over stay it's welcome but you won't be finishing it quickly. Completing levels often shows you stats revealing that you've not picked up some items giving you reason to replay. There are even trials that unlock that pose a particular challenge in the level like not using healing items. And the best news is that for a game where you might die a lot...the loading is SUPER fast so retrying a hard section is painless in terms of loading times. I guess the only thing that drags is the story at the end of the game. It just goes on and on and on...not sure if Hideo Kojima's input in this game added to the large number of long cutscenes but it does feel like a Metal Gear Solid game at this point with just an overload of story within cutscenes!! Overall, you're probably looking at anything between 25 and 40 hours for a complete playthrough on Hard depending on how much you back track/replay levels.

8/10 - Just try and be patient...it's a slow start but you will have a great time playing it through til the end. A truly epic adventure...and the sequel is just as good!!

I wanted to like this game, but it turns out that it sucks.

The controls are floaty with very little feedback, the character has annoying recovery times for his moves that leave you vulnerable, the combat and blocking is vague and frustrating, and attacks feel like they have no impact.

I wanted to enjoy this story, I really did, but after a few hours of almost pure frustration, I don't think I want to touch this again. Mind you, I'm not just giving up because I need to "git gud." Darksiders 2 had basically the same combat system, and it was very challenging at multiple parts throughout the game (sometimes even frustrating), but the combat felt so much tighter and intuitive, with great audio and visual feedback that makes it so much more controllable while still presenting a challenge.

The combat, which is the main focus of this game, is pretty much awful. Add in some opaque level design (where you can't see the specific ledge you need to jump to and fall to your death) and mildly infuriating menu prompts (four button presses to restart - why does it default to "No" when it asks if I want to continue?!) that will piss you off after dying 800 times, and this game goes from what could've been a great adventure into an anger-inducing mess.

4/10, pretty game for its time and nice presentation, but I will not waste my time with this.

84554488.review:
After the struggle Konami went through to successfully bring the series to the third dimension -- and a catalog of handheld entries which started to go around in circles -- it was time for MercurySteam to reboot the franchise and give it a breath of fresh air.

- Graphism -
With its gorgeous landscapes highlighted by clever camera works and inspired character designs that makes both new and old faces fit nicely in the universe, the title is a treat for the eyes and rarely ceases to amaze when you reach another location, meet more allies and face foes.

- Gameplay -
The magic battle mechanics are interesting but almost the entirety of your combos has to be purchased -- making you reach your true fighting potential too late in your progression to fully enjoy them during your first journey. Additional puzzles and platforming sequences help giving your adventure more variety.

- Story -
The world you evolve in is made more immersive thanks to knight logs and a bestiary you'll complete on your way to the end. Each level is introduced by a narrated sequence that serves the heroic-fantasy approach the developper were aiming for pretty well. The post-credits cutscene will definitely be the highpoint of your travel.

- Sound -
This is the best and most prestigious voice cast the franchise every had the chance to offer. The soundtrack chose to forget about the gothic influences of its predecessors to deliver an epic orchastral score. SFX is solid enough to make the monsters and environments that surround you believable.

- Replay Value -
Your first playthrough might take about ten hours but returning to previous areas to find every upgrades is advised. Double or triple that play time if you want to unlock all these achievements -- a task that requires a second journey in Transylvania on the hardest difficulty with additional trials to complete.

Fans of previous entries may not find what they were expecting here since familiar elements and characters are not developped as they used to be. It still remains an enjoyable game that can easily be recommended for fans of the heroic-fantasy genre.

OVERALL: 4/5

There’s nothing that Lords of Shadow does that feels all that new or fresh, but what it does offer in terms of recognisable gameplay elements and features are implemented quite well with the focus here placed squarely on being a large scale epic. Not only in terms of story but in giant boss battles that feel like you’re fighting a sentient skyscraper and large castles to explore that feel like they were built for creatures that even giants would consider, well, giant. The musical cues are also quite grand in their introduction during cut-scenes and bombastic during hectic battles, and the voice work by a few seasoned actors, like the aforementioned Patrick Stewart and the somewhat underused Robert Carlyle, is also quite good. So for anyone looking for a solid action game that foregoes the exploration and depth of the recent handheld Castlevania titles, Lords of Shadow comes highly recommended.

83776248.review:
tl;dr - Pretty and mostly good game. Worth grabbing on a sale if you want a nice looking if not mindblowing hack and slash experience. Just don't go in expecting Castlevania and you'll probably have fun if you enjoy this genre.
-
I'm a huge fan of the original Castlevania series, and while this isn't *really* a Castlevania game and does not feel like one it's still a pretty solid and enjoyable title on it's own. 

First off this is set in a completely different universe from the original Castlevania games, the only real callbacks being characters who are named after vaguely similar counterparts in the original series as a homage. For example there's a werewolf named Cornell, but aside from both characters being werewolves he has nothing in common with the Cornell from "Castlevania: Legacy of Darkness" on the N64. 

I have to say that the scenery and overall art direction and graphics are beautiful even over a decade after this game's initial release. The gameplay is mostly fun if not mind blowing. I'm told it's a pretty standard God of War clone gameplay wise, but I'm not familiar enough with that series to say. 

None of the iconic Castlevania music returns in any notable capacity. The music that IS in the game is fine but a year after playing LoS I can't recall a single track as outstanding in my memory the way tracks like "Bloody Tears", "Wicked Child" "The Sinking Old Sanctuary" and so many other songs from the classic series do. (Though in fairness, I did get to experience those songs over multiple games and years.) I'd say the music here is serviceable, it's fine. It sets the mood but doesn't stick with you.

I do have to dock points for the ending though. Most of the game is fun enough, but the true ending to the story is hidden in DLC expansions (thankfully included in this Ultimate Edition) with gameplay I can only describe as unfair and frustrating without being enjoyable. Also the cutscenes in these DLC expansions use a storyboard art style, this art style is actually beautiful and would be fine if it didn't stick out like a sore thumb (both aesthetically and as an obvious cost cutting measure) when contrasted with the cutscenes in the main game. So after beating a couple short but frustrating and unfun expansions the cutscenes for the true ending of LoS' story don't quite match the feel of the main game. These problems aren't enough to sour the whole game in my opinion, but are worth mentioning.

So yeah, if you see it on sale and fancy a hack'n slash I'd say grab it. $30 is a bit much to ask for a game as long in the tooth as this though.

83698337.review:
Disregard my hours played here because I've completed this game several times over on Xbox 360. Now, before we get into the review, it's important I clarify what this game is. This game is a single player Character Action Game in the vein of Devil May Cry or God of War. Please have a look at the following:

1. Fixed camera
2. Linear story progression
3. Only 1 playable character
4. No RPG mechanics, only DMC style upgrades
5. Quick Time Events
6.  Non-canonical story
7. Must play with a controller for a good experience

If you don't care about these things and want to know if this is a good game then the answer is YES. Let me convince you why...

Castlevania LoS feels like a complete experience. Nowhere does this game fall short in delivering its money's worth. The story starts off sort of uninteresting but around chapter 4 it sets a few hooks that will interest you in completing it. The characters are well written and even have stellar voice acting. There's a lot of passion here that really sells the characters and their experiences, even if some of the writing is a bit trite (nothing like hearing "You Lie" delivered like Orlando Bloom).

Gameplay wise there's enough variety in enemies to carry you through the whole game. It's essentially broken up into 3 major Acts with Act 1 being the weakest of the 3. If you don't quite enjoy the first 2 hours of gameplay that's understandable. You're very limited in the beginning and the combat suffers without the added challenge and complexity of later encounters. Don't worry, it will get better around Chapter 4.

Where a lot of reviews really fail is explaining how gorgeous Castlevania is. The team at MercurySteam NAILED the aesthetic of the world and each stage is painstakingly crafted to feel lived in and real. You'll travel through fetid swamps filled with goblins to ancient ruins overlooking a sunken city bathed in a warm shade of sunset. And what Castlevania would be complete without a Castle? Don't worry, this one delivers. Ooooooh does it deliver. Each environment is lovingly crafted and perhaps, imo, is the number 1 reason to play this game. 

Enemy design is stellar too, with each of them fitting a role in their sandbox. You have cannon fodder units, brawlers, large beasts, magic wielders, and puzzle enemies. Each sandbox has their own distinct monsters so you won't get too tired of fighting them. Bosses, however, do vary in their execution. This game has 3 Shadow of the Colossus style bosses that fail to execute that idea. The Colossus of Rhodes is a better attempt than anything seen here. But each of the Lords of Shadow and some of the in-between bosses are fun to fight. It's standard video game boss fare though and won't exactly rock your socks off.

The story is non-canon, but it's one of my favorites from the franchise. Gabriel is a great character who is fun to inhabit but also at times feels off the rails. He's wonderfully voice acted and the animators did a fantastic job selling his emotions during pivotal scenes. Zobek doesn't fare as well. His character model feels....off? Like it didn't get enough polygons to deliver the same level of creativity. But his voice actor is Patrick Stewart so I'll let it pass. The lore of this world is told through notes written by your fellow Templars of the Holy Order. Like the Ninja Scrolls in Ninja Gaiden, these lore tidbits are told from the first person and are well written. Some divulge secrets, some advance the story, and others are clearly jokes put in by the writers.

While the visuals in this game are gorgeous, in 2020 the sound design still reins supreme. From every clank of metal, thunderous thump, and insidious hiss the soundscape never struggles to reel you into the world. The soundtrack is full of bombastic orchestral pieces during fights with somber songs filling in the negative space between. I played this both with headphones and on my 5.1 home theater with RP Klipsch speakers. This game fully utilizes the space of the speakers and fleshes out nicely on a good setup.

If you've read it this far, you're obviously interested. Well, here's my final selling point: flawless performance. This game runs like a dream on most hardware. I used to play it 4k 60fps on a GTX 980 and now, with my latest 34inch monitor with 2070 Super, I play it at 120hFPS 4k locked. Never a dip. graphics settings are barebones though. So I suppose if you're using an intel chip for graphics you will struggle here. There's native 21:9 support for menus AND cutscenes, a rarity even in 2020 (which is a shame, looking at you Cyberpunk 2077).

So, is Lords of Shadow a bad game? No, it's not. It may not be the game most people wanted but for everyone else they've always enjoyed it after I gifted it to them. Buy it on sale as it LITERALLY goes on sale every few months. $7 is a steal.

83511323.review:
The first Castlevania in this new trilogy is... definitely something.
The thing is, when you try to do everything at the same time, nothing is done correctly. That's the case here, unfortunately. This new entry tries to throw references, inspirations, minigames and novelty together, but nothing really works.

What you get is a clone of God of War that sometimes thinks it's Shadow of the Colossus, in the world of Castlevania. All of this cut into about 40 levels that never feel linked together. You spend a level platforming with a couple fights, the next one is a boss, and the one after that will probably be a series of 5 fights and a puzzle. And we repeat that a dozen times...
The many puzzles vary a lot in quality. A few actually make you feel satisfied when you solve them, the great majority are boring and uninspired, and what's left is ridiculous. Poorly explained (when explained), obscure mechanics used once in the whole game, requiring luck... That's not pretty.

If the puzzles were the only issue, it'd still be okay, maybe even good. They're not.
The double magic system is never a success in any game, why try that here ? It's not awful this time, but it's not pleasant to use either. Few combos are actually useful, and apart from a parry that works most of the time, the game end up being a mashfest of X because Y doesn't do any damage. The jumps are really sketchy for a game that relies heavily on those sequences, and once you get the double jump, doodoo hits the fan, as the jumps in the previous levels are not programmed for a character with 2 jumps... Really ?
That's another issue. The game encourages you to revisit levels to get upgrades you couldn't get for dumb reasons. Easiest example : one of the first upgrade is on a rock in the middle of the road, but too high for one jump... And they're all like that. That's not how getting upgrades to have access to new areas work, I'm sorry.

The bosses... Half of them are okay, the other half are in the wrong game. If I wanted to play Shadow of the Colossus, I wouldn't have bought a Castlevania game. An example of a failure : The Stone Titan requires you to stay as far away as possible (?), remain still for about 10 seconds (??), wait for the boss to decide to throw a rock so you can start climbing on him... (???). Yeah, no. That's not a fight.

There's so much more, as well.
Half of the enemies are annoying to fight. Some mechanics required to beat sections or bosses are not explained, and a look at the controls is sometimes no enough. Your starting life is way too low, and special weapons are mostly gadgets. The unblockable attacks are sometimes faster than those you can parry, and take half your life of a fully upgraded bar on harder difficulties. Your life is not replenished in between levels. That makes sense in a classic Castlevania, not in something that's cut into 40 pieces...

There's more, but I think that makes it obvious enough.
If you only play the game once and forget it is supposed to be a Castlevania title, treat it as an action game with too many puzzles, you can have an okay time. You could even potentially give it 6/10 and rate it as "positive". That's when i went for the trials, which I thought could be fun, that I realized all that was wrong and how everything felt sketchy at best. Nothing fully works the way it's meant to, despite some pretty environments. 

I expected a lot more, and couldn't forget I bought a Castlevania game. That's unfortunate, as a new gen Castlevania in 3D had a huge potential. A big disappointment with a lot of ideas that never really work. I'd give it a [b] 5 [/b], but I can't honestly recommend it.

82713007.review:
[h1] Intro [/h1]

Ah, Lords of Shadow. Developed by MercurySteam with help from Climax Studios comes another entry in the storied Castlevania franchise. This one has been compared to God of War, and even Shadow of the Colossus in some of it's boss fights. Does it live up to God of War or other character action titles?

I'd say yeah.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]

The game takes you through various environments that are still pretty stunning today. I really like the art direction, and when the camera zooms out to show you a wide shot of certain vistas, it's very pretty. I do have one small caveat with the graphics though. Sometimes there are video files that seem to be compressed, or taken from the PS3/360 versions of the game, and it's a bit jarring going from a nice fluid cut scene into those. It's not a deal breaker, but I wanted to mention it.
Character models look great, and the environments are beautiful too.

On the PC, the game allows a resolution of up to 1080p, and runs at a silky smooth 60 fps. You can also modify some graphics settings if you can't exactly hit that 60 fps target.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

The game play is fairly standard for these kind of games. You have area attacks and heavy attacks, for multiple foes or just one. You do get some fun moves, but I relied on most of the same combos throughout the game. I also feel like air combat isn't as fluid as in GoW, as most of my moves didn't reliably connect in the air. The parry system is pretty cool though, and the main way you heal or do more damage is neat. You have these two magic meters, one for healing and one for more damage. They can get filled by focus, which is given when you find a fountain, or when you defeat enemies in combat. If you do well in combat, you'll fill up a focus bar which goes down completely on one hit. This is used to gain focus orbs on each subsequent hit on enemies, so having a full focus bar and using AoE attacks is a great way to gain magic. I do wish the focus bar only went down a little bit on hit, or at least maybe halfway. Doing different combos is a great way to fill up the focus meter quicker, which means more healing energy or more damage dealing depending on the situation. To aid you in combat, you also have sub weapons such as daggers or holy water. They are very useful, and can definitely help you get out of a bad situation. The daggers though are really only useful the early game, as most of the other monsters you face are resistant to them.

This game also takes inspiration from Uncharted in it's climbing and platforming sections. These are fun for brief respite between combat arenas, though some of them do take a while to get through. I did have some trouble where Gabriel wouldn't grab the ledge, and that caused some deaths. You also have to solve various puzzles throughout the adventure, and if you complete you'll get experience which you can use to upgrade Gabriel's abilities. The puzzles are all pretty good, and some of them really make you think.

[h1] Music / Replay Value [/h1]

The music in the game is very great, and while the songs aren't what you'd call catchy, they do an excellent job of keeping you invested in the world and story. The game also offers collectibles for you to find in the form of health and magic upgrades, and sub weapon upgrades for some slight replay value in the levels. Speaking of replay value, there isn't just the upgrades to collect. Each level has a trial you can complete, which is used to fill up your completion percentage. For more replay value, you can also finish each level on the hardest difficulty, which is only available after finishing the story.

[h1] Story [/h1]

The story in the game is actually pretty good, albeit the ending is pretty confusing where the main character kinda changes personality abruptly. To put it simply, you play as Gabriel Belmont, a warrior for the Brotherhood of Light out on a quest to defeat the Lords of Shadow, and to find a mask that is said to be able to bring back dead people. It has some great voice acting, and the cut-scenes are well directed too. The story has some big twists and turns, and all in all was pretty good. Nothing amazing, but it does it's job well.

[h1] DLC [/h1]

The Ultimate Edition of LoS comes with the two DLC chapters (Reverie and Resurrection). I won't spoil anything related to the story, but I'm glad they are here. The boss in Resurrection offers a nice challenge, and it's nice re-visiting an older area in Reverie again. The only real complaint I had with the DLC is the cut scenes. Due to budgets, the cut scenes are offered in a unique comic book style. It works most of the time, though when it tries to portray action, it's pretty hard to understand what's going on as the animation isn't super fluid.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

This was a long review, but hopefully it helps you decide whether you want this game or not. At $30, I'd say it's worth it as I played for almost 30 hours and that was collecting all of the upgrades and completing the game on Normal. I did get it on sale though, so maybe wait for that.

It's a very standard linear western hack & slash with an slightly medieval dark fantasy setting.
The combat presents an interesting dynamic of gaining health by doing damage when using light magic (but light magic depletes with time, regardless if you regain health or not), or getting refilling the magic bar by hitting multiple times without being hit.
This makes the combat to constantly alternate between an offensive style (when using magic and trying to gain health) and defensive style (when trying to get magic by hitting without being hit), and this keeps the combat engaging.
 It also has some cleaver puzzles and platforming sections.

78976348.review:
A really disappointing, boring and tedious game.

It is initially presented as a hack & slash game, but you spend most of your time doing platforming, solving puzzles and watching long cutscenes. The worst thing is that the platforming is not hard or challenging, it is easy, but really tedious, having long jumping sequences and some stages with platforms moving too slow (as if they were really trying to prolong the time of gameplay), like in the clocktower. Even some bosses consist in around 90% platforming, like the giant ones and the dragon... They are tremendously boring "battles" where you have to be climbing slowly trying to get to certain weak spots which you can hit, while the enemy is trying to throw you out so you restart the whole climbing again (I just can't describe in words how boring were those fights).

The puzzle sections could be interesting for some people who likes this kind of thing, but this is not what a Castlevania game is supposed to be like, and for me it was mostly easy or tedious (the music box stage is just awful).

Talking about the cutscenes section... it is exaggeratedly prolonged. At the start they seemed pretty well done and sometimes interesting, but there are just a lot of them (and sometimes, after finish one, you play for less than a minute before the next one starts). So I got easily tired (I still watched them all).

The combat system could be good (and, actually, should be), but there are more than a couple of things that just don't work here (and I am talking of my experience of playing the game on hard difficulty). First of all, the fixed camera, which you can't change, makes the fighting too uncomfortable (and sometimes, even exploring doesn't feel right) and in some fights it picks a really weird angle to be fixed, making easy for enemies to hide from your sight. Also, the game is really trying to make you use jumping in your combos, with a lot of attacks requiring to be mid-air, and, to be honest, they would look pretty cool, but the problem is that you can't move/dash in the middle of an air combo, and almost every enemy has an attack that will hit you in the air, so you will get a lot of damage if you try them. I actually died a lot of times at the start when I went for this, but the game became a lot easier when I stopped trying combos that included jumping. This will make that the fights will be mostly about striking and dashing, which, after some chapters will do the combat section very boring. Also the hitboxes with which the enemies hit you is broken, particularly with bosses; they can make a punch while standing in the ground, with you in mid-air, and they will hit you; sometimes they do a dash attack that doesn't get even close to you, but they wil hit you; and sometimes they will do a swing that doesn't reach you, but it will hit you anyways (and I realized because there is a slow-motion sequence with the attack that killed you).

On the other hand, one of the worst things in the game are the quick time events (QTE), particularly in boss fights. You can be kicking a boss's ass, then, at some points, a cutscene will start, and you will have to be really careful, because at some point there will be a quick time event (sometimes even 20 seconds after the cutscene started, maybe trying to catch you off guard, so it is really hard to actually focus on what is going on in the cutscene... You just don't want to miss the QTE), and if you miss it... you will get damage (sometimes you will die) and the boss will get his/her hp back... for some reason, forcing you to basically restart the battle with less hp. That is annoying and doesn't have any sense at all. It is particularly annoying with the giant bosses, because there is a really long way until you can hit a weak spot, and it can take more than a few minutes, so starting that all over can be really frustrating.

Finally, the dlc... This is just worse than the main game (unless you actually liked the game). They just got rid of all the battle sequences, and gave you some stages filled with platforming and puzzles, and some sections where you can control a new character, who is the most monotonous character you can ask in a hack & slash game (it only has 2 attacks, and no combo's variations). There is a hide and seek section and it ends with an awful boss fight (full of QTE).

So... What is good about the game? Graphics are pretty good. I would have really liked to play the first Darksiders with this graphic's quality. Also, even if there is a lot of tiresome stuff in this game, some fights can be good, like one against the male vampire boss (which I would have enjoyed greatly, until the QTE started), but still not good enough to recommend this game. And, finally, for some reason I really liked the cutscene that comes after you finish the main game... It actually made me consider playing the next game.

In summary, I don't recommend it at all, unless you don't like hack & slash games and you are looking for some 3d puzzle platformer... or you are just looking for a really different kind of hack & slash. For me it is a 2.5/10. Really bad game (probably it would have been a 4/10 without the dlc).

The game flops at some major points:

On the top of that, Zobek's final dialog to Gabriel was like out of some morning cartoon show, it was so cheaply written that it felt like a parody. Marie's final goobye was also written like it wasn't taken seriously. These were the games's closing moments that the majority of the people will remember.

4. The two DLC feels like it was designed to be as boring and drawn out to suck off your time as much as  possible to probably justify the price for it, when it was sold as a separate DLC.

In short: the game starts strong, the middle part is all fun and good, then the ending fell into it's own piss and couldn't get up. I loved this game as a kid, but as a 28 years old grown ass man, I can see it has major cracks.  Still could recommend it if you can buy it on a sale.

Lords of Shadow is an unnecessary product compare to the Classic series. It would have been great if they would follow the Classic route for this game. But for some reason, they did not and story-wise, it is disappointing.  Therefore the story was turning me down. Fortunately, the designs they made for the game were the biggest reason that make me to playing it.

Gameplay mechanics were at least playable. There were so many lacking things but in general, it had an enjoyable hack and slash sense. It was not a God of War in combat system but better than Darksiders. Special moves and skills would work much better if they would increase the number of variations. This is one of the general problems of the game. The Classic series was known for having so many skill and item options. Even if you were a Belmont and your primary weapon was the Vampire Killer whip, it would still give you many other weapons to use. The choices were so many and you could build up your character with attributes by choices. And this game wasn't even bothered with something like that. Thanks KONAMI.

I think the most hated thing by the fans was skipping Metroidvania elements. Castlevania was meant something and KONAMI ruined it by this game. Symphony of the Night was a revolutionary work in the 90s. Because there was a great improvement between Classicvanias and Metroidvanias. These two genres were different but you could see the elements in Metroidvania that were inherited by Classicvanias. Although it was new. You could say "I am playing a Castlevania game." There was connected progress. As I am telling you until this point, this game is not a Castlevania game. It is just a good copy of other hack and slashes. So yeah, if you want a good hack and slash then you can freely buy this game. But if it is a Castlevania game that you want to play, be careful you are in the wrong place.

[h1]Gabriel, contigo empezó todo[/h1]

Siempre me he considerado un gran seguidor de la serie Castlevania, por lo menos de los primeros de ellos. Bien es cierto que luego me despegué de esa saga al pasarme al mundo del PC, pero hay determinadas cosas que nunca se olvidan.

Siempre quedará en mi memoria ese magnífico e innovador juego llamado Castlevania II: Simon’s Quest, con su increíble ciclo de día y noche que me dejó con la boca abierta allá por 1987, y auténtico precursor del género metroidvania por mucho que Castlevania: Symphony of the Night y su creador, Toru Hagihara, quieran erigirse como creadores del mismo DIEZ años después. 

Sí, en efecto, fue Hitoshi Akamatsu el primero en dar forma a un modo de comprender las plataformas y la acción de un modo totalmente innovador. Y todo aquel que lo haya jugado sabrá de sobra que esto es así y que Simon’s Quest es un metroidvania de manual, en 1987, ojo. Aunque fue Symphony of the Night realmente el que impulsó y dio a conocer al gran público este género que hoy en día puede que esté en su mejor momento.

¿Por qué es esto importante y que tiene que ver con Lords of Shadow? A priori podría parecer que nada, pero realmente tiene mucho que ver. 

Cuando empecé a jugar a Lords of Shadow mi decepción fue brutal, para qué negarlo. Castlevania siempre fue una saga que tenía una personalidad propia, una que todos querían copiar o imitar, pero en el caso de Lords of Shadow esto no fue así. Realmente Lords of Shadow es un juego que quiere imitar a otros, especialmente a God of War, y eso provoca que por el camino se pierda mucho de su esencia. 

¿Lo convierte eso en un mal juego? Realmente no, pero todo lo que hizo grande a Castlevania no está aquí, no aparece por ningún lado y no se le espera. Salvo por el apellido Belmont y el lore poco más, aunque eso no es poco y además en ese aspecto supera con creces a lo visto en anteriores Castlevania.

Teniendo eso bien claro, el juego si hace algunas cosas realmente bien. La saga Castlevania siempre ha sido un icono dentro del mundo de los videojuegos, pero ni tenía el mejor de los argumentos, ni su lore era para tirar cohetes, eso seguro. En ambos casos eran bastante planos a partes iguales. En Lords of Shadow esto cambia para mejor. 

Sin duda, una de las mejores cosas que tiene este título es la manera que tiene de contarnos las cosas, muy detalladamente, y el magnífico lore del que hace gala.

Podrás leer toda la información detallada sobre los personajes de la historia, los monstruos, las armas, los lugares, etc.. y todo no hace sino engrandecer aún más la experiencia y convertirlo en algo realmente completo.

A su vez, la ambientación es magnífica, con unos parajes muy bien representados a los que siempre acompañará una banda sonora muy bien seleccionada y que imprime grandes momentos a todo lo que estemos viviendo.

Además, su duración es realmente notoria, mucho más que en cualquier otro juego de la saga, pudiendo alargarse durante decenas de horas si queremos explorarlo todo y descubrir todos sus secretos. Durante todo ese tiempo iremos descubriendo las motivaciones del personaje, sus conflictos internos y sus anhelos que no parecen llegar a cumplirse. En este aspecto, la experiencia es realmente fantástica.

En lo tocante a su parte más puramente jugable, el juego pasa directamente a ser un hack n’ slash, muy palomitero en algunos momentos y con grandes dosis de acción que, si bien tocan levemente el género de las plataformas, no lo hace del todo bien y además están excesivamente prefabricadas.

Realmente el juego es un hack n’ slash en toda regla, con sus inmensos jefes finales esperándonos al final de cada episodio, y no es que lo haga mal, pero se siente a algo ya visto con anterioridad. Realmente hay más cosas positivas que negativas en su aspecto jugable, pero eso no quita para que haya determinadas cosas que chirríen bastante. 

Por ejemplo, el número de paredes invisibles es ABRUMADOR, así como los entornos pasillescos, de los que se abusa sobremanera. Pero lo peor de todo, y con diferencia, es su cámara.

Lords of Shadow usa una cámara fija en un entorno de acción en 3D, lo cual es, básicamente, una estupidez, ya que nos dejará vendidos en más de una ocasión porque no pocas veces no veremos a los enemigos que nos atacan desde atrás, así como el mismo entorno que nos bloqueará la visión. En serio, en algunos momentos puede ser MUY molesta.

Afortunadamente, para la lucha con los jefes finales la cámara si se podrá girar, lo cual es muy de agradecer, pero es difícil entender por qué no se utilizó para todo el juego. Lo más probable es que esto fuera así para tapar todas las costuras gráficas y de diseño, si no, no hay otra explicación lógica.

A día de hoy, la calidad gráfica sigue siendo bastante potable, y soporta resoluciones hasta 4K sin problema alguno, aunque la calidad de las cinemáticas ya es otro cantar, ya que están en 720 con un aliasing que da más miedo que cualquier enemigo al que podamos enfrentarnos. Sin embargo, es algo totalmente secundario a efectos de diversión.

En definitiva, Lords of Shadow está lejos de ser el mejor Castlevania que haya jugado, pero sí es el que mejor lore tiene y el que tiene mejor argumento e historia. Ambos elementos ayudan tremendamente a querer seguir la trama y saber cómo acaba todo, independientemente de que su jugabilidad esté algo “empacada” y que el sistema de cámara pueda provocar más de una frustración.

Si buscas un título que albergue grandes dosis de acción, mucho lore y una buena historia, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow seguro que te dejará totalmente satisfecho y colmará todas tus expectativas, o al menos, la mayor parte de ellas.

77453449.review:
This game gets a bad rep for not being a proper Castlevania game and a God of War clone. I think it's fair to say that these things are broadly true. However, it is also one of the most genuinely beautiful and enjoyable games I had ever played when it first came out in 2010, and I am pleased to say I enjoy it now as well, even if I need a plug-in controller to play it well.

The combat, exploration and puzzle-solving, if you're used to God of War style combos and movement, should all be familiar. It has the same system of fixed cameras and spectacle fighting, where more upgrades are found through play and more moves and combos are bought from a menu. I find the controls solid and enjoyable, even as someone who is useless at pulling off complex combos and resort to basic attacks for the most part.

Where is this game truly shines the brightest, and where it won me over, was in the presentation. A combination of genuinely gorgeous and enthralling environmental artistry, interesting and varied enemy designs, and a soundtrack with which to emphasise these qualities as needed. Oscar Araujo's compositions range from haunting to bombastic, and several have stuck with me since I first heard them.

If you're looking for an experience which cleaves more towards Castlevania, this game probably isn't for you. If you want a beautiful, engaging, and detailed hack-and-slash action game with a sense of tragic adventure and a large world you travel through from level to level, you'll probably have a very good time with Lords of Shadow.

77002486.review:
Excelente 9/10

Este juego tiene una jugabilidad genial, en cuanto al hack n slash no se diferencia en casi nada, pero la aventura en si es una maravilla. Las habilidades son geniales, y la construcción es excelente, adoro la forma de entrar a cada escenario y poder regresar de vez en cuando para obtener alguna recompensa oculta. Lo jugué en modo paladín y la cámara en ningún momento me afectó en los combates y puedo decir que jamás sentí que fueran injustos aunque si complicados. [Para desbloquear la dificultad paladín pueden hacerlo con Cheat Engine]
Los puzzles y la recolección de gemas y pergaminos vuelven el juego super satisfactorio y expanden el universo.
Me gustó que no haya un "menu principal" como tal, sino un libro al que puedes recurrir en cualquier momento.
Los gráficos son excelentes y en esta época se estaba llegando hasta el punto de no poder aportar ya casi nada en este apartado.
El juego nos cuenta básicamente la historia de Gabriel y su conversión. De ahí en fuera no aporta nada en absoluto, mas bien perfecciona todos los apartados y consigue esta super obra.
La música va acompañar toda la aventura, es bastante buena aunque nada para resaltar
Los escenarios son por mucho lo mejor del juego. Se ve que fue uno de los puntos mejor trabajados durante el desarrollo. Realmente se sienten mundos bastante bien conseguidos y planificados. En mi opinión es mucho mas difícil conseguir escenarios como los de este juego que los aburridos escenarios de los sandbox.
La historia es bastante buena y te mantendrá interesado.


No me gustó que la dificultad Paladín estuviera bloqueada desde el principio. Tuve que desbloquearla con Cheat Engine para poder disfrutar el juego al máximo. Adoro que me den de palos xD.
A veces el autosave te cae un poco mal, sobre todo si quieres regresarte a ver una zona por la que no pasaste.

No puedo decir que es una joya, pues siento que tendría que innovar un poco cuanto menos. Pero eso no lo hace un mal juego y recomiendo altamente jugarlo. El juego tiene una duración de 50 horas en modo paladín. Las cuales disfruté muchísimo. No entiendo por qué la gente se queja tanto de este título es de mis favoritos.

PS. No entiendo por qué konami decidió aumentarle la clasificación metiendo un desnudo que no aportaba absolutamente NADA, como empresa ridículo!

I was a little disappointed by this game. Firstly, it's a little too driven by cinematics. I do love a good cinematic but this game goes a little overboard. It seems like every few minutes there's a cutscene and I just want to play the game, which is a far cry from old-school Castlevania games which were mostly action and not so much about story development.

I didn't get a chance to play much of this one before I just got over it but I think it speaks to the games lousy type of gameplay. It's kind of a new age game where it feels like the game is doing the playing for me rather than me making split second decisions to ensure survival. The game kind of forces you into a route to choose and if you don't abide by that pre-made decision, you cannot win the battle. 

I did like some of the lore that the game provided and some of the artwork looked cool but it honestly seemed more concerned with the dazzle than the actual gameplay. If you're okay with a game deciding what you should do an enjoy constant cut scenes for story development, a la the latest God of War, you may like this one, otherwise, you spend your money on something else like the old-school Castlevania.

76485342.review:
Lords of Shadow is the second attempt at a Castlevania origin story. 
Gabriel Belmont journeys out across the land to avenge the Death of his wife at the hands of the Lords of Shadow. The fact that this will also cleanse the land of their evil influence is somewhat secondary. Although far from Shakespeare, it does manage to keep the gameplay flowing, even if it is extremely predictable. Wait, the guy stalking me while saying I'm “a beautiful dark engine of vengeful destruction” is the bad guy? say it ain't so! 
The DLC chapters included try to bridge the ending and epilogue, explaining where Dracula got his powers, but not his grudge. Visually this decade old game still looks and sounds great. Especially the Vampire castle looks fantastic, and you feel at home once you check into Wygol village. 
On the down side, you can tell this game’s age by the QuickTime event spam. Titan sized boss battles inspired by “Shadow of the colossus” are a pain, and some of the puzzles just pad the playtime needlessly. outside of combat, you find yourself wrestling with the controls instead of demons. The Last three chapters (originally DLC ) especially are “throw-your-controller” levels of frustrating. 
Combat on the other hand works fairly well, doing a competent job of cloning “God of War”. In fact, outside of the visuals, that is probably the only reason to get this game, since it is the closest thing outside of emulation to playing that Sony exclusive title.
Overall, it is a nice looking “retro” game to pick up at a heavy discount, but not full price.

There's a point in this game where you have to collect coloured shards in a maze. The maze is made much more mazey by the constantly flipping perspectives. After going around the maze a few times you realise it's actually quite a small and simple area, but the camera angles make it 3.8 billion times more confusing than it actually is, in terms of physical layout. There are lots of werewolves and a troll you need to jump on the back of to crash through a pillar. I've done this, multiple times. However, I'm always a shard short and I keep dying at different, random points. And whenever I die, I lose another shard. I lost track long, long ago of which shards I needed to find, and the pillar thingy resets every time.
So I just stopped playing, because this area now bores me absolutely rigid and I cannot be bothered finding the shards again. And again.
And that's this game in a nutshell.

76080471.review: TL;DR: Save your money or donate it to charity.  Watch the Netflix series instead.Reviews giving this praise are most likely from those with low expectations, little gaming experience, or whose entire concept of gaming revolves around Assassins Creed.  This game is mediocre at best.  If there was a neutral option, I would give it.  The reviews stating that the game looks good visually are correct, especially for a 2010 game.  However, the controls are inconsistent and buggy (I can't count how many times my character would jump right after a respawn) making levels like Music Box just abhorrent, the camera is unacceptable for anything made after 1999, some of the voice acting is just atrocious (about on par with "WHAT IS A MAN?!"), player experience is a catastrophe (must watch cut scenes over again unless you go into the menu and select skip - 3 button presses that can't be "mashed" through just to skip), music is misleading and bland (battle music continues), the puzzles aren't hard just cryptic for no reason, and the story is just average.Overall it feels like an unfinished game, worthy of early access... even 10 years on.  Do not spend the $29.99 asking price for this game, it's simply not worth it.  It may have been worth $30 in 2010 and maybe $15 today (2020), but I would suggest getting it for $10 or less.  If you absolutely must know the story despite all of this, watch the GamerThumb videos on the red and white play button site, skip this, and save yourself some money for beer or smoke.  Both of which would improve the enjoyment of this game marginally at most.This game could have been saved by relatively simple changes that the developers just didn't take the time to include.  It's clear that Konami have no interest in continuing the original storyline in a respectable manner, and this series is proof of that.  That's really sad.

74054253.review:
The worst part of this game is the frequent forced shifting of the camera, which is linked to how the path will shift back and forth through the 3-d environment so you're always mostly just moving forward and back with left and right being only useful for combat (and the occasional forks in the path),  

The only thing this game has in common with other Castlevania games is using a whip as your main weapon, and making a handful of powerups that only accessible with skills from later levels. You play as some human (not connected with the Belmonts), fighting mostly werewolves. 

If that weren't bad enough, it feels like it was written for or by some church group. You play as a christian monk trying to break a spell that's cut earth off from heaven. Combat, while not uncommon, consists of fairly short battles in specific areas, against a set number of enemies. Much of the challenge seems to be focused on the platforming and figuring out how to reach a certain ledge or other point of interest.

Castlevania is probably my favourite video game series, besides Bioshock of course.

While this game has its many flaws, I still love it for what it is. It was originally going to be a completely different game without the Castlevania lore and it does feel like that at times. There are some parts in the game where it slows down and the puzzles feel a bit tedious but, overall the game is near perfect. It has some of the best music I have ever heard in a game, besides Bioshock of course. The world is beautiful, and I absolutely love that they retained the MetroidVania mechanics in a 3D Castlevania game. It is still in my top 10, after all the Bioshock games.

I just wish I could get into the sequel, but it honestly doesn't feel like the same game. I'll have to try again, one day.

9.999/10

73684018.review: First and foremost this is Castlevania. Are you a fan of Castlevania games? If you are, you will really like this game. If you have not played a castlevania game before then consider this a beautiful gothic-dark fantasy 3rd person action adventure game with vampires and werewolves that you will probably like a lot. This is very far from a generic god of war clone as some will say. From a castlevania fan's point of view this is an amazing game. The visuals are amazing. The characters models and the environment are full of detail, the scenery is always something to stare at and the special effects are colorful and vibrant as they should. There is a huge variety of environments so nothing seems as if you've seen it before. The sound is crystal with an awesome orchestrical soundtrack (typical castlevania quality) and the voice-overs featuring Patrick Stewart and Robert Carlyle speak for themselves. The gameplay is excellent. It combines fighting, platforming, puzzle-solving together and it's varied enough that never bores. The fighting itself is deep and rewarding. No more mindless button mashing. The game is very immersive and features a beautiful story. Another big plus for this game is its length. Quite honestly I don't understand what people want in a game any more. This is a beautiful game apparently made with love and care (cheesy but true) and every attention to detail as possible from people who really like the original castlevania games. Yet you will see reviews talking about how it doesn't feel like a castlevania game (not true IMHO) or how it borrows elements from other games. This is value for money and a lot of fun, highly recommended

73234803.review:
I'm sorry, but this game absolutely failed to entice me. It's a poorly implemented God of War clone. While God of War didn't start this particular gameplay style, it made it popular, and it's clear this game tried to cash in on that popularity, but its combat isn't nearly as visceral and satisfying, and its level design is bland and forgettable. Plus, it's completely linear. It doesn't feel like a Castlevania at all, even if you only take the classics into account.

But even if not compared to previous games in the franchise, it falls flat. It has a ridiculous excess of storytelling, but it's all just so painfully boring and uninteresting, even with Patrick Stewart himself as the narrator.

I don't know, maybe it gets better later, but I shouldn't have to waste the time in a game whose first hour has left me drowsy from boredom.

73228637.review:
"Castlevania" is a highly influential franchise in the history of gaming. So much so that there's an entire genre named after it and "Metroid": Metroidvania is a term used to describe games with a heavy focus on unlocking new areas through power-ups and backtracking. With that said, however, "Lords of Shadow" is distinctively not a Metroidvania game. Because by the time of its release, it mutated into something completely different.

"Lords of Shadow" really is a "God of War" game, with the occasional "Shadow of the Colossus" bosses here and there. It became a linear hack-and-slash with a heavy focus on combos and platforming: a game trying to be relevant for its time. Of course the game tries to maintain some of its DNA alive: there's some backtracking, to be sure. But the world you navigate in is not a series of places that seamlessly lead to each other; it's really a set of separate levels. Besides, backtracking is limited merely to the collecting of more power-ups, rather than unlocking new levels and such: it's not mandatory for progression. So the game does have a Metroidvania element, but it's faint, and it's there much more for a matter of keeping some sort of identity for the series.

So this is a game that heavily departs from its predecessors, trying its hand at different ideas. And from my part, it succeeds with flying colours... but it's not without its flaws.

The game has this old-fashioned fixed camera gameplay, in the sense that you have no control whatsoever over it. When you go from one area to another, the camera may abruptly change to such an angle that your character's movement will change suddenly: this is a big reason why games today don't have that sort of camera anymore. It's not as frustrating because this doesn't happen in combat, but it happens in exploration. On top of that, the fixed camera makes certain areas difficult to read, and it also doesn't help in precise platforming, which you'll be doing a lot in the game.

Since you can't control the camera, which is historically a function delegated to the mouse, developers must have imagined there would be no use for the mouse. So the game has no mouse support even at menus. The key mapping is all set for the keyboard by default, and it feels incredibly cumbersome to use the keyboard for everything. Thankfully, you can customise the controls to include the mouse buttons, and to make for something more intuitive. But then again, having a controller is always preferable.

Many times you'll be facing multiple enemies at once, but it lacks a lock on mechanic which could have been really helpful. You can dodge and block enemy attacks, and if you time your blocks right, you can cause your adversaries to drop their guards, oddly similarly to "Sekiro". The game is full of different kinds of enemies, and they require different tactics to be better taken down: for example, silver daggers are great against werewolves. At higher difficulties, enemy behaviour and resistance won't change, but they'll definitely inflict more damage. Some bigger enemies can be stunned and then mounted for the proposes of opening or making new paths. The more you kill your foes, the more points you gain, being able to unlock new moves.

Some combos are pretty effective, but there's no way you'll memorise everything. You'll just keep up with some of them, and most of the times, you'll be just button-mashing, getting some combos by chance. There's also the medallions, which will prove essential for combat: when activated, the blue one restores you health with hits, while the red one increases your attack power considerably. The game is also filled with quick-time events - at first they don't seem so bad, but it doesn't take long before they overstay their welcome and start becoming annoying.

As I said, the game is really this linear set of levels - each with its collectables. Once you complete a level, you'll unlock a trial mode for it, which was perhaps meant to make second runs more interesting. But I found myself just repeating a level I just concluded to beat the trial already - I would have much preferred if such trials were available from the moment you access the levels. Such trials are mostly quite fun, but some are frustrating and downright broken: at one point, the game asked me to dispose of more enemies than it could provide, and the solution for that would be to reload a checkpoint.

You'll also come across some puzzles, and while some are pleasant enough and very satisfying to solve, others are really strange. You don't even know how they work, let alone how to solve them. But they'll only make for a small part of the game, and besides, you'll usually find a scroll near them with the solution, which you can unlock by the cost of the puzzle's reward.

"LoS" is a reboot of the franchise, more or less introducing a new continuity for the series. The game is narrated by the one and only Patrick Stewart, and unlike in "The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion" (another game from the XBox 360 era that I'm also currently revisiting), this is not a mere cameo. Your character however is voiced by Robert Carlyle, who brings a lot of gravitas to what could have been an otherwise unremarkable playable protagonist.

The visuals are just splendid. This is a 2010 game that looks amazingly well even today. However, many of the cutscenes are pre-rendered and sometimes very long, and you can't easily skip them: you have to confirm you want to skip the scene! The orchestral soundtrack by Óscar Araujo is wonderfully arranged, even if a bit generic and repetitive. The game is very polished and well presented, and you can see it was a big investment from Konami, before it descended into a crappy publisher desecrating its own IPs.

As its title suggests, this is an expanded edition, with all the original DLCs included. The base game is already pretty extensive, and there are two extra levels adding a bit more to the journey. And with all its collectables and achievements, it will keep completionists occupied for a fair amount of time. 

The game generated a sequel which I never bothered to play due to its bad word-of-mouth and scourging reviews. Regardless of what, "Lords of Shadow" surely is a hell of a good time. Its positive aspects far outweigh its issues, and it was, in many ways, the last noteworthy game in the franchise.

72977784.review:
There is a lot of great stuff about this game and an almost equal amount of frustration and questionable design choices. Let me be clear that I am not a particularly good action game kind of guy but I like Castlevania and the mythos behind it all. I was determined to play through this because I wanted to see how the story played out, but man, that was grueling.

The game is beautiful and is full of jaw-dropping vistas and locations. I liked all the character and monster designs too. Gorgeous. But the jumping puzzles...oh God...the jumping puzzles. I fell to my death time and time again trying to nail jumps. The camera is normally decent but at times it is really hard to tell where I would land or where I even needed to try and go. This becomes worse as the game goes on. Difficulty for some people was sheer frustration for me.

If you dig hard games and want to search around to find every little secret, this game is your sweet cake. I'm glad I played it but I'll never go back again unless I really want to inflict pain on myself but don't want to have physical scars to show for it. 

Why:
Chupacabra. Why is this in the game? "Hey, wouldn't players love to lose all of their tools and have to do a fetch/puzzle quest to get their stuff back so they can continue?" "First of all, promoted! Second of all, let's have this happen multiple times!"

Quick-time puzzles. There are a lot of these in various forms. Failure often leads to instant death and having to redo a chunk of the level to see if you can hit the .2 second window. It gets brutal and downright mean.

But Patrick Stewart is in it. That pushes my review from negative over to positive.

Con Castlevania LoS me pasa lo mismo que con Darksiders: ¿por qué jugarlo cuando puedo elegir la fuente original en la que se basa? Si Darksiders era Zelda + God of War, Castlevania es God of War + Uncharted. Y no lo hace mal, es un juego competente pero inocuo. Prefiero rejugarme GoW 2 que es excelente en todo que echar las horas en una imitación correcta pero sin alma. 

Es una lástima, porque visualmente es impresionante y la banda sonora es fantástica. Pero el combate sin fuerza y la cámara traicionera (ríete tu de los DMC) no ayudan a mantener el interés. No voy a decir si es mejor o peor Castlevania, no soy experto en la saga, pero es una lástima perder su ambientación gótica por una de fantasía genérica y meterle un ritmo tan frenético a un juego que ganaría enteros con exploración y backtracking no tan ligero y de postín. 

Castlevania LoS no es mal juego en absoluto, pero no veo ningún interés en seguir jugandólo. Es un juego sin un foco concreto que se borra de tu mente en cuanto cierras sesión.

72444014.review:
First of all, you absolutely have to play this with a controller. I played this years ago with K+M, when I didn't have a controller—it is possible, but it is absolutely frustrating, infuriating and nearly making me give up. With a controller, it's not only possible, but becomes a game you can get to 100%.

I never played any of the original Castlevania games, so can't compare, but I believe it's an origin story.

The pseudo-isometric semi-dynamic view in a in a game that relies on timing in combat and platforming wasn't probably the best choice... that said, it does function and does the job. The platforming can be frustrating, and so can some pointless and painful trials. 
It does contain QTEs, but I'd say they are on the more acceptable side of this plague of gameplay mechanics.

The learning curve is quite decent; once you get to the end, you will be able to handle nearly anything on a first try, or don't have to try quite so many as when you started. I love the implementation of the highest difficulty—you finish the game, it gets unlocked and you can replay everything with all your abilities and upgrades you already collected.

The puzzles are generally good. Nothing too complicated, but nothing insultingly simple either.

Some bad decisions were made though:
- Putting cinematic behind a checkpoint (not the other way around like it should be)
- Unnecessary semi-cinematic views that you can't skip, but are stupidly long and pointless.
- Unnecessarily convoluted climbing paths—you can't just go straight up/down, you have to do a climb in a shape of capital letter G, in a 3x3m area. That doesn't equal fun gameplay, that equals a waste of time.
- When you die and are offered to restart from checkpoint, the option selected by default is "no"
- Claudia character, that—although mute—won't shut up and keeps on explaining the most basic math problems, like you are a 3-yo child.
