70869449.review:
[h1][i]”A storm is coming. Mankind faces ruin and despair. The world is changing, yet hope remains in the hearts of the people.”[/i][/h1]
[i]Castlevania: Lords of Shadow[/i] is a third-person action-adventure game that is very similar to the early [i]God of War[/i] games, just with a slightly different main weapon, the Combat Cross; a retractable chain whip that has many uses when handling enemies and level obstacles. I never played the old Castlevania games, so I won’t be doing any comparisons between them. 

[h3]Pros[/h3]
✔️ Good Story with interesting side characters.
✔️ The combat is fun, with lots of abilities and combos to learn.
✔️ Puzzles can be challenging.
✔️ Great variety of enemies.
✔️ Excellent boss fights.
✔️ Replayablility (trials).
✔️ Fun DLCs that have challenging puzzles and boss fights.
✔️ The game is visually Impressive, with lots of areas to explore.
✔️ Character models look excellent.
✔️ The game is well-optimized
✔️ Mostly great and memorable soundtrack.

[h3]Cons[/h3]
❌ The protagonist is bland and generic.
❌ Level Design needs some work.

[h1]Story[/h1]
You control Gabriel Belmont, a member of the Brotherhood of Light, who found that his wife was murdered recently. Your goal is basically to destroy an ancient order, known as the Lords of Shadow, to bring her back to life and save the world from darkness. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2123469352

Most of the characters in this game are interesting, mysterious and intriguing. On the other hand, Gabriel has very little personality; he is a generic protagonist with his cliche one-liners that you see in other games. It is until you play the DLCs where his character is more fleshed out.

The game has a total of 12 chapters (including the DLC), which include over 40 levels. Each level in this game usually takes about 10-20 minutes to complete, so you will be seeing a lot of loading screens. However, the story and writing overall were good enough to keep me intrigued till the end.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[u]Combat:[/u] 
Your main weapon is the [b]Combat Cross[/b], a retractable chain whip that can hit enemies from a great distance (very similar to the old [i]God of War[/i] games and especially [i]Darksiders 3[/i]). You will be earn new abilities and throwables while you progress that make the combat much more varied and engaging. 

You can also perform awesome finishing moves on enemies which vary from one enemy to another. QTEs and button mashing are also a common occurence; during kill animations, while solving puzzles, when operating a mechanism and sometimes during cutscenes. The QTEs were easy to execute and didn't bother me much.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2123469149

You earn points from slaying enemies and solving puzzles, which you can spend on learning new combos and skills. You will also obtain two types of medallions later in the story; one of which inflicts more damage to enemies while the other replenishes your health by attacking them. 

You can check all combos and skills in the menu, as each one has its own simple animated video that shows what happens when you do it ingame. The only issue I have with the combat is that the block/parry button is also used for dodging, so you can accidentally dodge an enemy instead of parrying an attack.

[u]Enemies:[/u] 
You will face all kinds of enemies in the game, such as Vampires, Zombies, Lycans, Skeleton Warriors, Cave Trolls and so many more. You can learn more about them in your Bestiary (located in the menu). You can ride some of the large beasts, after inflicting a good amount of damage, and use them to kill the other enemies.

[u]Puzzles:[/u] 
There are a lot of puzzles in this game. Aside from killing enemies, the Combat Cross can also be used to solve different puzzles and act as a grappling hook to swing to unreachable areas, or during platforming sessions. The puzzles get harder and harder as you progress through the story, and some require you to find particular scrolls from dead knights (can also be accessed in the main menu) or mount a certain monster to solve them.

[u]Bosses[/u]: 
There are a lot of bosses in the game that range from lieutenant vampires to huge titans, and some will grant you new abilities, once you defeat them. I like the boss fights, they are engaging, creative and balanced, even on higher difficulty settings.

[u]Trials[/u]: 
You can replay the chapters again, after you complete them, but with special challenges. Each and every level in the game has its own Trial, which are difficult but add more replay value.

[u]Difficulty:[/u] 
I chose the [i]Knight[/i] difficulty (hard) and it was perfect; the enemies and bosses are tougher and deal more damage but remain fair and balanced, as you will be using the abilities and combos that you learn to slay them and progress through the game.

[h1]Graphics and Level Design[/h1]
For a 2010 game, the graphics look pretty good. From vast and detailed environments to good looking character models. There are ingame cutscenes and prerecorded ones, the Ingame cutscenes still hold up and characters have decent facial animation. 

You will be visiting different areas in this game, such as enchanted forests and the cold and chilly oblivion lake, and these areas provide a good sense of immersion. Areas range from the more generic, like the Dark Dungeon, to the absolutely beautiful, such as the Clockwork Tower.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2123469174

Every so often you will come across a branching path, but the game fails to show you which way leads to the beaten path (long walks and similar looking paths), and if you missed it then there’s a chance you can’t go back and have to restart the level all over again. There are a lot of secrets and hidden areas that you can find and explore in the levels, so watch out for them.

[h1]Technical[/h1]
The game is well-optimized and ran beautifully. No issues to report.
[quote] Laptop: OMEN HP-17t
Geforce GTX 1070
Intel Core I7-7700HQ 2.80 Ghz
16 GB DDR3 RAM
OS: Windows 10 Home 64-bit[/quote]

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
A few of the songs are okay and not very memorable, while others are just excellent; some give you this gothic atmosphere, while others have a pleasant and calm melody when solving puzzles and during exploration. The songs range from the epic orchestra of [i]Hunting Path[/i] to the pleasant, heart-wrenching melody of [i]Waterfalls of Agharta[/i] and [i]Belmont’s Theme[/i]. 

[h1]DLC[/h1]
There are two main DLCs in the game, [i]Reverie[/i] and [i]Resurrection[/i], and they continue the story of the base game. I can’t say more than that to avoid spoilers, but they are 2 chapters and 1 hours long each and they were pretty fun. The first DLC is mainly puzzles and less fighting, and the second one is just two very challenging boss fights and that’s about it.

[h3]Additional Details:[/h3]
[table]
[tr]
[td]Total playtime[/td]
[td]18.5 hours (with DLC) without playing the trials[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Recommended difficulty[/td]
[td]Knight (Hard)[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]M&K or Controller[/td]
[td]Both work but a controller is preferable[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Offline mode[/td]
[td]Yes[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Achievements[/td]
[td]Yes, some are challenging[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Trading cards[/td]
[td]None[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Games Saving[/td]
[td]Automatically[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
When I first installed [i]Castlevania: Lords of Shadow[/i], I had low expectations and thought I would just delete it after an hour or two, but I actually had a lot of fun and enjoyed my time playing it. Despite some issues in the story and level design, the combat was solid, the story was good, the graphics still hold up and it has a great soundtrack.  

[h3]Final Rating: 8/10[/h3]

Un gran juego y buen representante de la saga Castlevania, pero lamentablemente  tiene 2 grandes problemas. Primero es  lo mal calibrado que esta la mecánica de salto tanto en el combate como en las partes de plataformas y exploración, al momento del combate te deja muy  vulnerable  y los combos aereos no siempre se efectuaran  como debería ya que la ia de los enemigos automaticamente  pondrá defensa o atacara  haciendo que se ignore la animación del ataque y consecuencia pierdas toda tu "concentración" de manera injusta,  y en las plataformas abra ocasiones que al momento de agarrarte a un borde o superficie el juego no detectara que el personaje deba agarrase  y caera haciendo daño o muriendo inevitablemente.
El segundo problema es la defensa, que en este genero  en un serio problema. Abra ocasiones en la que la defensa no responderá  por más rápido que preciones el botón (use varios joysticks) o que ataques que no deberían romper la defensa la rompen.
Estos dos problemas pueden llegar a ser muy frustrantes, pero no rompen el juego, se deja jugar, la música, y la atmósfera son excelentes. Si tienes tiempo no dejes de ver el arte que esta bastante bueno, si te gusta los God of War clasicos  o Dante's inferno, no lo dudes.

Disclaimer: The only previous experience in the Castlevania franchise I had was Castlevania: Portraits of Ruin and decided to play this game after watching the Castlevania anime so my knowledge of Castlevania games and what to expect is rather limited... 

But, I had a lot of fun playing Castlevania: Lords of Shadow and would recommend it to anyone interested in the Castlevania universe.  There are many pros such as exciting combat sequences, the level design and world are captivating, the cinematics draw you into the lore and complement the story well, and of course all the classic monsters are featured in some way.  My biggest criticisms are the platforming elements can be a bit frustrating at times and the camera angle can work against you. However, these cons did not persist in every scenario so they are not a deal breaker. 

Overall a solid action adventure game, and I look forward to playing the sequel!

69252437.review:
Como una buena idea puede llegar a convertirse en una mala realización.

Mi historia con este juego comienza en la época en la que lo había probado por primera vez en mi PS3. Decir que el juego lucía de escándalo por aquél entonces. Muchos como yo, sabían que esto se ha conseguido por las cámaras fijas. Si, el juego tiene una cámara fija. Esta va cambiando de plano según Gabriel (nuestro protagonista) se mueve por el escenario.

El juego, a pesar de ser muy bonito, siempre me producía algún rechazo que no supe explicar. Ahora, después de haberlo empezado por cuarta vez y llegar un poco más lejos que las anteriores, entiendo el porqué. A continuación sin más dilatación, voy a enumerar los puntos que no me han gustado.:

- Empecemos por lo básico y es si este Castlevania: Lord of Shadow se puede considerar digno de los clásico. La respuesta es obvia, pero para mi un NO retundo
- La historia del juego no es que sea muy interesante, pero anima a saber un poco más. LO malo es la forma de contarla. Normalmente es con un texto antes de cada fase de nivel. Hay veces que si te la cuenta algún personaje, pero es muy poco en mi opinión. Parte de la historia también se cuenta con notas de soldados caídos que nos iremos encontrando a lo largo del juego. Yo soy de los que odia saber más de la historia leyendo notas. Me parece una forma muy cutre de contar una historia. De hecho es un recurso que se utiliza en muchos juegos y nunca es un acierto. No me malinterpretéis, a mi me gusta leer, pero si quiero jugar un videojuego espero o jugabilidad o al menos, una cinemática por lo menos (aunque sea en plan cómic).
- La optimización del juego es excelente, y el port de PC es muy digno. Apenas te deja tocar los gráficos, pero funciona en cualquier PC medio de los últimos 7 años.
- La cámara en este juego es horrible, para mi es una cagada total ya que teniendo el stick derecho y no poderlo usar, es un grave error. No entiendo como a alguien se le ha podido ocurrir esta genial idea.
- El diseño de niveles, cortos, MUY lineales y casi siempre poco intuitivos y laberínticos. Me encanta que un nivel sea laberíntico, pero si no hay recompensa detrás de esa exploración, ¿qué sentido tiene?
- El combate es muy simple. Tiene varios combos que puedes usar, pero el combate en sí es aburrido. EL juego claramente intenta copiar la fórmula de God of War, pero se queda a medias. 
- Enemigos poco variados. Para matar a muchos de ellos basta con esquivar y dar dos golpes, seguidamente repetir una y otra vez lo mismo.
- La parte de plataformas es un script constante, no puedes apenas realizar un paso, un salto o un agarre a cornisa si tu vas por donde el juego no lo espera. Incluso cortando un camino que es obvio que podrías saltar por ahi sin problema, pero el juego simplemente te pone barreras invisibles.
- Los controles son poco intuitivos. Habiendo jugado a tantos juegos dónde los controles ya están estandarizados, este juego decide ir a su bola. Un ejemplo rápido, Para interactuar con objetos hay que pulsar R2 en vez de A o X o incluso B. Para esquivar, se esquiva con L2 + una dirección. Decir que también que el bloque se hace con el mismo botón pero sin mover el stick. Para bajar una cornisa debes de pulsar A (igual que para subir) + el stick hacia la dirección que quieres. ¿Por qué no hacerlo con B de toda la vida,? pues los desarrolladores decidieron que es más cómodo así..

He de decir que llegando a este punto, el juego definitivamente lo abandono y prometo nunca más darle más oportunidades. Veo que no encaja con lo que yo conozco por diversión, y por lo tanto si el juego no lo consigue; forzarlo por quinta vez creo que sería absurdo.

Normalmente los juegos que son más o menos buenos y/o recomendados por la comunidad de jugadores, les doy varias oportunidades a lo largo del tiempo, si por lo que fuera, no me hubieran gustado en un primer momento. Este es de los pocos en el que me he sentido que pierdo el tiempo y no me aporta nada de diversión.

Pretty solid hack and slash with great atmosphere.

Kinda clunky in some areas, and with some awful camera cuts in a few round arenas that really makes it hard to frame all enemies in view, but otherwise a solid game in its own merit. My only complaints are the titan boss fights that totally blow and feel like a chore rather than the epic moment they planned; and some puzzles which are really disappointing when you realize you missed a part of the puzzle because it was kind of hidden in a corner and you didn't see it because of the color palette of the area (namely the Frankenstein shock puzzle and its hidden switch behind a breakable wall that took me a good 10 minutes to find :[  ).

It also has unlockable concept art and a bestiary with info on enemies you encounter - both of which are always a plus in my opinion.

YES, I HAVE PLAYED OTHER CASTLEVANIA GAMES (Order of Ecclesia is my fav). I remember playing this on the Xbox 360. I've spent countless hours on this, replaying the levels over and over again. Looked back at this since it was on sale, and at the time of this review I have a decent PC... I have to say that even though it takes much inspiration from games like God of War, I still really enjoyed it. The atmosphere behind it doesn't always reflect a Castlevania, as it varies from chapter to chapter. The game also had cool lightning and graphics for a 2010 game. After replaying it I've noticed that the characters could have used more polish... as they appear bland at times. The soundtrack, even though much more western sounding (compared to other Castlevania titles) and less catchy, was not bad. I really like some of the tracks. Even though it loses much of the charm... It still is one of my favourites. Is it nostalgia? Probably...

edit: I didn't know Patrick Stewart voiced Zobek until I saw him in the credits... that's awesome!

67966872.review:
Primero lo primero , este juego va para gente adulta  que aprecia clásicos,  juegos duros y que quieren un desafio,  tiene mucho contenido Sexual, Violento y es duro en nivel Caballero y paladin, no es apto para niños minecraft, CoD, FIFA y esos juegos random asi que muchos entenderán los análisis negativos, así que si eres de esos que viene a comprar un juego y a pasárselo de risas y lágrimas saquese de aquí esto no es para generación Discovery kids.
Que decir del juego, principalmente es el inicio de la saga Lords of shadows, es el principio de como Gabriel era un miembro de la luz, luchaba y servía para su causa y nos muestran cómo se abre paso a su destino para convertirse en el rey de la oscuridad.
He de decir que el final te deja con muchas dudas, si juegas del capitulo I – XII y no juegas el prologo que es del XII – XIV no te enteraras de nada ya que es una parte esencial en la historia de Gabriel y que papel juegan los señores de la sombra.
Para mi este juego tiene aspectos muy buenos en:
-banda sonora estilo Zelda, gótica y fantasía, una sinfonía que acompaña un entorno bastante mágico a medida que nos adentramos en la historia
- el entorno que es tanto gótico, fantasioso , medieval y a veces tétrico en algunos aspectos hacen disfrutarlo mas
-los personajes que están bien detallados, cada uno con su papel en la historia y sus habilidades
-la historia en si que te envuelve de principio a fin y te deja con ganas de saber más de la historia.
Mas sin embargo veo este titulo como una copia o similitud con el titulo de God of war, Veo este castlevania como el Godo of War multiplataforma, dirán: ¿por qué? Voy a poner 3 ejemplos:
 1 de ellos es el titan que aparece en uno de los lvls el cual no podemos atacar con nuestras armas sino que tenemos que esperar a que nos ataque , subir por su cuerpo , golpear una de las gemas incrustadas para así irlo debilitando, una vez debilitado hasta cierto punto, debemos hacer uno o dos movimientos y presionar un botón para seguir así, algo que pasa en la saga godo of war sino estoy mal es en el inicio del 3 donde peleas con poseídon y lo golpeas 3 veces y aparece el icono del botón para que así vayas ejecutando combos, así esta este juego.
el ejemplo 2 es diría uno de los jefes que es un vampiro que es literalmente fácil, golpea y esquiva, pero ese chupa sangres recupera su salud etc.… lo mismo pasa en Godo of war y un combate donde tienes que evitar ese enemigo recupere la salud, y es cuestión de golpear y esquivar
3- la forma de desplazarse con el latigo en forma de cruz y el combate son parecidas a la de godo f war, solo que Kratos tiene 2 cadenas , Gabriel en este caso tiene guantes yuna cadena que va mejorando a medida que vamos avanzando

AHORA HABLARE DE LA HISTORIA Y EL JUEGO AL 100% EN SI CON SPOILERS ( si lees mas no es culpa mia)

Como dije arribita nos cuenta la historia de Gabriel, si jugaste el título mirror of fate , sabrás de sobra que los acontecimientos de este juego van antes que ese título, por lo cual la línea temporal seria : 
1-Castlevania Lords of shadows Ultimate edition
2- Castlevania Lords of shadows – Mirro Of Fate
3- Castlevania Lords of shadows 2
En si en el 2 ya te hacen un resumen exhausto de lo que paso tanto en miror off ate como en el lords of shadows 1,  en el inicio vemos a Gabriel protegiendo unos aldeanos de los ataques por parte de los licántropos una vez derrotados nos aventuramos en el bosque donde siempre estaremos con una presencia espiritual que tendrá 2 tipos de formas ( un caballo y un águila) es un guardián espiritual llamado pan, este personaje es fundamental tanto en esta historia como en mirror off ate, también nos toparemos con zobeck otro de los personajes fundamentales que no desempeñara en mirror pero lo hará en el 2.
Zobeck y pan son los personajes que se lleven más atención en la historia ya que uno nos engaña y otro nos muestra el verdadero destino, la historia en si es una obra maestra ya que nos hablan de que Gabriel está destinado a cumplir una profecía para acabar con los señores de la oscuridad, pero sin saberlo es un peón para alcanzar un poder para un señor oscuro.
No hablare del final sino del DLC ya dije bastante de la historia en si, en el DLC que son 3 capítulos cortos, muestra como Gabriel se transforma en el señor oscuro, es algo que no pasa en la historia principal, en la historia principal si acabas con el jefe, Gabriel sigue siendo humano, tienes que acabar los 3 capítulos restantes,  en el tendremos que jugar tanto con Gabriel como con Laura ( la niña vampira que jugo ajedrez con nosotros ) tendremos que ayudarla a que no huya un poderoso enemigo de los señores oscuros llamado el olvidado.
No puedo decir mas ya que siento que dije el 50% de el contenido, pero en si vale la pena el juego, la historia esta muy bien estructurada y no afecta si va antes o después de mirror of fate, pero seria bueno jugarlo en el orden que dije.
Encuentro al juego esta genial tenemos 3 barras las cuales son salud, una especie de magia azul y otra roja ( no recuerdo los nombres ) , lo que es genial es que vamos obteniendo poderes como alas, nuevas botas para correr, guantes mas fuertes y mejoras del látigo.
Algo que seguro va a molestar a mas de uno es una de las 2 cosas, los puzles o el chupacabras, los puzles porque hay unos difíciles que te harán perder mucho tiempo y el chupa cabras por que te roba todo lo que tienes, poderes, dagas, etc… y tienes que buscarlo y darle en los huevos.

Solo tengo que decir que lo que vale la pena es el cristal rosado, el cual invoca un demonio o demonia de grandes tetas, uñas con alas, una vez la invocas se traga todo a su paso (como una ex esposa rencorosa que quiere darse con mas del 95% de tu sueldo) pero lamentablemente no funciona con los jefes ( lastima que no sea así en la vida real T_T).

Creo que ya dije todo…( me van a pagar verdad… hola Konami :V almenos dile a KOJIMA que saque un nuevo silent hill )

67670211.review:
PROS
* Combat special moves look bad ass
* Cool music
* Responsive controls
* Patrick Stewart :)
* Fantastic looking scenery, the levels look incredible (even in 2020)

CONS
* Fixed camera can be a pain in combat and occasionally I lose track of where I am
* So many enemies attacking at once can sometimes make it hard to land hits because you are so busy dodging
* Sections can get repetitive. Combat if you die a lot, exploring if you fall a lot and puzzles if you don't know the solution. 
  You will have to re-do things over and over and over and over and over....
* Levels are so detailed I often have trouble figuring out where to go; hard to tell what is a ledge and what isn't
* Backtracking to get items feels like length padding, requires playing sections of previously completed levels.
* Kinda tricky to remember the button combos for ALL your moves. There is a lot happening! But the 3/4 of them you do 
  remember is enough to dispatch what you're dealing with just fine.
* The story is so chock full of different elements it gets bloated with filler levels (Music box level anyone? Why wasn't this 
  part a hidden secret level?)
* Chubacabras stealing your items is so frustrating and takes a while to deal with if you don't know where to go. It was bad 
  the first time and it happens multiple times during the adventure.
* Lots of Quick time events
* DLC is way too short and incredibly irritating; you will die a lot. Which is funny because you die a lot in the main game but 
  this is ridiculous. The final boss also takes FOREVER to kill, it gets boring and frustrating because you'll die a million times 
  until you finally figure it out.

SUMMARY
Overall it is a fun game and I do enjoy it despite the short comings. I have recently just finished it for the 3rd time. But the first time I've played the DLC. I hope one day to do a 4th play through, but I will ignore the DLC.

66995598.review:
I tried playing this game 3 times now. Once on consoles and two on PC. Every time I play it for 5 hours or so, and just give up, not because it's hard, it's has an adequate difficulty, but it is boring as all hell. 
It does god of war and shadow of the colossus in the most uninspired way possible. Hits don't feel well, dodge and movement is clunky. Every hit on the opponent feels bad.

The beggining of the game (the only part I really played) has so many cutscenes, you can literally play 10 seconds at a time in some areas. There is a cutscene when you enter a specific area, I kid you not, that spends something like 8 seconds showing the area, like it is something important, and then you just... go through the area... and it takes 5 seconds to go through it! It's amazing. I couldn't make this shit up if I tried.

The graphics are very nice for the era, and the main character's animation is good. Every enemy I encountered were as ugly as they were uninteresting. Their attacks were very poorly telegraphed, and the awful, awful camera made it even worse. At least it was not so difficult to just barrel through.

As a 2D castlevania fan, the series always pull me back, and I think this is one of the reasons I always come back to this game, along with its cool graphics. Maybe this review will remember me of how uninspired this game is next time I think "why haven't I finished this game yet".

66683181.review:
TL; DR - An underrated game in the Spectacle Brawler genre that successfully modernized the old-school "Classic-vania" formula. Has a hell of an ending and it's gorgeous.

At Length - Though this game is EXTREMELY derivative of God of War, as well as a bit of Shadow of the Colossus, that's really not a problem seeing as this is a Castlevania game in the old style - you control a Belmont and you whip your way through levels as you combat hordes of creatures of the night - and they always were derivative but fun games. The trick was always in the execution, the presentation, and the unique twists to formula each entry brought to the table. 

Such it is with Lords of Shadow, and the execution here is excellent. 

You're looking at a sprawling adventure that spans 49 decently sized levels (44 in the OG game + the 5 DLC levels that are integrated with this Ultimate Edition) following Gabriel Belmont, the 2nd "First Belmont" in the series in this reboot/spin-off from the main Castlevania continuity.  For most of this run, each level has at least one new thing going on, so the game should prove entertaining and novel for first time players. There's not a lot of replayability though, unless you want to go for the challenge mission "Trials" that unlock for each level after you beat them for achievements.

The combat is fast and fluid, and it has a good sense of progression to it. It's the real centerpiece of the game and holds up. The exploration and platforming that separates the combat sections is less interesting, following the Uncharted series as a model, so you mostly just hold a direction and occasionally press one button to follow a linear track that looks cool, but is boring to play. Surprisingly, the puzzles that are scattered throughout are also pretty good here, though devs were wise to always let players who don't care for puzzles optionally skip them.

The Spaniard Devs at Mercury Steam did a fantastic job here, especially with the presentation. Even though the game doesn't match the expected standards for gaming PCs of today in technical terms, the art direction still stands out and holds up these many years later from its original release. I feel that storywise, the devs brought a unique tone by more properly integrating larger elements of Christianity into the Castlevania lore (before the Netflix show would do something similar) that makes perfect sense when you consider the setting is dark ages Europe and ultimately demonic monsters of myth.

Though the story is often pretty brain-dead in its specifics of plotting and pacing, the ending of the game reframes the story so well and is such a fundamentally good concept overall that it's a bit sad that this never became canon. Plus the tapped voice-over talent is putting in a lot of work; both Robert Carlyle and Patrick Stewart do good jobs here. You're in for a treat if you just like Picard's voice, as you get a Stewart monologue with every level!

All in all, this is the best piece of software Mercury Steam has ever produced. The sequels didn't ever match this first, full-throated effort, and it's definitely worth anyone's time.

66468057.review: Excelente juego, lleno de acción, enemigos fáciles y difíciles, buena trama, la intensidad de juego es buena de acuerdo a la dificultad. Excelentes gráficos que acompañan en todo momento al juego. Es una joya la verdad.

66423673.review:
Juego recomendado por un compi fanático de la saga. Aunque es de la generación anterior, me lo he gozado exagerado. Juego desarrollado por MercurySteam, una empresa española y con el apoyo de Hideo Kojima. Épica banda sonora orquestal dirigida por el aclamado compositor español Óscar Araujo. Los escenarios, el arte gráfico y conceptual y la vuelta de tuerca que le dieron a la saga con este título lo hace una obra indispensable si te gusta el género hack and slash.

Me recuerda muchísimo al Dante's Inferno en el ámbito de la mitología cristiana y también en el poseer tanto poderes de luz como de oscuridad. Tiene muy buena jugabilidad en cuanto al combate aunque si es verdad que cuando toca nivel de moverte por plataformas se hace un poco ortopédico.

La historia, los enemigos y los combates llevan una buena escalada de calidad por la que cada capítulo es mejor que el anterior.

LO MEJOR: Buena jugabilidad de combate, muchos combos y poderes. Diseño de niveles bastante bueno e historia muy épica. Genial banda sonora.

LO PEOR: A veces se escucha mas fuerte la banda sonora que el resto de sonidos y queda todo como muy artificial. Sobretodo las primeras partes del juego se escuchaba raro y quedaba artificial. Los cambios de cámara en algunas partes de plataformas te hacen caer y morir. No está muy depurado el plataformeo.

Como nota final decir queda que me lo he pasado 3 veces y he conseguido todos los logros. Por tanto...

¡Recomendable 100%!

66140144.review:
I am an old school Castlevania fan.  Symphony of the Night is my favorite.  I am also enjoying the Netflix animated series, which uses the classic timeline.  In saying that I am really enjoying this game and have yet to complete it,  even though the ending has been spoiled to me.  Most critics say the game is a God of War clone to which I say GoW is a Devil May Cry clone.  Now I've played both games and enjoy Lords of Shadow more.  The game got me hooked from the start, and unlike other games I enjoy revisiting previous chapters to search for gems or weapon upgrades that were not reachable the first time.

I am not a graphics whore but find the game stunning even today.  There are some beautiful scenic shots when outdoors.  Oh yeah in the game you will be outdoors quite a bit.  There is a castle but it'a bit far off.  In the game you play as Gabriel Belmont the original Belmont.  You have been sent by the Brotherhood of Light to combat the Lords of Shadow.  The game mixes both Christian references with Pagan references.  The boss fights are epic and some bosses are huge like the titans and the Crow Witch.  There are a lot of QTE's in the game but it does not bother me I kinda like them, and there usually easy to pull off.  Gabriel's weapon of choice is the Combat Cross whip.  It has several upgrades.  Speaking of upgrades there are upgrades for your health and Light and Chaos magic.  Oh yeah you can use Light magic which makes every attack you make restore your health bit by bit.  There is also Chaos magic which makes your attacks stronger.  Lastly there are four difficulty modes to choose from ranging from easy to extremely hard.

65095315.review:
[h1]Castlevania Lords of Shadow - La luz prevalecerá sobre las tinieblas.[/h1]

[h1]Historia:[/h1]
En Castlevania Lords of Shadow nos ponemos a manos de Gabriel Belmont, un caballero de la orden y guerrero que recorre el mundo devastado por las tinieblas en busca de su redención y llevar el espíritu de su amada Marie al cielo. Para ello tendremos muchos desafíos ante nosotros. El juego se compone de 12 capítulos, entre los cuales y en cada uno de ellos hay varias zonas que iremos avanzando y desbloqueando. El juego es un Hack and slash con toques de plataformas. En ocasiones la vista se hace un poco isométrica. El juego dispone de algunos puzzles bastantes interesantes para poder avanzar en la historia.

[h1]Gráficos:[/h1] El juego a pesar de ser del 2010 tiene un apartado artístico y unos gráficos mas que aceptables a dia de hoy. El juego no dispone de muchas opciones gráficas a elegir, resolucion de pantalla, sombras, filtrado anisotropico y oclusion ambiental, ademas de la ya conocida V-Sync. La optimización es como una roca, no baja de los 60 cuadros ni en fase de carga, así que vais a disfrutar de el si os gusta el género. Cualquier PC a dia de hoy lo puede mover.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2020207063
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2023051801
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2023051928
[h1]Jugabilidad:[/h1] En ocasiones es un poco tosco, pero cuando te acostumbras es una delicia. Una cosa que podría haberse mejorado es la cámara en algunos escenarios, en ocasiones se posiciona en un ángulo un poco dificil, pero bueno.

[h1]Sonido:[/h1] Viene con voces en ingles y subtítulos en español, se hecha en falta el doblaje al español, pero bueno, todo no se puede tener.

[h1]Conclusión:[/h1] Un pedazo de juegazo con una historia y unos escenarios en ocasiones muy bellos y en otros muy lúgubres y oscuros. El mal reina sobre la tierra en forma de hombres lobo, vampiros, nigromantes y hay que poner todo en orden, para eso nos aventuramos en esta aventura a manos de Gabriel Belmont y velar por el alma de Marie. 

[h1]Nota: 8[/h1]

65051003.review: Uno de los mejores Castelvanias al que le gusta esta saga y la sigue desde sus inicios en el nes y snes, lo va a querer por que conserva esa esencia es cierto que parece mucho de god a war y dms que tambien me encantan, pero el que jugo castelvania 64 sabe que los que copiaron fueron otros, una dificultad buena no apta para niños como antaño que es probable que eche algunos para atras, pero muy satisfactorio. se notan los polvos de kojima y un excelente trabajo del estudio españolen Mercuri Steam, la buena historia, excelentes cinemáticas., fue el primer juego que jugue en mi ps3, y en pc me sigue sorprendiendo, los graficos y el arte son incleibles. un juego que no puedes dejar de jugar por este precio.

65041231.review: If you like the old God of War games or Devil May Cry, this game will be familiar and easily enjoyable to you. Although the combat system is not as deep, it's still a fun little reboot for the Castlevania series and a re imagining as a hack and slash title. The story is grittier than normal for series standards and a lot of the names of the characters are reused from classic Castlevania with the characters themselves not being the same as before. Graphics and sound are good for the era it released, the sound being a little bit forgettable but still serviceable. Replayability is fine, if you want to 100% you need at least 2 full playthroughs. DLC is included so that's an extra. One of the biggest downsides are the puzzles, which are not really fun or memorable, being tedious and boring. The other is that some abilities are not really useful in combat, if you want to be optimal. Although there is a system that encourages use of different moves, akin to DMC stylish, called focus, it does not have the same amount of depth here. So the less useful abilities could pass you by completely, with them not being used at all for a playthrough. I recommend a purchase, if you like DMC or GoW, especially if it's on sale.

63769906.review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#177 out of 555)... it's time for Castlevania: Lords of Shadow.

It's Castlevania by way of God of War, and is exactly what you'd expect from that descriptor. The combat is engaging, if derivative, and the bosses suitably impressive both in terms of overall design and sheer scale. If Lords of Shadow has any major flaws, it's that it's predictable: it's exactly the game you'd imagine it to be after reading a promotional summary. That's the thing about AAA action games from this era: they take themselves entirely too seriously and are deeply afraid of taking risks. 

Which is all a rather roundabout way of saying that Lords of Shadow is a fine game. By the standards of its genre, it's pretty good. Think better than your Darksiders, not quite as good as your Gods of War. In other words: a slightly above-average game in a middling genre. More devoted Castlevania fans might find it a bit uninspired and lament the absence of the series usual staples, but I was fine with it.

Note: also played on Sony Playstation 3.

62773249.review:
Disclaimer:  I haven't played for 12 hours. I played for a few, trying to give the game the benefit of the doubt, and fell asleep in my boredom.

Where do I even begin? The game graphically looks on par for a 2010 game. Nothing special there. The music is alright. And I'm sure the story would be good too if it gave me any in the first few hours.
Not only does this game start with no knowledge of what the f*** is happening, you don't get any interesting story in the first few hours I've played. I really wanted to give this game a chance for the story, cause the entire premise is interesting to me, but the gameplay is so abysmal that I can't do it.

Why is the gameplay so bad? Let me explain... Imagine playing an Arkham game without any sort of "warning:  incoming hit" notification but still having 3-10 enemies attack at once. Yea, it's really, really hard to keep track of everything, which leads to you getting hit.. a lot. I read that you can get some sort of regeneration ability later that makes it bearable, but really the game is a slog to get to that point.

Another annoying "feature" of this game is fixed camera angles. "Hey look, we're like God of War!" except it's just really annoying and often switches halfway down a hallway which leaves you standing still because controls have now switched.

Speaking of controls.. They. Are. TERRIBLE. Playing this game feels like a chore. It makes me wonder if the developers ever played a 3-D Hack-N-Slash game before making this one. Combat controls are awkward.. One example:  Block AND Dodge being the same button. Block standing still, and Dodge while moving.. Except this is a Hack-N-Slash and you're ALWAYS moving.. So pulling off any kind of "parry" is next to impossible. Not only that, but the QTE's (Quick Time Events)... Oh my god.. There's so many.

"How many QTEs do you want in your game?" "Yes"
Everything is a QTE. Wanna cross this tether, better do a QTE any time you wiggle too close to the edge. First boss of the game? Nothing but QTE. It would've been forgiveable if the QTEs were limited to combat, but nope. Wanna use your new gadget to open this passage? ANNOYING QTE INCOMING!
"BUT THE QTE MAKES IT MORE IMMERSIVE" ... F*** off.

I can't in good conscious recommend to anyone.. Hack-N-Slash fans or Castlevania fans.. Both are in for disappointment.

Time to play Lords of Shadow 2 which is actually fun and engaging.

60571127.review:
Set in an alternate universe from the mainline series, we get an action game that takes the Castlevania universe, and says "What if the first level had you fight a giant wolf-like beast while protecting villagers, then impale it on a giant log after it howls at the moon?"
The whole game takes the action and atmosphere from that first level and for the most part, sticks to it.
It's beautiful visually, fun to play, and the many references to the original franchise do nothing but make this yet another great entry in the series.

60507317.review: Highly underrated game in the Castlevania franchise. Even though Iga did not take part in it, Kojima did, and essentially this game is more of a reboot take on Dracula's story, in a sense. The chapters are plenty, with a lot of challenging puzzles and combat, which is more of a beat-em-up. Similar to DMC, but has it's own flavor to, and can be unique if players spent the time learning it. Graphics are amazing, even in 2019, and really, what makes this game great is the way the story flows. At first it might seem slow-paced, but remember, as you play, you start liking it a lot better for that.

60418116.review:
This is one of those games that made me wish there was a sideways thumb or something. I enjoyed my time with most of the game besides the two bonus chapters. I loved the story, soundtrack, characters, locations, and everything else but the gameplay is the biggest issue I had. The lack of free control over the camera means that once the game eventually opens up and wants you to do a bit more exploring to find things, you are constantly fighting with the camera to see jumps or see stuff that is hidden off screen and blocked from view. It also leads to a lot of off screen enemies hitting you during combat, which becomes annoying later in the game. Last complaint about the combat, the game wants you to parry enemy attacks later on for reasons, but it's usually really hard to get a sense of when the animation is actually about to begin, which can be really frustrating when you take a hit you were sure you timed right. 

Still, despite those flaws, the story alone more than made up for it for me, along with an incredibly satisfying ending. The DLC chapters (13 and 14) definitely drag down the experience and are required to "finish all levels" but if you're okay with like..not playing them, it's probably best to stop after you finish Chapter 12 and saving that DLC for another day. Took me probably 25 hours to finish =X

60367260.review:
Can't even get past the first chapter. It's so boring, linear, and filled with pointless visuals.

Combat can be described as: X, X, X, dodge. Even on the highest difficulty setting...so easy.
Camera angles are frustrating and clearly attempt to be "artsy" at times, but it just makes movement clumsy.
Sometimes the camera angle hides the monster that's charging up an unblockable attack.
It wants to look like it has platforming elements, but you can't fall off things, so jumping from platform to platform is really just an attempt to look like there's dynamic movement. There's not.

The thing that sealed it for me was a moment in the bog, in Chapter 1, where this happened:
"Grab the goblin to get his grenade." 
Okay, I know how to grab them. 
Pick the little dude up, and then I get a quick-time event with a target area and a shrinking circle. 
What do I do when the circle is in the target? Hit a button? Pull a trigger? Wiggle the stick?
No prompt whatsoever, so I just hit a button. 
Beat the goblin, and he drops his grenade! 
"The grenade has been defused. Try again."
Try again. Defused again. Try again. Defused again.
Why the hell am I even trying to get this grenade?
Try again. Success! "Press RT to pick up his grenade."
RT.
Then I pick up the grenade and automatically lob it at a big tree behind me.
Why did I do that?
"Grab the goblin to get his grenade."
Seriously? One more time!
Then I lob the grenade at the tree again, which falls and creates a new path for me. How the hell was I supposed to know that this was the goal? Worst tutorial ever.

It's like no one actually played this game when they were designing it. I'm mostly writing this review so I won't re-install it again in 5 years because I can't remember if it was good or not.

It's not good.

59912068.review:
Was hoping for a harmless 3D action game, and at the end I got as much frustration as fun out of this. When the game shows you its bad parts, it's showing you the absolute worst that the medium has to offer. Camera and level design are among the worst I've ever experienced--everything is blocked off by invisible barriers and you need to constantly walk around the edges or borders to find not just hidden areas, but sometimes main paths, which are hidden by a static camera that the moment it begins moving, generally spazzes out. Paths are never clear and there's even instances of enemies being the same color as the environment, and because of the zoomed-out camera, it's impossible to see what's going on. And levels have non-sensical end points, one level may take 45 minutes and another will take 5. The game lacked solid direction and seemed like it was trying to incorporate every single mechanic that was around in the era. Had they slimmed it down a bit and cut out half the environment interactions and skill mechanics, the game would have been more streamlined and enjoyable. As is, you're moving at breakneck speed with one new mechanic or skill introduced per level, with no time to ever assimilate any of it.

The settings and graphics are great, the soundtrack is amazing, and the story is a badly written teenage emo-fest, which in my case was a plus.

The game is absolutely NOT good. From a gameplay standpoint, it's absolutely deplorable. That said, there's something about it, so I would recommend it only if you're craving something just like this and go into it expecting the worst.

57370891.review:
Me duele mucho no recomendar este juego porque tiene cosas geniales, pero al mismo tiempo tiene algunas decisiones de diseño en cuento a jugabilidad que a mí en concreto me sacaron de quicio.

· En primer lugar un mapeado de botones demasiado complejo. Puede sonar ridículo, lo sé, pero créeme que más de una vez vas a salirte de la inmersión por no recordar qué botón es el que buscas. El joystick izquierdo tiene como 4 o 5 acciones que puede desencadenar según con qué lo combines y todas te hacen falta, mientras que el derecho no hace absolutamente nada por ejemplo. Bueno miento con R3 puedes absorber un tipo de objetos y con L3 otro tipo, ¿por qué no hacerlos con el mismo botón o que se autoabsorban? No lo sé. Todos los botones hacen varias cosas y todos los vas a usar.

· Las hitboxes van de aquella manera, estoy convencido de haberme llevado muchos (pero muchos) golpes que no tocaban

· Las animaciones son demasiado lentas/largas para luego el timing que tienes para hacer un parry  o cosas similares

· La cámara es fija, para un juego de acción no es lo más indicado, te deja muy vendido a menudo

· Presencia total y descontrolada de QTEs. Lo peor es que a veces saltan en medio de una cinemática cuando ya lleva bastantes segundos, cosa que pilla desprevenido y muy seguramente fallarás por ello (vampiresa te miro a ti). Nunca te relajes mientras veas un vídeo.

· Los puntos de guardado están ANTES de los vídeos introductorios al boss. Cada vez que te mate (que serán varias porque no es un juego fácil), prepárate a abrir menú para darle a saltar escena, lo que conlleva dos tiempos de carga por cada muerte. Es una tontería que se hace tediosa rápido.

Me fastidia porque prometía mucho y el lore está muy bien, pero no puedo recomendarlo, los hay mejores

57150072.review:
Lords of Shadow is not a Bad game far from it. It has a good plot nice visuals and some great voice acting. However it does have some problems.

First the controls. You will definitely want to be playing this with a controller. While it has keyboard settings there is a horrendous input lag which will make an already not great control scheme even less so. In addition, even with the controller there is still input issues especially with the sprint commands as, at least for me it would sometimes not register that I had double tapped the sticks and this can be killer in boss fights. The other is the blocking mechanic where you have to hit is just right, even if you are a millisecond off you will take the dmg which can stagger you and set you up for even more damage stagger again especially in boss fights. Moreover, even though you have a dodge there are no I-frames so if a monster attacks right as you leave the dodge you take that dmg. Finally and this might be only with PS4 controllers the because your mana gathering is linked to the L3 sometimes when you would want to do other things like sprint or just move it will instead trigger the L3 gather command which roots you in your place which again in boss fights can lead to you taking dmg if it happens at an inopportune time. 

However even with these problems for the majority of the game you can work through this but there are a few times where it can be simply aggravating and you feel like you are fighting the controls more than the game. Which leads me to the next thing the combos. I love them when they work and they look bad ass but I really wish there was a way cancel action mid combo as you will be locked into it and take dmg and there is nothing you can do about it, you cant even switch to a block or a dodge so if you miss with an attack combo be prepared to get hit from the back or sides. While we are on attack might as well talk about the Quicktime events . . . they suck. Not only are they just button mashing they really just break up the flow of the game and the combat and in longer fights can just get tedious. 

Finally the static camera. There are times where the camera angles really do not help you this game was made in 2010 static cameras should not have been a thing           
 
Yet even with these problems I would still recommend the game as while I was frustrated at times i still had fun and was invested enough in the story to want to see its ending. I think that if some of these problems had been ironed out when it first came out some of the backlash it got might have been muted a bit. They tried something different, even if it was following the likes of God of War and DMC, but because it wasn’t an other Metroidvania style game it got more backlash at the time then i think it deserved. Is it a Great game? No, but it is a very good game i’d say a B- while it has it problems for me it gets a lot of things right so is worth a play though I wouldn’t say it's worth achievement hunting for.

Fun to play DMC-like (even though the Castlevania series is much older than DMC) slasher. Juicy fights, tough and challenging though not impossible to beat. 56291162.review:
The first few hours of gameplay are basically just a very long and drawn out tutorial. A lot of wondering around through forced slow walk segments and showcasing all the enemy variants that might aswell be reskins of the same 2-3 enemy types. Backtracking/split paths feel uninviting between the forced slow walk, and hitting unexpected points of no return or very abrupt level ends, and seem to be abandoned almost entirely after the first few chapters.

The combat is actually quite promising, but is heavily bloated with an excessive number of unnecessary combos. Enemies are extremely predictable in the way they attack, although they have a habit of surprising you as soon as you get bored into playing to a script. The parry timing is the worst i've ever experienced - you have to parry so early that youve often finished the parry animation before the enemy attack even lands. The timing is so awful and the startup window so huge i've had instances of messing up my parry only to successfully parry a follow up attack - i should not be rewarded for messing up any more than i should be punished for timing correctly. Aerial combat is encouraged and yet enemies will frequently knock you out of the air with ease, often with attacks that appear to be ground based.

The level design is made up of a large number of fairly short levels, each of which sends you back to a main map screen to select the next level upon completion. This completely ruined any chance of immersion in the game - as a huge Patrick Stewart fan even his narration wasnt enough to save the repetitive cycle of narration>short level>map screen>repeat. Some levels felt like id barely done anything before they were over. Levels frequently have puzzles and platforming sections that often feel overly drawn out and tedious, and basically just a forced nod to the origins of the series in an otherwise hacknslash game. Checkpoints are also often in quite baffling positions, which adds to the general monotony of the game.

There is absolutely no camera control, and the camera often does very strange things - on occasion i have found myself confused about where i even am on the screen, or simply staring at a closeup of either my character or a wall. The player controls are in general kind of clunky, which combined with the lack of camera control can make platforming in particular quite obnoxious at times. Tank controls and fixed camera works in some games, but this isnt one of them.

La historia es interesante y pulida, con varios giros argumentales. Los personajes (y con esto me refiero casi que sólo a Gabriel) son carismáticos y te causan empatía. El soundtrack es muy épico y encaja con la situación que se está mostrando. Los puzzles son muy divertidos, aunque los del DLC son demasiados y terminan aburriendo.

El combate está bien trabajado, es muy intuitivo y da muchas posibilidades de luchar, sin embargo, los combos son muy incomodos de hacer (yo opté por nunca luchar en el aire, pues no se tiene control del personaje ahí y te terminan bajando). En fin, buen juego, pero recomiendo comprarlo en rebajas, la historia de Gabriel lo vale.

54942362.review:
Un relanzamiento a la europea (y con equipo español) de la saga Castlevania, esta vez desde el punto de vista de [spoiler] su eterno antagonista: Drácula,[/spoiler] o Gabriel Belmont en este juego, un guerrero de una orden sagrada que emprende una misión para destruir a los tres Señores de la Oscuridad que acosan a la Humanidad y recuperar a su amada. A lo largo de la historia, se nos irá contando como el alma de Gabriel se va oscureciendo a medida que lo sacrifica todo en su búsqueda de justicia, o de venganza. Eso si, hay que avisar que el argumento NO ES CANON, y que si esperas encontrarte un Castlevania al uso, este juego no lo es. La saga Lords of Shadow (este, Mirror of Fate y Castlevania 2) es su propio universo y no tiene más relación con la saga original que el nombre, el estilo gótico y los nombres y estética de algunos protagonistas.

El juego en si tiene poco que ver con el estilo metroidvania tradicional de la saga, centrándose en la aventura y el combate hack&slash más propio de juegos como Devil May Cry. Una gran variedad de combos de combate, plataformas y puzzles hacen que el juego no se vuelva aburrido, y la exploración también será importante si queremos encontrar todas las mejoras posibles para Gabriel. Destacan también la enorme variedad de enemigos y abundantes combates contra bosses, en general con una dificultad relativamente suave (aunque también depende del nivel de dificultad elegido); incluso algunos de los bosses son más puzzles al estilo Shadow of the Colossus que combates en si. Súmale una buena banda sonora y espectaculares escenarios, y te queda un juego redondo y que vale lo que pide.

Lo único que no me termina de gustar es que quizás abusa demasiado del Quick Time Event, aunque ello permite obtener unas espectaculares ejecuciones finales contra la mayoría de los bosses (la mejor de ellas [spoiler] el palizón que le metes a Satán en el último combate [/spoiler]). Pero quitando ese detalle, que tampoco es necesariamente negativo, es un juego muy recomendable.

También hay que destacar que los DLC, que vienen incluídos en la Ultimate Edition, son bastante prescindibles más allá de cerrar la historia explicando [spoiler] como Gabriel se convierte en Drácula [/spoiler]. El primero es solo una serie de puzzles bastante tediosos, y el segundo no es más que combatir una y otra vez contra un boss hiperchetado e injusto que no es divertido para nada. En mi opinión os los podéis saltar e iros directamente a YouTube a ver como termina la historia.

54878460.review:
Having now fully completed both the main game and the DLC episodes (of which there are two) I must say I leave this game feeling satisfied with the experience. This was also my second Castlevania game, so I recognize that this is a major departure from the standard gameplay (it being hack-and-slash instead of Metroidvania) of the series and thus won't be making any comparisons to other games. 

Pros: 
*The Music and Visuals of this game are top notch (until the DLC where the cutscene budget took an obvious hit, but it still works).
*There is no grinding for XP, you will have plenty to not only upgrade all the combat abilities, but to buy all the artwork as well.
*The story, while slow moving at times, was interesting enough to keep me invested in its characters.
*The puzzles weren't infuriatingly hard or boringly easy.
*New abilities and moves crop up frequently enough to keep combat more interesting
*Boss battles are a particular highlight in both scope and gameplay

Cons:
*The reading of the book in between each level is annoying and rarely conveys anything meaningful to the story, luckily it can be skipped.
*Trials can't be attempted until the level has been completed once, not a big deal but I found it annoying.
*The titan trials are super strict in their time limit and ended up not being fun at all
(SPOILERS)
*The Dracolich and Forgotten One boss fights were slow and boring
*WTF was the epilogue!? The DLC barely answered anything from it.

I definitely recommend the game to not only Castlevania fans (there is enough references and callbacks to previous games), but fans of hack-and-slash style games in general.

54635088.review:
I highly recommend this game.

Despite this not being a traditional Castlevania game like its predecessors, this game has a LOT going for it.

First off, the world building and lore of this game are phenomenal. Every single enemy, character, and weapon has a well written out entry about them, which gives a lot of backstory to this world. I always love reading the entries. On top of that, the world design is breathtaking; I always love seeing the camera pan out to display gorgeous views. There is also a lot of variety in the environments, as you go from forests to villages, a giant castle, a barren wasteland of undead, etc.

Second, while the gameplay does leave more to be desired and could do with some fine tuning, it's still quite enjoyable to play, especially if you are a fan of hack and slashes. You can purchase combos and mix and match moves with certain relics and artifacts you pick up as you progress.

The graphics are also very well done. I'm running this at 120 fps at 1440p and it's gorgeous.

All in all, I would highly recommend this gem.

54570081.review:
A goodhandful of complaints, but the more I think about the game, the more it's grown on me.

The controls just aren't tight enough to justify the game's difficulty. A lot of it comes down to the active-only camera which makes movement and viewing the environment difficult, and the animation-lock without hyperarmor or the ability to break away. 

Puzzles are confusing and generally have really simple solutions, the biggest challenge with them often being the camera and the game's movement/combat mechanics.

A good hand full of bugs and glitches throughout, occasionally found myself stuck on rubble or other environmental solids which caused my character to get stuck and had reload the checkpoint.

Last "boss fight" in chapter 14 is a frustrating mess. It really feels like the devs just kinda gave the boss a move set then cranked up its health pool and damage to the max. Wouldn't be as much of an issue if the controls weren't so clunky and you were able to refill health/magic during any one of the 5 or so interims between the fights proper. Overall a really intriguing and well fleshed out art design on the boss, but the climax was genuinely ruined by the sheer amount of time and 'effort' put into fights (aka pray to RNGesus until you get that one-in-a-million successful sequence, interlude, next fight stage, rinse and repeat).

7/10 only because art and voice acting are superb and the only thing that kept me playing until I beat it.  Recommend only buying this game under $20.

54230419.review: From a long time Castlevania fan, this was a disappointment. When I hear about Castlevania, I hear of a ever changing castle, and never ending fight against Dracula. I had played the heck out of SotN when I was a child, and I can say, this ain't even got the Castle part until halfway through the game, and even then you don't stay in the castle. With a name like this, it only boasts itself in namesake that it is a castlevania game. That doesn't mean this game is a complete flop. The game is padded with a lot of enemies that can take a lot of hits, though this is to set you up for the light and shadow mechanic that is introduced a bit of the ways in. While it rewards those who pay close attention to enemies, and the swing animations, it also is the padding this game does not need, like further down the line there are enemies that have shields, and they just hold up and goad you on and even if they are open, they still don't go down quickly. The large enemies, that are no more than a slog through what is padded out by holding on to an edge until you get to the place where you can smack a rune, not fun, and padded.  And the worst part is, there is no Dracula to fight. You fight satan. You become Dracula. While it would make sense that a man whose lost everything becomes the villain, it would hold better as a story if it didn't use the name of a series, to piggyback on for better results.

Chapter 14 on the other hand is GOD AWFUL. The entire chapter is filled with cheap 1 hit deaths. After dying 30+ times and not even reaching the final boss I instead reached for the paracetamol. 54151361.review:
Did you recently buy a new flashy 120Hz 4k TV or one of those BFGD:s? 
Well haven't I got a game just for you.

This is probably the best game available for comparing different resolutions and aspect ratios. Switching from your run of the mill 1080p monitor to 1440p 21:9 monitor made a world of difference in enjoyability. Level design in this game is top notch and deserves only the best.

On the other hand no matter how good the game looks you're stuck with the awful gameplay.
I've lost count on how many times I've died because hitboxes are exponentially bigger than actual models on screen. There is zero windup with attack animations making you lose half the healthbar from seemingly nothing. Full healthbar if you get stunned and another attack has already been dealt before Belmount gets up.

Controls are also seriously lacking. No way of cancelling animations - especially mid-air - gets you constantly hit by the previously mentioned fair and fun enemy attacks. Or you just roll down the cliff because who would have thought you don't always want to evade with a uncancellable fixed distance straight line roll.

PS. I see people saying this game isn't playable without controller, and I have to disagree with that. Keyboard controls are by no means great, but at least they are usable.

Do you know what every third person game needs?
1. Fixed camera that obscure what you want to see.
2. No target lock-on for enemies so you can't circumvent point 1.
3. Jump & Run sequences where the camera spastically  jumps around.
4. Boss fights that are so unfair you wanna punch through your table. (I just did)
5. One hit death sequences with tons of cut scenes before them.
6. An uninterruptable sequence whenever you die and then you have to chose to load the last checkpoint. Who wants to save time when you die every 2 minutes, huh?

And this game got them all! And as a bonus you get an uninteresting story and bland characters.

Oh wait! That's a list of the worst gamedesign decision ever made for third person game.
Whoopsie! I just hope that I got this game in some kind of bundle for around a dollar with it's sequel. Otherwise this was one of the worst decision I ever made.

53785839.review:
Ignore playtime-- finished this game on consoles before

Positives:
+ great atmospheric vampire scenario
+ great art style (monsters and bosses super detailed and well designed)
+ good combat system that allows strategic management of your life
+ the fixed camera is often a point of critique for this game but I liked it actually and it is well implemented (you don't have to worry about moving the camera when you play with controller)
+ good puzzles/riddles that are fun
+ the story is straightforward and nothing special but it is well narrated and makes you feel part of the world
+ fixed, linear levels with hidden goods make for a great casual experience where you don't have to use your brain and increase replayability in combination with the higher difficulty levels
+ nicely designed levels
+ pretty long game (20+ hours)

Negatives:
- the design of the world / buildings is too pompous
- except for the puzzles you will need no brain
- sometimes annoying quick time events I guess
- some of the puzzles require good timing which can be a cause of frustration

I decided to give this a review because I have also played the Nintendo DS port "Castlevania- Mirror of Fate HD" here on steam and it is unacceptable to see that this mediocre game has better reviews than Lords of Shadow, which is actually a pretty good game.

TL;DR
recommend

53288318.review:
Going back years later to revisit this game, still struck by its beauty.  Castlevania is known for its elaborate designs, but the visuals are so striking: there's a part where you're standing in the ruins of an old church and the sun's rays are beaming inside and you can see the rays of light moving.  Just awesome.

I love all of the callbacks and references, as the storytellers add dimension to a video game tale; I think they succeed with this chapter (Lords of Shadow 2 is a different matter.)  I'm one of those that feel that there's a place for 3D Castlevania, alongside traditional and Metroidvanias.  I loved Lament of Innocence as well, which I revisit often.

Playing the game on better hardware years later is a real treat.  Watching one of the Titans piece herself together before a boss battle is so dramatic and visually striking; it's one of my favorite cutscenes.

I highly recommend the game; it's like playing through stunning artwork - even if the gameplay struggles at times.  Enjoy (and with the Steam Summer Sale, it is a STEAL.)

53076834.review:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow, is a fantasy scenario taking place some centuries ago in Europe. Following the tale of Gabriel Belmont; a warrior on a quest.
Gabriel makes a journey over impassible terrain; overgrown forests, hazardous cliffs and abysses, murky villages and hovels, and sinister cathedrals surrounded by haunted graveyards and the occult.
The story seems to draw some inspiration from folklore, mythology, and other works of fantasy.

The protagonist journeys through worlds separated by videos, and is seen from a distance. The viewing-angle automatically adjusts towards the protagonist's location. Resulting in panoramic vistas of arenas and battles. Areas are connected by pathways and intersections. They contain obstacles that require climbing, jumping, swinging, and fighting to overcome, or by solving puzzles.
Worlds can be revisited, and offer difficulty levels and challenges. They also contain automatically rendered scenes, which are interactive, and require timing to overcome. 

While taking some artistic liberties, the worlds are thematically inspired, in the sense that they combine history, horror, folklore, and mysticism. There are atmospheric environments, resembling magical, fairytale worlds where iconic archetypes and architecture, set clear contrasts.
The protagonist has a dramatic backstory, supported by memorable music, and various different battles, and a drawn out finale.


This artistic image gives an impression of how the viewing-angle, automatically shows panoramic vistas of the environment:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2048799100
In sharp contrast to this, a video of the battle scenes; showing Gabriel engaged in violent, bestial savagery:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1788586635

51790398.review: Extremely linear with very short level and terrible gameplay.

51749727.review:
A hack and slash Castlevania sounds good, but its combat needs to support it, and Lords of Shadow feels sluggish. I imagine I'm probably just not using it to its full potential, but it generally feels like there's a lack of power behind my swings when every enemy has multiple attacks that give it hyper armour.

In all the game feels like a blast from the past of all the things I don't miss, while still making up for it in a way that stops me from absolutely hating the game. You'll find incredibly simple puzzles, as in turn lever, step on platform, jump. The game will let you buy hints that just give the answer with the points you collect. There are random moments where they throw in a new mechanic for one enemy as a way to get you to explore the level, mainly chupacabras, which will at random with no way to stop take your skills and items forcing you on a goose chase to go get them back.

5/10

51453823.review:
This game holds up extremely well despite it's age. 

Tight controls with a large arsenal of moves keep the action varied...It feels modern, still. With a rich story and epic set pieces, this game tells and displays an immersive experience that allows you to understand the characters motivations as well as the thoughts and actions of his adversaries...Not many games in this genre care to tell a tale from BOTH sides. Kudos to the devs for this inclusion.

In a game like this, audio should and rightfully does influence the overall mood of play with an orchestral soundtrack, each location not only looks different but sounds unique as well.

Once you get used the games cinematic presentation, you'll learn how to play within the frame  of certain areas...just as the devs intended. This ISN'T a matter of style over substance as this game has both...in spades!

50515441.review:
Una aventura épica protagonizada por Gabriel Belmont, donde lo acompañamos en la búsqueda de respuestas al estado decadente de la humanidad y vivimos su historia. Una duración bastante buena, bellos paisajes y personajes carismáticos en sus breves apariciones.
Eso sí, tenemos muchísima presencia de plataformeo y puzles, no está muy enfocado en la acción del título más allá de quitarte de encima a unos pocos monstruos antes del siguiente rompecabezas. Al cual seguramente tengas que llegar colgándote de una repisa a otra. Muchas técnicas para utilizar la cadena de Gabriel, pero pocas útiles en realidad y menos que vas a acabar utilizando.
En definitiva, un gran juego con buena historia, pero si buscas acción, quizá no has venido al lugar adecuado, pues parece más el condimento de la exploración y los puzles, y no a la inversa como puede parecer.

Si quieres seguir leyéndome escribir sobre videojuegos en general... https://www.yukharyan.com/

50485529.review:
Tras más de 50 horas de juego y todos los logros completos me veo en condiciones para hacer una reseña.
El juego al principio recuerda mucho a los God of War en cuanto a mecánicas, esto no es necesariamente bueno o malo, solo es para que te hagas una idea del tipo de juego.
Las fases se dividen en capítulos lo que permite volver a hacer una localización sin tener que dar otra vuelta al juego completo, esto es de agradecer sin embargo tienes que hacer los niveles un mínimo de 2 veces para conseguir todos los objetos (algunos solo son accesibles cuando ya tienes todas las habilidades), la dificultad máxima y el reto, así que lo mejor es jugar la primera partida en la dificultad que creas más conveniente sin preocuparse por desbloquear todo en la primera vuelta porque ya habrá tiempo de eso en la segunda o sucesivas.
En cuanto a los niveles están los de explorar el mapa que incluyen zonas de escalada, puzzles y/o arenas con enemigos que hay que derrotar para avanzar; el otro tipo de niveles son los jefes que hay básicamente de dos tipos: los típicos cuya estrategia es bloquear, golpear, esquivar y los Titanes que son básicamente un nivel de escalada.
El juego no está exento de algún pequeño bug pero nada grave, lo más incomodo es que hay zonas de escalada en las que te quedas "atascado", pero se soluciona bajando y subiendo de nuevo a la parte donde se nos ha quedado pillado.
El guión es bueno aunque el diseño de algunos niveles deja un poco que desear, recomiendo el juego siempre y cuando dispongas de un mando para jugar, en mi caso he usado el de PS4, con teclado la experiencia puede ser algo más frustrante sobretodo en las fases con plataformas y palancas donde hay que girar el joystick.

50133008.review:
Positive
- Music
- Voice acting
- Story is okay
- decent graphics (for a PS3/Xbox 360 port)
- stable fps
- Able to run at 1440p 144fps or 4K 60fps

Negative
- Can crash or freeze you PC so that you have to reboot
- The sound can be buggy at times
- The fixed camera can be bothersome
- Some levels are VERY linear
- Many ideas taken from others games but not as well done
- K/M is awful so stick with Xbox controller.
- Combat is repetitive (which is nothing new for this type of game)

C:LoS is an okay old God of War clone from the PS3/Xbox 360 days. Of course, playing it now you will notice some old and not always best design choices made from back then. Hell,  the real ending was sold as DLC. This edition has all DLC so you will not be cheated. 

The game is okay, but there is better games out there when it comes to gameplay (like DMC5). Only buy it if you find it cheap online or on Steam sale.

It's not like this is the worst game I have ever played, but it has alot of flaws. This game far over stays its welcome, the enemy variety is boring, the platforming is horrid and the game play itself is nothing more than slightly above average. The plot itself is not bad, which is why I slogged through this mess for the second time. There is alot of glitches and bugs and gameplay choices that will leave you scratching your head. This "ultimate edition" comes with the dlc which is two chapters and brings some sense to the out of knowhere ending. The dlc is trash. The cutscenes are done with still images with a "breathing effect" and its mostly puzzles with a few combat sequences and a final boss that is just a pain to fight because of the hitboxes with ground pounds. 49992115.review:
I'm not even halfway through the story,but after 7 hours I can point out well...mostly the flaws this game has.
I just want to highlight that LoS is the first 3D Castlevania I've ever played, so I have no comparison with the other 3D entries in the series.
[list]
[*]Firstly: the controls on PC are ridiculously bad. There's no point in even trying to finish this game with a keyboard, so if you even consider buying this, make sure that you've got a gamepad.
[*]The plot has its highs and lows, but so far there's much more of the lows. The story is bland and boring and so are the characters.
[*]The puzzles aren't challenging at all...
[*]...as well as the boss fights.
[*]The levels are very short and totally linear.
[*]Some animations and cutscenes are needlessly long or totally redundant.
[*]Mediocre, unsatisfying combat system(even in comparison to older games of the same genre)
[*]Sometimes you fight with the camera angle,instead of the monsters.
[*]The skeletons are tougher MOFOs than most of the bosses
[*]Lastly: it doesn't really feel like a Castlevania game for most of the time. It could be any other title(some levels,especially after 6th chapter, bring back that 2D-Castlevania atmosphere, but there's not much of it)
[/list]
If you're not a die-hard Castlevania fan, who gotta have and finish every single game of the series, just skip it and save your money.

49922973.review:
The problem with Castlevania: Lords of Shadow is not that it borrows almost all of its ideas from titles such as God of War, Shadow of the Colossus, and Uncharted. No, the problem is that it fails miserably in surpassing any of those titles in any respect: the combat is mediocre, most of the puzzles are laughably simple, the platforming is slow and dull, and the bosses are, quite frankly, boring at best, and atrocious at worst.

Even the great visuals and excellent score cannot save this game from its own mediocrity, and so I cannot recommend it to anyone. Avoid.

49520026.review:
Score: 7.5/10

Pros:
- Performance wise, it runs great. A constant 60fps on my outdated hardware at max settings.
- Great action gameplay similar to Devil May Cry series or Dante's Inferno
- Varied combos to unlock and experiment with. Many upgrades to the Battle Cross that is your only weapon for most of the game. which keeps it interesting.
- Graphically sound for the time, some nice effects on the hair/clothing etc.
- Story is fairly interesting 
- Absolutely nailed the casting choices, Patrick Stewart and Robert Carlyle leading the charge
- Interesting puzzles 
- Incentive to return, difficult challenges appear once you complete a stage to encourage returning for that glorious 100%
- Quite a long game, especially if you go back and do all the challenges.

Cons:
- Suffers from the standard "increase difficulty by throwing numbers at the player" fatigue. Artificially making the game harder in a cheap way.
- Not for the casual gamer as even on normal, this is a tough game to beat (doesn't bother me personally though)
