49076342.review:
Graphics:
The graphics in this game are very good for its time. Even playing it in 2019, the game has aged extremely well. I remember being surprised at how good the game looked on my PS3 when I had it. The only setting I had to adjust was VSync, otherwise the tearing was obnoxious. However, with VSync enabled, It stays pegged at 144 FPS on my 34” Ultra-Wide. Additionally, the game makes use of my 2 GTX 970s, something modern games are neglecting big-time. 

Sound: 
The sound effects are very good. The whip sounds, the crushing fists, the jumps, etc. are all spot-on. The Voice acting is phenomenal. There are some games where it sounds like a child was hired to perform the acting, this is believable and engaging. Perfect for the series. I’ve heard that Sir Patrick Stewart is too dramatic. I don’t think so. I usually pick up on cheese like that but I haven’t noticed it here. I was going to make a separate category for music but I’ll just review it here. One of the greatest components of a great game. The music definitely has a gothic feel to it and it is both varied and appropriate. There are some games that will have such a beautiful gothic setting but then the music is dark and dreary. I have never enjoyed that. I always wanted more of an epic feel to it and LoS hits the nail on the head with a sledgehammer. While it definitely has some drear, it mainly utilizes the symphonic goth you expect from the series. Yet somehow, it exceeds my expectations. 

Controls: 
The controls make sense for the most part. The combinations are plentiful. The mix of different modes (shadow and light) allowing for different combos are perfect. They are pretty easy to execute (aside from those requiring the dash) but even the dash combos/relic moves are well-executed considering their requirements. The biggest issue is when the camera switches, the controls sometimes remain for the previous perspective. 

Camera: 
The camera is by far the weakest point of the game. I think most people would agree, though I tend not to rely on ad populum. Even so, it is sometimes annoying. I do not think the camera is weak enough to detract from the fact that this game is a masterpiece. However, I think the game would have definitely benefited from being a proper 3rd person game with more control over camera panning. I think I can understand why there isn’t any control over the panning. I believe it’s because of how often the character is in close corridors.  However, other games have successfully implemented a mechanism in which walls disappear when the gamer is in tight spaces; this should have been utilized in LoS. The lack of panning options seems to detract from the incredible ambiance of the game. Sometimes, I would have liked to have the autonomy to view my surroundings. Again though, this one large flaw is not enough to dissuade me from finishing the game. 

Story: 
The story is very interesting. Even if it’s linear, sometimes I simply want to play through a good story. If the story is enjoyable, it doesn’t have to be an RPG-style game. Some RPG stories are horrible no matter which direction the gamer takes. I’ll take a good linear story with linear exploration over a drab open-world with open choice any day. The linearity of the game doesn’t dismiss the fact that the story and ambiance are incredible. 

Setting: 
The setting is perfect. This is one of the most beautiful games of its genre, even in 2019. The gothic style, the dark castles, the variety in backdrops and environments are beautiful. When you factor in the music and the art-style, they really nailed it in this game. For this style game, I am very impressed with all of the settings. This feels exactly like a Castlevania setting should feel. When playing through the game, I get a feeling similar to one of my favorite games of all time: Simons Quest. 


I’ve heard the knock on the game for drawing too much from Shadow of the Colossus and God of War. However, I feel as though borrowing many elements from those games and implementing them in its own unique setting is fine. Should I knock DCS for drawing elements form FSX, X-Plane, and Falcon? After burner for being similar to Top Gun?  Should I knock Tekken for being too similar to Virtual Fighter? GoW3 is the first game I beat on PS3 so I definitely enjoyed that game. However, I think this game did a phenomenal job of taking components from those style games and making them its own. In fact, I think the setting here is probably better than SoTC, GoW, and Dante’s Inferno.  

As stated, even in 2019 when so many games are being released, if you don’t feel like wasting money on a brand-new trending game, this game has aged very well. I strongly recommend a playthrough. I’m happy I decided to play this game again and probably should have completed it 9 years ago when I first played it on PS3. Additionally, I wish all games originally released on console would port this well.  In fact, when you watch reviews on the original consoles, there were many complaints about the game stuttering during important moments where the action is heavy. That doesn't happen at all on this game. I would go so far to say that this is the premier version of the game.

48663431.review:
This game is a cinematic thrill ride. There are some really breath-taking environments in this game, which are nicely complemented by a beautiful soundtrack. The designs for the characters and monsters are also great, and the voice acting is top notch. The story is also very interesting. It's a reimagining of characters and events that Castlevania fans will be familiar with.

The combat is also great. I really like the light and dark magic, and all of the combos you can memorize and utilize. And I've never been bothered by quick time events. I think the puzzles in this game are also enjoyable, without being too easy or too hard. However, my biggest gripe with this game has to be the camera. It is pretty dang shaky and wonky. There were some points in the game where I wanted to stop and look at the beautiful scenery, and the camera just kept annoyingly moving around. But at least the camera isn't always a problem. Just sometimes.

Overall I'm very happy with this game. It is certainly the best 3D Castlevania I've ever played - which isn't saying much, considering that the other 3D Castlevania games were pretty lackluster.

48202969.review:
Is this a fun game? Yes. Is this a Castlevania game? Not entirely.

So this game is good, story is engaging after the first chapter. The gameplay involves pince of persiaesque platforming, action combat where you have to dodge, block and use a good variety of moves/abilities. Combat also has quick time events aplenty. There are some good boss fights in this one. Also it has many of the iconic Castlevania enemies.

Coming to why this did not feel like Castlevania: the game is split into levels. The only reason to revisit levels are to get collectibles/upgrades that you previously did not. The story only advances linearly level wise. So when revesiting the level you play it from the beginning to get that collectible/upgrade. Sometimes even within the level some branches make it impossible to backtrack forcing you to start from the beginning of the level. For me the experience of Castlevania was backtracking seamlessly, the way "forward" could be anywhere, you search around with your new found upgrades. This does not happen in this game.

In conclusion, going in expecting a pure Castlevania experience might leave you dissapointed. Here is a game which has good gameplay and story worth playing. (Get it on sale tho)

48036303.review:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow is a mixed bag. Some things are good, some things can literaly go to hell.

Good things:
-Story is pretty good, if a little rip-off of God of War. I'll chalk it up to taking inspiration from Greek tragedy and not just copying though. It does have a little cliche "there's a betrayer in your midst," but it isn't that bad is is well set up. 
-Nice atmosphere. The beginning sections are quite gorgeous, and other sections up to the desolate areas are beautiful to look at. The beginning of the Titan Graveyard is a beautiful, but brief, set piece. 
-Characters are nice. Well designed, not too elaborate or over the top. I don't understand Gabriel's accent, but one can get used to things, if one wishes. Patrick Stewart is really good, and I like Pan. 

Really, Really, Bad Things: 
-The platforming works, only when it decides to work... Therefore it goes from being nice to everyone, to rage inducing. ESPECIALLY IF YOU PREFER KEYBOARD CONTROLS. YOU WILL NOT HAVE A FUN TIME IN CERTAIN PLACES. 
-Sometimes the combat feels really unfair. Best examples are from the DLC (included in this edition) and X bosses "rings of protection" that one needs to get through via changing auras. When navigation is dependent on vien diagrams, it feels really frustraiting. Or the Titans.
-Titan Battles: If I wanted to play Shadow of the Collossus I would play that. I'm playing a beat em' up essentially, so I would NOT want this in my beat em' up. 
-The game has a weird fasination with just taking away your (Gabriel's) hard earn powers for lols. This does not produce lols. Especially when one spends an hour going back through levels to upgrade said powers and wants to use them without the game saying "Lol isn't this Yoda type funny? He stole all your stuff! Gotta stop the plot and gameplay for you to run after this walking turd."

And a special note reguarding the DLC:
Personally, it feels rushed and terrible. Most times while playing I kept asking myself "Why am I playing this since I'm clearly not having a good time?" The puzzles aren't particulary fun, especially the Sawblade puzzle. Which is also a primary offender of platforming sins during the first act that caused me to fail a trial without even starting the puzzle. 

Then there is gaming offense no. 236, playing as weaker people other than the main character. No one wants to play as side character 6. It isn't too bad, but I personally feel it slows the gameplay down quite a bit. Perhaps have the puzzle levels as her with occasional fight? In one level?

Also, I feel this it is a sad missopportunity for Victor Frankenstein to appear, especially with the ammount of references in the 2nd part of the game. They have a collectible based around him, but it doesn't do anything. It's just there. Why not have a special level come up after finding all of them? But no, it does nothing. 

And the final boss? Oh good god its bad. The game at one point decides, "You know what this fighting game needs? reticals to throw into the enemy that spasm all over the place!" Something that hasn't shown up in any point of the game. ANY POINT. lovely. 

And what does one get for all this? Strangely scribbled cutscenes made out of sketches. It is not very impressive. And what it adds to the lore could be actually better animated by a common youtuber. And it doesn't make much sense storywise. Shouldn't the downfall of Gabriel be perhaps its own game, or addressed as the second half of the original game. Unless you're an achievement hound, its not worth playing the DLC. 

If you can get this game for cheap, then it's worth your time. Just make sure you're prepared for annoyances that will appear in the game. I wouldn't get it if it was not on sale though. Really, my recomendation would be neutral, had Steam had an option for it.

47957825.review:
First, the positive: the game is beautiful and atmospheric. If you like the Castlevania universe, as I do, then you may want to play this game. There is no other reason to play the game.

Above all, the camera angles are absolutely horrible, not only for fighting but for basic navigation. To be clear, you have no control over the camera; it changes depending on your location. You cross from one point in a room to another and suddenly the camera flips 180 degrees. It's ugly and disorienting. At times objectives are inadvertently "hidden" by the bad camera angles. Obviously, this takes the fun out of combat as well.

Invisible walls abound, making moving around stilted and unpleasant. Combined with the camera angle, some areas can be difficult to navigate; while wall-jumping, for example, you might find that the camera leaps back and forth between two points.

The combat is a bit boring, largely due to the camera angle. The timing on blocks is not intuitive -- it's almost useless, thus eliminating an important area of activity from gameplay -- enemy diveristy is low, and bosses/mini-bosses don't stun at all so combat is reduced to taking pot shots in the middle of battle. Boss battles are very boring.

With the difficulty turned up, all of the above defects become even more apparent and certain areas become quite frustrating. I recommend playing this game on the easiest setting because the flaws in the game make the difficulty artificially higher and unenjoyable; the mechanics simply don't scale well.

The puzzles are also quite boring and tedious. Combined with the atrocious camera angles, they're simply unbearable. Unfortunately, there are a lot of them. They aren't pleasant at all, but quite annoying actually. You often re-cover ground that you've already explored looking for the right object to find or activate. The level are very poorly designed.

47790923.review: Aside from Simon's Quest way back in the day, this is my first NEW Castlevania game. I really enjoy how they didn't deviate too far from the original plot, but made some changes to keep the story unique. That said the storyline was decent. The combat is extremely unique as far as my experiences with video games goes. If you don't know you get upgrades to your main melee weapon and attack combos throughout the game. This was challenging but rewarding. The puzzles in this game, likewise, are challenging but rewarding aside from a few that are just too difficult for my peabrain to figure out without a walkthrough. There were a few things that frustrated me throughout this game. First, the quick time events....... I had to redo a number of fights because I was too slow to react or bumped the wrong button (my fault, I know, but still). Also, some of the fights were nearly impossible on a keyboard and I had to plug in my controller to do them (namely, the fights were you have to swing object around in the air).....no chance my hand eye coordination is allowing me to type WASDWASDWASD without error in the middle of a fight. Overall, the game is great I just had a few hiccups with a couple mechanics. I'd say the game is worth just be warned if you intend to play with a keyboard and mouse, some areas are much trickier than if you played with a controller.

47776053.review:
Here is my totally biased review, based on playing far superior games with actual content, development and storyline. 
Upon reflection, I believe those games also had Quality Control, and possibly even play testing.

This game seeks to challenge those outdated notions, and summarily dispenses with them, replacing them  with fresh, new, invgorating... oh wait, nothing.

[h1]Pro:[/h1]
Is often in a Steam sale. (Probably because no one is [i]stupid[/i] enough to buy this at full price.)

[h1]Cons[/h1] (note this part is plural, whereas the former was a singular statement)

What a steaming pile of crap. 
Not only is the camera control absolutely beserk, but seemingly being a horrific console port, there is often no indication what key you need to be pressing.

This turns boss fights, minor goblin fights and even some environmental challenges into a frustrating bout of die, retry, die, retry another key, etc etc. 
Cut scenes requiring action, have a frantic indicator, showing you need to be reacting to the event, but mysteriously, fails to tell you *which* key, out of the 109 available keys on a PC keyboard.

Combat simply turns into a big old session of button mashing, because what works when you're close to the enemy, doesn't work when you're standing next to, say a tombstone. 
This may not sound like a detriment, until you have a fight in a graveyard, and your character is more investing in turning marble headstone into dust, than killing the large troll who's doing his best to mash your head into figgy pudding

Hilariously (or not), when jumping around like psychotic leprechaun during combat it will sometimes face you the wrong way, with predictable getting-ripped-apart results. Again.
Adding further depth to this frivolity, sometimes the keys change - again without notifying you. So, if trying to break free from a crushing grip was Space, next time it may be Right Click. Or.. who knows ? 
Just... just smash your face into the keyboard repeatedly, and you'll at least have some chance of finding the right key, because the game sure as hell isn't going to tell you.

And despite a deep well of mythical folklore to draw upon, MecurySteam happily ignored it all. For example, your first boss fight is with a troll. It's been long established (LOTR movie notwithstanding) that the only way to kill a troll is with fire, due to their fast regenerative healing. 
"Cool", you say, "Belmont has a fire whip in almost every Castlevania game, *this* should be a doddle".
Except he doesn't. 
No, instead 'Boy Band' Belmont has a chain cross, with not even a small flame coming from it. 
It is at this point, you realise it's going to be a long day.

This game isn't a challenge of skill. 
This is challenge through obscurity. memory learning and chance. It's a shite way to treat your gamers, resorting to a lazy programmers trick to prolong a game.  
In fact, the first few levels are simply wait-a-while events, interspersed with fleeting moments of combat. One of the sections I played was 8 minutes of watch, wait  and move, with approx 2 minutes of combat.
There's no story, character development, nor any reason why you would care about the protagonist.
I confess, I deliberately walked Belmont into the Naiads, just to watch him drown. And then again. And maybe again.

When not trying to decipher combat moves, your character will often get stuck in the scenery.
Or loot items that you need/want, are projected into unpassable vegetation or scenery.
The mighty Belmont, needing a resupply of daggers, is thwarted by a simple shubbery. 
Yep, it's really that pathetic.

Evidently MecurySteam think gamers are masochistic, and have not learned the key lessons from luminaries such as Tim Schaefer, which is a shame given the majority of the developer team would have grown up playing his games.
I absolutely loved Castevania: SOTN, but this atrocity is just too embarrassing to have in my library, so I'll be asking Valve to remove it. 
My only regret is that they cannot also remove my memories of this turgid, steaming pile of defecation.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
Should you buy this game ?
If you like:
[list]
[*] Confusing and inconsistent contextual keys
[*] Repeated deaths that could have been avoided, [i]if only you were clairvoyant[/i]
[*] Combat moves that make [i]no sense[/i] 
[*] Complete avoidance on educating the player on the arbitary contextual control interface.
[/list]
Then you, my masochistic friend, have a bargain on your hands. God help you.

For all other gamers who prefer their games to be fully developed and not stillborn, then please avail yourself of an [i]entire bounty of outstanding fabulous games[/i], filled with evocative nuance (and mindless violence) that lay before you like a room full of glittering gems.

Finally, for the fanbois that have descended upon this review, wondering who would dare desecrate their precious game - if you enjoy *this* game, then good for you. 
I'm not going to judge.
I've long since realised there are elements of the human race that I don't really understand, such as trainspotters, Twitter users, people who watch unboxing videos, and ... you know what, I'm just going to stop right there. I'm just happy that you're happy. 

By all means, leave your response in the comments, but please make it amusing. Anything droll or ranty will get deleted.
Toodles.

This game is a flawed gem. The story is great, the atmosphere is amazing, the fighting is fun and even the platforming has its moments. I only played this with a Xbox one controller however I imagine this is a game that would play poorly with a mouse and keyboard. The biggest issue with the game for me is its terrible controls, repeated QTE's and camera angles. The controls are appalling, where the difficulty seems to come from the imprecision of those controls and the terrible camera angles given. The QTE's are easy and pointless once you get the hang of and are only there to frustrate.

Overall, this didn't detract from the game until the very last chapter (the second DLC). I recommend not playing that level as is just consists of repeated and incredibly difficult platforming and a far too difficult boss fight that requires precicion controls (which you don't have). But despite all the abundance of issues I really enjoyed the game. 

I also only had a couple hours once or twice a week to play this game and in the end I set the level to the easiest level as the difficulty can be pretty punnishing. Everytime I would play it felt like I had to relearn all the combinations for moves which I just got sick of doing.

Pros:
Awesome and captivating story
Great art style - this game won't age bad
Runs really well 1080p 60fps max settings on r9 390x, not one drop. 4k on titan xp no problem also.
Fun fights  (mostly)
Alright platforming (meh)
Some OK RPG character progression

Cons:
Terrible camera angles
Horrible precision with a controller (probably worse with M&K)
Many parts of the game requires precision. This makes the difficulty seem artificial as getting through many levels required repeated attempts until you finally got some luck, not skill.
The last level isn't worth playing - just watch a walkthrough on youtube. This dlc was panned for good reason. Its just really punnishing, luck based platforming and an incredibly hard boss right that requires pin-point precision on your attacks.

47494242.review:
(Important note: This game, for whatever reason, doesn't like being set to fullscreen + max res on a display other than that which Windows / your video card identifies as Display 1, regardless if it's your primary display or not. Weird bug but easy to fix.)

Lords of Shadow is a flawed but polished masterpiece and a triumph of artistic direction. It's shortcomings are forgivable. That said, since you can expect to sink upwards of 40hrs into this, I'll go into some more detail.

Presentation wise, this game is stunning. Masterful visuals paired with smooth and optimized 4K performance make for an eye-popping experience. The art team went all out on this and it shows. I've never taken so many screenshots of a game before. Two major detractors though: 1. Some of the cutscenes were pre-rendered for console are unimproved by modern hardware (they still look passable but they're jaggy af); 2. Godrays are a weak point. The score is powerful but not iconic; you'll love it in the moment but try to recall the music later and you'll likely struggle, for the most part. This isn't objectively a bad thing, as it simply means it's enhancing the experience without overpowering it but I was disappointed by the lack of iconic singles and the abscence of a Bloody Tears revamp. 

The game's artistic merits help prevent the linearity of the gameplay from getting stale. This is great, because the entire game is on some pretty tight rails with even the camera angle being fixed. This seems to have been a deliberate decision to maintain a more cinematic vibe throughout than we see in most modern games. Paired with a meriad of quicktime events insterspersed with the action, some people may find themselves feeling a little claustrophobic. However, none of this detracts from the arcade action. The quicktime in this is generally unobtrusive and balances user input with the epic visuals  better than, say, God of War, where you're missing most of the cool action because you're focused on not screwing up the minigame. In LoS here, you can do all the QT without letting it distract you from the show that's being put on for us and it's a good feeling.

Gameplay wise, this has a balanced mix of combat, puzzle-solving, and climbing/exploring. It's blended in the ways of classic action adventure titles wherein a sense of journey/wonder is maintained without it becoming too non-stop bloody or too bland. That said, the puzzles are generally quite easy and the exploration is limited to the linear but cinematic route there for us to discover. Combat wise, the action is quite fast and your character has access to dozens of moves; mastering the action gameplay is pretty fantastic. I would have preferred to see a bit more action in the core game and I wish there was some sort of arena survival mode, like in Onimusha.

The gameplay difficulty caps at "Knight," the second hardest difficulty, until you clear chapter XII. This is a mixed bag as Knight is well tuned in that a competent player can expect to clear most of the game's encounters without dying unless there's some hidden trick you can only learn through trial/error. The downsides are as follows: a) Knight isn't really challenging enough to force you to use all the tools at your disposal in combat to succeed; b) to 100% the game you have to replay the whole thing on Paladin difficulty; and c) When you unlock Paladin, you have access to tools and powers that both enable you to speedrun most levels and which trivialize every fight, even on the highest difficulty, so skilled players spend most of the game feeling unchallenged and the whole point of locking Paladin defeats its purpose. That's not to say the fights aren't still exciting, just that you're not going to be a master of the combat system because you were never truly tested. There's a happy ending for thrill-seekers though in the form of the additional "DLC" content that's included in the Ultimate Edition's chapter XIV, when you get to fight a boss that keeps things interesting on Paladin.

The above positive points come with a major caveat: the last few chapters of the base game are failures in terms of using conveyance to inform the player. Throughtout most of the game, you'll receive a short, well-crafted cinematic to help you from thinking, "uhhhh what the hell do i do / where the hell do I go?" but near the finish line, with previously un-introduced gameplay elements, you're suddenly forced to feel around in the dark for a bizarrely obtuse course of action. In a game with only one direction to go, this is ridiculous. Eg climbable bone paths, right in front of you, that don't look very climbable, islands you can jump to that you can only see if you stand at the extreme edge of the island you're currently standing on, etc. Basic silly things that shouldn't be an issue. It's ultimately a minor annoyance but when the fix for it would have been so easy it's hard to not be frustrated. It took me an embarassingly long time to figure out why I kept falling off a boss due to a mechanice that only exists on that boss, is only perceptible if you're watching hands to catch a few quick frames from quite far back where your grip slips, and which looks exactly like an input error as opposed to an actual mechanic. It's bad because it busts up the tempo and kills the immersion at a crucial point leading into the conclusion. The plus side is that when you replay the same sections after learning your lessons, the tempo/flow feels amazing, makes for an even more cinematic experience, and you feel like you've really mastered the game.

The narrative is quite good. It starts out as what seems like decent B-movie fare, passable without getting in the way of the action. It quickly evolves into something good in its own right. I was aware of the big twist going into this but the journey to get there is well crafted and well executed with lots of little twists and depth along the way. The voice acting is pretty stellar as well. At first, you're going to wonder wtf is up with Patrick Stewart narrating with the feigned innocence and naivety one uses when reading to a child, but there's actually a method to his madness and his narrtive performance, ultimately, is spot on. Everyone's, Patrick Stewart's included, character acting is superb. Solid VA casting. There are some powerful moments in here. The story is a departure from the norm for the Castlevania series but it also gives it more room to grow laterally, so really nothing to complain about here.

The game should be played with a controller. A modern fight stick also works perfectly and pairs well with the quick arcade action. This has tight controls but they're initially frustrating until you master the little quirks of direction/timing to make it feel like you have 100% control of the action. It's almost like a cross between a hack & slash and a fighter in terms of how much control you have, how fast you have to react, and stupid you feel if/when you screw it up. It's actually pretty rewarding. Once you master it, the game is going to look/feel as smooth as a movie the entire time without hamstringing your actions in combat.

Overall, this is well produced AAA title with a lot of heart behind it. You -will- get annoyed/frustrated/confused at times by a few instances of derpy design cheese but there's way too much good stuff in this title to let that get in the way or spoil your enjoyment.

I'm a big fan of the Castlevania series, and honestly this doesn't feel like it fits.  Not much Castle, no Vania to speak of.  It plays like a Devil May Cry; broken into linear stages with occasional divergences from the main path that either lead to collectibles or loop back to rejoin the main path later in the stage.  Which, if that's what you're in the mood for or were expecting, then great - that's just not what I think of when I think 'Castlevania'.

I genuinely enjoyed the first half of the game.  The writing is a bit hamfisted (and hearing as esteemed an actor as Patrick Stewart deliver some truly awfully written lines was quite a shame) but overall, not bad.  Things start to go downhill halfway through the second Lord's castle, and decline from there.  Questionable puzzle mechanic choices, very little variation in enemies or mobs, and it felt a bit like they finished the game, thought it was too short so shoehorned a good half-dozen extra levels in to make it longer.  By the end, it felt like a chore, and I only stuck with it to finish it because of the time I'd already invested.

Estoy en mi tercera rejugada, ahora vía Steam, y sgue siendo un juego brutal, uno de los mejores Castlevania que existen y el port más redondo jamás hecho a PC.

Primero: Corre a 60 fps en una tostadora. Esto lo corroboro habiéndolo jugando en mi antiguo FX4300 con 8 GB de RAM y una HD7770 con los gráficos a medio. Cualquiera que tenga un ordenador mínimamente actual no debería preocuparse por poder o no jugarlo

Segundo: Es bueno. Muy, muy bueno, Como viene haciendo la saga desde Symphony of the Night toma la jugabilidad descaradamente de otras sagas, en este caso God of War, pero no tiene a Kratos así que afortunadamente el juego no da asco. El estilo freeform de los combos le sienta de maravilla y los movimientos especiales, armas secundarias y magia le dan vidilla al asunto. No esperéis un Castlevania tradicional que no lo váis a encontrar, pero eso tampoco es necesariamente un defecto.

Tercero: La ambientación es sublime. Cada nivel es diferente dando la verdadera sensación de estar realizando un viaje, y todos los niveles son oscuros y retorcidos. La banda sonora es ambiental, lo que para muchos será un defecto, pero lo cierto es que le viene como un guante.

Cuarto: Si eres novato en la saga ¡No importa! Lords of Shadow supone un debut, con nuevo maloso, nuevos orígenes para el primer Belmont y viejos nombres colocados en nuevos roles. Si te atrapa lo suficiente tienes una saga enteriiiiiiiiiiiiita por explorar. Los 3 Castlevanias de GBA están en Wii U, los 3 de NES y los 2 de SNES en Wii U y 3DS, Rondo of Blood y SotN en esa especie de timo que ha publicado Konami en PS4 (Y exclusivamente en PS4, porque son las versiones incluidas en Dracula X Chronicles metidas en el emulador propietario de PSP de Sony al doble de precio) y para el resto ya te buscarás la vida. Es una sagaza, y Lords of Shadow es el punto de partida perfecto.

El único defecto es que el juego es de Konami pero ¡Ey! Está a 5 € así que tampoco ganarán tanto dinero con tu compra.

Incredibly linear game with lacklustre predefined camera angles, laden with mindless button bashing, brimming with egregious QTE sections with endless cutscene after cutscene breaking up any gameplay you may be given. 45871713.review:
Good game, combat is well done, puzzles are well done, visuals are good, optimised for PC too, has a very lengthy campaign and has a decent story. 


Story:

The story starts off as being a quest for love but slowly becomes something else and (minor spoilers), Gabriel becomes more and more worn down by the end, he always means well and even [[major spoilers start]] takes on the embodiment of evil itself to save humanity. He is actually a great character with a pure heart that will sacrifice himself for a higher cause, unfortunately he ends up in the worst possible situation by the very last chapter [[major spoilers end]]. For this reason I'd say its a great story if you look at character development. 

Also great logs and scrolls left by dead knights, flesh out the world more and even foretell of upcoming events. There is also an index for characters and monsters which helps you learn more of the lore but also what weaknesses each creature has in combat. 

Combat

It is good but the final boss (from the DLC chapter) is almost like a devil may cry boss whilst the game doesn't have devil may cry level combat speed and execution of moves takes slightly longer than the boss will allow for so you need to have perfect timing to beat it. OTher than that the game is very enjoyable with a great deal of combat techniques and the need to switch between light and shadow magic to be most effective against enemies. 

Many bosses and sub bosses which adds a great deal to the whole journey. 

Puzzles are interesting and some require a bit of thought too, which is fantastic. Really enjoyed this aspect of things. 

I did the game collecting everything except the last few magic gems and it took me over 20 hours. 

Definitely worth the purchase, and its even cheaper on humblebundle store when discounted. 


Cons:

Platforming is an issue, in some places requiring tight parameters but controls aren't good enough for this so expect many deaths in some places. 

Also I wish there was more interaction between gabriel and random townsfolk, etc. But I understand why this wasn't the case given the story and his motives. But it would have made us care for the main character a bit more and allow for some personality development outside of the main motives. Also would have helped the pacing as at times it can feel a bit too long between dialogue with others. 

Some parts require you to replay to get items, etc. These parts seem a bit drawn out upon replay but this is a minor complaint. 


8/10 overall, recommended!

45853176.review:
[h1] All of his Love [/h1]
Basic premise/Story

From developer studio, Mercury Steam and Kojima Productions is a dark fantasy action adventure starring Gabriel Belmont; a member of the brotherhood of light. An order full of knights dedicated to defending the innocent from the supernatural. He embarks on a quest against the Lords of Shadow who have disrupted the natural order of Earth and its bond with the heavens. Seeking absolution for his wife who no longer walks on this earth. But bound between the living and dead, forever trapped for eternity. Evermore determined by his recent tragedy Gabriel’s mission is clearer than ever. To release souls in perpetual torment caused by the Lords of Shadow. His quest begins. 

[h1] Seeing Beyond Whiplashes [/h1]
Unique Gameplay to be aware of

Castlevania: Lords of Shadow plays as an third person action adventure set in a dark fantasy setting with certain homages to famous folklore all contained in it’s own universe. It takes the classical spin of fantasy into a darker turn as evident by literally throwing players in a fight against a werewolf as a boss. Such a gloves off approach details to anyone interested in an enthralling and serious story in the Castlevania universe. 

The game is divided by chapters with multiple levels within a chapter to tackle. These aren’t a single area created by developers to have Gabriel wack at his enemies on end. But semi-linear areas within levels to traverse and in some cases different paths to take as well. Paths littered with platforming, an area of combat, and verticality swinging as if your mistakenly called the medieval Tarzan. What is interesting is some slight backtracking involved when you need a certain tool you haven’t required yet, as well as several paths cleverly hidden to mask these paths. Making what you would assume a linear level to hide its true nature. Players who enjoy a sense of exploration and cracking at every jar or crate will feel familiar with such gameplay mechanics. These levels aren’t without some consequence, almost all of them have some form of puzzles to solve. These puzzles are never mind-bending nor outside the box thinking. Newer mechanics, for example, are shown slowly as you progress further into the story in order to ease players with new tricks and gadgets to use at their disposal. More often than not these tools are vital in clearing a level to progress or backtrack to an earlier level to unlock a secret you couldn’t unlock before. Even more helpful are scrolls you may find littered by deceased brotherhood of light members who may shed more light on the puzzles or deliver a final account of their last days. However, some puzzles can be bypassed should they prove too hard for the player. Making it easier for those who do not want to be blocked by puzzle obstacles. 

The chapter levels are never too long to become tedious nor are they too short to experience to the fullest. The level design changes in every level to not become an eyesore for repeated mechanics of jumping, platforming, puzzle-solving, fighting enemies, mini-bosses and repeating the formula albeit with changes in the pattern. 

What is interesting to note is the combat. You can buy more moves each time you kill an enemy in the form of experience. With advanced moves and special moves unlockable as you progress further into the story and acquire more weaponry to unlock more moves to do. The combo based combat is light, and nearly all the moves are easy to execute and to purchase. There are enough enemies in the game in Warrior difficulty to buy any combat moves to flesh out Gabriel some more. The decision to make some more combat moves purchasable by experience is a welcome feature. But also I can learn the controls early on. It allows me the freedom to purchase more advanced moves later to supplement Gabriel’s arsenal even further in bashing the skulls of my enemies to dust. 

While it can be a daunting task for Gabriel to undertake to defeat the Lords of Shadow, he will meet certain individuals on his journey to help him. So never fear, you are not alone on this venture!

[h1] Dark, yet Vibrant Fantasy Awaits [/h1]
The Graphics

The dark fantasy setting for Lords of Shadow is aptly named. Each time you enter a new chapter level there are larger than life in nature, on trees, the looming castles, and dreadful creatures oozing with terror and power. Even the bosses and mini-bosses look particularly well defined and can be differentiated from the common mobs of enemies you encounter. Graphically, the game also makes use of smooth transitions from quick time events in game to cinematic that doesn’t detract from the overall depth of the story. Exemplified by the actions of Gabriel and what he does during harrowing moments. 

[h1] To Live on, To Struggle further, And the Weight of Burden [/h1]
The Usage of Sound And Music. 

The sound design is full of drums, violins, trumpets, piano and high, low, short and long vocals. Reminiscent of an orchestra playing in the background seeking to give morale to the player in need. Or start in low haunting and dreary tones to gradually increasing levels of tempo. To deliver urgency and frantic action inbound. Then there are moments of classical heroic tracks comes along as if your about to pull an epic feat in an intense battle. These tracks are numerous and never feel tedious to listen to. To the voice actors Robert Carlyle and Patrick Stewart, they put up a phenomenal job delivering their lines. I could hear the emotions pouring from the two and couldn’t stop listening to their dialogue whenever they said something. 

[h1] Finding Purpose, despite Recent Tragedy [/h1]
Final thoughts/Ruminations

The camera placement in a third perspective is a mixed bag. While I did appreciate the sense of scale regarding the environments of each chapter level and the setting landscapes used. I didn’t like the camera fixed without player input to see around Gabriel. It was a hamper for exploration, whenever I wanted to backtrack and then the camera shifted in an angle that forced me to see the area only from that angle. These camera changes can change spontaneously as Gabriel moves around into a different part and isn’t truly a dealbreaker. What does take away from the majesty of the game’s environments is the combat during times of intense clashes with the enemy that requires a lot of moving. These moments weren’t a lot, but a sizable portion remained where I had to move a lot during combat and the camera abruptly changes to match a different view of the battlefield is troublesome. And these abrupt camera changes occurs frequently during levels with a large area making the momentum you gained fighting enemies sometimes lost. Because of a second or two to reorient my eyes to the new perspective. It’s not a deal breaker, by any means for the change in camera perspective is still manageable. But, it's a troubling matter easily fixed if I had control of the camera. 

[i] Throughout my 22 hours with Castlevania: Lords of Shadow I didn’t experience any major bugs or glitches. The game ran smooth like slicing butter with a knife. Overall; Lords of Shadow feel like a cinematic experiment trying to mix the best parts of cinematic and combo-based combat along with slices of puzzles and platforming is an interesting challenge to undertake. While it does suffer mainly in the camera and certain dodging mechanics, it presents players with a unique story in a dark fantasy setting. Unafraid of tackling shadows nor facing beings larger than life itself. Bring a struggling hero, who is dealt a heavy hand in tragedy. And ultimately demonstrates to newcomers and veterans of Castlevania a new story unfolding from the darkness. [/i]

45791445.review:
I remember when this title first came out critics panned it, saying "it's basically 'God of War.'"

I also remember being confused as to why this was a bad thing, considering how much the same reviewers could not stop gushing over their man-crushes for Kratos: the revolutionary anti-hero, who would rather heroically kill every man, woman, and child on Earth, than admit he was an idiot for trusting the word of a man made entirely of fire and spider legs. But, I digress.

Yes, "Lords of Shadow" shares mechanical similarities to the combat in "God of War." But, it also features a whip as its primary weapon. A whip is a much more practical ranged melee weapon than a pair of flaming machetes attached to bungee-chains. (Okay. I promise that's my last jab at GoW.) 

Castlevania Lords of Shadow is also a jaw-droppingly beautiful game, and it knows it. It welcomes you to judge. Heck, it even gives you the original concept art mock-ups and dares you to compare them to the finished 3D set pieces. And considering that this was a 2010 release, the fact that it still looks damn fine is no small feat.

The game's musical score isn't especially varied. However its main theme is epic enough that it never gets old throughout the entire quest's run-time. And most of the score is just variations of that main theme. The fact that it's good enought that I wasn't annoyed by it after 12+ hours is sort of amazing. You know waht else is amazing? The stage-crafted tone P. Stew's thespian monologues! And there are quite a few of them. Trust me, you will get MORE than your money's worth of Patrick Stewart voice overs. And the voices that aren't Sir Patrick Stewart? Yeah, they're also pretty dead solid. Quality VA work all around.
 
Castlevania's focus is naturally on combat. However, the constant skirmishes are nicely broken up by a variety of puzzles, that breathe a lot of life into the experience. There are also extended platforming challenges. And, I will admit, the jumping mechanics are less than great. Originally, I was going to make this a serious black mark against Lords of Shadow's design. But, then I thought of its NES source material and remembered trying to jump anywhere in Castlevania has always been a nightmare! So for all I know, the godawful jumping was an intentional choice...it certainly makes the Clock Tower a more authentic experience.

Oh, and the game's story is pretty okay. Gabriel is sympathetic enough as a character that you can't help but feel badly for the Catch 22 he finds himself entrapped between the bureaucracy of Heaven and the vengeful denizens of Hell. As far as reboots go, I think this is  one of the better ones in gaming history. It tries to install some serious emotional legs to a well established series, and does so with relative finesse. Without spoiling anything, after you beat Lords of Shadow, it will make you seriously rethink the dynamics between all the big players in previous Castlevania titles. [spoiler] Dracula hates his roommates as much as you do. He also wishes, he was dead as much as you do. Suddenly, the fact that he always refuses to come down from that one damn tower makes a little more sense. [/spoiler]

In summary, Castlevania Lords of Shadow is basically "God of War." Except for the fact that it looks, sounds, and controls better than the game about the pouty, misogynist, psychopathic albino.

45621837.review:
"A myriad of good ideas, buried beneath an average game with terrible design choices."

This game was....a thing. There's a lot to process here, so I'll try to break it up into three sections. The good, the bad, and the ugly. LoS came out in a dark time with video games, and it suffers from every conceivable drawback that brings with it.

The good: LoS has some amazing design choices, with a simply inspired design team working as best as they could with a dark fantasy setting. A lot of polish was put into this game, and the optimisation is absolutely phenomenal. A smoothe 60fps can be expected at almost any resolution, with max settings. The bosses are frequent, which is (personally) a favourite. As for immersion, it does a great job of making you FEEL like you're in whatever frozen wasteland, arid abyss, or muggy swamp you're in. 

The bad: It's dated. It's SO dated. From the Gabriel's mop haircut, to his almost Liefeld proportions, to the abominable use of quick-time events. No, the reviews were not joking. Open a door? Turn a lever? Fighting an enemy? QUICK TIMES. The bosses are plagued with them too, meaning it becomes more a game of whittling the boss down before trying that DAMN quick-time for the UMPTEENTH TIME!
Now, this is spoiler territory, but it is worth mentioning, so I'll tread lightly. Many of the bosses suffer from gimmicky design. Some you climb up, which makes them more of an obstacle course than an enemy, and unfortunately with the latest example in game? This completely ruins any modicum of intimidation they once posessed. Some bosses require button pressing to defeat, and some...Some are insane. I mean really, truly insane. I'm talking you can die in about 4-6 hits, while they take (and I am not exaggerating here) over 100. It took me almost two hours to beat the DLC's final boss, and I promise you it was not a fun time. If not for the mid-bossfight checkpoints, I don't believe any human being could beat that boss without entering some transcendent realm where they can see the very fabric of the universe and tug upon its strings to tear that bosses heart out of his wretched, steel-clad, glowing weak-spot chest. 

The ugly: This is a special category reserved solely for decisions that were made outside of the game itself that were...poor. Patrick Stewart isn't known as a particularly talented voice actor in games, but boy howdy is he phoning it in here. Another poor decision is the fact that the POST GAME CUTSCENE plays before the DLC, DESPITE that the DLC is set BEFORE the cutscene. Pro tip? Skip the post credits cutscene, then bring it up on youtube after you finish the DLC.
Which brings me to the next point? The cutscenes. While (thankfully) the designers didn't end up locking them at 24 fps (the MADNESS!) they did, however, resolution cap them at around 1080p, so if you're running a monitor higher than that you'll be greeted with more jagged pixels than a busted Pac-Man arcade machine. 
My final victim to mention is the character of Gabriel, who is completely infallible. The game makes no efforts to truly lay any honest blame at his feet. Even when characters call him a savage murderer who has carved his way through hundreds, one must look back across the long line of vampires, ghouls and werewolves who were little more than butcherous animals, and wonder "WHO exactly did I kill that didn't deserve it?"

In conclusion, this game is on sale right now. Pick it up if you want a cheap castlevania with a bit of quality hidden beneath layers of trash. I give it a solid 5/10 -  It would have been 6/10, but holy hell did that final cutscene misplacement burn my soul something fierce, and that final boss....That accursed, final DLC boss...

NEVER AGAIN.

I'll be honest - the difficulty is simply unfair. When you see the enemy casts an attack, it is already too late. There is no fun in not being able to predict a blow. For example- you cannot land a good mid-air combo on the second boss, because eventually you'll die with no way to counter his attack. It's so quick you literally take damage BEFORE his smash animation starts!
Why give a "perfect block" move when there is no way to predict an attack? I mean really! It's all about luck!
It's not "easy to learn, hard to master" type of the game. No, it's not even "hard to master" type of the game. It's "hard to learn, pointless to master" type of game. You literally cannot get to be so good at it, to be able to record you beating a boss fight without taking any damage.  No matter how godlike your reaction time is -you can even be a bot as far as I'm concerned- you'll never be able to mash the buttons so quick that no enemy will be able to hit you. 
Now imaging arriving to a boss area with like 20% of your healh bar remaining. If you're unlucky, there will be no healing fountain in the vicinity. Then you're on your own kiddo, good luck, have fun.

Only 89 minutes into the game, I feel like I dodged a bullet, becuase I still can get a refund.

45512294.review:
I would have said that this was a great game up until the last 2 chapters. Most of the game is playable and fair, though a bit clunky. If you are used to platinum's games then it will feel awkward due to the slight changes to functionality that makes blocking and dodging less than stellar. The story is good but nothing special. 

Now for some insight on why the last chapters ruin this otherwise OK game. The way that Gabriel is writen for the last bit flips his character completely around and feels like an unnatural change that exists purely to make writing his twist easier and worse. Where there could be some reason for his change, we are given none and just expected to accept that he no longer thinks, feels, or acts at all similar to how he was when last we saw him pre credits. In addition to this minor storytelling complaint, the final chapter in particular made me happier to uninstall this game than any point made me happy to be playing. Evey fighting mechanic that was introduced throughout the game outside of double jump is made useless. A major portion of the game's fighting was the perfect block counter with unblockables being shown with a glow on the enemy weapon, but in this last chapter, no attacks are blockable in any form and dodging still goves no invulnerability. In other words, if an enemy attacks then you take damage. The final fight is the worst form of artificial difficulty added in at the last second that I have ever come across. 

TL:DR: 
Good game if you plan to play all but the last 2 chapters. Horrible game if you plan on finishing it past the original content. If you want more Castlevania story, just read about it. This whole thing is an AU anyway.

45494342.review:
The camera will send you to Hell. The voice acting will bring you to Heaven.

For a game called Castlevania, the first 10 hours are devoid of any castles and have little 'vania' to speak of. In terms of what you expect from a Castelvania game, they could have named this something else and you wouldn't have known otherwise until the end. This is a reimagined world. And oh, what a world they've created! 

Unfortunately the camera almost ruins the entire experience. On the one hand, the fixed camera angles make things cinematic and create a sense of scale. On the other, they take control away from the player, resulting in endless frustration, countless misplaced jumps, and accidental deaths. Not to mention the level design being ruined because you can't see where you're supposed to go next, causing immediate annoyance. I would preferred a camera like Dark Souls, where I am in control of it, and yet nothing of the aforementioned qualities are lost.

The music is great, but there's not enough of it, and they use the same songs too often.

The concept art, the environments, and the game design--on paper--are exceptional. It's when they have to turn this into a game that it doesn't work quite as well. It's drawn out much longer than it should have been, and there are many annoying segments, due in large part to you fighting against the camera, rather than the enemies. But Patrick Stewart as the narrator saves the whole experience. And the DLC that comes with the game is also good. 

Overall, a flawed gem. It's not what I expected or wanted out of a Castlevania game, but at the same time I was compelled to keep playing and beat it. It was a slog to get through, even on the easiest setting, but in the end, the positives outweigh the negatives, and the story pays off. 

This game wasn't my cup of tea in terms of game design and overall fun, but it's a game I'll never forget for the feeling that it left me with. Quite an odd experience. I want more of it, but I want it to be better. It makes me want to play more, so I guess it's time to jump into the sequel!

45449428.review:
This is a fun, but highly flawed game. The music is phenomenal and the game is really pretty. 

The combat feels fluid, but there are several game design elements conflicting with eachother. There are no incentives to learn all of your combos, as monsters seem to have seperate cooldowns for dashes, shields and attacks. A monster could be stunned on the floor and it'll still hit you with an unblockable attack as you prepare a combo in mid-air. You'll find yourself spamming the same attack over and over. 

Game has artificial difficulty. On a scale of 1 - 10, Easy is a 1, Normal is a 7 and Hard is a 10. The mechanics are the same, but the monsters' health and damage are scaled. Do not waste time playing on Hard during your first playthrough - I switched after 12 hours of frustrating combat.

Annoying camera angles. The flip between entirely different angles in a single area, making some fights harder. Sometimes monsters that you battle are completely off camera, and they can still lunge at you with an unblockable attack. 

Poor level design. Do you see an open space? Then you're fighting a mob of monsters. It's incredibly predictable. This makes combat feel grindy because you'll never face a monster alone unless it's a mini-boss. Sometimes you'll fight mini-boss after identical mini-boss; how fun. 

Lack of player agency. The game holds your hand throughout the entire game - highlighting where you need to go and telling you exactly what you need to do. The camera will zoom in during a new boss mechanic to emphasize the importance of the next few moments, even though it also highlights the appropriate object. Characters will literally yell at you and tell you what to do. You are handed scrolls that give you information too.

Poor storytelling. The majority of the story is told via long-winded dialogue before each new area. There aren't many cutscenes that relate to the story.

Yet, after all these issues I came back again and again. I'm glad I did. The final fight is intense and the conclusion is tremendous. If you can buy it on sale, do it.

45203149.review:
TLDR:  An otherwise good game reduced to simply being 'above average' by terrible forced camera angles.

The main strike against this game is the camera choices made throughout.  Not having the camera rotate with the player, as is common in almost every third person 3D adventure game, proves clunky, frustrating and wasteful.  It is clunky, because many of the 'hidden' objects rely simply on a poor camera angle obscuring something (a path, an alcove, etc.) that you must blindly walk into to discover. 

 The camera angles are frustrating, because while the camera angle might change from scene to scene - your controls do not.  For example, running off the left side of the screen might transition to a scene where your character enters from the top of the screen... yet holding 'left' on your controller remains 'forward' in movement, which would be down on the hypothetical second scene.  Once you let up on the controls 'down' becomes 'down' once again, but the controls on transition are annoying.  

The camera angles are wasteful, because it's clear they put a lot of effort into some of the scenes.  The detail and artwork are occasionally quite impressive.  Unfortunately, you never really get to take in the whole of a room at once.  You might see the south wall of a room on entry, then the scene will do something stupid like switch to a fixed camera on the south wall that shows most of the north wall, part of the western and eastern walls and most of the floor.  It really is a wasted, missed opportunity for immersion.

Aside from the terrible, terrible camera angles, the only other persistent frustration in the game is the occasional appearance of the Chupacabra.  In short, this little guy appears  periodically, steals all your items and powers, and forces you into a jump-puzzle bout of hide and seek mid-level to recover them.  It's a pointless time-wasting activity which disrupts the flow of a level and grows annoying very, very quickly.  While not as terrible as the terrible, terrible camera angles, it is nonetheless something that should never have made it into the game.

Finally, Sir Patrick Stewart...  As much as I enjoy anything with him in it, sadly, not even his reliably solid voice-over work can erase the previously mentioned negatives which turn this otherwise good game into one that is simply 'above average'.

45049233.review:
This game is good. It's a solid 8/10. Nothing spectacular but definately a solid video game.

The amount of effort put into this game is impressive. I can't believe how many chapters there are. This game is packed with content.

The combat is good. But could have been a lot better in my opinion. 

For starters, 95% of the combo attacks that require a lot of buttons to activate are actually weaker than just holding X? What the heck?? Im not joking

There are so many things wrong with the light/shadow magic orb regeneration system. It's fun when you have a full bar of light/magic energy.. But when you finally deplete your resources, the system to manually refill them totally sucks! It should have been awesome. But its not.

You generate yellow orbs by keeping on your toes and not stopping..Yet they vanish in 7 seconds? Not only that but they only restore a pathetic 0.1% of power each.  That is just plain counter intuitive. You also have to stop combo'ing and put your guard down to vacuum them up. On top of that craziness, your orb-vacuuming range is very small. 

There are so many things wrong with it that you end up having to mostly ignore it. Otherwise you will find yourself trying to restore your health after collecting 1 orb at a time like a fiend!

There are also no invincibility frames while dodging in castlevania LOS. So it's just impractical to expect your players to be able to produce an adequate amount of yellow orbs. You end up having to optimize the time when you activate your powers. And even thats not enough. Oh that reminds me of another thing! They make it seem like the light/shadow energy depletes with TIME. But you quickly notice that it depletes at a pre-set rate based on which move you use. Not cool. 

It's just wasn't worth the mental effort for such a small amount of regeneration. The regen system needs a serious buff. 

Another thing that sucks is that health/powers can only be restored manually. You would think his body would heal naturally on his "Long journey" It really sucks having to quit mid level just to go back to play an earlier level just so you could fill your health/energy bars/materials. 

And if you make the same mistake as me and buy ALL of the skills, it actually makes the game harder because now you will find yourself accidentally consuming HUGE chunks of light/magic energy doing regular moves that were free before. Like double jump becomes "Holy jump" (The game claim it blinds enemies but it seems 99% of enemies are immune to it)  So now, even while in combat, i have to watch that i do not accidentally do a doublejump because i know it will zap all my resources. Easier said than done. What i am forced to do now is doublejump THEN activate light magic so that i can do the powerful spinning attack.

And the puzzles got annoying. There were parts where the game threw so many puzzles at you that it felt like you were playing a 99cent mobile game like temple run or something. Too many brainless kiddy puzzles. Come on konami.

And i really hated the hitboxes. A boss could CLEARLY miss you by a mile and you would still die. If you are going to make a game focused on combat shouldn't you at least ATTEMPT to make the hitboxes somewhat accurate? 

And it bothered me that the cutscenes were 720p. Nothing takes you out of the immersion more than a pixelated resolution drop.

But for 3 dollars. I got to see some really nice graphics/environments and have many hours of relaxing fun leaning back in my chair with a controller. So it would be foolish of me to not reccomend this title.

Basically its just your average video game. Nothing special

**Update** DO NOT BUY THE SKILL HOLY JUMP! It uses up a ton of light energy and activates when you are doing something you would do normally (double jumping) This makes it so your light energy mode depletes near instantly at the last boss which you must double jump to hit his head. And if you want to regen HP off his head then you will have to activate light magic only after you doublejump. Which sucks having to have to pay attention to.

44375576.review:
Since I recently finished the game, I thought I'd post a short-ish review.

The level design and the puzzles both are occasionally frustrating, and sometimes more vague or unclear than I'd personally care for. I also ran into a few bugs here and there, where the game would either freeze for a minute apropos of nothing, or crash to desktop (but that only happened once or twice that I remember). Those minor blemishes however don't spoil or hold back what is otherwise an engrossing and fun game! The story and the lore are interesting as well, which is more than I can say for many games. 

The art direction is enticing, the voice acting is great, and the gameplay gave me plenty of challenge. Personally I don't mind quick-time events, as long as they don't feel unreasonable, and this game has them in just the right amount for my taste. I also don't mind not having control over the camera, as I feel it gives the game a certain kind of "Castlevania" quality to it, but I'll admit that sometimes it can be a smidge wkward. And for an Xbox 360/PS3 game, the graphics are pleasingly pretty on all max settings, even if those seldom-played cutscenes (the ones that aren't in-engine) didn't get the upgrade, but those are very short anyway. There's something to be said for the atmosphere and the music, which are beautiful and par for course for this franchise. 

Overall, decent game. I love the concept, and it feels right at home in Castlevania. It is unfortunate however that I found myself scratching my head so often at the game's knack for making you feel stupid; there's definitely a difference between thought-provoking and plainly unclear, and this game straddles the line a bit. Not to mention the bugs, which are always disappointing. 

If you can overlook the small imperfections, and you're into Castlevania, it's definitely worth playing.

44260670.review:
This is definately a sale game as previously reviews have stated. If anything is compareable, it is a poorly translated God of War. The campaign is serviceable and the graphics are rather stunning in HD. My complaints are with just about everything else.

Pros:
-Graphics
-Combat
-Interesting Puzzles

Cons:
-Glitches (lots)
-Camera (I haven't seen such a bad camera in a while)
-Inconsistent flow (difficulty, some bosses require no effort, while others may just randomly toss you around like a rag doll)
-Platforming/pathing

As stated by other reviewers a major issue is the camera which leads to other problems. While there are hints to where you are going, sometimes the camera even blocks them. I have actually experienced glitches to the point I have had to reload entire sections because I was correctly solving the puzzle, but the piece refused to either go in place or reflect light properly. 

Other notes is the platforming. For some reason the game will normally prevent you from jumping off inaccessible ledges. But if you are at the edge of one attempting to go to the next you will either succeed or fall, regardless of positioning as jumping requires no thought.

There are alot of quicktime events, and sometimes they do have purpose, such has bosses and the flow. Other times such as for turning switches or rotating cranks, it almost feels superfluous.

God of War fans will appreciate new scenery for the similarly built combat and progression design. Just be aware this is essentially a poorly optimized adaptation to the God of War series though. My biggest gripe as stated before is the awful camera, and the non-responsive controls. Sometimes the required buttons, and othertimes it gets you killed.

Good for a sale though, which is how I got it. The artwork is also amazing.

A solid game that conveys a new take on the franchise.

Lords of Shadow ditches the eponymous metroidvania genre in favor of the "god of war formula". The game maintains a few exploratory elements but to be honest everything is mostly straightforward - not exactly "on rails", but definitely not open.

The story is actually very good, even though it has some noticeable flaws and the plot twist can be seen coming a mile away. The bosses are memorable with a few exceptions, and the lore of the world is enticing.

Also surprisingly, the soundtrack is very good. Not Symphony of the Night or Lamment of Innocence levels of grandeur, but it is fitting and nice to listen to.

I definitely recommend it!

Terrible hitboxes, bad camera, bad level design ( despite the game being extremely linear ), weird delay on animations, 720p cinematics, QTE galore, and the game doesn't save at the end of a level, making you start the previous one at the checkpoint if you quit before selecting the next mission.

For some reason in this game you don't get hit when the enemy finishes his animation, but at the start of it. That lycan 10 meters away will totally hit you when it STARTS jumping at you, and not when it actually gets to you. Same for titans, I couldn't understand why I always got hit by their stomping despite jumping/dodging the shockwave, and that's because you get hit exactly when the fist/foot hits the ground (or even before, even if you're far away ) and not when the shockwave hits you.

This makes dodging/blocking almost impossible since you don't even know when to dodge/block. It's extremely noticeable when you manage a timed block BEFORE the enemy even moved to hit you. It's complete bullshit.

Add to that a fixed camera showing you only a portion of the combat zones, you constantly get hit by enemies being offscreen, and during the plateform bits sometimes you don't know/see where to go, or your character isn't even on the screen due to blind spots. And it doesn't help that the direction you're moving in doesn't change with the camera sometimes, like, you're going right, then the angle changes et you're going forward but you still have to press right to go forward. Also some asshole thought it would be funny to have the camera constantly swing like if it was affected by the wind or something. It doesn't add anything to the game, it's annoying and can even cause motion sickness.

43642627.review:
Castlevania Lords of shadow is the type of game that either people like or do not like. The game has many good things, but at the same time I can understand why there are fans of the series who did not like the game. At first, I often wanted to uninstall it. I really did not know what to think about it, so I kept pushing and playing and I'm glad I finished it. The game consists of story, combat, exploration (it is linear), jump on platforms, puzzle and repeat (not on all levels but in most of them)
The game has a more than decent story, I would say that it is one of the best stories in the series. The problem with this is that at the beginning it is slow, very very slow (this being one of the reasons that I did not liked the game). You’ll need patience, but it's worth it. It's different from the other games, it's not about going to kill Dracula ... again. Which is refreshing and interesting. It’s 14 to 16 hours long on normal difficulty (not including the dlc). The voice acting is incredibly good as well as the sublime artistic direction and an excellent soundtrack. The level design is good and the architectural details in them are beautiful, but some puzzles affect the levels design. These puzzles become frustrating at times, they take a while to complete, there is also the possibility of committing an accident and having to restart it. Something to mention is that looking for the chupacabra is a nuisance later ... .. It's good the first 2 times, and then it's something that is abhorred
The combat can be described as a copy of God Of War. There are combos, you have to dodge, block, etc. But not as Devil May Cry or Bayonetta. You can  combine many moves and you can experiment, It’s not  a single button. Nothing amazing or special but it works ... but something that does not work sometimes is the camera. The camera already has a fixed angle(Like resident evil) in all the rooms which makes the combat in some parts more difficult than it should be. Also in combat there are many QTE (Quick time events) which consist of pressing a certain button in due time or pressing fast and these are many.The graphics are very good, it still looks very good today, Even with the low graphics it looks very good. We also have our movements to explore. (Some are unlocked in the course of the story, combat moves are the only ones that are purchased.) They are very similar to those of Assassins Creed or Shadow of the Colosus, so you have to climb and move around the walls, among others things. Finally I have to say that the difficulty of the game is somewhat challenging, even in normal.But at the end it's a good game,It has problems but it is a good experience. 
There are some very good details in the game, the sunlight harms the vampires and when Gabriel grabs something from a dead body he cross himself. Small details that’re cool and give a certain charm.
Can I recommend this game? I can recommend it but it doesn’t mean that you might like it. As I said, I can understand why there are many who did not like it. If you like Castlevania games then yes, buy it and play it at least once. The story is great. Very underappreciated game.
________________________________________________________________________________
Castlevania Lords of shadow es el tipo de juego el cual o le gusta a la gente o no le gusta. El juego tiene muchas cosas buenas, pero al mismo tiempo puedo entender por qué hay fans de la seria a quienes no le ha gustado el juego. Al principio, muchas veces se me dieron las ganas de desinstalarlo. Ha decir verdad no sabía que opinar de él, así que seguí empujando y jugando y me alegro haberlo terminado. El juego consiste de historia, combate, exploración(es algo lineal),saltar en plataformas, puzzle y repetir ( no en todos los niveles pero si en la mayoría). 
El juego tiene una historia más que decente, diría yo que es una de las mejores historias de la saga. El problema de ello, es que al principio es lenta, muy muy lenta (este siendo uno de los motivos el cual el juego no me agradaba). Se tiene que tener algo de paciencia, pero vale la pena. Es diferente a la de los otros juegos , no se trata de ir matar a Dracula…de nuevo.Lo cual es algo refrescante e interesante. Está siendo de 14 a 16 horas de largo en dificultad normal  (sin incluir el dlc). La actuación de voz es increíblemente buena al igual que la sublime dirección artistica y una excelente  banda sonora . El diseño de nivel es bueno y los detalles arquitectónicos en ellos son hermosos, pero algunos puzzles llegan a afectar su diseño. Estos puzzles llegan a ser frustrantes muchas veces, pueden tomar algo de tiempo en hacer y porque hay también la posibilidad de cometer algún accidente y tener que reiniciarlo. Algo que mencionar es que buscar al chupacabras es una molestia mas adelante….. Es bueno las primeras 2 veces, ya luego es algo que se aborrece.
El combate se puede describir como una copia de God Of War. Hay combos , hay que esquivar,bloquear,etc.Pero no como Devil May Cry o Bayonetta. Pero se pueden llegar a combinar muchos movimientos y se puede experimentar, no solamente es de presionar un solo botón. Nada asombroso ni especial pero funciona… pero algo que no funciona algunas veces es la cámara. La cámara ya tiene un ángulo fijo en todos los cuartos el cual hace el combate en algunas partes sea más difíciles de lo que debería de ser.  También no falta de mencionar que en el combate hay muchos QTE ( Quick time events) los cuales consisten en presionar cierto botón a su debido tiempo o presionarlo rápido y de estos son muchos.Los gráficos son muy buenos, aun se ve muy bien hoy en día, Incluso con las opciones graficas bajas se mira muy bien. También tenemos nuestros movimientos de explorar. (algunos se desbloquean en el transcurso de la historia. Los movimientos de combate son los únicos que se compran.) que son muy parecidos a los de assassins creed o shadow of the colosus ,asi que hay que escalar y moverse por las paredes entre otras cosas.Por ultimo tengo que decir que la dificultad del juego es algo desafiante, incluso en normal.  Pero es buen juego, tiene sus problemas pero es una buena experiencia.
Hay unos detalles muy buenos en el juego ,la luz del día daña a los vampiros y Gabriel cuando agarra algo de algún cuerpo se persigna .Son detalles pequeños que dan un encanto y cierto carácter.
Puedo recomendar este juego? Lo puedo recomendar pero no significa que te podría gustar. Como he dicho, puede entender por que hay a muchos a quienes no le a gustado. Si te gustan los juegos de castlevania pues si ,cómpralo y juégalo por lo menos una ves. La historia en buenísima. Un juego que lamentablemente no es muy apreciado.
