43496337.review:
Castelvania: Lords of Shadow feels like a game released 15 years ago that was actually released 5 years. It has not aged well in any respect. It is an isometric action game with some mild platforming and puzzle elements. It handles none of these things in either an innovative or fun manner.

People will claim this is a God of War clone. They are correct to a point; God of War's combat was crisper, more fluid, more natural, and more responsive to player inputs. While both had camera angle issues it seemed less annoying in God of War. Castlavania lacks for enemy variety and it's lack of weapon choices makes combat a chore as you progress. Many of the new moves you will learn require magic, and since that is in finite supply you won't be using it much on trash mobs. This just worsens the repetitive gameplay. In the end you are going to stick to a move set that works and simple forget trying to memorize the other combos out there. Basically, X, X, X, roll, X, X, X, block, etc. 

The platforming elements are similar to God of War or the Prince of Persia: Sands of Time, but lacks the organic movement of those games. Basically, unless it's glowing you can't touch it. That wooden plank that looks grabbable? Nope, not shiny, can't touch it. That hook 50 feet in the air? Yup, it's shiny all yours. But not that other hook 20 feet in the air. Platforming becomes a 'find the shiny thing' game. They couldn't just do away with it or the game would be impossible as far as progression goes. There'd be know way to tell which way to go, particularly with some levels that have an element of verticality. Lastly, the "Titan fights" are ripped straight out of Shadow of the Colossus without any of the atmosphere. These look good but ultimately just take a required number of attempts to learn the patterns, and then it's just one big Quicktime event.

The puzzles are not much better. Puzzles in video games are tricky - they have to nail that sweet spot of not too easy but not too hard. But Castlevania plots out a new axis - frustrating and unsatisfying. I was able to solve all of the puzzles without a walkthrough, but they were either too easy amounting to a speed bump, or I was spending half hour playing 'find-the-glowing-thing". You don't get those "Eureka!" moments you do in games like Portal or traidtional point-and-click style adventures. What a chore.

Lastly the game has borrowed mechanics that gamers have long since grown bored of. Quicktime events were so very 10 years ago, no one wants to see them again. Worse, "the cake is a lie" makes a guest appearance as a pickup. Ugh.

Graphically it's a dated game. Gabriel looks blocky. The voice acting is weak (even Patrick Stewart), it's hard to get invested in the story, and I think I will throw up if I have to watch another Superhero Landing after breaking through stained glass.

It doesn't help that the game is just too long and too padded. Huge chunks of levels could have been trimmed or stitched with other levels and not taken away from the experience. Worse, many levels have areas blocked off in a Metroidvania fashion. These places aren't hidden or secret, they're sitting in front of you, taunting. The only reason for them to exist is to further pad out the play time by forcing you to go back for the collectible after you got the requisite item. I mean you don't [i]have[/i] to but it does feel like a naked attempt to try and increase the playtime with some unnecessary mechanic.

I can't recommend this game to Metroidvania fans because, well, this isn't a Metroidvania, and I can't even recommend it to God of War fans as it's just inferior and does nothing new. It is however a long game. But as the saying go, "The food at this place is really terrible, and in such small portions"

43363047.review:
Talking from the perspective of someone who only barely touched the original Castlevania games, I can't really say I'm a hardcore fan. But the Lords of Shadow series has always intrigued me, and the first chapter is responsible for that. It's honestly a very underappreciated game, and there is some genuine talent and art put into it. The story is quite interesting for its genre, and while it could have used a bit more interactions or characters, I feel like it more or less delivers, again, considering its genre. The highlights of the game are the gameplay, music and art-style.
It's a type of hack&slash, God of War-type of game, clearly born on the console. I honestly have no issue with that and I quite liked the idea of the combat cross combos. It's definetely fast-paced, even if a bit repetitive at times. Bosses are a challenge sometimes, though, and they are all original and well-designed.
The areas you visit have interesting backstories, and I really liked the fact that not all the game takes place inside the castle, but you actually see quite a bit of the world around it. They are all crafted with great artistic talent and, especially the castle is a marvel to look at, having that special gothic feel to it. Music is also very good, with some of the tracks being quite emotional, and creating an original mood and feel to the game.
On the flipside, the main hero Gabriel has an interesting story arc and conclusion, but his personality is extremely boring and could have used more work. Voice acting is top notch, accompanied by the skillful Patrick Stewart, who's a joy to listen to.
Overall, I'd reccommend this game as an easy to get into, action game with fast-paced combat, good music and atmosphere and amazing gothic art assets. Just don't expect anything revolutionary from the story or protagonist.

43335706.review:
"That's odd." I said after playing this game for 30 minutes. "This feels a LOT like Darksiders 1."

After playing the game through to completion, that is probably the best way to sum this game up.  Similar to Darksiders, this title is a mash-up of a God of War style combat system and a Nintendo collectathon where you solve puzzles and slowly gather items and abilities to make you stronger.  Unlike Darksiders though I'm sort of torn on whether to give this one a positive recommendation.  It's certainly a servicable title but there are a host of issues that make me wonder if this game was rushed out the door at the last minute.

Let's start with the cutscenes.  They look like shit, especially in the few times there's rain.  Granted this game isn't exactly new but the game in motion looks ten times better than the cutscenes which is kind of jarring.  

The plot has some interesting threads, but they're poorly tied together and a lot of the overarching narrative is as predictable as it gets.  Bad shit's going down in medieval dark-fantasy Europe, and Gabriel is on a journey to fight some Dark Lords and gather their power to bring his wife back to life. Patrick Stewart voices an NPC that sometimes helps you out and reads a brief intro to each stage, commenting on Gabriel's journey.  Unfortunately most of his commentary is "Gabriel hasn't slept or eaten and he's feeling increasingly angry" which is odd given that we see virtually no sign of this in game.  We're supposed to believe that Gabriel is taking a journey down a dark path as a anti-hero but the man is constantly acting like a classic good guy. The rest of the actors are hit-and-miss, though I do like Gabriel's accent. A side note: the game's epilogue makes NO sense unless you play the DLC chapters - which is part of the reason I'm convinced this game was rushed out the door.

The game is divided into chapters, which are further divided into stages.  You can replay stages at any time, and each stage tends to have some hidden upgrades that make revisiting them worth the trip when you've powered up.  It's not quite classic Castlevania but it does the trick I guess.  I kind of wish that there were more hidden upgrades other than "more life/magic meter" or "more sub-items" though.

There's a bunch of climbing in this game, and if you've played any of the Assassins Creed/Prince of Persia games you'll hate every second of it.  It's slow as hell, and often clunky in terms of detecting whether you've grabbed a ledge.

The combat on the other hand is pretty satisfying, though it's very different in terms of pace when compared to other action games.  This title emphasizes dodging and countering attacks rather than constant aggression.  It also has something interesting in the form of Light/Dark magic.  Hitting the bumpers activates magic which will empower certain items, grant access to new combos, and give you healing (light magic) or extra damage/block crushing capability (shadow magic).  If you're low on your magic reserves you can refill the meters by turning magic off and getting some solid attacks/counters in to build Focus - when full, every attack you make will drop magic-fueling orbs for you to hoover up.  Get hit, and your Focus is gone.  

It's a nice system that flows well... until you get hit by an attack you couldn't see coming due to the camera.  Or until an enemy does an unblockable attack with a nanosecond telegraph.  Or until a ground pound forces you to jump at the same time someone swings at you (midair blocks are not allowed).  Or until you clearly dodge roll but get clipped by the hit anyway.  This game's combat is sometimes as frustrating as it is fun, and I'm not sure if it's because I suck at it or because the game itself is janky.

There's a few puzzles to solve as you progress.  The game lets you skip them but you miss out on xp.  I'm not sure why this is even an option, given that 99% of the puzzles are braindead - I only got stuck once or twice and it was usually because the game expected something VERY bizzare.  The best example is probably the music box stage - there were some saws over a passage I had to go through and I couldn't figure out how to avoid them.  Turns out the answer was dodge rolling... something that hadn't been used out of combat until then. These moments are few and far between, but annoying nonetheless.

If there's something I can unconditionally praise about this game, it's the sense of style.  The environments are cool looking, the monsters well-designed, and the few bits of lore you get drip-fed are interesting.  It's a pity that the rest of the game lacks the level of polish that went into the art design because the main thing that kept me playing was the desire to see where I would be going and what I would fight next.  The game has the Castlevania flavor - everything is nasty yet stylish as all hell, brutal yet refined.

I wouldn't go out of my way to recommend this game, but it's alright.  Just don't go in expecting a perfect experience or you'll be disappointed for sure.

43312879.review: Because it's mission-based, there is no natural backtracking, just replaying old missions. 43210788.review:
This is the Ultimate Edition (DLC included, we'll come back to that in a bit). So I played it on the second level of difficulty, I think it was called warrior; I have some experience with these type of games, back from my PS2 days, but never been a fan since my fingers always took a hard toll after a session... So the story is pretty captivating with some twists, the main character is voiced by Robert Carlyle which does an excellent job, and it's narrated by Patrick Stewart, who is spectacular ! (didn't expect anything less from these two). 

   So you have a "GOD of WAR" type of game, and a couple of segments that feel like Shadow of the Collossus, plus some puzzles... let's start with the "good" :
 + good voice acting, pretty nice graphics (considering when it was released on console), varied locations and every level is trying to bring something new, that keeps things fresh as you progress through the story (didn't have a single crash) ! 
 - the "bad" cut-scenes are low quality console stuff, and you are going to jump to your death or miss  jumps, A Lot (I mean it); the camera is trying to pull a cinematic angle, but it often gets in the way and it's just irritating. By far the worst part is the End DLC BOSS FIGHT; after you finish the game, the story continues with 2-3 added chapters and the final chapter was absolute crap !! It literally took me 2 hours to beat this guy, and forget tactics since they won't work... all you have to do is hit & run, horrible design, I toughed it out, but I suggest decreasing difficulty for this !
   
 *It's a rough diamond, but it's worth it, and now that I've finished Lords of Shadow 2, This is the better game, and the soundtrack is quite amazing, really liked the main theme.

43192215.review:
Draggy. I'm not a fan of the universe, but that's not important.

The repetitive tasks on each level got really boring. Especially breaking down doors and riding on big enemies. The first 10 times you can tolerate it, but damn, how many more times can you break down those poor doors/stones with trolls, spiders, and vargs? Is that supposed to be engaging? Plus, each of these enemies is pretty tough, obviously stretching out the game time. And that imp that steals things got annoying. It was funny the first time, but the fourth time? Stupid.

There are also other cons that aren't as annoying:
1. The plot is weak, it started with Loki and then they connected them with transitions. Sometimes it makes no sense at all. In the first chapter, we already see everything - glaciers, swamps, village, rocks... then all these locations start repeating themselves, alternating in a completely random way.
2. The camera isn't very convenient, it sometimes chooses inconvenient angles.
3. Why have a combo of 5 hits if any enemy can interrupt you on the third hit? I came up with a pattern - block/roll --> strong punch and so on. It's easier to catch weak enemies with the whip and they die with one hit. So there are combos aplenty, but they aren't necessary. IMHO.
4. The DLC is terrible. They crammed in all the work that didn't make it into the final product. Plus, I encountered a few bugs, had to replay a couple of times.

Pros:
1. Beautiful landscapes, really.
2. A really cool art book that you unlock with points from mobs. I recommend getting lost in it.
3. There are really a lot of bosses, and they don't repeat themselves. That's nice.
4. The puzzles aren't difficult, but some are quite interesting.

Verdict: 2/10, just not my thing.

43085593.review:
Having had the time to put some thought and time into the game, there's certainly some problems with it. Given when it was produced, the fixed camera angles are honestly unforgivable. Especially when so often they mess with your controls because plowing ahead like a tank is going to get you into more trouble than you can handle. The real issue is during combat when those changes happen and suddenly you can't see your target. But that was the only huge issue I found with the game!
The voice acting is very well done, the story is interesting and engaging, the environments, at least what you can see of them that aren't walled off because of the fixed angles, are very attractive and the fights are enjoyable. Sometimes figuring out what to do with a boss can be a challenge, but what game doesn't have that at least in one fight? I say look past the flaws, stop trying to compare the game to GoW (frankly Castlevania actually did giant monsters you climb first anyway so the comparison really isn't just or fair) and either enjoy the game on its own merits or don't, but I feel there's something here if you are able to look past pre judged biases and the camera flaws (though if you can't look past the camera flaws, I can totally understand that!)

42900287.review:
A pesar de que le tengo un gran cariño a este juego, porque lo jugué en Xbox 360 en su dia y me enamoró, he estado a punto de ponerle un voto negativo debido especialmente a su último DLC.

Del juego base en si solo puedo hablar bien, aunque hay que reconocer que tiene ciertos fallos que a determinados usuarios puede estropearles la experiencia considerablemente, pero bajo mi punto de vista no rompen la sensación final que quiere transmitir el juego.

Como puntos a destacar, dos principalmente: BSO y Apartado Gráfico, en este ultimo destaca en todos sus aspectos, desde el punto técnico (teniendo en cuenta que ya tiene unos años a sus espaldas) y el apartado artístico que es el que mas destaca de los 2 de lejos. Su ambientación es espectacular, desde el primer momento entra por los ojos y en varias ocasiones he llegado a quedarme quieto absorto mirando algún paisaje, junto con la BSO que le acompaña que considero que es perfecta para cada momento y situación.

Su sistema de combate que es un punto a destacar en un juego de este tipo está bien sin mas, es entretenido, tiene muchas opciones: Combos, Reliquias, armas secundarias, combinaciones entre ellas... Creando combates muy dinámicos y qu enos dan diversas opciones a la hora de enfrentarnos a la diversidad de enemigos que tendremos enfrente, cada uno con unas características definidas.

Respecto a los puntos negativos, el mas destacable sin duda, y muy mencionario en otros comentarios: La Cámara. Es totalmente fija, no existe posibilidad de moverla como en otros juegos en 3º persona, el juego va cambiando de planos constantemente conforme avanza nuestro personaje, incluso en combates tendremos que apañarnos con el plano que en ese momento nos quiera dar el juego para combatir. Sin embargo tengo que decir que a pesar de ser un aspecto negativo, el estilo de cámara fija esta bien conseguido porque al final los planos nos muestran lo que necesitamos ver, pero es totalmente comprensible que a muchos esto no les termine de convencer, sobretodo en combates donde se agradeceria tener un control sobre la cámara para ser nosotros mismos los que decidieramos donde enfocar nuestra atencion.

Respecto a los DLC's... tengo que decir que especialmente el último, el Capitulo XIV me ha hecho el juego insufrible, con una mecánica de plataformeo (que si, es super corta pero ha sido horrible) muy mal conseguida y con un Boss dificil con una mecánica y unos combos muy poco creibles y absurdos... Pero en fin, no voy a condenar a un juego mas que Notable simplemente por un capítulo mal hecho.

[b]Cons[/b]

41935073.review:
Mi opinion general es que es un juego con suficiente personalidad como para desmarcarse tanto de los demas hack n' slash (genero trillado) como de la franquicia castlevania (juegos absurdamente arraigados en la cultura gamer). Lo mismo se aplica a sus secuelas. Aunque hay unos cuantos e importantes peros:


Puede ser el juego mas "si pero no" que he jugado en mi vida, mientras jugaba no paraba de pensar en todas las cosas que ensuciaban una posible obra maestra. Un juego basado en la mitologia de "vampiros, cazadores de vampiros y hombres lobo y similares" de accion, en 3D, dificilmente podria salir mal, aun asi me parece una oportunidad muy desperdiciada de hacer la saga mas pepino de la historia.

Hablando mas concretamente:



-Jugabilidad: Dividir el juego en capitulos me parece un acierto, ya que permite rejugar los niveles y ayuda a la narratividad del titulo. Por no decir que crear niveles separados permite un diseño mas cuidado y detenido de los mismos. 

La accion no es para nada mala, aunque el diseño de enemigos hace que el combate se vuelva algo obtuso (de que te sirve saber hacer combos si los enemigos no dejan de bloquear? al final solo haces ataque fuerte y esquivar) y aburrido y repetitivo en ocasiones.

El diseño de niveles en el aspecto jugable deja bastante que desear, los puzles me parecen acertados, pero cuando el entorno se vuelve no-lineal y te abren varios caminos... ufff, mucho que aprender en este aspecto. Es sencillo perderse y encima la recompensa por encontrar esos secretos no es motivacion suficiente. La exploracion en este aspecto se vuelve torpe y lenta.


-Diseño/arte: Brutal... cuando quiere. Los capitulos que transcurren en el castillo de Carmilla son insuperables, el castillo se ve brutal y sus puzles, jefes etc. Que pena que no dure demasiado.

El resto del juego lo veo tan fuera de contexto y poco inspirado que lo siento casi como un relleno, como si perteneciese a otro juego. Por ejemplo los capitulos del bosque son infumables y la parte de la meseta arida no puede ser mas sosa.

Ademas respecto al lore, me sobran muchas cosas. El tema de los gigantes de piedra sencillamente es lamentable y no pega ni con cola, lo peor es que no se recupera nada relacionado con ello en ninguna secuela, como si hubiesen admitido la cagada.

Vamos que cuando el juego es gotico su diseño es brutal pero el resto del tiempo sobratodo.

Los mejores momentos del juego bajo mi punto de vista han sido cuando gabriel se dedicaba a escalar por edificios gigantes, se podia apreciar bien el diseño y realmente se sentia como el protagonista se esfuerza por continuar su viaje.


-Historia: la historia general de la saga, y la fase presentada en este titulo, me parecen brutales, pero el problema es que de todos los momentos empleados en narrar la historia en este juego, solo en el ultimo y poco mas suceden cosas relevantes. En algunos capitulos la historia da vueltas y ocurren pequeñas mini-historias, lo cual enriquece el lore, pero al final son detalles que no importan, la historia general se explica en un par de momentos y al final se marca un FF9 y justo antes del combate final ocurre una conversacion de sus 10 minutacos buenos explicando toda la historia que no han sabido como contarte antes.

Encima, en lords of shadow 2, en el prologo del juego, te explican en cuestion de 5 min toda la historia acontecida en este juego y no te pierdes nada en lo absoluto.





Total, que es un juegazo, lo recomiendo, lo que ocurre es que se puede mejorar practicamente por todos los lados y abundan las carencias. Es ese tipico juego que no puedo disfrutar al 100% porque estoy constantemente pensando que otra cosa se podria haber hecho

41359563.review:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow is a 3rd person action adventure and is a reboot of the considerably long Castlevania franchise. It was originally released in 2010 for the PlayStation 3 and ported to windows in 2013. Considering its age, it holds up quite well both in game mechanics and graphically.

Being a reboot this game starts right at the beginning. You control Gabriel Belmont when an end of days’ event happens. The Lords of Shadow are threatening the alliance with heaven, and human souls are now unable to pass into judgement. Werewolf’s, Vampires, Necromancers and other evil creatures are stalking the land, destroying town and feasting on the population. Having recently lost your wife, you are sent by her spirit into the Lords of Shadows lands to stop the evil and you are advised you will be able to resurrect your slain wife by the order. Along the way you team up with Zobek, a hero of your order and its longest surviving member who knows many secrets and you meet a few other helpful souls along the way. I thought the plot was really well done, and paints a very tragic story for Gabriel. After everything that happens, it still didn’t explain how Dracula came about, or why the order would want to kill him after everything he has done (especially with how many knights you find dead through the game). This is resolved in the 2 DLC that are included in this edition of the game, which continues Gabriel’s story. Gabriel’s sacrifice to protect humanity (or what was left of it) was very well done, as was his corruption into Dracula to save humanity.  

Gameplay is consistent with others in the franchise, with a lot of time being spent solving puzzles to proceed, fighting enemies, swinging, jumping, rolling and collecting upgrades which improves your chances of succeeding. A fair chunk of upgrades require replaying a stage at a later time after you have collected a different upgrade, this might put you off but it isn’t required to finish the game (it just means you won’t have full magic power or secondary weapons). The combat cross is Gabriel’s main weapon (its design makes you question the church), and it has plenty of combos to keep combat interesting and entertaining. You have a few secondary weapons that provide different bonus vs different enemy types, a crystal that summons a bound daemon (not sure why the order has these) to deal massive damage to anything on screen and light and dark magic as well (one which heals as you do damage, and one which does extra damage). The 3D platforming was good, if you mistimed a jump you simply restarted on the last area with a health decrease instead of at the start of the stage so it wasn’t frustrating. Combat was good, varied and provided visual cues as to when an enemy was going to attack. For the easy/medium run this was very helpful (this is turned off when playing Paladin mode), so I can imagine that for hard you would need to know how each enemy attacks (though you should hopefully be plenty upgraded by then).  There are quite a few QTE button mashing events, these are very prominent with the larger bosses. The stage length is quite varied, some stages are quite short, some of the latter stages are very long to complete.

I thought the game was excellent visually, with the world really looking decaying and uninviting. Living in fear, most of the humans shun your approach (even if you are the only thing that can save them), and nearly everything is hostile towards you. The Vampire castles are frozen gloomy places, the caves where the werewolves stalk are dark and forbidding, while the area of the Necromancers are blasted deserts where nothing lives. The monster design was well done, and I think praise is deserved for the werewolf boss and the vampire boss, both were designed very well (if a little lacking in clothes). I would advise having any young ones around when playing this, there is a fair amount of gore and a bit of female nudity (Pixes, the crystal daemon, Carmilla in her Kim K dress)

The orchestra score used for the music was amazing, it really fits the dark world that you find yourself playing in. I can understand why it won awards. The voice acting was top notch, with Patrick Stewart narrating each stage and also Zobek. Gabriel, Cornell, Carmilla, Laura and even the forgotten one are also very well voiced.

If you are chasing 100% achievements then you are going to be in for a very long run. It will require at least 3 runs of every stage (the first run unlocks Paladin difficulty and challenges). Some of the challenges are very difficult to do, and you will want to be fully upgraded to do Paladin difficulty. An easy run took close to 30 hours (there was fair bit of exploration the first time around). You will also have to factor in any upgrades/collectables that you missed the first time around (might be better to grab these when doing the challenge run).

41116057.review:
It is a fine game for the most part if you can put up with some horrible decisions in its design.

Principally the biggest issue for me have to be the boss battles, they try and resemble, to not say replicate, the boss fights from shadow of the colossus, you climb on top of massive enemies and then you have to attack their weak points, the problem is that everything has to be mediated, and, or, scripted somehow, so in order to progress through those fights, you have to allow the game to let you do so, rather than something that actually falls under your own judgement, and ability, to decide.

Then there's the fact that the game prolongs its stay for too long, the game has twelve chapters, with 46 missions in total.

After a while of doing the same thing over and over again the game feels as if its artificially extending its lenght rather than it, being something necessary for the game.

This game could've, should've, been a heck of a lot shorter...

The first chapter or so it's also terrible, the whole chapter it's practically an extended tutorial in which the game consistenly takes the controller away from the player to explain the most basic, and rudimentary, mechanics, and systems, that you can think of.

Pair that up with the horrid dependance of the quick time events that the game is plagued with, and well...

The quick time events in this game seem to be (to me) a petty attempt at replicating, through a very narrow, and short-minded perspective some of the fundamental and otherwise satisfying mechanics of games such as God of War.

This is a game that you can tell it practically tried to go through a series of games to conform its own design, instead of designing its own unique aspects.

The game constantly takes systems, mechanics, and even controls from other games, Shadow of the Collossus, God of War, Uncharted...

It is as almost the devs went out of their way to borrow as much as they could from a series of Sony exclusives, and as end result, at times the game it's constantly bouncing back and foward between a series of mechanics, and systems, that ended up destroying whathever pace the game already didn't have.

It is not all bad of course, the game holds up visually incredibly well, the games aesthetic its diverse, and unique, playing it at 1440p, and at over 60 fps ended up offering a flawless experience in regards of the technical aspects of this game.

Not only that but after the first chapter, the game really offers a lot of freedom for the player to explore, run around, collect power ups, and level up some of his skills to run around murdering an onslaught of enemies.

The skill system, I found, a bit disappointing, the game only allows you to upgrade combos, for the most part, and the rest of the upgrades that you can level up are simply upgrades for equipment that you probably will never use, simply because at times there really isn't any need for it, although this might change with different difficulty modes.

Besides that though, this is one of those games that to me it isn't bad, but it isn't really that good, or great, or decent...

It is a bearable, mediocre experience that allows players to witness a time from not that long ago in which developers, similar to a lot of the ones you'll sadly find right here on Steam, try to borrow from some of the "success" from other games.

I understand taking inspiration, but one thing is to take inspiration, and another one it's to try and recreate exact moments from other creations.

As if somehow just by doing so the game might end up as much, if not more, than the original product already did for people who are currently playing it.

I'm looking at you Minecraft, and the series of clones that people ended up producing from the originality of your idea...

40851008.review:
Call it blasphemy, but this is one of the best Castlevania games ever made, possibly THE best.

It takes the classic Castlevania mythology and repeated map gameplay, and projected onto a three-dimensional fixed camera God of War style action adventure game.

This is the game that the dark, Gothic Castlevania mythology always deserved.

I played through this game about 2 years ago, and I still think about it often, some of the best boss fights and combat I've ever seen.

Even run-of-the-mill enemies can prove a challenge,  and you can upgrade your characters skills to meet that challenge.  

In classic Castlevania fashion, there's platforming that provides a reasonable challenge, and also requires upgraded skills in order to Traverse certain areas which inevitably make the player return to Maps they've already defeated in order to finish upgrading their character....  I normally find this metroidvania style of gameplay to be annoying, but in this case it wasn't a problem at all.

The addition of mini games and puzzles with a nice touch.

You won't do any better than this game for boss fights, they run the gamut from very challenging enemies of your own size, all the way up to gigantic Titans hundreds of feet tall.  The boss of the final DLC is perhaps one of the most challenging boss fights I've ever seen, even on the easiest difficulty, he's almost impossible to defeat.

The story is a deep, tragic tale of Supernatural, medieval misery,  gray morality, and fate. It takes an interesting look at Humanities struggle with powers Beyond its scope, and the reality that we are often the greatest villains in our own existence.  The developer doesn't leave you in any doubt about the world you play in or the lore contained therein, you are given a codex which unlocks as you progress, helping you understand the characters, the story and certain strategy elements to help you defeat the enemies you encounter.

The voice acting is absolutely top-notch, if you read the description you'll see what a great cast Konami manage to round up for this title. In particular Robert carlile's performance is absolutely unbelievable, if you know him from his previous work, this game will show you an entirely different realm of this capability is a performer,

The graphics look gorgeous, demonstrating all the best that the PS3 era had to offer.

I thought about this game today, and though it's been awhile since I've played it, it's on my shortlist to revisit and I wanted to let everyone else know how great it is.


Absolute 100% must buy, even if you were to pay its full price right now, I don't think you would be disappointed.

If you pick it up on sale, you'll be guaranteed to get an absolute steal.

I couldnt get it to work and after 2 hours of watching you tube videos trying to figure it out i descided the game simply wasnt worth it. 

TLDR cool game missing some really basic core game features that are just standard on virtually every other game.

40801236.review:
A great reboot of Castlevania franchise in a hack and slash form.                  
The story is fine and take an interesting different approach to the "Belmont vs Dracula" paradigm of Castlevania which feels really refreshing (as a reboot should be).                        

Combat system is good and fun, the art is amazing and the music are excellent.                    
It kinda drag itself a little too much in some point though and the end show a clearly missing point until the DLCs are played (which are included but their value is quite low compared to the main game, like really lower especially the only boss that is just an hitbox gimmick to make it last way more than it should)               

An excellent game that is definitely worth the price and the playtime: 8.5/10

40486526.review:
C'est un bon hack & slash, ça m'a bien défoulé. Bons graphismes (après, chez Konami, le héros ressemble souvent à Actarus de chez Goldorak ou à Ken de Street Fighters ... une coupe de cheveux qui n'a pas changé depuis les années 70, quand les rebelles se laissaient pousser les cheveux), histoire qui se tient (un peu adolescent, ce n'est pas encore le Seigneur des Anneaux mais bon, ça fait le job), univers immersif (en mots simples : j'ai été pris par l'histoire et j'ai eu envie de voir ce qui se passe après).
Mon souci est que la souris n'est pas utilisée - à part pour les boutons. Du coup, je n'arrive pas à orienter la caméra. Pas trouvé de solution sur les forums. Peut-être que les japonais ne connaissent rien d'autre qu'une manette de console, pourquoi pas. Ca voudrait dire que je suis trop vieux pour les jeux vidéos ? héhé. Je ne comprends pas qu'un tel jeu se prive d'une population de joueurs en faisant l'impasse sur des types de périphériques (en 2013 ! date de sortie du jeu).
En toute subjectivité (c'est l'intérêt des revues persos), je ne recommande pas, je vous déconseille le jeu si vous êtes comme moi, FPS aventure avec des écarts de conduite jouissifs sur Lord of The Ring, en sacrifiant parfois le réalisme des graphismes et des déplacements à la jouabilité, pour le fun (Duke Nukem par exemple). En revanche, si vous aimez les jrpg à la manette, j'imagine que vous prendrez plaisir à jouer à ce bon jeu. Moi, j'ai arrêté.

Looking over Bayoneta, God of War, Devil May Cry, and any other hack and slash you can see one battle mechanic worth it, but in this castlevania battle is fully garbage, enemies have a stupid and incessant atack pattern that hits you even if you are high above in the air......... totally nonsense.

40413961.review:
I wonder why I had not discovered this game earlier. It is epic! Already bought it at release in 2013 and it just could not interest me back then. I uninstalled it after playing 4 or 5 levels. All these years I did not discover this gem and I think because it just did not make me feel like I was playing a typical classic Castlevania game.

I rediscovered it in 2018 and the game is definitely awesome. The graphics look a bit dated now against today's standards, but still good enough. Gameplay is great; the first few levels are a bit slow and nothing special but as you progress further and further and level up, the story unfolds this game really starts to shine. What I hate is the awkward camera at times, what I love is all the numerous cool boss fights. In addition, it is a very long and entertaining piece of software, which you can pick up for a very low price today, 

In my opinion; the further you proceed, the more it starts to feel like a Castlevania.

40405317.review:
Press RT to grapple
Press RT to grapple
Press Left to move left
Press A to drop down
Press RT to grapple
Press Alt+F4 to Quit
Press Uninstall

(In short, the game tells you what to do every step of the way. Once you learn how to do something once, you don't need prompts telling you how or when to do them again. The sounds are great, the environments are great, but the constant prompts telling you exactly what to do and when to do it are dreadful. Enough that I couldn't make it even an hour in.)

40402792.review:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow es un juego Hack & Slash en tercera persona el cual brilla gracias a su interesante mundo y enemigos, además de contar con una buena historia y jefes de alto calibre. Su ambientación y las diferentes razas de enemigos [spoiler](Vampiros, Licántropos y no muertos)[/spoiler] hacen que el juego no se sienta repetitivo. Cuenta con momentos en la historia los cuales sorprenden, ya sea por un giro en la trama o por la presentación de un jefe [spoiler](La torre que resultaba ser un dragón de hueso, o el jefe final)[/spoiler] pero el título tiene un punto negativo el cual es:
El "Mantén pulsado para sostenerte" es una mecánica que arruina los épicos combates contra los jefes de tamaño colosal, habría sido más comprensible el hacer un QTE donde se deba presionar un boton antes de estar 6 segundos manteniendo pulsado para no caerte y tener que volver a escalar al jefe, además este momento se produce cuando el jefe realiza un determinado movimiento (normalmente cuando se sacude para sacarte de encima) pero el jefe lo realiza constantemente porque es su única manera de contraatacar, otra opción también hubiera sido el tener que esquivar cuando intente defenderse, pero esto solo ocurre para cambiar el lugar del jefe donde se debe atacar.
El que podría ser el mayor problema de este juego es su control, prácticamente injugable con teclado, es decir que si uno no cuenta con un joystick la va a pasar muy mal, pero no me parece un punto completamente negativo ya que el juego fue creado para ser jugado con mando al igual que la mayoría de Hack & Slash en tercera persona (es como jugar un DMC con teclado, no tiene mucha gracia) pero estos puntos resaltan debido a que este es un excelente juego, además de ser perfecto para los que nunca habíamos jugado un Castlevania. Ya que pueden no compartir jugabilidad pero si el increíble mundo y ambientación.

[h1]9.5/10[/h1]

Respecto al DLC se supone que son dos, pero la verdad es que el primero es 70% puzzles y el segundo es 85% pelea contra el jefe, por separado no sería una buena compra, pero como ya vienen incluidos los tomo como un único DLC, la primera parte solo tienen una cosa positiva: [spoiler]La transformación de Gabriel en vampiro, lo que da contexto a la secuela[/spoiler], la segunda parte del DLC es lo bueno: [spoiler]El olvidado es un muy buen jefe, imponente y con patrones de ataque aceptables, pero esto se ve aplacado en parte por lo monótono que fueron al diseñar cómo combatiríamos contra él y además cada vez que sea necesario golpear un punto alto en el jefe habrá que usar combos aéreos, pero ese es el problema, solo hay 2 [/spoiler]. Pero a pesar de esto el jefe es de muy buena calidad, desde la presentación hasta los increíbles momentos de plataformas donde debemos evitar que nos vea, sin duda muy recordable

DLC[h1] [9/10][/h1]

39825030.review:
The great visuals and the amount of attention paid to everything from the loading screens and menus to the environments are ruined by the one essential, basic thing every game should be based on: control. Don't get me wrong, there is nothing mechanically wrong with the controls and I thought the camera functioned quite well too. You just have so little control over the game that its insulting. 
  The game is like a windows media player file and all you do is hit play. There is a cutscene every 20 or so seconds and when you get to walk uninterrupted for a few minutes (which is rare) I wished there was much more of that. On screen prompts harass you all the time to tell you obvious things like "get out of the way!" or "hit the enemy's weak points". And at that point you realize, all you do is pressing the buttons you are told to. There is no initiative at all given to the player, which destroys the sense of satisfaction, discovery, and challenge you get in good games; like the 2D Castlevania games or a masterpiece like Prince of Persia: The sands of time. That should have been their influence when designing a Castlevania game in this genre. Not with regards to the visuals, but the way the game plays; of which there is very little here.

39673132.review: Keep in mind this is just my own opinion, but I just didn't have any fun with this. Despite all the elements being there, the controls just didn't feel right, the combat didn't grip me, and the art direction is painfully generic, and it doesn't help that the game is just kinda... boring. And I really hate to level these kinds of criticisms at a Castlevania game.
